Justification: From Medieval Greek φαρδύς < Ancient (εὐ-)φραδής 'wise; linguistically correct', with metathesis /fra-/ > /far-/ ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1523), further a derivative from the same root as Ancient Greek φράζομαι 'to consider, think (up), perceive', but with no known etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1588).

No certain etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1063-1064, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1413-1414);  [LIV²](src-141) 603 mechanically reconstructs ?*strebʰ-, but ?*stregʷʰ- also remains theoretically possible.

Apparently related to tʿacʿ- the aorist stem of Classical Armenian tʿanam 'to (become) wet, to moisten, drench' (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:150-151), further to PIE *teh₂- 'to thaw, melt' ([Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):113-114, [LIV²](src-141) 616).

Comment: Loanword from Persian.
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3945; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: Etymology uncertain. Traditionally derived to PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' (cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:580, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):403). [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353); not in [IEW](src-49)].
No certain etymology ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).
Root etymology disputed, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):388, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):994-995 for various proposals.
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):297 no. 5385.
Loanword from Persian سرخ / sorx 'red'.
Parallel loans from Saṇu-viri: Wâmâ ẓ′oːk

Comment: Gharib (1995: 429 #10568) suggests a connection with Av. vǝrǝzra, which is not attested in Bartholomae (1904)

Justification: Derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'be warm, hot' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):376, [Matasović 2009](src-50):147, [NIL](src-274) 196-199).

Hellenic lexemes as though from PIE *skl̥h₁-ró-, an derived adjective to PIE *(s)kelh₁- 'to dry out, dry up' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1012-1013, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1345-1346, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 553).
Cognacy in this class for the verb is coded for NHG -legen (cf. NHG überlegen 'to consider, reflect, think'); cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):939 for the history of the formation.

Comment: Bailey (1979: 440) < *an-āmara-ka- ‘not sour’, as the reverse, Khotan Saka āhvarai ‘sour’, is ‘not sweet’. Reference to Pokorny om- and Old Indic amlá-, amblá- 'sour; sorrel'.

Justification: Classical Armenian tʿakʿowcʿanem, secondarily derived from Classical Armenian tʻakʻcʻi- 'hide oneself' as though from PIE *pth₂k-eh₁-sk̑e/o- (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):79, 262; [LIV²](src-141) 495).
Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Persian برف / barf 'snow' (cf. [cognate set 126](cog-126)).
Loanword from Calabrian Italian culírcia 'winged / reddish ant'.
Loanword from Early Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic leggr 'leg' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Comment: Original meaning "to observe".
Justification: Ultimately a derivative of PIE 1. *ser- to look after, protect' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):10, [Cheung 2007](src-83):129, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 534).
Probably from a compound containing *h₁en- 'in' + temh₁- 'cut off' ([Adams 2013](src-345):92-93).
Loanword from Latin numerāre 'to count, enumerate' ([Orel 1998](src-105):291).
Loanword from Middle English putten 'to push' ((ref Macbain & Macfarlane 1911}:284, cf. [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):356).
Loan from Old French songer (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):677).

Comment: Cognate class A should be reserved for borrowings from Persian, not for Persian itself.

Justification: Parallel loans from from Old French fruit.

The etymology in this cognate set is tentatively assigned to PIE *h₃rei̯H- following [Orel 1998](src-105):366, [Holm 2011](src-130):56, but cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):344, [Holm 2011](src-130):56 for discussion of alternative etymologies.

Italic lexemes continuing a derivative of PIE *dʰeh₁-k- 'to make, produce' ([LIV²](src-141) 139-140), widely considered to be connected to PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place, to set up; to do' ([LIV²](src-141) 136-138), but the origins of the k-element on the root remain obscure (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):198-199).
Cf. Swedish slå ihjäl 'beat to death'

Comment: perhaps from PIE *sek- 'to cut'

Justification: North Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *spurda- (cf. Middle High German sporte 'tail', without attestation in East Germanic). Cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):367, [de Vries 1977](src-468):537 for uncertain attempts at an etymology outside of Germanic. [Not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165)].

Comment: cf. Turkish kuyruk "tail"

Justification: Slavic lexemes of onomatopoeic origin ([Boryś 2005](src-259):422, 424, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1189. For a proposed comparison to Latin pānus 'tumour' see [Derksen 2008](src-81):416 (but cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):444).

Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)κτείνω 'to kill, put to death', derived from PIE *t⁽k̑⁾én-i̯e/o-, a derivative of the root *t⁽k̑⁾en- 'to injure' ([LIV²](src-141) 645-646, [Beekes 2010](src-66):789-790, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):591).
Generally considered a derivative of a PIE *bel- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):52, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:193-194, [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) I:105).
Root ref. form follows [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):564-566 to *meu̯h₁- 'to move (oneself), but cf. [LIV²](src-141) 445-446 reconstructing *mi̯eu̯h₁-.

Possibly from Proto-Iranic *safša- ([Bailey 1979](src-320):416-417); [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):340 also considers the possibility of a loanword from Turkic sač, čač 'hair (on the head of a person)'

Comment: maybe identical with 1584 *sem-; Nyberg "Manual" (1974: 93) derives this word from *hama-van- without indicating the meaning of the elements. (There is only van "tree" in his word list.)

Justification: Etymology outside of Greek uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):243-244, [Beekes 2010](src-66):289-290, 293).
From Old Breton sco 'stroke, blow', further etymology obscure ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):666).
Originally a loanword into Middle English from Old French cunter, conter ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Parallel loans from Persian کوه / kūh 'mountain'.
Parallel loans from Low German.
Parallel loans from English breast.
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *ugʷ-ro- 'wet', a Caland adjective in *-ro- to *u̯egʷ- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1525-1526).
Anatolian lexemes derived from PIE *nei̯H- 'to lead' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):598-600, [LIV²](src-141) 450-451).
Etymology uncertain, possibly to PIE *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' if from *dʰēubotyo- (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):296-297).
No certain etymology (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:167).
Etymology uncertain (cf. [Korn 2005](src-344):319).
Loanword from Hattic eštan-, aštan- 'sun(god)' ([Tischler 1983](src-578):428-430, [HED A+E/I](src-406):465-468, cf. [Laroche 1947](src-573)).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):524, [de Vries 1977](src-468):624 for further discussion.

Comment: Bailey (1979: 153) suggests a derivation from the verb dar- "to split"

Justification: Tsakonian (ι)κ̔άρα < Ancient Greek ἐσχάρα ‘hearth’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):379-380, [Beekes 2010](src-66):472).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed; likely to be of onomatopoeic origin. Cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):257-258, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):185, and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):228 for various proposals and references to further literature.

Modern Greek forms in this class continue Ancient Greek ἀκοντίζω 'hurl a javelin' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), a derivative to Ancient Greek ἄκων, -οντος 'javelin, dart', in turn derived from the PIE root *h₂ek̑- 'sharp, point' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):59).
An early loanword into West Germanic from Latin curtus 'short' (cf. [EWA 5](src-398):927-929, [Kluge 2011](src-397):551).
Loanword from dialectal Swedish snafsa 'to snap; get dirty' ([Den Danske Ordbog](src-97)).

A verbal adjective from the strong verb *grōan- 'grow', cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):260-261, [Kluge 2011](src-397):378, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):191-192. Extra-Germanic connections unclear, but perhaps further connected to Lat. grāmen 'grass', but the latter may also be connected with IE *gras- 'fressen' (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8369](cog-8369), and in [Seebold 1970](src-556):242-243, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):191-192.
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to perceive, see' (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:86-88, [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) III:253, [LIV²](src-141) 561).
Loan from Old French grif 'claw' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):663).
Root only attested in Indo-Iranic, further IE connections uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:153, [Cheung 2007](src-83):153, [LIV²](src-141) 222).

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse keppr 'cudgel, club', further from Proto-Germanic *kip(p)a-, related with Germanic to the weak verb *kippōn- 'to chop(?)', but without any certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):289, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):289)

Comment: Loan from West Caucasian

Justification: Originally an agent noun to the same root as OHG slingan ([Kluge 2011](src-397):808, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):453). The Germanic forms must continue a Verner variant *-gʷ- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) s.v. *slenkʷ-, n1).
Friulian vaî is from Latin uagiō, -īre 'to cry' (G. Cadorini, p.c.), further etymology unclear ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):711, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):651).

Etymology outside Germanic disputed; either (1) to PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):55-56, [Orel 2003](src-388):32, 39; for the root cf. [LIV²](src-141) 98-100); or (2) to PIE *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ- and related to the IE word for 'upper-arm' *bʰeh₂g̑ʰ-u- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):47).
Generally derived from a PIE s-stem *h₁regʷ-os- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):203, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):259-261).

Balto-Slavic and Germanic lexemes generally connected to a common IE root *gleh₂dʰ- ([ALEW](src-352) 345, [Derksen 2008](src-81):162-163, [Derksen 2015](src-353):183, [Kluge 2011](src-397):361, [EWA 4](src-415):478-480, [Orel 2003](src-388):135), but cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):179 who prefers an alternative etymology.
Possibly a variant to the more widely attested root *terh₁- 'bore, rub' ([LIV²](src-141) 632), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 647 s.v. ?*treh₁-, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):546, [Seebold 1970](src-556):519.
No certain cognates outside of Germanic, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):381; [Orel 2003](src-388):303. No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Etymology disputed ([Kluge 2011](src-397):498; [EWA 5](src-398):581-584). According to [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):322-323, followed by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):290, to the root underlying OIr. glenaid 'adhere, stick' and also in Gk. γλίνη 'sticky substance', OCS glьna 'mud, clay', to PIE *g̑lei̯- / *glei̯- 'smear, stick' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 190 s.v. *gleiH- 'bestreichen, kleben bleiben').
Proto-Germanic *singwan- 'to sing', probably from PIE *sengʷʰ- 'to sing, proclaim' ([IEW](src-49) 906-7, [LIV²](src-141) 532, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):437, [Seebold 1970](src-556):392-393).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁em- 'to take' ([LIV²](src-141) 236, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 395-397, [Derksen 2015](src-353):200-201, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:71, [Derksen 2008](src-81):158, 533). The cognacy in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 236 s.v. *h₁em-, but cf. also [LIV²](src-141) 453 s.v. 1. *nem-; it is possible that these two roots formed a rhyming pair in PIE.
Continuing Vedic tr̥prá-, originally an epithet of soma of debated semantics. Further etymology obscure ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):338-339 no. 5934, [EWAia](src-172) I:666).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *ret- 'to run' ([LIV²](src-141) 507, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:23, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):538-543, [Matasović 2009](src-50):310).
Lit. 'to break (open)'.
No consensus on an IE root etymology outside of Albanian, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):99, [Holm 2011](src-130):80, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):973-974 for various proposals.

Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *čāt⁽ʰ⁾- ([ESIJa](src-331) II:252-253, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:285), on the connection of Khowar čhat to this class, cf. [Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):660.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. discussion in [EWA 5](src-398):1172-1175.

Comment: <*čid-t-.The word is a compound 'not-clean'.

Justification: Adjective derived from Old Irish don 'misfortune', further etymology obscure ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:169).
For the interpretation of the Hittite and Luvian forms underlying the Sumerogram ᵈEN.ZU and Akkadogram ᵈSÎN, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):206-207.
Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *bʰendʰ- 'to bind' ([LIV²](src-141) 75, [EWAia](src-172) II:208, [Cheung 2007](src-83):4-6, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):64).
Loanword from Latin viridis 'green' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):466, [Orel 1998](src-105):499).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. [EWA 5](src-398) s.v. OHG jagôn with extensive discussion of previous proposals.
Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Iranic *dau̯č- 'to sew', a root restricted to West Iranic and possibly substratum loanword ([Cheung 2007](src-83):67).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *blōda- 'blood'. The further root etymology remains uncertain, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):76-77, [Kluge 2011](src-397):135-136, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):68-70 for various proposals.
Probable loan from Old French (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):226).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):79, [EWAia](src-172) I:756 for further discussion.

Germanic lexemes, generally considered derivatives of PIE *pek̄- 'to pull hair, fight' ([LIV²](src-141) 467, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):190-191, [EWA 3](src-441):108-112, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):134).

A denominative verb formed to Danish skjul 'hide, cover', further to Old Norse skjól 'cover, shelter', probably to the same root as Danish sky 'cloud' ([Den Danske Ordbog](src-97)), but further etymology uncertain (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):495-496, [Orel 2003](src-388) 339, 347, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):442, 452 for various hypotheses).

Germanic lexemes continuing denominal verbal formations from Proto-Germanic Proto-Germanic *spila- 'play, game', further etymology unclear (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):867, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):467).

Probably a derivative of PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ([Orel 1998](src-105):371, [Holm 2011](src-130):73; cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):251, 344 without attempting to assign a root etymology). For the root reconstruction, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 299-301.

Baltic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE 2. *sekʷ- 'to say' ([LIV²](src-141) 526-527, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 884-886, [Derksen 2015](src-353):387, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):420, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):565-568, [Matasović 2009](src-50):328).
Loans from Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit samudra- 'the sea, ocean' ([Adams 2013](src-345):739).

Comment: etymology unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):462 for various proposals.

Etymology uncertain; occasionally attempted to be derived from the root *u̯ed- underlying the IE word for 'water' (cf. [cognate set 335](cog-335), [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575), but such a secondary formation does not easily explain the strong stem formation in Germanic ([Seebold 1970](src-556):539, [Kluge 2011](src-397):972).

Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *slabъ 'weak', as though from PIE *slob-o- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):452-453, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) s.v. *(s)leb- ‘schlaff werden’).

Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: Albanian forms derived from verbal kalb 'to let rot', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):165, 355 for various proposals).
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):794).

Latin currere 'to run' and Romance lexemes continuing a PIE zero-grade thematic present stem *⁽k̑⁾r̥s-e/o-, derived from PIE *⁽k̑⁾ers- 'to run' ([LIV²](src-141) 355, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):157-158, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):224 no. 2415).

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *baka-, possibly to a root *bʰeg- 'to bend, arch', but there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic ([EWA 1](src-383):418, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):48, [Kluge 2011](src-397):80-81).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ 'black', further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾r̥s-nó- ([ESSJa](src-458) 4:155-157, [Derksen 2008](src-81):92).

The reconstruction of the Proto-Germanic form of this adjective is problematic, therefore connections outside of Germanic are difficult to ascertain (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):157-158, 162-163; [Kroonen 2013](src-165):100).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:287, [KEWA](src-399) II:540-542). For the Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):554 no. 9696.
Loanword from Arabic اسم / aism 'name'.
Parallel loans from Turkic *küčik

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *alda- '(grown) old', further from PIE *h₂el-tó-, a verbal adjective to PIE *h₂el- 'to nourish, rear' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):29-30, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):97-98, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):20, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 262).

Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *brinnan- 'to burn'. The Indo-European root etymology remains unclear: either to (1) PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ([LIV²](src-141) 92-93, [IEW](src-49) 166-7) or (2) *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ([LIV²](src-141) 219-220, [IEW](src-49) 493-5); cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):77-78; [Seebold 1970](src-556):137-138, [EWA 2](src-386):342-345.
Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):127-128 for various proposals.

The only extra-Germanic correspondences are found in Baltic (cf. Lith. sver̃ti 'to weigh') which could go back to an original IE root *su̯er(H)- (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):578-579, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):499, [ALEW](src-352):998-999).

Comment: basic meaning "radiant, shiny" etc.

Justification: Etymology in this class follows [Orel 1998](src-105):515, [Matzinger 2005](src-663):99, but cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):68 for further discussion.
Generally considered a loanword from Albanian lule 'flower' (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):791-792), although the possibility of a Wanderwort is probably also not to be excluded.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):445, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):417-418 for older proposals).
A loanword from Latin intelligere 'to perceive' ([Orel 1998](src-105):62, cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):66).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):229-230, [Orel 1998](src-105):210, 221 for various suggestions and further discussion.
Loanword from Latin largus 'big, large, great (of distances)' ([Huld 1984](src-571):85, [Orel 1998](src-105):214).
Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *karš-/*xrah- 'to draw, plough', further to PIE *kʷels- 'to draw a furrow' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):241-243, [EWAia](src-172) I:319-320, [LIV²](src-141) 388-389).
Loan from Latin pōmum 'fruit tree; fruit' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):326, [Orel 1998](src-105):314, [Holm 2011](src-130):85-86).

Origin and structure uncertain, cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):419, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 4:255, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):455-456, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1053-1054, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:186 for various proposals.
Manx fliaghey continuing Old Irish flechud ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):168).
Etymology disputed, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):36, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):70-71, [Orel 1998](src-105):1-2 for discussion of various proposals.
Etymology disputed, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):246-247, [Orel 1998](src-105):219, 234 for various proposals and further discussion.
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:15.
Etymology outside of Greek unclear ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):979-980, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1294-1295). For older hypotheses, cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:665-666, [IEW](src-49) 1004.

Comment: derivation of verbal root *dai̯H "to see" of cognate set 2012

Justification: Loan from Iranic (cf. [Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):671).

Comment: Loan from Romance.
Justification: Loan from Late Latin cocceus 'red, scarlet' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):210, [Huld 1984](src-571):84, [Orel 1998](src-105):205, [Holm 2011](src-130):75).

Generally compared with Vedic ándhas- 'sprout of the soma plant' which can be accounted for via an s-stem *h₂éndʰ-os- from which Greek ἄνθος would also be a regular reflex ([Beekes 2010](src-66):104-105, [LIV²](src-141) 266, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:79). See, however, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):89-90 with some reservations.
Hellenic and Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *selk- 'to pull' ([LIV²](src-141) 530-531, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):753, [Beekes 2010](src-66):412).
Loanword from Latin venīre 'to come' ([Orel 1998](src-105):508).
Etymology uncertain, possibly to be connected Gk. ὄρμενος 'shoot, sprout, stem, stalk' (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):337). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).
Loanword into Brythonic from Latin piscis 'fish' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):574, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. Welsh pysg 'fish').

Tocharian lexemes continuing PIE *kʷolh₁-o- 'turning point' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):126, [Adams 2013](src-345):211), a derivative of PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn' ([LIV²](src-141) 386-388).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):562-563, [Orel 2003](src-388):383, [Kluge 2011](src-397):887, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):476, 487 for various proposals and references to further literature.
Probably a loanword from Italian milza 'spleen' ([Orel 1998](src-105):259), but possibly even earlier from Gothic *milti-, cf. Catalan melsa 'spleen' ([Holm 2011](src-130):69-70).
Hellenic and Armenian lexemes from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1212, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1115, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):316).
Etymology outside of (East) Baltic uncertain, cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):568, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):819-820 for further discussion.
Root ref. form in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 243 s.v. *h₁eu̯-, but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):227-229 reconstructing *h₂eu̯-.

Comment: s, not š, in Nuristani.
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dau̯šā́- 'evening; night', no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:750, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):376 no. 6590).
Etymology here tentatively follows [Orel 1998](src-105):16-17, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):201-202, but cf. the objections and further discussion of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):89-90).
Etymology outside of Albanian unclear, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):274, [Jokl 1911](src-661):58, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):277, [Orel 1998](src-105):274, [Holm 2011](src-130):70} for various proposals.
Generally derived from *du̯eh₂ró- or *duh₂ró- to √*du̯eh₂- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):198-199, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):266-267).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes backformed from the Old Indic suppletive aorist √dr̥ś- and replacing the inherited present stem paśya- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):371, no. 6507). Ultimately to be derived from PIE *derk̑- 'to see' ([EWAia](src-172) I:704-706, [LIV²](src-141) 122-123).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):427-428, [Orel 1998](src-105):524, [Holm 2011](src-130):53 for discussion of various proposals.
Probably a loanword from Iranic, cf. Wakhi ṣ̌ʉw 'black' ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):669).
Connections outside of Tocharian unclear ([Adams 2013](src-345):478).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):483 for discussion of various proposals.
Armenian forms generally derived from PIE 2. *h₂eg̑- 'to say' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):117-118, [LIV²](src-141) 256).
Etymology uncertain ([Kluge 2011](src-397):536).
Loanword from Old French sentir 'to perceive' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):643).

Italic and Romance lexemes continuing Latin dormīre 'to sleep', further derived from PIE 2. *drem- 'to sleep' ([LIV²](src-141) 128, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):179-180, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):247).
A Wanderwort of obscure origin, cf. [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 1:123-124, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):701, [Skok 1971-1974](src-589) 3:569, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 1:279 for various proposals.

Connections outside of Albanian uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):89, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):254-256, [Orel 1998](src-105):243, [Holm 2011](src-130):72 for various proposals and further discussion.
Loanword from Syriac ṭarpā 'leaf' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):933, [HAB](src-740) IV:398, [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):317). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tereu̯-o-].

Denominal to Armenian kap 'bond, fetter'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly an Iranian loanword ([Olsen 1999](src-180):16, 887, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:519-521). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kap-].
NB: [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):351 no. 6145 compares Iranic forms which [Cheung 2007](src-83):48 assumes to be a separate root of onomatopoeic origin.
A denominal formation from Breton kaw 'hollow', originally a borrowing from Latin cavus 'hollow, excavated' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):377).
Loan from Latin *camba ~ gamba 'leg' ([Huld 1984](src-571):80, [Orel 1998](src-105):177, [Holm 2011](src-130):63).
No clear etymology outside of Celtic ([Matasović 2009](src-50):152, cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):266).

Etymology disputed. Either to the Germanic word for 'hide, skin' in [cognate set 820](cog-820) or to Celtic words for 'hide' from PIE *keu̯dʰ- in [cognate set 8434](cog-8434) (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84), [Orel 2003](src-388):196). Not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165) or [Seebold 1970](src-556).
Loan from Calabrian ad(d)urare, -ari 'to smell' with apheresis, cf. Sandard Italian odorare < Lat. odōrāre.
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Abkhaz ləgaž 'old man' from *ləg 'person' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:19-21).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1506-1507, [LIV²](src-141) 154). For the Tsakonian lexemes in this class, cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):556-557.
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic kurkurá- 'dog', probably imitative after the sound of a dog barking 'kur-kur' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):172, no. 3329; [EWAia](src-172) I:372).
No known etymology; perhaps a substratum loanword (cf. [Lucht 2007](src-151):397).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3949, Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 314

Justification: Of unknown etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):941, cf. [HAB](src-740) III:348-349). [MM: Proto-Armenian *mortʰ-o-].
Loanword from Slavic *goditi ([Meyer 1891](src-585):126, [Orel 1998](src-105):119).

A unique Greco-Armenian isogloss ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):214, [Beekes 2010](src-66):264-265, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):336-337, 340-341, [LIV²](src-141) 162; cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):126-131 for extensive discussion of the various reflexes and derivatives from this root).
Hellenic, Armenian, and Baltic lexemes from PIE *dʰg̑ʰuH- 'fish' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):474, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1331-1332, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):439-440, [ALEW](src-352) 1331-1332).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sterban- 'to become stiff, die', further to PIE *(s)dʰerbʰ- 'to become stiff, firm' ([LIV²](src-141) 512; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):477 reconstructing *(s)terbʰ- with the same basic comparanda). For older comparisons cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):472-473.

Possibly, but not certainly, to be connected with Latv. diêt, in turn from PIE *dei̯h₁- 'dahinjagen' ([LIV²](src-141) 107), cf. [ALEW](src-352) 169, [Derksen 2015](src-353):112), alternatively to Lith. dejà 'Wehklage', without certain etymology (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 189).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit saṁkula- 'crowded together, dense, disordered' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):744 no. 12828). further etymology unclear, cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:211, III:416 for further discussion.
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 720-721).
Borrowing from Romance (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):289, [Orel 1998](src-105):277).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin grandis 'full-grown, large, great', further etymology obscure ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):327 no. 3842, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):281, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):270).
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑i̯eh₁- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:661).
Germanic lexemes reflecting PIE *h₁eh₁t-mon- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):119-120, [EWA 1](src-383):393-394, [Kluge 2011](src-397):67, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:164).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike down' and further to PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, chop' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):234-235, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555).
Proto-Celtic reconstruction uncertain; no etymology outside of Celtic (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:2, [Matasović 2009](src-50):49).

Comment: dy-bod (GPC)
*su̯elk̑s- cf. Middle Persian xwaš, Parthian wxaš

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:227). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):523, no. 9250.
Lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit haḍḍa- 'bone', only attested in lexicographical works. Further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):807 no. 13952; [KEWA](src-399) III:573).
Loanword from Anglo-Norman carier ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

The Bulgarian form goes back to the *korkŭ variant. The etymology of the Slavic lexeme and its further IE cognates are not entirely clear. Lithuanian kárka is rather a cognate but the other words linked to PS *korkŭ not.
Loanword from Italian, either directly from macinare 'to grind', or a denominal formation to a loan from macina 'mill, millstone, grinder'.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯afra- 'snow', derivatives of an Indo-Iranic root *u̯ap- 'to disperse, scatter' to which there are no certain connections outside of Indo-Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):418-419,[Bailey 1979](src-320):305-306, [EWAia](src-172) II:503-505, [KEWA](src-399) III:145).
Two possibilities for a root etymology: Either to *ser- ([LIV²](src-141) 534) or to *u̯er- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1095-1097, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 3. *u̯er- 'to observe, perceive', [IEW](src-49) 1164).
Probably a loanword, cf. Saṇu-viri istˈã 'star' ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):666).
Connected with Avestan raočah- 'light', Old Persian raučah- 'day' ([Korn 2005](src-344)), further from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:463-464).

Comment: possibly a Turkish loan word: kol "arm", if it was used for all extremities

Justification: No known etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:65-66, [Matasović 2009](src-50):177).
Catalan lexemes from Latin labor 'work, labour' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):391), further etymology uncertain (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):320).
No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:811-812). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):811, no. 14021.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *gȏdъ 'right time' < PIE *gʰodʰ-o- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):172-173, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:189-192, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 195).
Slavic lexemes generally connected to PIE *u̯elH- 'to be strong, have power' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):514).
Further etymology outside of (East) Baltic uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 469-470, 486, [Derksen 2015](src-353):234, 243, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):282 for various proposals and further discussion.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):139-140 for various suggestions.

Old Prussian tiēnstwei (inf.) may be derived from PIE *tens- 'to pull' ([LIV²](src-141) 629, cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):366-367, [Derksen 2015](src-353):464, [ALEW](src-352) 1095). This root could well be secondary neo-root abstracted from a desiderative formation to *ten- 'to pull' already in PIE (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 629).
Etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):163 no. 3193, [EWAia](src-172) I:355-356).
Derived from PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):353-355, [LIV²](src-141) 293-294).

According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:254 a derivative of Proto-Iranic *barz- 'high', cf. Av. bərəzant-, Ved. br̥hant- 'tall' etc., further to PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'to become tall; raise oneself' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 78-79).
Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):963, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:510-511). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kanatʃʰ-].
Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *taxma-, cf. Avestan taxma- 'mighty', Old Persian taxma- 'id.' (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:306).
An early borrowing from Iranic ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):669).
Etymology disputed, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:497, [ESIJa](src-331) III:49-51 for various proposals.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic Lexemes from PIE *u̯emh₁- 'to vomit' ([LIV²](src-141) 680, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):416-417, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):245, [EWAia](src-172) II:534-535, [Cheung 2007](src-83):417, [ALEW](src-352) 1216, [Derksen 2015](src-353):497, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):690).

Comment: from Sanskrit ḍayanam (lex.), cf. Turner 1962-66, 5535

Justification: No certain etymology; cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:14 for a survey of various hypotheses.
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯elH- 'to roll' ([ALEW](src-352) 52, [ESSJa](src-458) 31:124-126, [Derksen 2015](src-353):58-59, 497; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 677).
Root etymology in this class follows [de Vaan 2008](src-54):99, but cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):106. For Romance lexemes in this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):170-171.

Comment: Buck gives Grk. KYLLOS 'crooked' as a cognate (1949: 194)
etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 64)

Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin focus 'hearth, fireplace' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):292-293). Further etymology uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):243, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):228-229 for further discussion).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯es- 'to breathe (in, out)' ([LIV²](src-141) 160, [ALEW](src-352) 252-253, [Derksen 2008](src-81):124, 131-132, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:151, 153).

Cognacy in this class follows [Matasović 2009](src-50):317 in treating the lexemes as inherited, but note that the possibility of some borrowing or loan-adaptation between Brythonic and Goidelic and/or early Romance may still be possible (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:54).

Italic lexemes from Latin frīgidus 'cold' (adj.), a derivative of Latin frīgus 'cold, frost' (n.) < PIE *sriHg̑-e/os- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):254, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):243, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):301 no. 3512; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 587)

Iranic lexemes as though from PIE *k̑r-uH- to the same root *k̑er- underlying various derived lexemes in the meaning 'horn' ([EWAia](src-172) II:653, [Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):285, cf. 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457) for further etymological discussion).
From Early Modern Dutch vijs; further etymology uncertain, cf. [EWNl](src-757) for discussion.
Baltic lexemes continuing *gʷerh₃- 'to devour' ([LIV²](src-141) 211-212, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 315-316, [Derksen 2015](src-353):172).
Etymology disputed, cf. [Henning 1947](src-763):47, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):73, [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:242.

Comment: Turner 1931: 128
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):205 no. 3881 *khiñc- 'to drag, pull'. No further etymology.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *nēan- 'to sew', a strong verb continuing PIE *sneh₁- 'to spin (wool, etc.)' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):647, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):385, [LIV²](src-141) 571-572, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):447).
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):427-428); cf. [HED K](src-408):14-15 for unconvincing attempts to relate to Old English hōc 'hook', etc.

Comment: This could be related to zānū: zırānü < *zızānū < *zānū, maybe following the pattern dɨdan "tooth" (though this derives from dandān).

Justification: From PIE *telH- 'become quiet' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):382-383; [LIV²](src-141) 621). NB: [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:170 conflated two roots *tel- now reconstructed separately as *telH- ([LIV²](src-141) 621) and *telh₂- ([LIV²](src-141) 622); [LIV²](src-141) 621 s.v. *telH- does not connect the Germanic lexemes connected to OHG stillen as [Matasović 2009](src-50).
Slavic lexemes to be derived from PIE *gʰlend⁽ʰ⁾- 'to look at, see, shine' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):164, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:122-124, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 200).

Comment: fr. CeltLat. *VIRARE, cf. Gael. gwyro 'turn away, make a detour, remove' (Spanish dictionary online)

Justification: Modern Greek lexemes derived to the root of Ancient Greek ζέω 'boil, seethe' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):530-531), further to PIE *i̯es- 'to boil, foam' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):399-400, [Beekes 2010](src-66):499-500, [LIV²](src-141) 312-313).

Comment: cf. Skt. dhávati 'cleans' (Turner 1931: 329)
Cognate with Gothic 'lasiws'.

Justification: Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *uz-maisa-, a derivative to PIE *mei̯k̑- 'to mix' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:281-282, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):261, [LIV²](src-141) 428-429).

Comment: cf. Turkish fena “bad” < Arabic faniya “vernichten” (fanāˀ) ?
Formally unclear whether the etymology goes back to *Hoi̯-no- or *sem-.
Justification: The etymological handbooks differ on whether Alb. një 'one' should be assigned to PIE *sem- (Gk. εἷς, Arm. mi, etc.) [cognate set 6066](cog-6066) or *Hoi̯-no- (Lat. ūnus, Goth. ains, etc.) [cognate set 91](cog-91) (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):101, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):207, [Orel 1998](src-105):304-305, [Holm 2011](src-130):74 for various assessments).  Consequently the Albanian numeral '1' has therefore been placed in its own cognate set reflecting this etymological uncertainty.
Brythonic lexemes of obscure origin (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):476).
Iranic lexemes derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root noun *tau̯k- 'progeny, children', without certain correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:651, 670).
Exact origin uncertain, probably a Wanderwort (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:588).
Loanword from Slavic *o-met- 'swept snow; snowdrift' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:124).

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek γεμᾶτος 'full', a derivative of Ancient Greek γέμω 'to be full' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):292), further derived from PIE *gem- 'to press, press together' ([LIV²](src-141) 186, [Beekes 2010](src-66):265; cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):215).
Possibly related to English 'cut' in cognate set 2579, but further etymology uncertain; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):286.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fraiwa- 'seed', further etymology disputed (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):123, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):152).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *magino- 'stone, place'. Further connections not fully certain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:9, [Matasović 2009](src-50):252-253 for further discussion.
From Proto-Celtic *kʷello-,; perhaps further to PIE *kʷel(h₁)- 'turn' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):176, [LIPP 2](src-294) 490).
No certain etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):573, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):522). For the Romance lexemes attached to this set cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):603-604.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):247, [Orel 2003](src-388):264). [Kroonen 2013](src-165):358 suggests a comparison with Ru. motýl' 'maggot'.
Parallel loans from Persian راست / rāst 'right'.
Etymology uncertain ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):669).
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:177-178, [Matasović 2009](src-50):108-109).
Continuing a causative stem formation *tu̯orH-éi̯e- to PIE *tu̯erH- 'to grasp' ([LIV²](src-141) 656, [Derksen 2008](src-81):501).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):186-187, [Adams 2013](src-345):263 for various proposals).

According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:37-39, the Ossetic lexemes in this class continue an East Iranic root *rap- also found in Pamir languages (cf. Ormuri we-raf-s-, Shughni wi-ruv-d-). [Not in [Cheung 2007](src-83)].
Loanword from Turkish čök 'knee' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:242-243).

Italic and Romance lexemes typically compared to Proto-Indo-Iranic *pazdu- 'beetle, maggot'. If so we may consider a root *pesd-, perhaps identical with PIE *pesd- 'to fart quietly', although it may well be we are dealing with an independent onomatopoeic formation within PIE as *pesdu- 'annoying insect' vel sim. (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):493, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):454, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):523-524).

Comment: This word is most likely related to the armpit, cf. Av. kaša-, with suffix -ka- and a modern diminutive (?) suffix -ıḷa.

Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic, cf. [Delamarre 2003](src-157):320-321, [Lucht 2007](src-151):430 for various proposals. See also ([Matasović 2009](src-50):423.
No certain etymology outside of Indic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:294).

Comment: There is a second lexeme for small, PCL. *leg-o, lag-o 'small', from PIE  *h₁le(n)gʷʰ-'small, light' (IEW: 661) Matasović (2009, 236). Does not seem to be the Swadesh term in Brittonic, because of its pejorative connotations, cf. MW 'law 'small, sad', OBr. lau gl. petusculum 'small, bad', MoBret. law 'miserable, bad'.
Justification: No clear etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:24, [Lucht 2007](src-151):355), cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):60-61 for a derivation from *bʰeg-ko-, although Matasović admits that this proposal is formally difficult and speculative.

Celtic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *mati- 'good', a derivative of PIE *meh₂- 'good; at the right time' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):181-182, [Matasović 2009](src-50):259-260, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:12-13).

Anatolian, Hellenic, and Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original athematic root-present to PIE *h₁eh₁s- 'to sit' ([LIV²](src-141) 232, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):252-255, [Beekes 2010](src-66):518, [EWAia](src-172) I:181).
Loanword from Germanic *hūsa- ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:159-160, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).
Cf. Old Irish uisce 'water' derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well, to spring' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:21, [Matasović 2009](src-50):394, [NIL](src-274) 706-715).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *ryba 'fish', further etymology obscure (cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) III:525-526, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):552, [Boryś 2005](src-259):528-529, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 3:177).

From Latin pulsāre 'to strike, beat' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):566-567), secondary from Latin pellere 'beat against, push, strike', further to PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):455-456, [LIV²](src-141) 470-471).

Comment: cf. Avestan xšuuiptauuaṇt- "mit Melkmilch versehen"; *xšu̯iptī̆ka- (?)

Justification: Derived from IE *gʷou̯- 'cow' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):89, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:478-480).

Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:187-188, [Lucht 2007](src-151):295-296 for a survey of various proposals. The Proto-Celtic root reference form given for this cognate set provisionally follows [Matasović 2009](src-50):352-353.
No etymology outside of Iranic (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):445-446).
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰrem- 'to buzz, to bellow' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):24, [LIV²](src-141) 94).

Comment: zāk could represent a nasalised zãk (?) < *zank- (?) < *zang-a-k, cf. Av. zaṇga- „ankle“, alternatively one would have to assume zāk < *zaγ-k < *zaγ-ak < *zaga- < *j́nͅgʰ-

Justification: Germanic lexemes generally connected to Latin sordēs 'dirt' and derivatives (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1052, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):333, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):574-575, [Orel 2003](src-388):392; tentatively [Kluge 2011](src-397):833; cf. also [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):637, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):576 cited in [cognate set 4865](cog-4865)) as though from a PIE o-stem adjective *su̯ordo-. If these lexemes go back to the same source, then they may be a post-PIE innovation in Germanic and Italic. [Not [Kroonen 2013](src-165)].
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):247, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):358).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *kerla- ~ *karla- 'man, freeman', a derivative of PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to wear down, make old' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):301, [Orel 2003](src-388):210, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):285, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 165-166).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃er- 'to set in motion; rise' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):826, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1109-1110; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 299-300).

Comment: etym. dub. CHECK VGK I, 66
Justification: A Brythonic word of uncertain origin ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):197).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰlei̯g̑- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):45-46, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:121-123, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 88-89).

Of obscure origin, probably a prehistoric loanword (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):420, [Beekes 2010](src-66):530 for discussion of various hypotheses). The different dialectal forms point to either a Proto-Greek or borrowed source form *tʰalak⁽ʰ⁾i̯a (vel sim.).
Originally 'fresh', a transferred epithet from the phrase νηρόν ὕδωρ 'fresh water' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):915-196), further to PIE *neu̯- 'new, fresh' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1018).
Loan from Spanish empujar 'to push'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66 s.v. khalla m., no. 3848: "connexion with challi <-> and of both with skhádate ʻcutsʼ Dhātup. [...] doubtful"?

Justification: Loan from Lat. ponderis 'of weight' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):596).

Traditionally connected to IE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' (cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):425-426, [LIV²](src-141) 525), but this etymology is unclear on phonological grounds; cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):996, [LIV²](src-141) 525-526.
There are no certain cognates beyond Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):322, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 369-370), cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 19:144-147, [Beekes 2010](src-66): 893.

Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Traditionally connected to a root *mer(ə)- with various root extensions (cf. [IEW](src-49) 739-740, [Seebold 1970](src-556):352, [de Vries 1977](src-468):393). [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):417 does not propose an updated etymology. No lemmata in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165).
Of uncertain etymology, it is doubtful that the lexemes may be derived from Latin cossus 'a kind of larva' as previously supposed ([DCECH](src-423) III:287-290, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):211).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kʷei̯t- 'to perceive, to recognise' ([LIV²](src-141) 382-383, [ALEW](src-352) 919-920, [Derksen 2015](src-353):401, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:119, [Derksen 2008](src-81):89-90).
Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑ad- 'to fall' ([LIV²](src-141) 318, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):78-79, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):134 no. 1451).

Comment: There is mrγ “pasture”, which is given in Sogdian for “forest”, formally *ati-margā- would work, but does it make sense?

Justification: Cf. Old Irish folach 'hiding'. For various etymological proposals, cf. [Bergin 1938](src-766):220-222.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *tungla- 'star, celestial body(?)', further connections outside Germanic uncertain ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):348, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):526).
Continuing a derivative of PIE *tu̯em- 'to swell up' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):663, [LIV²](src-141) 654).
Romance lexemes based on a stem *pīkk-, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):536)

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally considered to be from PIE *(s)lei̯b- 'drag, glide' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:131, cf. {ref LIV² 566 s.v. ?*(s)lei̯b-, [IEW](src-49) 663) via an original meaning '(slippery) slope', but [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) finds this development semantically dubious.
No clear etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):515-516, cf. also [HED L](src-409):40-44).

Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin lārgus 'generous, bountiful' ([DCECH](src-423) III:586-587, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):399), further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):342, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):327).
No certain etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):30); possibly to *h₃emh₃- 'to grab' according to [de Vaan 2008](src-54):40.

A derived adjective from Hellenistic Greek κίτρον 'fruit of the citrus tree', a loanword from Late Latin citrium, cf. Classical Latin citrus 'citrus tree' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):667-668, [Beekes 2010](src-66):705).
Old English tígan is a denominal formation as though from earlier *téag-jan 'to bind', based on OE téag 'rope', to be connected with ON taug 'rope', probably from Germanic *taug-.

Perhaps further from PIE *koi̯(H)lo- if connected with Latvian kaîls 'naked, bald', but the comparative semantics are rather remote (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:6, [Matasović 2009](src-50):220).

Comment: Bartholomae (1904: 1523) quotes the reconstruction *srān°. In Ossetic also "belt".

Justification: Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as a transferred adjective in the phrase nummi aspri 'rough coins', the original semantic development to 'white' appears to have been '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white', cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):223-224, [Beekes 2010](src-66):154.
Either a loanword from West Caucasian or a nursery word (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:362).
Same as 'fly_V' in [cognate set 9512](cog-9512)?
Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes derived to PIE *h₁egʷʰ- 'to drink' ([LIV²](src-141) 231; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):236-237, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):810-811, [Adams 2013](src-345):551-552).
Ossetic lexemes, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:14).
As though from Iranic *padakā- according to [Humbach 1989](src-767):194, cf. [Henning 1955](src-768):43, [Benzing 1983](src-764):540), further etymology uncertain.
No clear etymology outside of Celtic, cf. [Delamarre 2003](src-157):453, [Matasović 2009](src-50):231 for various suggestions.
There is no certain etymology. The relationship to PS *prętati and Russian prygat' is dubious. Cf. [cognate set 5208](cog-5208).

Cognate with Lithuanian peldė́ti 'to swim'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally assigned to PIE *pelǝ-, *plē- 'to fill' (now reconstructed as *pleh₁-, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 482-483) with a root extension in *-d- ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):565, [IEW](src-49) 800-801, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:34-35). Not in [LIV²](src-141), [Derksen 2015](src-353), or [ALEW](src-352).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vālukā- 'sand' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):675, no. 11580). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:196, [EWAia](src-172) II:547 for discussion of various conjectures.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek σκέπτομαι 'I look about carefully, examine' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1279-1280), further derived from PIE *spek̑-, with metathesis *sp…k > sk…p ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1347-1348, [LIV²](src-141) 575-576).
Loan from Arabic, cf. Standard Arabic دِمَاغ / dimāḡ 'brain'.
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *smei̯- 'to smile, laugh' ([LIV²](src-141) 568-569, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):456-457, [Derksen 2015](src-353):550-551).
Modern Hellenic lexemes derived from Ancient Greek κόκκος 'kernel', further etymology unknown ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):694-695, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):553, [Beekes 2010](src-66):733}).
Etymology uncertain, cf. Ved. dhánu- 'dry land', dhánvan- 'desert'(?) ([EWAia](src-172) I:774, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):384 no. 6724)
As though continuing Sanskrit *skambha- 'shoulderblade, wing, plumage' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):786 no. 13640). Further etymology uncertain.

From Proto-Slavic *rъvati 'to tear' and further derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'to tear (up)' ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) III:452, [Derksen 2008](src-81):441-442, [Boryś 2005](src-259):528, [LIV²](src-141) 510).
Identical to Khwarazmian 'long' in [cognate set 3381](cog-3381), further to PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):299, [EWAia](src-172) II:232).
West Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *uba-eta- 'side dish', the lexical root of *eta- corresponds to PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):2, 665; [EWNl](src-757) 3:463).
As though from an Indic stem *muṭṭa- 'heart', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):587 no. 10188).

Proposed to Sanskrit nudati (otherwise isolated, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:176, [LIV²](src-141) 456 s.v. ?2. *neu̯d- 'stoßen') by [Jasanoff 1978b](src-645):39 via a pre-form *nud-sk̑e/o-, but this connection is formally difficult from a Tocharian perspective (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):682-683, [Adams 2013](src-345):356-357 for further discussion).
Loanword from Italian destra 'right'.
Iranic lexemes derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root noun *tau̯k- 'progeny, children', without certain correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:651, 670).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *telamon- 'earth, ground', a derivative to PIE *telh₂- 'to raise, support' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:22-23, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):288-289, [Matasović 2009](src-50):366, cf. {ref LIV² 622-623).
Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ([Derksen 2008](src-81):494, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4:183, [Boryś 2005](src-259):77, 84 for various proposals.
Loan into Romance from Old Low Franconian ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:210-229, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):109).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *rokъ, derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *rekti 'speak, say' < PIE *rek- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):433, 438; [Boryś 2005](src-259):517, 532; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 506).
Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *mai̯θā-, cf. Avestan maēθā- 'change, evolution' ([Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):45-46, [MacKenzie 1990](src-680):116).
Cf. Sanskrit gaḍa- 'young of the fish Ophiocephalus lata or Cyprinus garra' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):212 no. 3970), only attested by lexicographers. Further etymology uncertain.
As though continuing an Indic stem *ḍoka- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):313 no. 5566). No further etymology.
It's disputable if the Slavic word belongs to PIE ?*dʰreb- or *dʰrebʰ-. The majority view is adopted here.
Denominal formation from Old Breton sco 'strike, blow', further etymology obscure ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):666).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *bōan- ~ *būan- 'to live, dwell', further derived from PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to grow, emerge, become' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):124-126, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):71, [LIV²](src-141) 98-101).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *dʰeu̯- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:789-790, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):389 no.6802, [Cheung 2007](src-83):65-66, [LIV²](src-141) 147-148).
Parallel loans from Persian پوزه / pōz(e) 'muzzle, snout' (cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):68).
The Latin and Romance forms are based on a reduplicated formation *pró-pro with dissimilation of the second *-r- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):492-493, [LIPP 2](src-294):641).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *derb- 'to join, tie, sew (together)', and further to PIE ?*derbʰ- 'to bind together, braid' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 121).

Latin abscondere 'to hide', unprefixed verb -dō, -dere from PIE *dʰeh₁- 'put, place; do' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):175-176, [LIV²](src-141) 136-138). For the Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):4.
Perhaps to PIE ?*leu̯p- '(ab)schälen' ([LIV²](src-141) 420, [IEW](src-49) 690-1), cf. [EWA 5](src-398):1454-1457; otherwise obscure (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):328).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):357 for a summary of various proposals.

Perhaps to be connected with Balto-Slavic forms (Latv. merguôt 'rain slowly', merga 'soft rain', Ru. morositь) to a root *mergʰ- (with Greek forms reflecting a Schwebeablaut variant *mregʰ-), but this etymology is uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):195, [Beekes 2010](src-66):238; not in [LIV²](src-141)).
The root is ideophonic. Any further etymology (as *(s)kreb-, cf. [ESSJa](src-458)) is speculative.
Loanword from Middle Low German made 'worm' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600) III:388).
Breton lexemes, first attested in Middle Breton, but further origins obscure ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):669).

Comment: probably simply „what is to be eaten“

Justification: Generally assumed to be connected with Proto-Germanic *sehwan- 'see' (cf. [cognate set 288](cog-288)) from PIE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' ([LIV²](src-141) 525-526), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):704-706 (rejected, however, by [HED SA](src-699):50-57 on the grounds that the etymology contravenes Sturtevant's Rule).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin concha 'shell, seashell' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):199), an old loanword, already attested in Plautus, from Ancient Greek κόγχη, κόγχᾱ 'mussel' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):136).
North Germanic lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *skenþan- ([Orel 2003](src-388):338, cf. [de Vries 1961](src-214):493). Further etymology uncertain. [Not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165)].

Welsh lexemes, which along with Old Cornish trein and Gaulish *trugna- (implied through Romance, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):744 no. 8947) appear to reflect Proto-Celtic *trugnV- ([Schrijver 1995](src-305):442n2, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Matasović 2009](src-50):353).

Generally connected with PIE *h₃bʰreu̯H- 'eyebrow' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):67, [Holm 2011](src-130):67), cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):48, [Orel 1998](src-105):36-37 for a more tenuous comparison to a Messapic gloss in Hesychius and the Etymologicum Magnum.
Etymology uncertain, perhaps of onomatopoeic origin? (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:6).

Comment: < Lat. PILA 'bundle (of hair)'? (Dietz 1864:342)

Justification: Further connections uncertain. Perhaps to be connected with the complex of 'white' words from PGmc. *blank- but due to the difference in semantics this connection remains unclear, cf. OED, [EWA 2](src-386).
Probably a loan from Old French diguer ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Generally derived from a basic PIE root *bʰel- 'to blow, swell' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):525, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):178-179).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:133-134, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):220, 231-232, 305; [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):398 for further discussion).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):666).

Probably a formation derived from TochAB kät- 'strew (on purpose); sow (seeds)' ([Adams 2013](src-345):686), further to PIE *(s)kedh₂- 'shatter, disperse' ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):564-565, [Adams 2013](src-345):166-167, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 550-551).
Extra-Tocharian connections unclear ([Adams 2013](src-345):68)

Comment: lit. "cutting"

Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *māro- from PIE *meh₁-ro- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:18, [Matasović 2009](src-50):258).
Of onomatopoeic origin. No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:18-19, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):202).
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):99, 507; [LIV²](src-141) 119-121).

Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *lagja- 'leg; hollow bone, stalk'. Attestation is restricted to North Germanic and there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):321-322).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *kelH- 'to rise up, to tower' ([ALEW](src-352) 441-442, 475-476, [Derksen 2015](src-353):221, 236, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 349).
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Wakhi pʉz 'chest', Sarikoli puz 'id.', etc. ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):662).

Comment: Also Welsh 'cig', Breten 'kik', both meaning 'flesh' Buck (p249)

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):65, [Orel 1998](src-105):103 for various proposals and further discussion.
Derived from Middle Breton liam, a borrowing from Old French liem ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):463).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):244, [ESSJa](src-458) 12:70-74, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) for further discussion.

A denominative verb to Gk. κυνηγός 'hound-leader, huntsman'. The lexical root for the 'leader' element of the verbal governing compound is from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'drive' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 255f.), compounded with *k̑un- 'dog' (cf. [NIL](src-274) 436-440 s.v. *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥- 'Hund' cf. [cognate set 21](cog-21)).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g̑- 'to belch, to vomit' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 848-849, 877-878, [Derksen 2015](src-353):385, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:134, [LIV²](src-141) 509).
Root ref. form follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), but note that the Proto-Luwic form this class represents may also formally represent *gʷelH-. Cf. [LIV²](src-141) 679.
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *leg̑- 'to collect, to pick up' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):625-626, [Beekes 2010](src-66):841-842, [LIV²](src-141) 397).
Lexemes as though continuing Old Indic latā- 'creeper, vine' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):633 no. 10928). Further etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) III:88).

Etymology outside Tocharian uncertain. [Adams 2013](src-345):23 proposes a connection to Hittite ḫaḫ(a)ri- 'lung(s), midriff' (but this Hittite form remains of obscure etymology according to [HED H](src-407):7).

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *nabja- 'beak', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([de Vries 1977](src-468):406, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):380). Cf. however [Orel 2003](src-388):279 and others attempting to connect to Proto-Germanic *nabō- 'nave' via a meaning 'protuberance, knob'.

Goidelic lexemes probably continuing a compound containing Proto-Celtic *retu- 'course', and ultimately a derivative of PIE *ret- 'to run' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:112, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):310).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):522, [Kroonen 2011](src-656):333, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):460-461 for further discussion.

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish tút, túth 'smell, stench' (cf. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):371). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:189 for references to an uncertain proposal to OHG stiuz.

Comment: fr. the notion of 'quick, swift' (Buck 1949: 896)
= Lat. CRATIS 'wickerwork, hurdle', Gr. KARTALOS 'basket', SKT> KṚT- 'twist thread together, spin' (Buck 1949: 668)

Justification: No certain etymology outside of North Germanic; traditionally considered a derivative of PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):671 citing [IEW](src-49) 81ff. *u̯ē-; not in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165)).
Loanword from Latin piscem 'fish' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):329, [Huld 1984](src-571):103, [Orel 1998](src-105):316-317, [Holm 2011](src-130):63)
See also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 668-669.
No certain connections outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:123-124, [Matasović 2009](src-50):210).
Hellenic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₂rei̯- 'to count, reckon' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):131, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):281-282, [Matasović 2009](src-50):313).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (pace [Kluge 2011](src-397):768, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:434).

Comment: *grilla- 'wet, damp', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 235, no. 4386; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ἀμαυρός 'dim, faint' ([Andriotis 1999](src-271):828-829). No further etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):71-72, [Beekes 2010](src-66):84).
Etymology uncertain. Loanword from Bulgar? (cf. [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 2:633
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Turner 1931](src-69):241, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):330 no. 5803.
Etymologically isolated, the proposed connection with Lithuanian girià 'forest, wilderness' remains doubtful ([ALEW](src-352) 332). For older proposals cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:291-292.
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84) for further discussion.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kau̯fa-, perhaps originally 'hump', without certain cognates outside of Iranic ([Schmitt 2014](src-358):202-203).
It is related to PS *golŭ ['naked']. The original meaning was thus 'stick without twigs, naked stick' [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 218.
Latin flūmen and Romance lexemes from PIE *bʰleu̯H-mn̥- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):228, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):292, [LIV²](src-141) 90).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):389 for similar Romance lexemes in the same meaning).

Comment: Could skarəna- be derived from *kʷelh₁-? *s-kr̩H-na- > skarna-

Justification: No consensus etymology; cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174):585, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):384, and [Beekes 2010](src-66):478 for various proposals.
No known etymology ([Adams 2013](src-345):401).

Comment: < 'excrement'

Justification: Loan from (Low) German voll 'full' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):1095).
Romance lexemes as though from Latin *tīrāre, of uncertain origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):725, [DCECH](src-423) V:505-508 for further discussion).

Comment: Origin unclear, l can derive from *rd/rz if this verb had originally a prefix. It is also possible that there is a kind of r/l alternation. Then it could be related to cognate set 6659 *Hrab/f-: raw- > *rū- (?), though this is pretty wanted.

Justification: Cf. MIr. cethramthu 'quarter, fourth part' in the sense of 'quartered human body; thigh' ([Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language (eDIL)](src-300)), further to OIr. cethair 'four' from PIE *kʷetu̯or- 'four' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):179).
Uncertain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic, cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1131-1132, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):691 for further discussion. [Not in [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353)].
Loan from Finnic, cf. Livonian puk'k' (cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:85).
Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'to stick; be pointy' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):879, [EWNl](src-757) 4:272-273, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):476, [LIV²](src-141) 592-593).
Anatolian lexemes continuing PIE *di̯eu̯-ot-, further derived from PIE *dei̯- '(to be) bright, to shine' ([NIL](src-274) 69-81, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):766-767).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *belgan- 'to swell', further derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'to swell' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):99-100, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):73-74, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 73-74).
Slavic lexemes as though from PIE ?*pel- 'to flame up, blaze up' ([LIV²](src-141) 469, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):390, [Boryś 2005](src-259):409).

Romance lexemes from Latin tūtāre, tūtārī ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:446-449). Further root etymology disputed: Either to ?*teu̯H- '(freundlich) beachten, betrachten; schützen' ([LIV²](src-141) 639-640) or to* teu̯h₂- 'to be strong' > 'keeps strong, protects' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):632-633).
IE root etymology disputed, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):493-494 for a critical discussion of competing alternatives; see also [HED K](src-408) 245-248.
Derived from Old Irish cengal 'link, belt, tie', a loanword from Latin cingulum 'belt' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:65).

Comment: comp. NPers. GŌŠĀ 'edge, corner'. Rather not: NP gušād is from Middle Persian wišād! MJK

Justification: No known etymology ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):980).

Comment: Initial H may be either *h₁ or *h₃ (Kloekhorst 2008:167-168).
Justification: A root restricted to Anatolian. [LIV²](src-141) 234-235 mechanically reconstructs ?*h₁e⁽k̑⁾- 'to die'; [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):167-168 assumes *Hók- / *Hk- with indeterminable laryngeal under the assumption that laryngeals merged with *h₁ before *o in Anatolian (cf. [Kloekhorst 2006](src-654)).

Adjective derived from Latin sordēs 'dirt, filth, stain', generally further connected to Proto-Germanic *swarta- 'black' appearing to reflect an adjective *su̯ordo- 'black, dirt-colour' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):637, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):576, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1052, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):574-575, [Orel 2003](src-388):392).
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *keh₂u̯l(o)-, further analysis of the word formation within Indo-European is unclear (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 467-469, [Derksen 2015](src-353):233).
Loanword from German schmutzig 'dirty' ([Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).
Of uncertain etymology, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):408-409 for various proposals.
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *u̯ei̯s- 'to sprout, thrive' ([ALEW](src-352) 1170-1171, [Derksen 2015](src-353):485, 495; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 671).
An intensive formation to Swedish skrata 'scare, chase away', of onomatopoeic/imitative origin ([Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).

Romance lexemes from Latin bastum 'stick' as a secondary n-stem *bastō, -ōnis. No further etymology ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 1:279, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):83, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):67).

Literally a participle to the verbal root ā(i)- 'to be hot'; further etymology uncertain. For competing IE root analyses cf. [LIV²](src-141) 229, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):164-166, with references to further literature.
No certain etymology outside of Italic (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):642-643, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):581).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):434-435, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):453-454. Perhaps to an IE root *sleh₁b- 'be slack'(?) if to be connected with Lith. slobstù, slõbti 'be weak' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 565).

Derived from Middle Welsh bwyd 'food' (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)), further from Proto-Celtic *bēto- < PIE *gʷei̯h₃-to- ([Matasović 2009](src-50):64), cf. PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'live' ([LIV²](src-141) 215-216).
Generally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'hit, beat' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:177-180, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):642-646, [Matasović 2009](src-50):393; cf. {ref LIV² 601).
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *kret- 'to shake' ([ALEW](src-352) 524, 527; [LIV²](src-141) 370-371).
Etymology outside of Celtic disputed, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:22, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):170, [Matasović 2009](src-50):295-296, for various proposals.
Parallel loans from Arabic علف / ʿalf 'feed, fodder'.

Etymological connections outside of Baltic uncertain, traditionally compared to Proto-Indo-Iranic *sau̯- 'to press, squeeze' but this etymological proposal is no longer widely accepted ([ALEW](src-352) 908, [Derksen 2015](src-353):396, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:713-714, [LIV²](src-141) 537-538).
Celtic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *mīlo- 'animal' continuing PIE *meh₁lo- 'small animal' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:51, [Matasović 2009](src-50):271-272).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2368 and ff.

Justification: No certain etymology outside of (East) Baltic (cf. Latv. juõds 'demon, evil spirit'). See [ALEW](src-352) 419-420, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):238 for further discussion.

Comment: Parallel loans from Arabic

Justification: From Ancient Greek συλλογίζομαι 'reckon, compute' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):526), from συν- 'with' + λογίζομαι 'count, reckon' a denominal verb in -ιζω from Ancient Greek λόγος 'computation, reckoning', and o-grade noun from PIE *leg̑- 'collect' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):841, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 397, [IEW](src-49) 658).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *preh₁- 'to blow on; stoke up' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1192, [LIV²](src-141) 489, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1153).
Loanword, but precise source uncertain. Either from Romance rombulus or from Greek ῥύμβος.
Derived from Ancient Greek θεωρέω 'to view, look, behold' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), no certain etymology outside of Greek: for further etymological details cf. 'see' in [cognate set 8257](cog-8257).
The ablaut and morphology of related vocabulary within Greek suggest a root *h₂u̯ei̯d-, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 288, [Beekes 2010](src-66):23).
Derivative to Proto-Germanic *drita- 'shit, dirt' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):103-104, [Seebold 1970](src-556):164-165).
As though from Proto-Iranic *u̯azi̯ā̆-u̯ant- 'possessing weight', cf. Avestan uaziia- 'weight, load' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:105).

Iranic lexemes, as though continuing a prefix *ka- + PIE *ml̥h₃dʰ-, cf. Vedic mūrdhán- 'forehead, head, top part', Ancient Greek βλωθρός 'grown high', Old English molda 'top of head' ([EWAia](src-172) II:368, [Bailey 1979](src-320):52).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *stinkwan- 'to thrust, to clash; to stink', a derivative of PIE *stengʷ- 'to thrust, push' ([LIV²](src-141) 596-597, [Seebold 1970](src-556):471-472, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):480-481).

Extra-Tocharian connections unclear, possibly to be connected within Tocharian to Tocharian A kāts, B kātse 'belly', cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):112, [Adams 2013](src-345):165-166 for further discussion.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gau̯b- 'to say (positively/negatively)', no certain etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):113-114).

Comment: From Old Irish gar 'short; near'

Justification: Derived from Lithuanian gìrti 'to praise', further derived from PIE *gʷerH- 'to express agreement' ([ALEW](src-352) 335-336, [Derksen 2015](src-353):171, 178-179, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 210-211).
Extra-Tocharian connections are uncertain (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):504-505 for various suggestions).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from derived from Vedic √cet- 'to recognise' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):261, no. 4815), ultimately from PIE *kʷei̯t- 'to observe, recognise', traditionally analysed as a root-extended form *kʷei̯-t- to a more basic root *kʷei̯- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:547-548, [LIV²](src-141) 382-383).

Comment: from *u̯ert- 'turn, roll, spin', Vedic vartáyati (RV), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11356
could this be identical with Kumzari bidrit?

Justification: Parallel loans from Arabic عورة ˁawra 'flaw, blemish', pl. عورات ˁawrāt 'pudency, pubic area'.

Etymology uncertain. According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:148, to be connected to lexemes from PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, chop' in [cognate set 697](cog-697); [Cheung 2007](src-83):442 hesitates between etymologies to either Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh' or Proto-Iranic *xa(m)p/b- 'to dismount, descend, move away'.

The Germanic and Celtic forms in this class reflect a derived stem *kh₂p-no- or *kap-no- (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:261-262, [Matasović 2009](src-50):197, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):196-197}), for the reconstruction of the IE root as either *keh₂p- or *kap- cf. [LIV²](src-141) 345n1.
Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain; cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):9-10 for various proposals.

Comment: North Germanic only.
Justification: Possibly to be connected to the verbal root underlying Ved. √śak- ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):264-265, 301-302), but the etymology is not fully certain; cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:600-601.
No clear etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):975-976, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1288).
Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:83-84, 123; [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:176, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):230).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *lě̀to 'summer', as though an o-stem derived from PIE *leh₁t-. Alternatively, an analysis as a secondary derivative to an original t-stem from a hypothetical root *leh₁- remains possible; cf. note by Scarborough in the cognate class citations for further discussion.

Comment: Loan from East Caucasian
Justification: Loanword from East Caucasian ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:333-334).
Parallel loans from Middle Low German trecken 'to pull' (cf. [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97)).

Comment: < AOIS  'age'

Justification: Parallel loans from Middle Low German glatt 'smooth'.

From PIE *treb- 'dwell', a Western Indo-European isogloss common to Celtic, Italic, Germanic, and Baltic ([Untermann 2000](src-279):765-766, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):388-389, [ALEW](src-352) 1126).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):267-268).
Etymology outside of Anatolian debated, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):645-646, [HED PA](src-412) 168-170, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar Vol. 2, 446-447 for various proposals.
Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 421, [Kluge 2011](src-397):590, but cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):350.
Loanword from Latin coccum 'berry' ([Orel 1998](src-105):189, [Holm 2011](src-130):65-66).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):267-268, cf. [Melchert 1993a](src-377):45).
Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE stem *pitu- ~ *pei̯tu- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:130 s.v. Vedic pitú- 'food, solid food).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Strand 2011a](src-432).
Etymology uncertain ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):533-534, cf. [HED L](src-409):111-114, 127-128).
Light verb constructions using parallel loans from Arabic as the semantic head, cf. Arabic milāḥa 'swimming, sailing', mallāḥ 'sailor' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:606-607).

Comment: loan, via Hindi farāḵẖ from Persian (Turner 1931: 401)

Justification: Onomatopoeic in origin, no further etymology outside of Slavic ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:135).
No certain etymology outside of Celtic (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:43-44, [Matasović 2009](src-50):341).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10186
Turner 1931: 260

Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):410-411 for various proposals.
No clear etymology outside of Tocharian ([Adams 2013](src-345):26-27).
Loanword from South or East Caucasian ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:376)
Of uncertain origin, perhaps an East Caucasian loanword? (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. {ref [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:383).
Loanword from Low German recht 'right' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):634-635).
Light verb construction with Marathi माहित / mahit 'know' as the semantic head.
Cf. Old Lithuanian tiẽsus 'straight, direct', without certain connections outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1100-1102).

From MHG swanz, a backformation to MHG swanzen which is in turn in all likelihood an intensive formation to schwanken 'to waver, oscillate', in turn derived from the adjective schwank 'swaying' < Gmc. *swanka- (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):832, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):573).

Comment: fr. Ir. FIADH  'animal' (Buck 1949: 191)

Justification: Loans from Middle Low German (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):144).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from *choṭṭa- 'small', further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):279 no. 5071).
Greek and Celtic lexemes as nominal derivatives of PIE *h₁ers- 'rear' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):838, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1127-1128, [Matasović 2009](src-50):118).
Loan from Persian تخم / toxm 'seed'.
The Modern Goidelic forms in this class derive from the OId Irish compound do·srenga.
An old borrowing from Persian/Tajik xān(a)- 'house' ([Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):409).
Italic and Romance lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *u̯enH- 'to grow fond of' ([LIV²](src-141) 682-683, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):662, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):766 no. 9186).

Generally connected to words for male sexual organs in other IE languages, cf. Vedic pásas- 'penis', Gk. πέος 'penis', Lat. pēnis 'penis', OHG fasal 'seed, descendant' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):670, [HED PE, PI, PU](src-413):37-45).
Without certain etymology (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:276-277).
Etymology uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):583 for a critical discussion of previous proposals).

Comment: = NE EVEN

Justification: Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):278 for discussion of various proposals.
