Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):571 for references to older (now uncertain) proposed etymologies, [Orel 2003](src-388):395 for a proposed Albanian cognate and references to older literature. No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).
Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):554).
No convincing etymology outside of Celtic. See [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:7-8, [Matasović 2009](src-50):86-87 for various suggestions.
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *walþu- 'field, uncultivated area, wood', further from a PIE derived stem *uólH-tu- ([Kluge 2011](src-397):968, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):571-572).
As though from *h₂er-u-ti- to PIE *h₂er- 'to fit (together), join' ([Melchert 1988](src-416):224-225).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:319-320).
Loanword from Latin spīna 'thorn, spine; spine, backbone' ([Orel 1998](src-105):430).
Etymology outside of Tocharian unclear ([Adams 2013](src-345):611-612).

Generally considered a loanword from Latin ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:128) but occasionally disputed (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):587). On upholding the loanword hypothesis, cf. comments by Irslinger in this class.
Apparently a loanword from Old Norse hitta 'to hit upon, light upon, meet with' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Welsh lexemes derived from PIE *terh₁- 'to rub, bore' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):370-371, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 632-633).
Loanword from Modern High German leben 'to live' ([Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):796).

Comment: fr. Lat. SOLUM 'bottom, base, sole, ground'

Justification: Etymology uncertain; cf. [HED A+E/I](src-406):178-182 and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):212 for various proposals.
Anatolian lexemes generally compared with Proto-Germanic *dankwa- 'dark' derived to a PIE root *dʰengʷ- ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):829, cf. also [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):146).
Old and Middle Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √ard- 'to scatter, spray'. Further connections unclear, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:60 for various suggestions.

Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off' ([EWAia](src-172) I:537, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):255 no. 4701, [Boryś 2005](src-259):553, [Derksen 2008](src-81):234, 452; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 556-557).
Loan from Low German, cf. Middle Low German sât 'seed' ([Polański & Sehnert 1967](src-354):135).
Loanword from Slavic *kostъka ([Orel 1998](src-105):187, [Holm 2011](src-130):53-54).

Ossetic lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *u̯i-tarta-, a verbal adjective to PIE *terh₂- 'to go through, cross over' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:344, [Cheung 2007](src-83):382, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:629-632, [LIV²](src-141) 633-634).
Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *rak(k)an- '(sleuth) dog'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):432, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):404).

Comment: cf. *kauč- “to bend, draw into, contract”, which is possibly reflected in Abyānei köta/kuǰ- “to gnaw” (Cheung 2007: 249)

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit accha- 'clear transparent'; further etymology uncertain, perhaps to Vedic acchāyá- 'shadowless' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):8 no. 142).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2538, Turner 1931: 565

Justification: Probably an from an IE s-stem *h₃er-es- 'high' to PIE *h₃er- 'rise' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 299-300) that has been secondarily transferred into -r/n- inflection, which is morphologically productive in Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):314-315).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4153: presumably from a non-Indo-Aryan source

Justification: Root etymology in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 402, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):350-351 to PIE *lei̯d- 'set in motion'.

Comment: Morgenstierne considers the derivation of kˈāṇay < *karna-ka- possible and compares it with Lithuanian kálnas. This suggests an input form *klͅHn- or *kolHn-.

Justification: Denominal formation, but further details are disputed (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):963-964, [Adams 2013](src-345):787-788 for further discussion).
Parallel loans from Persian (زندگى (كردن  / zendegī (kardan) 'to live'.
Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442), no. 8397 s.v. *pōḍ- 'burn'. No further etymology.
Loanword from Iranic (cf. [Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):666).
Parallel loans from Persian گردن / gardan 'neck'.
According to [Strand 1998](src-431) to be connected with Vedic hári- 'golden, yellow' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):809 no. 13981). If so, further to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green'.
Loan from Middle Persian.
Of uncertain etymology ([EWAia](src-172) I:487-488).
Etymology outside of Iranian uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):104-105).
Ultimately derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'make red' ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) III:207, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 508-509).
Loanword from Livonian nuja 'stick' ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:631).

Comment: Perhaps with Slavic *mězga 'sap'?

Justification: Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hrugja- 'ridge; back'. Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):250, [Kluge 2011](src-397):775 for further discussion.
Adjective derived from the common Iranic word for 'stone, rock'.

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing secondary derivatives of a Celtic verbal root *klek- (cf. Old Irish clich- '(s)he moves', nominal cluiche 'game, event, sport'), probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:127).
Romance lexemes apparently going back to a stem *pe/itt- 'small', probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):543 no. 6544a, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 8:342-347).
Parallel loans from Persian. The Pamir words (Wakhi, Sarikoli) are probably loaned from Tajik.
No clear etymology; often considered to be a non-Indo-European Wanderwort (cf. [Weeks 1985](src-68):125, [HED A+E/I](src-406):32-33 for further discussion).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):46-47, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):113-114, [Orel 1998](src-105):42-43, [Holm 2011](src-130):70-71 for various suggestions and discussion.
Loan from Old Norse vængir ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Loan from Pāli sītala- 'cold', cf. Sinhalese hīl 'cold' as the inherited reflex from Sanskrit śītalá- 'cold' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):723 no. 12487).

Comment: Loan from Arabic qarīb

Justification: Unexpected vocalism points to parallel loans from Persian.
Parallel loans from Persian گوشت / gūšt 'meat'.
Parallel loans from Middle Low German swanz 'trailer; tail, penis' (cf. [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).
Loan from Latin coccum '(berry which was used to produce scarlet dye)' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):139).
According to [Orel 1998](src-105):425, a loanword from Germanic *skurta- 'short'.
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. Middle Persian pwst / põst 'skin', Persian: Tehran پوست	 / pūst 'id.'.
Loanword from within Iranic, probably via Tajik or Persian.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 14018 s.v. *hallati intr. 'moves, shakes'
Justification: Modern Indic as though from Old Indic *hallati 'moves, shakes', cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):810 no. 14018. Further etymology unclear.

Comment: via "swollen" > "thick", cf. Benzing (1983:256)
Ir. *duai > (WA)LWEDEL; root cautiously proposed by Cheung (2007: 81).
etym. dub. (Buck 1949: 1012)
Justification: The forms seem to point back to a root *blei̯d- / *blid- to which different stems were formed within Celtic; further connections outside of Celtic uncertain (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:59, [Matasović 2009](src-50):69). See [de Bernardo Stempel 1999](src-733):79 for a discussion of the stem formation.
Loanword from Russian год 'year' (cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) I:127).
Loanword from Latin bestia ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:49).

Possibly to IE *drep- 'scratch, tear' according to [Adams 2013](src-345):574, although note that the Anatolian evidence which he cites for a semantic parallel is not certainly from this root ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):812-813, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):871).
Parallel loans from Persian, cf. Persian: Tehran تیز / tīz 'sharp'.
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *h₁erH- 'to wash', cf. TochA yär- 'to bathe' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):197-198, [LIV²](src-141) 239).
Possibly from PIE *mergʷ- if to be compared with Proto-Germanic *merkwa- 'dark' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):562-563, cf. also [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):409-410, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):366).
Slavic lexemes from PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to perceive, see' ([LIV²](src-141) 561, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):91, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:136-138).

Etymology uncertain, possibly connected with Ancient Greek αἰονάω 'to moisten' (cf. [Melchert 1994](src-368):102), but this proposal is not without some formal difficulties ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):340-341, cf. also [HED H](src-407):301-304).
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original athematic root-present to PIE *ses- 'to sleep' ([LIV²](src-141) 536-537, [EWAia](src-172) II:716-717, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):746-747).
From PIE *mneh₂- according to [Starke 1990](src-373):147; tentatively accepted by [LIV²](src-141) 447.
Etymology uncertain, either an onomatopoeic formation or an East Caucasian loanword (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:620).

Comment: cf. Avestan frā̊nk-/ Instrumental sg. frača and Old Indic prā́ñc-
lit. 'un-swallow', Ir. SLUCIM 'swallow' (Buck)
etym. dub.?

Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin sentīre 'to sense, feel' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):645-646), further to PIE *sent- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):554, [LIV²](src-141) 533).
Well attested in Pamir languages, origin uncertain.
No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):762, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1031).
Hellenic lexemes continuing PIE *poi̯H-u̯eh₂- 'grass, meadow', cf. Lithuanian píeva 'meadow' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):922, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1214-1215, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 769).
Cf. 'shadow' in [cognate set 8269](cog-8269) for further discussion regarding the root ref. form.

It is often assumed that Proto-Slavic *bľĭvati is derived from *bʰleu̯H- and related to Latin fluō, fluere etc. ([LIV²](src-141) 90, [Derksen 2008](src-81):46). This etymology is adopted here, however cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 2:140-141, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):82, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) with skepticism.

The link to PIE *terkʷ- is formally and semantically attractive. An alternative etymology points to PIE *(s)ter- 'hard(en)', cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598), but it has formal and semantic issues, cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4: 227.
The etymology of this word is obscure.
Loanword from Lahnda laṇdā 'crop-tailed' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):44, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):645 no.11081).
Parallel loans into Modern Indo-Iranic languages from Persian جگر / ǰigar 'liver'

Comment: Etymology disputed.
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):131-132, [Orel 1998](src-105):513, [Holm 2011](src-130):80 for various proposals and further discussion.
Derived from PIE *h₂edʰ⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to press' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):334-335, [LIV²](src-141) 255).
Etymology unclear, perhaps further to PIE *pelh₁- 'to make swing' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):410-411, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 469-470).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *sal- 'salt' ({ref NIL 586-590, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 586-587, [Derksen 2015](src-353):387-388, [Derksen 2008](src-81):459. Cf. 'salt' in [cognate set 283](cog-283) for further discussion of the root reconstruction.
Loanword from Scots, cf. Middle English flour, Old French flour ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):176).

Etymology uncertain, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156):18-19 suggests from Proto-Iranic *laštyaka- in comparison to Lithuanian lazdà 'stick' but without further parallels within Iranic; alternatively possibly an old loanword from Armenian lcʼakʼ 'lever' (Oleg Belyaev p.c.).
Since the source is as late as Middle Low German, then the Faroese and Danish lineages should be considered by then already divergent, and therefore this is a parallel loan.

Comment: Loan from Low German.
Justification: Loan from Low German mân 'moon' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):396).
Loan from Latin pōmum 'fruit tree; fruit' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):326, [Orel 1998](src-105):314, [Holm 2011](src-130):85-86).
The Vedic root √cakṣ- is likely to have been an inner-Indo-Iranic reanalysis of an s-desiderative form of the root *kʷek̑- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:523, [LIV²](src-141) 383-385).

Comment: with prefix ham-

Justification: Cf. Vedic parṣá- 'sheaf, bundle', Young Avestan parša- ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:75), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:101, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:230 for various uncertain proposals).
Loanword from (Eastern) Middle High German stomm, cf. Middle High German stam ([Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1474).

Comment: < DRECK 'dirt'

Justification: Of obscure etymology; cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:66 for various unsatisfying proposals.
Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):404). Cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):386 for older proposals.
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *tres- 'to tremble, be afraid' ([LIV²](src-141) 650-651, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):393-394, [EWAia](src-172) I:678-679).
Loanword from Old French flour, flur, flor ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Comment: etym. dub.
Justification: Denominal from Welsh gwth 'a push, shove, thrust', further root etymology uncertain, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) for various suggestions.
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:188-189 for further discussion.

The Celtic forms in this class are often considered to be connected with Germanic in OHG eben, Goth. ibns, etc. (cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):92), but there are many formal difficulties with this identification (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):222, [Matasović 2009](src-50):113, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):202)

Comment: Parallel loans from Persian (after p > f, but before ē > ī)

Justification: From Latin captīvus 'taken prisoner' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):157), derived from Latin capiō, -ere 'take', further to PIE *keh₂p- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):89-90, [LIV²](src-141) 344-345).

Comment: cf. OCS loza 'vine'
LIV suggests *h₂u̯i̯edʰ-

Justification: Loanword from dialectal southern Italian ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):301-302).
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *neh₂- 'to become afraid' ([LIV²](src-141) 449, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):591-592).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain ([Adams 2013](src-345):628).

Comment: Parallel loans from Skt. yákr̥t [lexeme 22444](lex-22444)
Justification: Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Sanskrit yákr̥t 'liver'.
Parallel loans from Old Turkic arqa.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5574 ?

Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):275, no. 5014; no further etymology.
No certain etymology, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):901-902 for a critical appraisal of previous proposals.
From Vedic śilā́- 'rock, stone' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):721-722, no. 12459), further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:640).
Balto-Slavic lexemes from PIE *(h₂)u̯elk- 'to drag, pull' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):514, [Derksen 2015](src-353):504, [ALEW](src-352) 1244-1245, [LIV²](src-141) 289-290).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):667 and [Adams 2013](src-345):333-334 for previous proposals.

Comment: < MHG BOZEN 'to strike' (Diez 1864: 86)

Justification: No clear Indo-European etymology ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):440), cf. [HED K](src-408) 66-72 for older unconvincing proposals.

Generally considered a loanword from Romance *pluverem < Latin *pulverem 'dust' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):346, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):323-324; but cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):331-332, 335 for an alternative proposal.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):158 for various proposals).
Loan from Latin pulsus 'a pushing, beating, striking' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):595-596)

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10781 s.v. rundra ʻrich inʼ (lex.)
Loan from Latin angustus 'narrow'.
Justification: Loanword from Latin angustus 'narrow' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):307, [Huld 1984](src-571):98, [Orel 1998](src-105):298).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):349-352 for a critical survey of previous proposals.
No certain etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):218-219, [Beekes 2010](src-66):269-270).
Armenian lexemes probably to be derived from PIE *sengʷ- 'to go under, sink' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):90-91, [LIV²](src-141) 531-532).

Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Borrowing from Late Latin *virdis (Lat. viridis), cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):69, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):305-306.
(Parallel?) Loan from Middle Low German.
Lexemes continuing Old Breton strit, a loanword from Latin strictus 'drawn together, close, strait, tight' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):699)
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ekʷ- 'to say' ([LIV²](src-141) 673-674, [EWAia](src-172) II:489-491, [Cheung 2007](src-83):402-404).
Etymology outside of Celtic difficult to establish ([Matasović 2009](src-50):239-240, cf. also [Deshayes 2003](src-309):458).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pei̯H- 'to swell up' ([EWAia](src-172) II:83-84, [LIV²](src-141) 464-465).

From Old Norse reikna, a loanword from Middle Low German rekenen ([de Vries 1977](src-468):438).  Since this is already found in Old Norse, its presence in both Elfdalian and Swedish can be presumed to reflect a parallel shift to this meaning, not a parallel loan.

Tocharian, Albanian, and Balto-Slavic lexemes from PIE *g̑ombʰ-o- 'peg; tooth' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):126-127, [Adams 2013](src-345):208, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):158, [Orel 1998](src-105):82, [ALEW](src-352) 1289, [Derksen 2008](src-81):549, [Derksen 2015](src-353):512).
From Proto-Celtic *slattā; further connections outside of Celtic are difficult (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:127-128, [Matasović 2009](src-50):345).

Generally connected since [Fraenkel 1932](src-734):229-230 to Lithuanian ker̃gti 'tie, bind' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):87-88, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):573-574, [Adams 2013](src-345):171-172) from a PIE root *kergʰ- or *kergʷʰ- (not in [LIV²](src-141)).
Etymology uncertain ([HAB](src-740) III:577). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *ord-].
Etymology outside Hellenic uncertain ({ref Chantraine {1968–1980}:1025-1026, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1364).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain ([Kluge 2011](src-397):142, [de Vries 1977](src-468):70). Traditionally considered an extended from an extended form of a root *bʰer- 'to cut' according to [IEW](src-49) 166 (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):37). Cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):53 for a proposed comparison to Albanian barmë 'bast'.

Modern Greek φεγγάρι from Medieval Greek φεγγαρίον, a diminutive in -αριον, derived from Ancient Greek φέγγος 'light, splendour, lustre' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1528). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1184-1185, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1559-1560).
No known etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):519-520, [Beekes 2010](src-66):679).
Root etymology outside of Slavic disputed: Either to PIE *g̑u̯elH- 'to burn, blaze' or to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' (cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) II:103).

Modern Hellenic lexemes, ultimately from an Ancient Greek diminutive formation πέσκος 'skin, rind'. Further etymology uncertain cf. [Andriotis 1999](src-271):1168, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):890, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1180.

Comment: Non-Persian words with additional -xVnV might all be loans from early Persian rōdxāna (or a later form), although this can be proved only for Mazanderani.
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow, stream' ({ref EWAia II:784-785, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 588).
Probably a loan from Tocharian B ([Adams 2013](src-345):115, [Carling 2009](src-147)).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek λαιμός 'throat, gullet' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):755). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):613-614, [Beekes 2010](src-66):824).

Modern Greek lexemes continuing a derived adjective to Ancient Greek κόκκος 'kernel' used in the production of red dye, further etymology unknown ([Andriotis 1999](src-271):729, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):553, [Beekes 2010](src-66):733}).

A formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, originally in the sense 'chat, prattle', later generalised as the generic verb 'to say' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):615-616, [Beekes 2010](src-66):827-828).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ned⁽ʰ⁾- 'to link, connect' ([Untermann 2000](src-279):493-494, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):119).
No convincing etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:522-523, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):892-893, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1182).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):6, [Beekes 2010](src-66):7), cf. [Pinault 1979](src-717), [Beekes 1996](src-716) for competing hypotheses.
Loan from Italian petto 'chest'.
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:61-62 for various doubtful suggestions.
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):289, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):279).
Related to the common words for '(finger)nail' widely found elsewhere in Indo-European via a derived feminine stem *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):354-355, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164).

Etymology dubious. [Adams 2013](src-345):517 connects to a putative PIE *mel- 'member' comparing Gk. μέλος 'member', Breton mell 'knuckle' < *melso-, Lith. mélmenys 'fat around the kidneys', Skt. márman- 'member, vulnerable part of the body', but the etymologies of these compared lexemes are all for the most part considered to be unknown or dubious (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):927-928, [EWAia](src-172) II:329, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):386).
Loan from Church Slavonic нєбо 'sky' ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:53).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):243, [Olsen 1999](src-180):908). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯at-a-].
Parallel loans in Modern Greek dialects from Turkish toz 'dust'.

Indo-Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *reu̯dH- 'to howl, to weep' ([LIV²](src-141) 508, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:465-466, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):627 no. 10840, [Cheung 2007](src-83):194, [ALEW](src-352) 847-848, [Derksen 2015](src-353):377).
Parallel loans from Persian گرد / gard 'dust'.
As though from Indic *phutta- 'insignificant', cf. Bashkarik phut 'fly' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511 no. 9085). Further etymology uncertain.
Loanword from Italian frutto 'fruit' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1562).
Parallel loans from Church Slavonic ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:102, 105, [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 2:174).
Loanword from Turkish, cf. Turkish avlamak 'to hunt' (cf. also [Dawkins 1916](src-452):665).
Parallel loans from Middle Low German.
Loan from Turkish kanca 'hook' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 2:201).
No generally agreed etymology ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174):64-66, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):609-610, [Beekes 2010](src-66):817-818. For a recent attempt, cf. [Nikolaev 2010](src-721).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn (around)' ([Boryś 2005](src-259):694-695, 710; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 691-692).
No satisfactory etymology outside of Greek; for some proposed inner-Greek connections cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):384-385, [Beekes 2010](src-66):479.

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *vę̄zati 'tie', a derivative of PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'make narrow' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):521, [Boryś 2005](src-259):688; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 264-265, [NIL](src-274) 301-303).

Romance lexemes from Latin iactāre 'to hurl' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):372), an intensive/iterative stem to Latin iaciō 'to throw' and further to PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):292-293, [LIV²](src-141) 225). The Italic derivatives from this root show an anomalous extension in *-k-.

No clear etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):34, [Beekes 2010](src-66):38-39}). It is likely that Ancient Greek αἷμα was a lexical replacement for the inherited word for 'blood', ἔαρ < *h₁esh₂-r̥- (cf. [cognate set 859](cog-859)), which was only retained as a poetic word in the language of Homeric epic and other archaic poetry.
Generally derived from a PIE root *ser- 'to string together, connect' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):727, [LIV²](src-141) 534-535).
Indo-European root etymology uncertain (see note by Irslinger to this class); cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):442-443, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):359, [NIL](src-274) 476n33 for competing proposals.

[EWAia](src-172) II:258-259 supposes two possible (homophonous) root etymologies either to *bʰes- 'to skew, to crunch' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 82 s.v. ?*bʰes- '(zer)kauen') or *bʰes- 'to blow, to breathe', however [NIL](src-274) 34-36 considers these two postulated roots to be one and the same. For developments in Middle and Modern Indic, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):537, no. 9425.
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174): II:333, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):763-764, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1033).

Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic dunóti 'distresses' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):366, no. 6410), further derived from PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to catch fire' ([EWAia](src-172) I:707-708, [LIV²](src-141) 104-105).

Romance lexemes from Latin tornāre 'to turn (in a lathe)' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:46-80, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):729-730). A denominal verb from Latin tornus 'turner's wheel, lathe', in turn an old loanword from Ancient Greek τόρνος 'turning lathe' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):695-696).

It is uncertain whether this lexeme is a loanword from Latin spīna (via Old Polish?) or a cognate of it (cf. [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) II:708, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) III:735). [Not in [Derksen 2008](src-81) and therefore implicitly not considered a part of the Slavic inherited lexicon in that work.]
Parallel loans from Low German brav, further borrowed from French brave, from Italian bravo (cf. [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).
Parallel loans from Polish skóra 'skin' (cf. [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 12:167, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 6:432, 436

Originally referring to counting by making scores on a piece of wood with a knife. A description of this method of counting is attested in one of the oldest Slavic texts ("On the Letters" by Chernorizets Hrabar). The meaning 'cut' is attested in Old/Middle Polish. Cf. Proto-Slavic *briti 'to shave', ultimately derivatives to PIE *bʰrei̯H- 'to cut' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):63, [ESSJa](src-458) III:31-32, [Boryś 2005](src-259):40, [Skok 1971-1974](src-589) 1:209-210, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 92-93).

Comment: Reflexes of this root in Slavic have meanings 'hail', 'black, rain cloud', 'cloud', 'rainbow' etc.

Justification: Etymology outside Italic uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):148-149, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):142 for various speculative proposals). [LIV²](src-141) mechanically reconstructs ?*⁽k̑⁾remH-, but without any certain cognates outside of Italic.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- (Cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):706-709, [Derksen 2008](src-81):415, 524 [LIV²](src-141) 668-669).

Comment: Loan from Turkish
Justification: Loanword from Turkish deniz 'sea' ([Dawkins 1916](src-452):674).
No certain etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:122, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):640, [Beekes 2010](src-66):861).
Loan from Old Spanish chifle 'whistle; container made of horn'.
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):441, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):409).
Loan from Middle German rechen 'to count' (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):507-508).

Hellenic, Armenian, and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂leh₁- 'to grind up' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 277, [Beekes 2010](src-66):65, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):26-27, [Cheung 2007](src-83):166, [Bailey 1979](src-320):22, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):93).
Lexemes from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):411-413).
No convincing etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:57-58, 10:124, [Derksen 2008](src-81):203-204, and further discussion by Lechosław Jocz in the further citations to this class).

Modern Indic lexemes derived to Ved. √chad- 'to cover' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):275, nos. 5020-5021); further etymology uncertain, perhaps to PIE ?*(s)k̑ed- ([IEW](src-49) 919, [LIV²](src-141) 546) if connected with Old English hætera 'garments' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:554-555 for further discussion). The root reference form for this set tentatively follows this etymology.
Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick' No certain further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) I:692, [KEWA](src-399) II:11-12, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):350 no.6128).

Tocharian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE ?*pei̯H- 'to sing'. The cross-branch cognacy in this class tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 465, [Adams 1982](src-436):133, [Adams 2013](src-345):409-410, [Derksen 2008](src-81):398, but cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):723-724 with some reservations over the proposed Tocharian-Slavic connection.
[Samadi 1986](src-724):247 suggests *xšiwya-, [Cheung 2007](src-83):452 connects with Avestan xšī- 'misery' and suggests a root *xšai-.

Comment: PS *ob-volk- with PS *volk < PS *velkti 'pull'. The etymological meaning of the compound is 'something that covers (the sky). The similarity to ?*u̯elg-/*u̯elk- is superficial.

Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat' ([EWAia](src-172) II:169, [LIV²](src-141) 466-467; cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):460 no. 8140, 465 no. 8221).

Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes based on Vedic pipīlá- 'ant', of unknown origin ([EWAia](src-172) II:132-133, [KEWA](src-399) II:284-285). The modern forms exhibit six main variants, for which cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):463, no. 8201.

Comment: The Etymological Dictionary of Belarusian claims that this lexeme is a derivative from Proto-Slavic *kyp- 'seethe' (Proto-Indo-European ku̯eh₁p-). However, it seems unconvincing.

Justification: Etymology outside of Italic uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):628, [Sihler 1995](src-290):40, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):566). For Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):655 no. 7947.
Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit lakuṭa- (~ laguḍa-) 'club', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):629 no. 10875, [KEWA](src-399) III:84-85).

Comment: < *chaṭa- and variants, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 271f., no. 4966
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):272 no. 4966 s.v. *chaṭa- 'stick, cane'. Further etymology uncertain.
From PIE *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- 'sun' ([NIL](src-274) 606-611; for the semantics cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:201-202, [Matasović 2009](src-50):324).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):424 for various proposals. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *an(-)dzreu̯-o-/-a-].
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯ei̯t- 'to shine brightly' ([ESSJa](src-458) 13:162-163, [Derksen 2008](src-81):258-259, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 340).

Comment: possibly related to Vedic (RV, AV) pavástam n. 'covering' (cf. Old Persian pavastā- f. 'skin, parchment'), cf. entries *pōta-, *pōtta- and *pōttha- 'cloth' (with variants) in Turner 1962-66, p. 477f., no. 8400, 8414
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10299, s.v. mr̥ṣṭá-, either from marś- (< Hmelk̑-) or marj- (or blend), cf. LIV, p. 280f. with Anm. 1
Justification: IE root etymology uncertain: either to [LIV²](src-141) 226-227 *Hmelk̑- 'abstreifen, (ab)wischen' (> Ved. √marś- 'touch, stroke, handle') or [LIV²](src-141) 280-281 *h₂merg̑- (> Ved. √marj- 'wipe, rub, cleanse'). A blend might also be possible. (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594-595 no. 10299, [EWAia](src-172) II:325-326, 331-332, 373.

Perhaps from IE *kai̯to- ([IEW](src-49) 521) if inherited and comparable to Germanic terms found in Goth. haiϸi 'field', Engl. heath, etc. These forms are, however, restricted to Celtic and Germanic and we may be dealing with borrowing or (independent) borrowings from a prehistoric NW European substratum language (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):198).

To be derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):62, see which for a discussion of the possible stem formations in Armenian; cf. also [HAB](src-740) I:452, [LIV²](src-141) 80).

Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit rakṣā- f. 'preservation, care; guarding'; 2. 'ashes (used as a preservative)', further derived from Ved. √rakṣ- 'to protect' and derived from PIE *h₂leks- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):611, no. 10551-10552; [EWAia](src-172) II:422, [LIV²](src-141) 258).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic kṣudrá- 'small, minute' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):193, no. 3712), further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:434, 439; [LIV²](src-141) 372).
From Ancient Greek σφάζω ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):493-494), further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1073, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1426-1427).
From Hellenistic Greek κέλλα 'room, chamber', a loanword from Latin cella 'storeroom, chamber' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Comment: In Avestan, gaona- is also attested with the meaning "hair", probably "body hair" or "hairy meat" (probably animal meat with hair on it), cf. the Nerangistan 47.4/9 and the forms gaonauuaṇt- "hairy" and pouru.gaona- "having much hair".
Justification: Cf. Avestan gaona- 'hair' ([Benzing 1983](src-764):299), further etymology uncertain.
Loanword from Pāli aggini- , gini- 'fire', replacing Old Sinhalese aga 'fire' < Ved. agní- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):3 no. 55).

Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):943, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:468). Sometimes considered a loanword from Urartian ṣûə 'inland sea' ([Diakonoff 1985](src-743):600), but the Urartian word could just as well be a loan from Armenian (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):140-141). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsou̯-u-].
Probably inherited from Indo-European in view of the morphology, but there are no known cognates outside of Hittite (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):987).

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally derived from *k̑l(e)i̯-tr- (cf. Gk. κλιτύς,  Lat. clīvus 'slope, rise; hill'; Goth. hleiþra 'booth, tent' (PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean') (rejected by [HAB](src-740) II:270). Alternatively, from *lḗh₂-sr̥ ‎(cf. Alb. lerë '(heap of) stone(s)', Gk. λᾶας, OIr. líe 'stone' ([Hamp 1967](src-744):16-17, accepted by [Olsen 1999](src-180):122). Both etymologies rejected by [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):306. [MM: Proto-Armenian *liar-in-].

From Ancient Greek κοβαλεύω 'to carry as a porter', a derived verb from the nominal κόβαλος ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):717); further origins obscure (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):550, [Beekes 2010](src-66):727-728}).
For root ref. form *leh₃u̯-, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) and [Melchert 2011](src-690):127-132.
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):81-82, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):224, [Orel 1998](src-105):193-194 for various proposals and further discussion.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10948 s.v. lábhate (~ rábhate), analogically influenced by MIA deti and neti 'takes', thus e instead of a
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes derived from Old Indic √labh- 'to grasp, seize', ultimately from PIE *lembʰ- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):635 no. 10948, [EWAia](src-172) II:434-435, [LIV²](src-141) 411-412).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:297-298, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):560, no. 9758).
Origin uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):944, cf. also [HAB](src-740) IIi:262, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):511). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *mar-].

This word is well attested in Iranian languages. Cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):267 on Khotanese bata- "small" deriving it from a root *vā "be deficient", cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):204 *h₁u̯eh₂- "to be empty, absent, lacking".

Armenian and Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₁erkʷ- 'to shine, to sing' ([LIV²](src-141) 240-241, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):259, [EWAia](src-172) I:114-115, [Bailey 1979](src-320):25).

The Celtic and Italic lexemes in this class are generally agreed to be cognate, although some aspects of the formal reconstruction of a common root are uncertain ([LIV²](src-141) 195, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):277-278, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):318-324, [Matasović 2009](src-50):148-149).

Comment: < Vedic vā́ra- ~ vā́la- m. 'tail hair', 'hair of animal, wool', cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 545, Turner 1962-66, no. 11549, 11572
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic vā́ra- (~ Sanskrit vā́la-) 'hair of tail, tail, hair' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):673-674 no. 11549). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:545 for further discussion.

From Ancient Greek κρούω 'to strike, stamp, knock' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):337, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):736), possibly further connected to TochAB kärn- if the lexemes in [cognate set 2701](cog-2701) reflect an unextended form of the same Indo-European root (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):785-786, [LIV²](src-141) 371).
There is no certain etymology ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:396). The relationship to Proto-Slavic *prǫtŭ and Russian prygat' is dubious.
Loan from Polish rachować 'to count', itself ultimately a borrowing from Middle German rechen 'to count' (cf. [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 5:33)

Comment: Uncertain origin. Formerly connected with Goth. dags 'day', Skt. dáhati 'burns', LIth. dagà 'heat of the Sun', etc; the latter, however, go back to PIE *dʰegʷʰ-, which is incompatible with the Armenian development.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian takʿ 'warm, hot'. Of uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:391). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), [Olsen 1999](src-180). [MM: Proto-Armenian *takʰ-i-].

Originally a root-noun in the sense *'visible, outer form' > '(outer) body; skin' (cf. Hittite tu̯ekka- 'body, person') from PIE *tu̯ek- 'be visible' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:684, [LIV²](src-141) 654).

Romance lexemes from Latin metus 'fear, alarm' ([DCECH](src-423) IV:66-67), no further etymology outside of Italic (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):402, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):378 for various uncertain proposals).
Loanword from French jambe 'leg' ([Varella 2006](src-455):252).

Traditionally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'push' ([IEW](src-49) 1032-1034, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):564-565), but more recently [Kroonen 2013](src-165):487 argues that the Germanic internal evidence cannot support this etymology.
Etymology uncertain, cf. [DCECH](src-423) VI:849-851 for various proposals.
Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain, perhaps to the root *meh₁- 'to measure', but  ultimately unclear. Cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):571-572, [HED M](src-410) 116-119 for further discussion.
Loan from Low German grö̂ne 'green' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):187).
Based on a loanword from Italian largo. Greek: Italiot λάργκα treated as a separate loan event in in [cognate set 5868](cog-5868).

Cf. Vedic raśmi- 'rein, ray of light', Sinhalese rasmiya 'rays', rasnaya 'heat' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):616 no. 10648). The root of Vedic raśmi- is not attested verbally, but cognates in Iranic allow for the reconstruction of a basic root *rać-, probably 'to bind' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:440-441).

Comment: Connected with SMG δουλεύω 'I work' in the sense 'worked, finished' > 'smooth'??? (-MJCS)

Justification: Root etymology in this set follows [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):366-368, [Oettinger 1979](src-649):480-481 to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' ([LIV²](src-141) 287), however cf. [HED H](src-407) 423, [LIV²](src-141) 287-288 preferring to set up *h₂u̯ei̯- to a perfect stem ?*h₂e-h₂u̯ói-/u̯i- considering the semantics 'blow' > 'run' semantically problematic.

Of uncertain origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):941), perhaps a Semitic loanword according to [HAB](src-740) II:517-518 (cf. Akkadian kūšu 'skin', Arab. qašʿa 'dry skin' [< Sumerian kuš 'skin']). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kaʃ-ii̯a-].
Loanword from Italian anca 'hip'.

Cf. SMG άχαρος ᾽without grace, elegance, beauty' from Ancient Greek ἄχαρις, remodelled as an o-stem άχαρος ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):246), further to PIE *g̑ʰer(H)- 'desire, enjoy' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1606-1607, [LIV²](src-141) 176-177).
Loanword from Low German runt 'round' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):655).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:249-250, cf. also [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 4:123-124)

Greek: Pontic ροΐζω 'fall' from Ancient Greek ῥοΐζω 'to drench (of horses)', a derivative of PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow, stream' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):482, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1281-1282, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):970-971, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 588).

Tsakonian σποΐα, π̔οΐα from Ancient Greek σποδία 'ash' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):507). Further etymology outside of Greek obscure ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174):771, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1040, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1386).

Cf. SMG αδρός 'sizable, stout' from Ancient Greek ἀδρός 'thick, stout, bulky', further a derivative of PIE *seh₂- 'to satiate' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):69, [Beekes 2010](src-66):22, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):20, 121-122).

Cf. Standard Modern Greek τρανός 'very big in power or importance', from Hellenistic Greek τρανός, morphologically remodelled from early Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear distinct' < PIE *tr̥h₂-n-, cf. PIE *terh₂- 'to pass through, cross' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1444, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1498-1499, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1128).
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *dʰer- 'to fix, make firm' ([LIV²](src-141) 145-146, [ALEW](src-352) 177-180, 193-194, [Derksen 2015](src-353):116, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):93-94).
Parallel loans from Persian مکان 'place, location', ultimately from Arabic مکان 'id.'.

Cf. Lithuanian gul̃ti 'to lie down', which with the Latvian and Latgalian lexemes in this set may go back to an East Baltic root *gul-, but a further IE root etymology remains uncertain (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 377-379, [Derksen 2015](src-353):193-194, 196).

Generally considered to be a (at least a semantic) loanword from Middle Low German ([de Vries 1977](src-468):289; no North Germanic cognates connected by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):271-272 s.v. Proto-Germanic *jakk/gōn-).
If this is only a semantic realignment by contact influence, then technically it is not to be considered a loanword in CoBL, but a semantic realignment of a still cognate word.  
But since this is analysed as a loanword from Middle Low German, by that period fragmentation of North Germanic varieties had already begun, so this is to be taken as a parallel loan.

Generally connected to Gk. κιχάνω < *gʰeh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 196, [Kroonen 2013](src-165)174-175). Whether these forms are to be further connected on one hand to Arm. gam 'come' (so [LIV²](src-141)) or to Indo-Iranian lexemes (so {Kroonen 2013}) would decide whether to reconstruct initial *g̑ʰ or *gʰ.
From Ancient Greek ἐκκλύζω 'wash out, wash away' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):227), further to PIE *k̑leu̯H- 'purify' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):718-719, [LIV²](src-141) 335).

Comment: not found in Cheung (2007)

Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek βέργα, a loan from Latin virga 'twig, bough, branch' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):263).

From Ancient Greek ῥύγχνος 'snout, beak' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):482). This is further connected to Armenian ṙngunkʻ 'nostrils, nose' by [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) and [Beekes 2010](src-66), but the lexeme may well also be expressive in origin (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):978-979).

No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):390; cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:191-193, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):441-443, [Boryś 2005](src-259):408-409, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 3:5 for various proposals and further discussion).
Loanword from Tocharian B eprer ([Carling 2009](src-147):74-75, [Adams 2013](src-345):70).
For the etymology, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):545-546; for the root ref. form cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Indic lexemes from Vedic uṣṇá- 'hot', derived to Vedic √oṣ- 'to burn' and further connected with PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'id.' ([EWAia](src-172) I:281, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):112, no. 2389; [LIV²](src-141) 245).

Romance lexemes from Latin casa 'small house, hut, cabin' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):165-166). Further origins uncertain, possibly a loanword from one of the non-Indo-European languages of Ancient Italy ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):103, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):96).

A verbal adjective derived from Hellenistic Greek βράζω 'boil, froth up' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):277). No further etymology, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):193, [Beekes 2010](src-66):235-236 for various uncertain proposals.

According to [Cheung 2007](src-83):32-33, from Proto-Iranic *čap- 'to seize, attach, stick, strike'. Further etymology uncertain, [Cheung 2007](src-83):33 further speculates a possible connection to PIE *keh₂p- 'to seize, grasp' as semantically attractive; cf. also [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:306-307).
Loanword from Italian l'occhio 'the eye' with the Italian definite article analysed as part of the nominal stem.
Slavic lexemes generally considered to continue a derivative from a PIE root *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'disgusting, gross' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):160-161, [ALEW](src-352) 303-304, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 6:81-82).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 273, no. 4994 s.v. *chapp- ~ *chipp-; further etymology unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from an Indic stem *chapp- ~ *chipp- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):273 no. 4994), further etymology obscure.
Loanword from Middle English battle, cf. Scottish Gaelic baideal 'battle, battlement' ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):37, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):26).
Loanword from Venetian rozza 'stone' ([Varella 2006](src-455):251).
Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):304, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:467 for older hypotheses).
From Ancient Greek ῥεῦμα 'that which flows' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):438, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1210), further to PIE *sreu̯- 'to flow' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1281-1282, [LIV²](src-141) 588).
Loan from Latin fortis 'strong' or Italian forte 'id.' (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):110, [Orel 1998](src-105):101).
Loanword from Turkish kelle 'head' ([Varella 2006](src-455):268).
From Ancient Greek κωφίας 'a kind of snake' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):344). No clear cognates outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):528, 607; [Beekes 2010](src-66):816).
Loan from Latin coxa 'hip' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):193, [Orel 1998](src-105):188).

Baltic lexemes as though from PIE ?*seu̯k- ([LIV²](src-141) 540, [ALEW](src-352) 988-989), although there are no certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic so an IE provenance is not assured. [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Comment: cf. Vedic (Br) grathnā́ti, Sanskrit granthayati (MhB), grathati (Dhātup.), Pali gantheti; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 233, no. 4353, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 504f.

Justification: Albanian forms derived to an original loan from Latin līmāre 'to file, polish, finish' ([Orel 1998](src-105):222).

No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic according to [ALEW](src-352) 1218-1219. [Derksen 2015](src-353):497 connects the Balto-Slavic forms with Germanic *warha- following [Kroonen 2013](src-165):574, but this proposal has not yet been widely accepted.
Etymology uncertain, perhaps with PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'throw' according to [LIV²](src-141) 225, but rejected by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):381-382 on formal and semantic grounds.
No certain etymology, probably of expressive or imitative origin (cf. [DCECH](src-423) IV:498-502).
Borrowing from East Romance, cf. Romanian luptă 'fight' < Latin lucta 'wrestling' ([Orel 1998](src-105):233)
Assumed to be Persian loans.

No clear etymology outside of Baltic. A connection with PIE *klep- '(secretly) steal', hide' is often considered, but is only possible if one considers a secondary s-mobile and if the initial cluster *skl- can be simplified to *sl- ([LIV²](src-141) 363-364, [ALEW](src-352) 940-941).
Loanword from Latin hospitium 'lodging, inn' (with metathesis of p and t in the borrowed form), cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):415-416, [Huld 1984](src-571):115, [Orel 1998](src-105):438.

Italiot Greek lexemes continuing a diminutive formation *σκουλλίον 'little neck' to Ancient Greek σκόλλυς 'fringe of hair' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):466-467). Further etymology disputed (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1020-1021, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1356).

Tsakonian νίου 'hear' from Ancient Greek νοέω 'perceive, observe, apprehend' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):395), which is turn a denominal verb from Ancient Greek νόος 'mind, sense, intellect'. Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):756-757, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1023).
Derived from Ancient Greek ἁπαλύνω (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further a denominal verb to Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak' of uncertain etymology ([Beekes 2010](src-66):113).

Stem alternation between, e.g., nominative singular θρίξ, genitive singular τριχός due to Graßmann's Law point to a Proto-Greek stem *tʰrikʰ-, but further connections outside of Greek are unclear ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) I:684, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):441-442, [Beekes 2010](src-66):556).

Identical to the general word for 'foot' and 'leg' in many other Slavic languages (cf. 'foot' in [cognate set 1252](cog-1252), 'leg' in [cognate set 1231](cog-1231)), and ultimately derived to the same root as the widespread root *h₃negʷʰ- also found in '(finger)nail' and 'claw' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):354-355, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164).

Generally derived from Proto-Celtic *tuk-slo- ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):734, but cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):393-394 preferring *tullo-), ultimately derived from PIE *teu̯k- 'beat, hit' ([LIV²](src-141) 640).

Comment: Loan from English.
Justification: Loanword from English 'carry' (first attested 1500s) ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Comment: The Avestan verb vaxš- means "to sprinkle" (not found in Cheung 2007). MacKenzie (1970: 553) "The Khwarezmian Glossary I" (BSOAS 33): derives the noun from *waxšu-.

Justification: Etymology uncertain ([Matasović 2009](src-50):363-364), for various proposals cf. [IEW](src-49) 1050, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:90).
Loan from North Italian
No certain etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 308).
Loanword from Middle Low German schrī(e)n.
No certain etymology ([Schrijver 1995](src-305):223). [Deshayes 2003](src-309):281 considers a loanword from English wail.

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *3. men- 'to rise, stick up' ([EWAia](src-172) II:313, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):566 no. 9858, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:72, [Matasović 2009](src-50):276, cf. [IEW](src-49) 726, 747-748, [LIV²](src-141) 437).
Loanword from Slavic *glъtъ 'sip, gulp' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).
Loanword from North Italian

Comment: cf cognate/6399

Justification: A loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian njušiti 'to smell' (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):311, [Orel 1998](src-105):301-302).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:68-69, [IEW](src-49) 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ([Matasović 2009](src-50):205, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, [EWAia](src-172) II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).
From Old English cest 'box, coffer', perhaps a loanword from Latin cista 'box, chest', but not fully clear (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Comment: scrape off, cut off > reject, refuse > throw out > throw

Justification: The etymology is not entirely clear but the word is probably related to Proto-Slavic onomatopoeic *pukati 'bang, knock, beat' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):489-490).

From PIE *g̑erh₂- 'wear down, make old' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):271, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):312; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 165-166); for the Romance lexemes in this class from Latin granum 'grain, seed', cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):327-328.
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):95, [LIV²](src-141) 157-158, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):102 for further discussion).
Loan from Slavic zapadati 'to fall' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Romance lexemes from Latin prehendere 'grasp, seize' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):558-559, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 9:339-354), further derived from PIE *gʰed- 'grasp' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):487, [LIV²](src-141) 194).
Continuing a derivative of PIE *kemb- 'small' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):439).
No convincing etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:39).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):564-565, [de Vries 1977](src-468):684).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):163-164, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):75, 150 for proposed further connections.
Loanword from Italian or Latin combatt(u)ere 'to fight'.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin sapere 'to have a good taste, taste of' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):628 no. 7586, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 11:193-201, further to PIE *seh₁p- 'to perceive (by taste)' ([LIV²](src-141) 519, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):538-539).
Etymology uncertain, an old proposal of [Thurneysen 1917](src-659):312 connects with Old Irish fairsing 'broad, spacious'.
Parallel loans from Persian برگ / barg 'leaf'.
Romance nominal derivatives based on a loanword from Old High German grīfan 'to grasp, grab' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):330, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 16:73-80).

Lexemes continuing a derivative with PIE *-mo- to Proto-Germanic *malan- 'to grind', further from PIE *melh₂- 'to crush, grind' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):242-243, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):351, [LIV²](src-141) 432-433).

Continuing Old Irish úr 'soil, earth' ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):387), further etymology unknown (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:26 an evaluation of various uncertain proposals).
From Old English brid, further etymology unknown ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Loans from Low German (cf. [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97)).  Given that Danish is the main lexical source of Riksmal, and the latter derives from it within the last few centuries, the loan event here should arguably have been into Danish before the derivation of Riksmal, and therefore not 'parallel'.
Romanian lexemes from Lat. frondea ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further etymology uncertain (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):244 for further discussion).

Romanian pădure, as though from *padule(m) < Latin palūde(m) 'fen swamp' (nom.sg. palūs) with metathesis ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):507, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further generally compared to Skt. palvala- 'pond, pool' and Lith. pélkė 'bog, marsh' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):442, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:105, but [ALEW](src-352) 753 against the connection of the Baltic lexemes).
Loanword from Turkish sert 'hard, stiff', cf. SMG σέρτικος 'heavy, strong (of blends of tobacco and cigarettes)' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1260).

Romance lexemes from Latin fracidus 'very soft' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):297-298), a derivative of Latin fracēs 'grounds, dregs (from olive pressing)'. Further etymology obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):251, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):238 for various proposals).

Comment: Dhātup., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3747

Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin uadere 'to advance, proceed' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):760), further to PIE *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'to stride' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 664, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):650).

Derived from a PIE base *k̑uH-, if to be connected with Skt. śū́la- 'spear' with the shortened vowel length in Celtic and Italic due to Dybo's Law (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):150, [Matasović 2009](src-50):229).

Comment: via verbal meaning "to fit", however Bailey's link to the PIE root is not very convincing

Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):317-318, [DCECH](src-423) III:353-354), further to PIE *⁽g̑⁾el- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):256).
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *tekti, in turn derived from PIE *tekʷ- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):489, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:159, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

From Latin pavimentum 'pavement' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), derived from Latin paviō 'to thump, pound, strike' and further to PIE *pi̯eh₂- 'beat' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):451-452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 481-482).
Generally assumed to be a loanword from Continental Celtic, cf. Gaulish *banno- 'horn'.
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic ([ALEW](src-352) 512-513, cf. also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):303-304).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *menH- 'to step, stamp on' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):276, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 438).
Probably a loanword from Andalusian Arabic ġárfa 'handful' ([DCECH](src-423) III:102)
Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):178 no. 3441, to Vedic kr̥śá- 'lean, thin', further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾erk̑- 'to emaciate' ([EWAia](src-172) I:318-319, 395-396, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 355).
Loan from Bulgarian nasip 'bank, embankment' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Possibly to be connected with Greek κακός (cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):175, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):239, [Beekes 2010](src-66):619-620), but it is difficult to be fully certain of the etymology (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):216-217); cf. discussion in [cognate set 7332](cog-7332).

The further IE cognacy and the PIE root are not entirely clear (cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 3:323, [Boryś 2005](src-259):579, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):604-605, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1362-1363. The Kashubian and Sorbian phrases are calques of German 'Angst haben'.
Loan from Church Slavonic used in place of the inherited Russian lexeme солодкий ([Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) II:657, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) III:666).
Loanword from German schwach 'weak' [Not in [Karulis 1992](src-534)].

From Ancient Greek τρανόω 'make clear, plain, distinct', a secondary verbal derivative via Ancient Greek τρανής 'clear, distinct', ultimately from PIE *terh₂- 'to pass, cross' ([Dawkins 1916](src-452):652, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1498-1499, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 633-634).
No satisfactory etymology. Some attempts have been made to relate to PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink', cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):267 for further discussion.
Goidelic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'to rise, to stride' ([LIV²](src-141) 593-594, cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):637-640, [Matasović 2009](src-50):376).
Loan from Scots English debate (?), cf. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):299, 354.

Comment: uncertain etymology

Justification: Loan from Arabic بحر / baḥr 'sea' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:110).
Loan from Persian ستاره / setāreh 'star'.

There is no certain etymology. The widespread hypothesis ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:46,  [Rejzek 2001](src-593):629, [Boryś 2005](src-259):602) assumes an irregular phonetic change, cf. also [LIV²](src-141) 546. [Not in [Derksen 2008](src-81)].

The cognacy of the Greek and Germanic forms is generally agreed, but the derivation of the forms from a common IE proto-form is disputed. An explanation from a compound stem *h₂k-h₂ou̯s-i̯e- 'is sharp-eared' is commonly considered (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):71), but this analysis remains uncertain (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):55). For references to older literature, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):50-51; [Lehmann 1986](src-179):180-181.

Comment: cf. Vedic (ŚB) abhyàkta- 'anointed', nasalization due to blend with abhyaṅga- 'anointed' (Mn.) (both from √añj-), palatal due to *bhiyajyate 'is smeared, get wet'; cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 542; parallel derivations

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):231, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):339; cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):371-372 for discussion of variant forms within Germanic).

Often considered cognate with Lat. crūdus 'raw, bloody, rough' although aspects of the nominal stem formation remain unclear, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:250-251, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):146; against a connection with Lat. crūdus, cf. [NIL](src-274) 448n30, with references.
Loanword from Greek φρίκη 'horror' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).
Loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian, Slovenian umoriti 'to murder, kill' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).
From Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip, hip-joint'. No further etymology (cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):285, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):472, [Beekes 2010](src-66):602-603).

Comment: with parallel sound substitutions: kʰ for x
Justification: Parallel loanwords from Persian خون / xūn 'blood'.
Loanword from Slavic prachŭ 'dust' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Loan from Latin galbinus 'greenish-yellow' ([Orel 1998](src-105):131, [Holm 2011](src-130):64, cf. 'yellow' in [cognate set 1409](cog-1409)).
Derived from PIE *(s)teg- 'cover' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:39-40, [Matasović 2009](src-50):376; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 589).
No certain etymology ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:76).

Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √dru- 'to run, hurry', ultimately to PIE *dreu̯- 'to run' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):378-379 no. 6624, 6634, [EWAia](src-172) I:755-756, [LIV²](src-141) 129).
A loan from South Slavic mirosati, cf. Serbo-Croatian mirisati 'to smell' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Comment: cf. Sanskrit nāśaka- (MBh) 'destroying, wasting'

Justification: Derived from Hungarian gând 'thinking, thoughts', a loanword from Hungarian gond ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 331, no. 5812 and p. 789, no. 13693; Sinhalese e in teta from temanavā < *temayati

Justification: From earlier Greek ῥαπίς, with contamination from Lat. ramus ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):435, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):477). Further etymology within Greek uncertain ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1275).

Comment: original meaning "to shine, to bloom"
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *spaič- 'to shine; to bloom'; further etymology outside of Iranic uncertain (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):437, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):350).
A loanword into Tsakonian from Medieval Greek (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
From Ancient Greek τραύσανον 'firewood' (Hesych.) (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further etymology disputed (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1129, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1500).
Cf. Lithuanian žíedas 'blossom, flower'. No certain etymology outside of Baltic ([ALEW](src-352) 1304-1305).

Cf. Avestan gaēsa- 'hair'. According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):84 the Avestan and Khotanese forms may be related via a more basic root *gai̯- to a group of Iranic words also found in Proto-Iranic *gaip/b- 'to spin (thread)', but the proposed derivational morphology in such a connection is entirely unclear (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):96-97).

Comment: cf. S, Cr. čȉt 'whole'
Justification: Extra-Baltic connections unclear. The traditional connection to the family of Serbo-Croat čȉt 'whole', etc. is improbable ([ALEW](src-352) 490, cf. also [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):252, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):285). [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353)].
Loan from Latin baptisma.

A denominal adjective from Ancient Greek ῥόδος 'rose', in turn a loanword from the East, probably from Old Iranian *u̯r̥da- 'rose' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):976-977, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1289-1290).

Comment: Proto-Indo-European *mo[u]-lo-
Verbal meaning in Avestan "to press together", PP ϑraxta-, this is taken by Benzing (1983: 100) as the input of Khwarazmian ˀšxt "near", which is formally possible.
perhaps from Vedic (ud- +) drāpáyati (ŚB), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 379, no. 6634

Justification: Root ref. form in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 353-355, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):401-403, but cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:72, [Matasović 2009](src-50):202-203 for older proposals.

Hellenic lexemes from a PIE stem *gʰebʰh₂l-. A reconstruction with a laryngeal *-h₂- is required because of the connection with Tocharian AB śpāl 'head'; also connected with OHG gebal 'skull' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):522, [Beekes 2010](src-66):682-683, [Adams 2013](src-345):703).

Romance lexemes from Latin colubra 'snake' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):195), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):133-134, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):126 for various proposals).
Of unknown origin (cf. [DCECH](src-423) I:227-229 for discussion of various hypotheses).
Loanword from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian loviti 'hunt', etc. ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), cf. 'hunt' in [cognate set 1145](cog-1145)).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):601, [Beekes 2010](src-66):805-806 for various proposals.
No certain etymology outside of Indic ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):729 no. 12579, [EWAia](src-172) II:652-653).
Loanword from Finnic (cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534):561).
Ossetic lexemes, probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:336).
Loanword from Old French flour, flur, flor 'flower' (via Middle English flour, flur 'flower'?).

Derived from the verb γyr- 'to turn' and further to Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind', without clear correspondences outside of Iranic ([Samadi 1986](src-724):84, [Cheung 2007](src-83):104). Probably further related to Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn' in [cognate set 8398](cog-8398).
Mycenaean pa-si (= Attic φησί), derived from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to speak, say' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1566-1567, [LIV²](src-141) 69-70, cf. [Aura Jorro 1993](src-303):88).
According to [Deshayes 2003](src-309):97, a loanword from regional Latin *batto-, in turn borrowed from Gaulish batta (cf. Fr. batte).

Comment: pǝrǝtu- means "passage" in Avestan, etymology follows Humbach (CLI, 1989: 195), derived from the verbal root PIE *per- "to transfer, come, bring across" (Cheung 2007: 294)

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit jválati 'burns brightly' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):292,  no. 5306). Indo-European root assignment in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 170-171, but cf. the reservations of [EWAia](src-172) I:607.
Of uncertain origin, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):747 no. 8975, [DCECH](src-423) 5:539-543 for further discussion.
Identical with Albanian madh 'big' < PIE *meg̑- in [cognate set 360](cog-360).

Romance lexemes derived from Latin fascis 'bundle of rods; (symbol of) power' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):279), further to be connected with Celtic lexemes, cf. Old Irish basc 'necklace', Welsh beich 'burden', Breton bec'h 'load' < PCl. *baskio-, as a unique Italo-Celtic isogloss from *bʰaski-, probably a non-Indo-European loanword in origin (cf. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):102-103, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):203).
Probably to a Romance root *bot- of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) I:420-423).
A probable nursery word, but cf. [Tischler 1991](src-457):393-394 for various alternative proposals.
Etymology uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):757-758).

Comment: Wider connections uncertain

Justification: Loanword from Arabic صاف / ṣāf
Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:336, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:76-77.
A loan from Germanic *handjan- (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 16:139).
According to [EWNl](src-757), an early loanword from Latin plūma 'feather'.

Apparently continuing a verbal root √mac- attested in various meanings by Sanskrit lexicographical works which may have further IE connections but ultimately uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):555 no. 9710, [KEWA](src-399) II:548).
Probably a Caucasian loanword, although the exact source language is difficult to ascertain (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:320).

Comment: Suggested by Cheung (2007: 244) *ham-kr̩nta- "to twist, braid together". Samadi (1986: 128) suggested a "Gegenbildung" to *wi-kana- "to destroy" (i.e. *ham-kana- "to repaire" ?) of the root *kan- "to dig".

Justification: Borrowing from Old Low Franconian sûr 'sour' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:288-289, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):698).
Root etymology in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 79-80, cf. also [Seebold 1970](src-556):106-107, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):60 for further discussion.

Romance lexemes from Latin recentāre 'refresh; wash with water; clean' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):589-590), a derivative of Latin recēns 'of recent origin, new, fresh', further to PIE *ken- 'fresh, recent' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):516, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 351).
No certain etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 242).

Denominal formation based on Classical Armenian apowr 'salvation, deliverance; life'. Further etymology uncertain ([Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):70, cf. [HAB](src-740) I:239-240). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79) or [Olsen 1999](src-180). [MM: Proto-Armenian *apur-].
Ossetic lexemes of disputed further etymology, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:552, [Cheung 2007](src-83):158, [LIV²](src-141) 223 for proposals and further discussion.
Loanword from Germanic *sunni-, cf. Old French songne 'worry, concern' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:272-282, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):667 no. 8089a).
Etymology outside of Germanic difficult (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):135, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):115).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰā́rā- 'cutting edge' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):389 no. 6793, [Strand 1998](src-431), [EWAia](src-172) I:789).

A Germanic-Celtic isogloss with further connections uncertain (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1057, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:76, [Matasović 2009](src-50):377, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):617-618, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):537).
Loanword from Germanic *harpa 'curved instrument' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):341, [DCECH](src-423) I:344-345 for further discussion).
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *čai̯H- 'to sew', without certain etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):29).
Etymology uncertain, perhaps from Iranic *āyavana-, cf. Avestan ayaona- 'dwelling' with the meaning 'shadow' arising via *'shelter' (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:87).

Comment: Loan from Russian
cf. Old Indic namrá- "untertan, ergeben, demütig, unterwürfig", lit. "biegsam". This cognate set may rather mean 'soft'.

Justification: It is unclear whether the *-s- reconstructed is part of the root or s-stem morphology that has been transferred into thematic classes. Cf. [EWA 3](src-441):142-145, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):134 for further discussion.

Comment: Parallel loans from Persian or Iranic
cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 476

Justification: Forms from Proto-Germanic *ūtian-, secondarily derived to Proto-Germanic *ūd- 'out' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):680), further to PIE *úd- 'upwards, up; out' (cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) 824).
Continuing Indic *giḍḍ- 'to fall' with metathesis > *ḍigg- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):222 no. 4157). Further etymology uncertain.
Derived from Ossetic ad | adæ 'taste', possibly further to PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' but this proposal is quite speculative (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:28).

Lexemes continuing Old Norse springa from Proto-Germanic *spring/kan- 'to break out, leap', ultimately from PIE *(s)préngʰ-e- ([LIV²](src-141) 583, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):470, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):457-458).
West Caucasian loanword, cf. Kabardian tẖapä, Adyghe tẖap 'leaf' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:351).
Parallel loans from Persian بلند / buland 'long'.
Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):104-105, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):136 for various proposals.
Loan from English serpent 'snake, serpent'.
Lexemes as though from Indic *muṭṭa- 'defective' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):587 no.10187.1).
Loan from Middle English smọ̄th(e) 'smooth'.
Etymology uncertain. First connected by [Bailey 1979](src-320):383 to Vedic aváni- 'stream', but this proposal has been judged to be unclear by [EWAia](src-172) I:131.
Denominal verbs from Latin sāpō 'soap' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):628). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loanword from either Celtic or Germanic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):596).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):793, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):443 for various proposals).
Loan from Latin lūdere 'to play' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):242-243, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):231-232).
A loanword from Hurrian ([Starke 1990](src-373):220, [Melchert 1993a](src-377):285, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):936).

Comment: possibly base of *kʷels-, but not well attested outside Iranian

Justification: Of uncertain origin, possibly a Dravidian loanword? Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442)161, no. 3153.

Perhaps an extension to an original onomatopoeic base *mu- and connected to the more widely attested PIE *mus- in [cognate set 5031](cog-5031), but this proposed connection remains speculative. Cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):278, [Kluge 2011](src-397):637, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):379-380.
Lexemes based on an Iranic root čak- ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156):I:387-388, cf. [Benzing 1983](src-764):213).
Tocharian lexemes generally derived from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew' ([LIV²](src-141) 168, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):922-924, [Adams 2013](src-345):691-692).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:159-161 for various proposals.
Etymology uncertain (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.; cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:280 for an earlier, unconvincing proposal).
To be connected with Hittite Hitt. šani- 'the same, one and the same', but further etymology outside of Anatolian unclear (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):722-723).
According to [EWNl](src-757), to be connected with PIE *(s)teup-/*(s)teub- 'to hit, beat' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 602-603 s.v. *(s)teu̯p-, without Germanic lexical material listed).
No certain etymology outside of Anatolian.
Of uncertain origin (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Origin uncertain, perhaps a loanword from South Caucasian (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:631).
Loan from Arabic جلد 'leather, skin'
As though from Sanskrit *ghum(m)ati, further root etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):243 no. 4485).
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):662-664, [Adams 2013](src-345):317 for various proposals.
Possibly to be derived from PIE *dens- 'to become informed; skilled' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):853-855, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 118-119).

Likely to be connected to Old Lithuanian žieždrà 'Sand', but there are difficulties in reconciling the forms to a single Proto-Baltic reconstruction; no certain connections outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1307-1308 for further discussion).

Comment: Further etymology uncertain. It is probably an expressive variant of PS *svig- (cf. Polish śmigać and dialectal świgać) which can be linked to PIE *su̯ei̯- 'bend, spin, wave'.

Justification: Derived from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'take, obtain' ([LIV²](src-141) 250-251, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):538-539, [Adams 2013](src-345):81-82).
Generally considered a nursery word (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:614).
Probably a loan from Turkic qabar, qapar- 'bulging, swelling' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:278).
Loanword from East Caucasian (cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:408-409).
Cf. Lith. võras 'old', further etymology uncertain ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):767, cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1274).

Iranian root *sau̯H- 'to rub, wear, whet', either a u-stem derivative of Proto-Iranian *saH- (from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)-, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:627), or a contamination of two semantically similar roots *dauH- and *skauH- (so [Cheung 2007](src-83):340-341); cf. also [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:278, [MacKenzie 1990](src-680):120.
Generally assumed to be a nursery word (cf. [Tischler 1991](src-457):345-346).

As though continuing ā-lagna- 'fastened to', a derivative of Proto-Indo-Iranic *√lag- 'to stick, attach', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):61 no. 1356.2, [Strand 1998](src-431), [EWAia](src-172) II:473).
Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):147-148, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):619-620, [Adams 2013](src-345):238-239 for various proposals.
Parallel loans from Persian.
Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *ten- 'to stretch, span' ([ALEW](src-352) 1111, [Derksen 2015](src-353):467-468, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 626-627).
From Latin longa (G. Cadorini, p.c.); for further cognates and the etymology cf. 'long' in [cognate set 257](cog-257).

Comment: Etymology uncertain, perhaps from PIE *k̑elH- 'cold'.
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Lithuanian (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1022).
Generally assumed to be a loan from (early) Middle Iranian, cf. [Tremblay 2005](src-732):426, [Adams 2013](src-345):657-658 for recent discussions and references to further literature.

Comment: orig. 'right, true'
Justification: Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1106-1108, [Derksen 2015](src-353):465 for further discussion and various proposals.
Etymology uncertain.
No known etymology ([Adams 2013](src-345):675).
Loan from Russian лытка 'leg, calf, shin, thigh, heel'.

Originally a denominal verb to Ancient Greek κτύπος 'loud noise, crashing sound', probably of onomatopoeic or expressive origin ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):592-593, [Beekes 2010](src-66):792, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):740).

From Proto-Germanic *knūϸan- ~ *knuttan- 'knot' and probably continuing a derivation of PIE *g̑enu- 'knee, nodule' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):322-323, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):298-299; cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):508).

Comment: Cognate with [cognate set 8503](cog-8503)???

Justification: Derived from PIE *u̯elh₂- 'hit, strike' ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):872-873}, [Adams 2013](src-345):639; for the root reconstruction, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Etymology unclear ([Adams 2013](src-345):483-484); [Malzahn & Peters 2010](src-648) suggest a relationship with Greek μάχομαι 'fight' < *megʰh₂-, but the meanings are divergent and the etymology of μάχομαι remains disputed (cf. 'fight' [cognate set 4897](cog-4897)).
Probably a loanword from South Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.)
Semantic identification not entirely clear ([Melchert 1993a](src-377):9), therefore etymology also uncertain.
No certain etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 1285).
According to [Strand 1998](src-431), to be connected with Old Indic *ṭakk- (1) 'remain, stop' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):300 no. 5420).
Loanword from Arabic قلب / qalb 'heart'.
No known etymology ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).
Parallel loans from Persian سينه sīneh 'chest'.
No known extra-Tocharian connections ([Adams 2013](src-345):64).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):205, [ALEW](src-352) 368, 521-522 for further discussion.
Loanword from English '(to) hit' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).
North Germanic lexemes continuing Old Norse ský 'cloud', further connections unclear (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):508).
Root etymology uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):892-893 for further discussion.
