Pace [Orel 1998](src-105):359, because of the onomatopoeic nature of the lexemes in this meaning it is difficult to establish an etymology outside of Albanian with certainty.
Probable loanword, either from Turkic or West Caucasian ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:404).
Lexemes as though from Sanskrit dhūli-, Indic *dhūḍi- 'dust, powder' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):391 no. 6835), further etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) II:110).
A Brythonic word of uncertain origin ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):99, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).
From PGmc. *uber- 'over' + *geban- 'to give'. For the problems of the IE root reconstruction, cf. 'give' in [cognate set 228](cog-228).

Germanic forms as though from PIE *u̯olH-u-, a derivative of PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):393, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):572; for the root reconstruction cf. [LIV²](src-141) 677).
Cf. s.v. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):310 no. 5524 *ḍagga- (2) 'defective'.
A loanword from Syriac mezzē 'crines parvi' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):932). [MM: Proto-Armenian *maz-o-].

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √krand- 'to neigh (of a horse), roar (of clouds, wind, water); cry piteously, lament, weep' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):185), further etymology outside of Indic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:408-409).

Possibly to be connected with Proto-Albanian *kakii̯ā̆- (cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):239), but it is difficult to be fully certain of the etymology (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):619-620. Cf. further in [cognate set 6597](cog-6597).

Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *meh₁- 'to measure' ([LIV²](src-141) 424-425, cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):852-853, [Beekes 2010](src-66):939-940, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:199-201, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):596 no. 10329, [EWAia](src-172) II:341-343).
A loan from Old French ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):639).
No certain etymology, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):61-62 for a survey of various proposals.
Loanword from Old French flor 'flower; choice, elite' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):243).
loan from Arabic اخسأ
As though from *cīssa- 'sharp pain' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):263 no. 4847). No further etymology.
Possibly to be connected with Vedic kurkurá- 'dog'? Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):164, no.3219. Otherwise uncertain.
As though from Sanskrit *khasati ʻfalls, slips' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442) no. 3856), further etymology uncertain.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'to consume, eat', further connections uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):147-150, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 609).
As though from Sanskrit *girati ʻdrips, falls' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442) no. 4159). Further etymology uncertain.

Generally connected to PIE *gei̯bʰ- 'bend' ([IEW](src-49) 354, cf. Lat. gibber 'humpbacked', Lith. geibùs 'frail') after [Starke 1990](src-373):504-509; etymology followed by [Melchert 1994](src-368):254.

Comment: From older Iranian *miθra-, name of the sun god
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *mitrá- 'contract; god of contract', further etymology disputed (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:354-355, [Encyclopædia Iranica](src-780) s.v. Mithra).
Loanword from French cacher 'to hide'.
Parallel loans from Persian ناف / nāf 'navel'.
Borrowing from Old French estanc 'pond', itself ultimately from Latin stagnum 'body of standing water, pond, pool, fen, etc.' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):689).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *per- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):427-428, [Boryś 2005](src-259):478-479, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 473).
No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):45, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):103, [Orel 1998](src-105):27, [Holm 2011](src-130):83 for various proposals and further discussion.

From Classical Armenian ertʿa- 'go'. The etymology in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 590-592, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):96, 104 to *per-steh₂-, but cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):263 who instead prefers a denominal formation from ertʿ 'going, journey' as though from a nominal stem *h₁r-sk-ti-, and in which case could be root-cognate with Greek ἔρχομαι 'come, go' in [cognate set 5151](cog-5151).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 645, no. 11083: s.v. Vedic lúpyate 'is lost, is removed' (TS), apalupyate 'perishes' (AV) "replaced in MIA. by *lukka- in P[rakrit] lukkaï intr. 'hides'"
Lat. crocus (ultimately a LW from Gk. κρόκος).
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin crocum 'saffron flower' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):216), a loanword from Ancient Greek κρόκος 'saffron flower, Crocus sativus' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):152).
Loanword from Latin or Romance floc(cus) ([Orel 1998](src-105):100, [Holm 2011](src-130):65).
Etymology outside of Indic uncertain, possibly to Old Norse hrista 'shake' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:413).
As though from Sanskrit *jañjāla- 'worry, affairs' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):280, no. 5085).
Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):301 no. 5441 s.v. *ṭaḍḍha 'distant'; further etymology uncertain.
Continuing a derivative of Sanskrit √gharṣ- 'to rub', further connections remain unclear ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):240 no. 4450, [EWAia](src-172) I:513-514)
Parallel loans from Sanskrit hr̥dayam 'heart'.
Derived from PIE *bʰelH- 'to sound' ([ALEW](src-352) 113-115, [Derksen 2015](src-353):90, cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):54ff. [LIV²](src-141) 74).
Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit pallava- 'sprout, shoot, twig', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):450, [KEWA](src-399) II:235-236).
Parallel loans from Persian ناخن / nāxun 'nail', in some cases with sound substitution kh for x; Sanskrit nakha- 'nail' also may have had influence.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13264 s.v. saru- 'fine' lex.
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit saru- 'fine', only attested in lexicographical works ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):766 no. 13264). Further etymology unclear ([KEWA](src-399) III:445).

As though from Latin iūstus 'lawful, just', a derived adjective from Latin iūs 'law'. Further etymology disputed (cf. [NIL](src-274) 283n17, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):316-317 for various proposals and further discussion).
Parallel loans from Persian آسمان / āsmān or Tajik осмон / osmon 'sky'.

Etymology uncertain. Loan from Greek θυμός?, Bulgarian dymъ?, Turkish duman? (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):117, [Orel 1998](src-105):470-471, [Holm 2011](src-130):81 for various proposals and further discussion).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE root noun *h₂ep- 'water, river' ([NIL](src-274) 311-317, [EWAia](src-172) I:81-82, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):19 no.407).

Romance lexemes from Latin galbinus 'yellow' [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):312, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:24-27). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Celtic loanword (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):266, 291, 297 for further discussion).
Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ([Derksen 2008](src-81):494, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4:183, [Boryś 2005](src-259):77, 84 for various proposals.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kep- 'to chop, hit' (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):594, [LIV²](src-141) 555).

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek ἀέρας, a new α-stem morphologically remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀήρ, ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds, atmosphere', and ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er- ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):70, [Beekes 2010](src-66):27).

Often connected to PIE 1. *sekʷ- 'follow' under the assumption of a semantic development 'follow with the eyes'; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):431-432; [LIV²](src-141) 525-526; [Seebold 1970](src-556):387-388. Probably to be connected with Hitt. šākuu̯a- 'eye' in [cognate set 3305](cog-3305).
From Ancient Greek κράζω 'to croak, cry' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), further probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):575-576, [Beekes 2010](src-66):767-768).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 409, no. 7136 s.v. nikaṭam vel sim. adv. 'near' R.

Justification: Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry (through heat)' ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):533-535, [Adams 2013](src-345):63, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257-258).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *ātr-, *ātar-, a derivative of PIE *h₂eh₁- 'to be hot' ([ESIJa](src-331) 1:318-324, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257).

Etymology uncertain. No connection to Lithuanian lãbas, etc., as suggested by [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 is accepted by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352) (cf. [cognate set 678](cog-678)). [Clackson 1994](src-319):181-182 likewise finds Hübschmann's proposed connection to Gk. λωΐων doubtful. Arm. law seems to be etymologically isolated.

Comment: Parallel loans from Sanskrit
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit puruṣa- 'man, person'.
Parallel loans from Sanskrit párvata- 'mountain'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 459, no. 8141 s.v. *pāhāḍa- 'rock, hill' and no. 8140; compare RV gen. du. pāṣyóḥ 'stone, rock'
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):460 no. 8141 'rock, hill'.
Probably a loanword from French ciel 'sky'.

Comment: The loan note "hard to tell if from Persian āftāb" probably refers to Kashmiri alone.

Justification: Armenian forms reflect a derived i-stem *h₂reu̯-i-, and are directly cognate with Vedic ravi- 'sun, sun-god' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):135-138, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:440). NB: Classical Armenian aregakn is a nominal compound of arew 'sun' with akn 'eye' (cf. [cognate set 211](cog-211)).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from Middle Indic *jhilla- 'swamp, lake', cf. Prakrit jhillaï 'bathes', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):297 no. 5392).
Cf. Lith. vė̃zdas 'stick'. No certain etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 1228-1229), perhaps a loanword from Belarusian vjaz 'elm' according to [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):745.

Etymology uncertain. [Orel 1998](src-105):100 connects to PIE *lek- (of uncertain reconstruction in [LIV²](src-141) 411 s.v. ?*lek- 'die Gliedmaßen bewegen'(?)). [Meyer 1891](src-585):108 assumed a loan from Italian foglietta 'leaf'; cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):100 for a summary of various other proposals.

Cf. SMG χώνω, from Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'heap up, raise, fill with earth' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1619), further to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1654, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1281, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 179).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1324, s.v. āruddha- 'blocked', ppp. of ā́ruṇaddhi RV, rudh- 'grow'
construction with t̪ʰɑːʋon < stāpháyati, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13756, initial part presumably non-Aryan, cf. ibid. no. 4937f.?

cf. Sanskrit kṣvelati 'leaps, jumps, plays' and keli- f. 'play, sport, fun', -d- may stem from blend with Sanskrit krīḍa-, cf. Maryhofer EWAia I, p. 413, Turner 1962-66, no. 3918 s.v. *kheḍ- vel sim: "if krī́ḍati is IE., it has crossed with these"

Justification: Etymology outside of Indic uncertain. Perhaps associated Nūristāni forms (e.g. Kati parši 'mountain' might allow a preform *parṣ- which in turn could be connected to PIE *pel(e)s- in Gk. πέλλα· λίθος (Hesych.), OHG felis, NHG Fels, etc., but this remains uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:125-126; cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):459, no. 8138).

Cf. SMG χλιός 'warm', χλιαίνω 'to make warm' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):569, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1601), probably further to an IE root *g̑ʰlei̯- 'gleaming, clear' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1637-1638), but cf. the reservations of [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1263 on the comparative semantics.
Etymology uncertain. Probable parallel loans from Dravidian (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):166 no. 3243, [KEWA](src-399) I:359, [Burrow 1948](src-759):377).

As though continuing Sanskrit alupta- 'not cut off, undiminished' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):32 no. 719), derived from Vedic √lop- 'to break, damage, destroy' and further to PIE *reu̯p- 'to break, tear (apart)' ([EWAia](src-172) II:482, [LIV²](src-141) 510-511).

Comment: Parallel loans from Sanskrit
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit nā́bhiḥ 'navel'.
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *(ava-)kaḍḍh- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):133 no. 2660, 822 no. 14245), further etymology uncertain.

Comment: < Sanskrit lambate (MhB), Vedic rámbate, PIE *lemb(H)-, cf. LIV, p. 411
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √ramb- ~ √lamb- 'hang down, dangle', [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):636 no. 10954), further to PIE *lembH- 'to hang slack' ([EWAia](src-172) II:436-437, [LIV²](src-141) 411).
Parallel loans from Persian بارش / bārish 'rain, precipitation'.

Comment: < 'fine, minute, thin, small' according to Turner 1962-66, no. 13548 s.v. *sūṅkṣa-
cogn. with 'suck' in lexeme 25941, ultimately related to 'eat' lexeme 19955 and probably 'breast' lexeme 18670

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit kāleyaka- 'a particular part of the intestines; liver' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):158 no. 3103). Further etymology uncertain. [Not in [KEWA](src-399), [EWAia](src-172)].
No convincing etymology outside of Greek ([Beekes 2010](src-66):551), but [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):438, [Beekes 2010](src-66):551 for older proposals to Germanic lexemes.
Further etymology outside of Balto-Slavic uncertain, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 15:143-144, 147-148, [Derksen 2008](src-81):279-280 for further discussion.
Without secure correspondences elsewhere in Celtic or other Indo-European languages; perhaps a non-Indo-European substratum borrowing ([Lucht 2007](src-151):331-332).

Of uncertain origin, possibly an Iranian loanword ([Olsen 1999](src-180):965, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:82). [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):552 considers the proposed etymology to PIE *bʰendʰ- 'to bind, fasten', but this requires the assumption of Grassmann's Law in Armenian, for which there are no other parallel examples.

Comment: Loan from Germanic.
Justification: Romance lexemes loaned into Late Latin from Germanic *blanka- 'colourless(?)' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:138-146, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):100; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):67).

Comment: cf. ākhu-kirí- (MS), Turner 1962-66, no. 3175; thus < PIE *kerH- (3.) "austreuen, schütten" (LIV, p. 353)

Justification: Parallel loans from German (cf. [Polański 1962-1994](src-600) 243-244, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):272).
Indic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁reh₁- 'be calm' ([EWAia](src-172) II:443-444, 447; cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):619, no. 10702).
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Late Vedic lāṅgūla- 'tail' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):639 no. 11009), further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:477-478, [KEWA](src-399) III:98).

From Latin astrātum 'starred' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):59), a derivative of Latin aster 'star' < PIE *h₂ster- 'star', cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):585, [NIL](src-274) 348-354, and 'star' in [cognate set 131](cog-131) for further etymological discussion.
Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯olk̑-o- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):526-527, [EWAia](src-172) II:526-627; for Pashto cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):94).
Loan from Sanskrit vr̥ṣṭi-.
Loan from Persian رود / rūd 'river, stream, flood'.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a stem *khaḍa- *'erect'(?), further etymology unclear ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):198 no. 3784, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:443).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8588 s.v. prátirati and prátarati and no. 5821 tiráte, for Bengali cf. ibid. no. 12888 - different derivations
? cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4883

Justification: A denominal verb from Ancient Greek παῖς (gen. παιδός) 'child', cf. cognate set 1462 for further discussion.
Probably to be derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'beat' ([Starke 1990](src-373):313-316, [Melchert 1993a](src-377):269).

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian počʿ 'tail'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:98, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):641 for various proposals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *potʃʰ-o-]
Probably to be derived from Vedic √ray- 'flow' ([EWAia](src-172):459); for the root reconstruction. cf. [LIV²](src-141) 305–306.
Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *ḍhākka- 'back, waist' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):316, no. 5582). No further etymology.
Baltic lexemes generally derived from PIE *u̯elg- 'to become damp' ([ALEW](src-352) 1178-1179, 1242-1243; [Derksen 2015](src-353):486, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 676).
Loanword from Turkish çayır 'meadow, grass' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

An Indo-Iranic and Albanian lexical isogloss from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, contemplate' ([LIV²](src-141) 141-142, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):969; cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:777-778 without discussion of proposed Albanian cognates).

Comment: PLEASE REVISE ENTRY! cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13253

Justification: From Ancient Greek ἐξευπορῶ 'to supply, deliver' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):246), further to PIE *perh₃- 'to provide, make available' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1222, [LIV²](src-141) 474-475).

No accepted etymology outside of Germanic; cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):292, for the suggestion that Proto-Germanic *saiwi- is a probable non-IE, pre-Gmc. loanword. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):423, 435-436 accepts an etymology from IE *sei̯kʷ- without referring to other hypotheses.

Comment: ultimately *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur-

Justification: Loan from French sucré 'sweet'.
As though continuing Indic *laṭṭa- 'hanging, tangled', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):633 no. 10918).

Comment: Not listed in Morgenstierne 2003.

Justification: Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Root etymology possibly to PIE *h₃ekʷ- as in Ancient Greek ὄσσε 'eyes' (dual), but the stem formation is very unclear ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:452-453, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):811-813}, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1133-1134). Cf. note by Scarborough in cognate set citations for further justification and discussion.

[Adams 2013](src-345):714 connects the root of the Tocharian forms to Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'swell' (cf. [cognate set 315](cog-315)), but this etymological connection remains uncertain (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):489-490, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):499).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5545 and 11004

Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek ὀψάριον 'little side-dish', a diminutive formation to Ancient Greek ὄψον 'cooked or prepared food', but esp. at Athens 'fish' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1624), further from an o-grade derivative *h₁op-s to *h₁ep- 'on, upon' with the sense of being a supplementary dish eaten on top of grain or bread ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1139-1140).

No certain etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):940, cf. [HAB](src-740) I:77-78, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):5-7). Cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):6-7 for further discussion and a tentative proposal to PIE *p(e)h₂u̯- 'small'. [MM: Proto-Armenian *(h)ag-ii̯a-].

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 6419: "poss. all NIA. forms, and cert. those of Dard. with l-, are < Ir., Av. duma- [...]. But. besides Kal., some derivatives [...] suggest possibility of orig. IA. form" - Hindi and Urdu may have Persianized forms of an originally inherited form; not a simple loan event - for the sequence *Cumbʱa- compare Vedic kumbhá- m. 'pot' and Av. xumba-
presumably ideophonic nursery word
extracted from compounds in catur- via 'square', thus 'squared', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4534 and 4595ff.
tentative, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8996
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9933

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Old Indic *bura- 'defective' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442) 526 no. 9289). No further etymology.

Compared by [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:183-184 to the root of Avestan saef- / sif- 'carry out a sliding, sweeping movement', no certain etymology outside of Iranic, sometimes compared to Vedic śíphā- (name of a river) but the connection remains uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):327-328, [EWAia](src-172) II:637).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit ṭaṅka- ~ ṭaṅga- 'leg', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):301 no. 5428, [KEWA](src-399) I:456).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8377; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: Generally considered to be cognate with the Balto-Slavic word for 'head' (cf. Lith. galvà, etc.). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):43, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):220). Cf. further discussion regarding the Balto-Slavic lexemes in [cognate set 1142](cog-1142). Classes indexed at proposed-cognacy level 5/6: large majority view.
Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 386-388.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no 9962
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8393
MBh.,cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7788

Justification: Loan from Late Latin putris (putridus) 'rotten, putrid' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).
Of obscure etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):168-169; cf. [HAB](src-740) II:445). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsan-u-(r)]
Loanword from Middle Low German slichts ([Karulis 1992](src-534) II:227).
No certain etymology outside of English ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Parallel loans from Persian میوه / mīwah 'fruit'.
From Latin costa 'rib, side' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):211, [DCECH](src-423) II:278-279), further etymology obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):146, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):140)
Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit √ḍhauk- 'approach, bring near'; of uncertain etymology, probably a loanword ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):318 no. 5610, [KEWA](src-399) I:465).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4782
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit cikkaṇa- 'smooth, slippery' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):259 no. 4782). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Dravidian (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:385).
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc. ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:619).
Loan from Latin frūctus 'fruit' ([Orel 1998](src-105):103).
The Breton verb chasseal was productively formed within Breton to chass 'dogs', a loanword from Old French chace 'hunt' (n.) ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):153).
Etymology uncertain; perhaps originally 'to carry on the back', cf. Skt. vr̥kká- 'kidney' ([Turner 1931](src-69):460, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):527, no. 9311).
Hellenic lexemes as nominal derivatives PIE *dʰegʷʰ-r-h₂ from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1475-1476, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1112; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 133-134).

Comment: via 'strong' from 'overpower, have power over', cf. LIV, p. 515; Turner 1962-66, no. 13298ff.

Justification: Loan from Turkish bed, ultimately from Persian bad 'bad' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 1:39).

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *gʰr̥dʰ-ó- ~ *gʰordʰ-ó- 'enclosure' ([EWAia](src-172) I:495, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):239, no. 4428; [Kroonen 2013](src-165):169, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 197).

Derivatives of Ossetic myg | mugæ 'sperm', according to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:137-138 to be further connected to Latin mūcus 'snot, mucus', Ancient Greek μύξα 'mucus, discharge from nose' to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, remove (smth.)' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 443-444) as a Scythian-European isogloss.

Uncertain, perhaps to in some way to Sanskrit madhurá- 'sweet' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):562 no. 9793)? If so, then to be connected with PIE *médʰu- 'sweet drink, honey' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:302-303).

Indo-Iranic and Balto-Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₂seu̯s- 'to become dry' ([EWAia](src-172) II:648-649, 658, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):724, 727 no. 12548, 12508; [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:250-251, [ALEW](src-352) 892-893, [Derksen 2015](src-353):390, [Derksen 2008](src-81):473-474, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 285).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7955 s.v. Vedic pálāyate ʻfleesʼ (TS); cf. Vedic párā + i (áyate?), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 233

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit piccha- 'tail-feather' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):460 no. 8151), further etymology unclear ([KEWA](src-399) II:270-271; cf. also 'tail' in cognate set 1260 ???).

Comment: Common Brythonic loan from Latin fructus [cognate set 227](cog-227)
Justification: Borrowing into Brythonic from Latin frūctus ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):258, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. ffrwyth).

Comment: سبز with sound substitution uj for z
Justification: Parallel loans from Persian سبز / sæbz.

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian hast 'firm, steady, tough; thick, dense', generally connected with Germanic lexemes for 'hard, steady, strong, dense' (OIc. fastr, OHG festi, fasti) from PIE *past- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):201, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)390-391, but preferring the hypothesis of an old European loanword in PIE on the basis of medial *-a-).

Comment: Vedic mr̥dú- 'soft' (VS), 'weak' (AV), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10292

perhaps comparable to Sanskrit lokottara- (loka- + uttara-) adj. 'surpassing the world, extraordinary', Pali lokuttara-; Prakrit loguttara-, later also 'uncommon', 'sublime', cf. Sinhalese lovuturu, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 648, no. 11126
< Skrt. ŚOCYATE 'is purified' (Turner 1931: 622), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12621; LIV, p. 331

Justification: There is no certain etymology outside of Slavic. All the existing hypotheses (linking it to PIE *kes-, PIE *i̯eh₃s- and PIE *h₂ek̑-, cf. [LIV²](src-141): 261, 311, 357) are unconvincing formally and/or semantically (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 32:9-10, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):421-422, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:178).
Germanic forms identical to Old Latin tongēre 'to know' < *ton⁽g̑⁾-éi̯e- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 629, [IEW](src-49) 1088, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):533-534, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):353).

Root ref. form tentatively follows the reconstruction of [Adams 2013](src-345):241 to a putative PIE *klemH- (not in [LIV²](src-141) or [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)), rejecting alternative proposals to PIE *k̑lei̯- 'lean' as formally improbable; cf. [Adams 2013](src-345) s.v. TochB klänts- and [Malzahn 2010](src-341):624-625 for further discussion.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5979 s.v. toláyati ʻlifts, weights, considersʼ (MBh.), √tul-

Justification: Traditionally derived from PIE *pro-u̯o-, remodelled in PGmc. as *frau̯i̯a- 'the one in front, lord' (cf. [NIL](src-274) 645, [Kluge 2011](src-397):314). Doubted by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):153) on account of phonological difficulties.

Perhaps continuing an original causative formation *dou̯h₂-éi̯e- to PIE *deu̯h₂- 'to join, fit together' but the details remain unclear (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 123, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):342, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):511). Cf. also Runic (Gallehus Horn) 1.sg.pret. tawido 'I made'.

Comment: cf. lápati (AV) 'chatters, talks'; via 'whisper', 'talk secretly, make secrets'

Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Sanskrit √dar-¹ 'to tear, split' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442) 353-354, no. 6186, 6190), ultimately from PIE *der- 'tear (intr.), split' ([EWAia](src-172) I:701-703, [LIV²](src-141) 119-120).
Parallel loans into Modern Indic from Persian برف / barf 'snow' (cf. [cognate set 126](cog-126)).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *staba- 'staff; letter'. Further connections not fully uncertain, possibly with Lithuanian stãbas 'post', Old Irish sab 'shaft, pole' < *stabʰ-o- or *stobʰ-o-? (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):471, [ALEW](src-352) 967).
Indo-Iranic lexemes of onomatopoeic origin, imitative of suckling, cf. Skt. cuci- 'female breast' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):264, no. 4855; cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:394-395).
Anatolian and Indic lexemes from PIE *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'water' ([NIL](src-274) 715-717, [EWAia](src-172) II:544-545).

Romance lexemes from Latin impingere 'to push, strike, drive at' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):358), further to PIE *pei̯g- 'to paint', probably a variant of the better attested root *pei̯k̑- 'carve out, cut out' ([LIV²](src-141) 464, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):465-466).

Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):517-518, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):456}). A connection has been proposed with Lat. malus 'bad', OCS malъ 'small', and Gk. μῆλον 'small cattle, sheep, goat' since [Solmsen 1904](src-712):17-18, but the semantics and morphological structure are unclear.

Comment: Loan from Old High German

Justification: Loanword from Turkish kuyruk 'tail' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603):82).
No clear correspondences outside of Germanic, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):517-518, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):456.
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 5:154-156, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 1:552, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):149, [Boryś 2005](src-259):132).
Loanword from Waigali yū̆z, yoz 'cold' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):601 no. 10396).
Loan from Arabic فاكهة / fākiha 'fruit' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:352).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing a denominal formation from Ancient Greek σκότος 'darkness, dark' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1287). For further discussion and justification of the root ref. form, cf. 'shadow' in [cognate set 8269](cog-8269).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', possibly from a root ?*slak- 'to hit, beat' only otherwise attested Celtic, cf. Middle Irish slacc 'sword' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):425-427, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):452, [LIV²](src-141) 564).

Comment: cf. Persian نزدیک næzdi:k - via Urdu? - outside Urdu with sound substitution j for zd

Justification: Goidelic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *rēdi- 'simple, easy', further derived from PIE *(H)rei̯dʰ- 'to shake, wobble' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:16-17, [Matasović 2009](src-50):306-307, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 502).

Comment: parallel Persian loans, with sound substitutions j for z in Magahi, Marathi, Nepali

cf. Henning "Sogdica" (1940: 51): "Here, ʾʾywz is clearly "pond, fish-pond", or "lake" ("river", as the obvious etymology might suggest, is perhaps less likely)." Could this word be related to Sogdian ʾwzy "lake"? The Parthian reading may then be 'āywaz' or similar.

Justification: Cf. Standard German holen 'to fetch, get'. Etymology outside of Germanic unclear ([EWA 4](src-415):774-777).

Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑u̯eh₁- 'to swell up' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):728 no. 12565, 12568, [EWAia](src-172) II:623-624, [Cheung 2007](src-83):341, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 339-340).

Comment: cf. Vedic (ŚB) chardáyati 'vomits', etc.; root related to PIE *k̑er-H- 'to defecate'

Justification: Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:241-242, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):114 no. 2420); for Khotanese cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):492.
Extra-Tocharian connections uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):96 for various proposals.

Comment: Morgenstierne (1974: 72) only notes suγδ for Sarikoli, which could be a dialectal variant of sleʁ with metathesis and δ/l alternation.

Justification: The basis of this Ossetic lexeme may go back to a root *men- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 728-729) if [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:122 and [EWAia](src-172) III:386 are correct in connecting the lexeme to the basis of Sanskrit manāk 'a little, slightly, in a small degree', but there are many unclear details of this etymology.
Armenian and Nuristani lexemes derived from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):55, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):720 no. 12438, [EWAia](src-172) II:627, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 319-320).

Of unknown origin. Traditionally connected with Germanic *buddǭ 'bud, seed-pod' but the comparison is uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:112-113, [Olsen 1999](src-180):937, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):552-556 for further discussion). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pi/utuł-o-].

Hellenic and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑elh₃- 'green, yellow' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):542, [Polański 1962-1994](src-600):1067-1068, [ALEW](src-352) 1296, 1325-1327, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1263-1264, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1638).
Parallel loans from Persian هموار / hamwār 'smooth, flat, level'

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ([NIL](src-274) 526-540), cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1227-1228, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):534-535, [EWAia](src-172) II:77-78, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):438 no. 7747, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):152, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):462, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), [LIV²](src-141) 458).

Latin rotundus 'round' and its Romance continuants, derived from Latin rota 'wheel' and ultimately further to PIE *ret- 'run' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):611, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):527, [NIL](src-274) 575-580).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hwassa- 'sharp', further connections outside of Germanic uncertain ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):315-316, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):264, 266, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):284-285).

No generally accepted etymology (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:385-386, [Olsen 1999](src-180):442, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):724 for various proposals; not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tar-i̯a-].

Comment: nursery word for 'mother', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9198
variant of kūdak < *kau̯tá-?
blends of word of different origins, cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4111 s.v. *gāṭṭa- ʻneck, throatʼ and no. 4459 s.v. ghāṭā- f. ʻnape of neckʼ (Suśr.), no. 4124; cf. Vedic gā́tram

Justification: No certain etymology (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):418-419, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):393 for further discussion, rejecting formerly proposed connections to Latin mollis 'soft'); for the Romance forms cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):472.
No etymology given in Morgenstierne (1974:48); onomatopoeic according to [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):227.

Slavic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 2:203-204, 2:213-214, [Derksen 2008](src-81):57-58, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):53).
Its Slavic and further IE cognacy is not entirely certain.
Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑enu- 'jaw' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):280, [Matasović 2009](src-50):158).

Comment: could this word be related to the verb var „zusammenhalten, einschließen, umhüllen, bedecken“? cf. EWAia II 512 , cf. Sanskrit vará- and derivations like varimán, várivas, all ≈ “Raum, Gebiet”

Justification: Continuing Latin vallis 'valley' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):762 no. 9134), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):712, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):652).
Generally agreed to be derived from PIE *seu̯h₁-, but some debate remains over the precise details of the verbal stem formation (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 538-539, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):797-798).
Etymology disputed, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):226, 494, 511-512; [Holm 2011](src-130):50-51 for further discussion.
Of imitative/onomatopoeic origin, cf. [HED H](src-407):7-8, HW² Ḫ. Unlikely to be etymologically related to the comparanda given by [Weeks 1985](src-68):223 for phonological reasons.

Armenian, Indic, Baltic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sen- 'old' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):, [EWAia](src-172) II:695, [ALEW](src-352) 901-902, [Derksen 2015](src-353):393, [Matasović 2009](src-50):330).
No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 512-513 for further discussion).

Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 572-573, [EWAia](src-172) II:769-770, [Cheung 2007](src-83):348-349). For Punjabi, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):796, no. 13791.
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *skel- 'bend, curve' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1013, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1346).
Loan from Persian خوب / xūb 'good'.
From Latin cōlāre 'to percolate, sieve' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):193), a denominal verb to Latin cōlum 'sieve, wine filter', no further certain etymology ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):193).
Greek θηρεύω is a secondary formation to an old IE root noun *g̑ʰu̯eh₁r- 'wild animal' (> AGk. θήρ) ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):435-436, [Beekes 2010](src-66):547).
Etymology unknown. Derivation from Lat. suburgere or superurgere? From a verb in some German language related to Old High German sweran? (G. Cadorini, p.c.)
Generally derived to IE *u̯er- 'observe, perceive' ([LIV²](src-141) 3. *u̯er-, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):886-888, [Adams 2013](src-345):647-648).

Modern Greek lexemes directly continuing or continuing secondary derivatives of Ancient Greek χόρτος 'enclosure, court', from PIE *gʰor-to- 'fence, enclosure' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1606-1607, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1644-1645).
Loan from Latin sonus 'a noise, sound' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):677).
Parallel loans from Persian.

Comment: The Lari form may contain an inchoative suffix. Not noted in Cheung (2007).

Justification: Loan from English 'fight'.
From Latin *plattare, a derivative of Latin plattus 'flat, level', in turn a loan from Greek πλατύς ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):547)
Derived from Sanskrit valāhaka- m. 'rain-cloud, thunder-cloud', further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):665, no. 11411, [KEWA](src-399) III:162-163).
Loanword from Arabic.
Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 455-456, [Derksen 2015](src-353):228, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):278.
Loanword from Arabic, cf. Standard Arabic  رقبة / raqaba 'neck'.

North Germanic lexemes continuing Old Norse slangi, a loan from Middle Low German slange 'snake' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):513).  But if the source is as late as Middle Low German, then the Icelandic and Danish lineages should be considered by then already divergent, and therefore this is a parallel loan.
Armenian lexemes continuing PIE *h₂r-nu-, derived to PIE *h₂er- 'to take, acquire' ([LIV²](src-141) 270-271, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):112-113).

Friulian cjoli, from Latin tollere (G. Cadorini, p.c., cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):727), further a nasal-infix present stem formed to PIE *telh₂- 'raise up' in origin ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):621-622, [LIV²](src-141) 622-623).

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.
From Latin boreās 'north wind; north' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):107), an old loanword from Greek βορέας 'north wind; north' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):73-74).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:120-121).

Cappadocian ανανούμαι 'think' from Ancient Greek ἀνανοέω 'call to mind' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):101-102), which is turn a denominal verb from Ancient Greek νόος 'mind, sense, intellect'. Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):756-757, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1023).

Comment: Probable loanword from local Arabic 'powder'.

Justification: No satisfactory etymology.

Comment: from Sanskrit raṭati 'howls, shouts', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1301 s.v. āraṭa- n. ʻcrying outʼ (Pāṇ.), 2. āraṭi- f. ʻnoiseʼ (Kathās.), √raṭ-
Justification: From Sanskrit √raṭ- 'to howl, shout' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):59 no. 1301, 1302); no certain further etymology, probably onomatopoeic (cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:36).

As though from Proto-Slavic *životŭkŭ 'small stomach', the diminutive of *životŭ 'stomach' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):1054-1055), cf. 'belly' in [cognate set 2238](cog-2238) for further etymological discussion.

Armenian lexemes generally connected to the family of Greek θάλλω 'to bloom, flourish, grow' ([Clackson 1994](src-319):118-120, [Olsen 1999](src-180):51, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):231-232, 237-238). The PIE root reconstruction *dʰalh₁- for this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 132.
Unknown etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):964, [HAB](src-740) III:142-143). [MM: Proto-Armenian *dzax-o-/-u-].
Loanword from Latin veterem 'old' (acc.sg.) ([Meyer 1891](src-585):476, [Huld 1984](src-571):131, [Orel 1998](src-105):512).
Derived from the inherited word for 'nose'. For further etymological discussion, cf. [cognate set 267](cog-267).

The root has an onomatopoeic origin and and its reflexes show various instances of an irregular phonological development. No certain further IE cognates (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:122-123, 129-135; [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 6:161, [Boryś 2005](src-259):57).
A borrowing from English savour ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):422-423).
Loanword from Iranic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:21-22, [Boryś 2005](src-259):57).
Loanword from German, possibly via Polish ([Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 1: 317-318).

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around, roll' ([LIV²](src-141) 691-692, [EWAia](src-172) II:518-519, [ALEW](src-352) 1197-1198, [Derksen 2008](src-81):529, 539, [Derksen 2015](src-353):492, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):666-667).
Baltic lexemes derived to PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to beat, split' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 470-471, 517; [Derksen 2015](src-353):234, 254, [LIV²](src-141) 345-346).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯d- 'to let go, release' ([ALEW](src-352) 567, 577-578; [LIV²](src-141) 402-403).

Comment: Parallel loans from Persian

Justification: Loanword from Arabic قرن / qarn 'horn'.
Possibly an Arabic loanword.
Etymology uncertain, maybe a loan from local Arabic.

Pace [Katz 1998](src-456) who argues for a compound 'eel-snake' consisting of elements *illui̯- (cf. Proto-Germanic *ǣla- 'eel') and *anka- 'snake' (Latin anguis, Greek ὄφις), Hittite illui̯anka- is generally considered a Hattic loanword ([HED A+E/I](src-406):358-359, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):384).
Loan from Slovenian modrak (G. Cadorini, p.c.)

Comment: Cheung (2007: 379) assumes prefix *abi-. Horn (1893: 1, 9) suggested a compound of āb + tāb with āb „Glanz“.

Justification: Loan from local Arabic, cf. Arabic wād 'dry riverbed'.
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi gulʹava
Romance lexemes derived from Latin pēnsāre 'to weigh' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):526), further to be connected to PIE 2. *spend- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):457, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 578).

Comment: probably loans from New Persian (Tajik: garon)

Justification: Possibly a variant to the more widely attested root *terh₁- 'bore, rub' ([LIV²](src-141) 632), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 647 s.v. ?*treh₁-, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):546, [Seebold 1970](src-556):519.
Ossetic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *g̑ar- 'to sound, call' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:288-289, [LIV²](src-141) 161, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):470).

Cf. Sanskrit gāḍha- 'dived into; pressed together, thick, firm' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):220 no. 4118), derived from Vedic √gāh- 'to dive into, bathe in, plunge into; penetrate, enter deeply into' and ultimately to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- 'to go into water, wade into' ([EWAia](src-172) I:486, [LIV²](src-141) 183).
Loan from English cloud.
Loan from Arabic ركبة / rakba 'knee'.

Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit bhagín- 'prosperous, happy' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):531, no. 9348), further derived from Vedic √bhag- 'to apportion' from PIE *bʰag- ([EWAia](src-172) II:239-240; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 65).

Comment: "From a pre-Indoeuropean root meaning "to cut", attested in Romanian and Bulgarian too." (–G. Cadorini)

Justification: Probably to be connected with lexemes for 'belly' in [cognate set 854](cog-854) ([Adams 2013](src-345):651).
No certain etymology outside of Tocharian. Cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):778 for some proposed Balto-Slavic comparanda, but no etymology given by [Malzahn 2010](src-341). Not in [LIV²](src-141).

Comment: for Ossetic *frā-xai̯za-

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indic ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):132, no. 2641; [EWAia](src-172) I:290).

For the purposes of establishing a root-ref. form, we tentatively follow [Cheung 2007](src-83):15-16 in distinguishing two separate Proto-Iranian roots, although the semantic shift *'to perceive, notice' > 'smell' is not entirely inconceivable and the lexemes could very well belong to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- ([LIV²](src-141) 83-84, [IEW](src-49) 150-2).
Classical Armenian am 'year' seems to continue an old deverbative stem *sem-(e)h₂- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):60, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):45-46; cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:704).
Loanword from Middle High German bom, boum 'tree' ([Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):51
Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):507-508 for further discussion.
According to [Adams 2013](src-345):318 to be derived from PIE *dʰeu̯H- 'move quickly back and forth' via a semantic development 'make arise (a cloud of dust)' > 'covered in dust', 'yellow'.
Loan from Modern Greek κόκκαλο(ν) 'bone' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 2:530-532)
According to [Adams 2013](src-345):617, probably to be connected with Ancient Greek ὀλίγος 'few, small', Albanian lig 'bad, evil; thin' etc. as a derivative from PIE *h₃lei̯g̑-.
Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂er- 'to fix, fit together' ([LIV²](src-141) 269-270, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):112).
Presumably a loanword from Arabic.
Origin unknown (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:202). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79) or {OIsen 1999}. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃei̯r(-)ana-].
Etymology uncertain, possibly an Arabic loanword.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):592). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):470, [Beekes 2010](src-66):600-601 for various proposals.
No certain etymology ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):147, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):141).

Denominal to Classical Armenian vax 'fear, dread; steep place, precipice'. Further etymology uncertain ([HAB](src-740) IV:294-295; not in [Olsen 1999](src-180) or [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯ax-].
Romance lexemes as though from Latin *tīrāre, of uncertain origin (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):725, [DCECH](src-423) V:505-508 for further discussion).

Negative compound as though from Sanskrit na- 'not' + rāma- 'good, pleasant', cf. RV su-rā́ma- ([Turner 1931](src-69):536, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):615, no. 10636). Further to Skt. √ram- from PIE *h₁rem- 'become calm' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:435-436).
Possibly from an IE formation *h₁ēd-so- *'flesh (for eating' > 'skin' according to [Adams 2013](src-345):549, but this proposal remains uncertain.
Loanword from Iranic ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):189-190, [HAB](src-740) 3:198). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃerm(-)aka-].

Comment: 'stab'>'kill'.
Justification: Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break', cf. OCS klati, 1.sg. koljǫ 'to stab' ([ESSJa](src-458) 10:154-156, [Derksen 2008](src-81):230, [LIV²](src-141) 350).

Comment: presumably from 'to clump together', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4177, 4182, 4271

Justification: Continuing Proto-Iranic *čak/g 'to strike, hit', probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Cheung 2007](src-83):31-32).

The root etymology in this cognate set follows [LIV²](src-141) 154 to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to haul, to pull', cf. also [Kroonen 2013](src-165):99, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):93-94, [Seebold 1970](src-556):160-162.
No certain etymology (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):362-363, [HAB](src-740) II:587 for further discussion).
Of onomatopoeic origin ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:146-147).
Loanword from Arabic (dial.) salj (cf. Standard Arabic ثلج / thalj 'snow').
Loanword from Luvian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):980).
Loanword from Turkish göl 'lake' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) I:306).
Loan from Turkish çomak 'club'.
Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin aptāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):46, [DCECH](src-423) I:389-390), further to PIE *h₁ep- 'grasp, seize' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):47, [LIV²](src-141) 237-238).
Of onomatopoeic origin ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) I:357).

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯eit- 'to shine brightly' [EWAia](src-172) II:679-680, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):316-317, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):267, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 340). The Germanic forms irregularly reflect final *-t-, but this is generally explained by a secondary gemination *-tn- > -tt- or secondary influence from Gmc. *swart- (< IE *su̯ord-o-, cf. [cognate set 188](cog-188)), cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):980.
Loanword from Middle Low German gel, gele 'yellow' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600) II:149).
Loan from Middle Iranian, cf. Pahlavi spētak, Parthian spytk' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):240, [HAB](src-740) IV:264-265, [Olsen 1999](src-180):907). [MM: Proto-Armenian *spei̯t-aka-].
Loanword from Persian پست past 'low, inferior, small' (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:77 [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):636).
Etymology outside of Italic uncertain, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):83-84, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):80-81 for various hypotheses.
Usually explained as a blend of PIE *k̑erh₁- 'grow' with *sper- 'strew' (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):504, [Clackson 2017](src-673):112).
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi büm 'earth'.

Goidelic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach' ({ref LIV² 282-284, cf. [Pedersen 1913](src-308):557, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:151, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):200-204, [Matasović 2009](src-50):36-37).
Loanword from Latin cantāre 'sing' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):187, [Huld 1984](src-571):80, [Orel 1998](src-105):178)

Etymology uncertain but generally connected to PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'to kindle' ([LIV²](src-141) 259) despite phonological difficulties, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):11; [Orel 2003](src-388):7; [de Vries 1977](src-468):99-100.
Generally considered to be of onomatopoeic origin ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603):235-237).
From Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike, thresh' + preverb *pati-; further etymology uncertain (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):141-143).
Loan from Latin directum 'straight, not curved' ([Huld 1984](src-571):55, [Orel 1998](src-105):73).
Armenian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([NIL](src-274) 706-715, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):205, [Derksen 2008](src-81):523).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. OCS лѣвъ 'left', Macedonian лев 'id.', etc.
Latvian and Latgalian forms derived from Latvian siẽva 'wife' and further connected to PIE *k̑ei̯-u̯o- 'socially close' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1016-1017, [Villaneuva Svensson 2011](src-758):32).
Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):767, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1037-1038; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.
From Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):592). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):470, [Beekes 2010](src-66):600-601 for various proposals.

Comment: Parallel loans from Old Indic

Justification: Root etymology uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):407-408 for two possibilities to either *bʰleg- 'shine' or *bʰel- 'speak, yell; bark' of which [Malzahn 2010](src-341):721 prefers the former etymology.

Comment: A general shape of the root as *(s)keu̯H- seems probable. Only Beekes assumes *(s)keHu-. However, alternative explanations of the Greek forms are presented by ALEW and EWA.The root might be identified with  *(s)keu̯h₂- 'stochern, ritzen' (LIV² p. 561) or for the time being accepted as *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover' without laryngeal identification (cf. IEW 951ff.).

Justification: Caucasian loanword, cf. e.g. Mingrelian č̣anǯi 'fly' ([HAB](src-740) III:184-185, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):939). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʃantʃ-i-].
Armenian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *med- 'to measure' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):470-471, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:48-49, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 423).
Loanword from Italian cantare ([Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯anH- 'to call', further to PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):144-145, [LIV²](src-141) 611).
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian лови, Serbo-Croatian loviti 'to hunt'.
Parallel loans from Sanskrit bī́ja- 'seed'.

From συκώτιον, the diminutive of Ancient Greek σῦκον. The meaning 'liver' was taken on as a transferred epithet from the phrase ἥπαρ συκωτόν 'liver (of an animal) fed on figs' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1354). Further etymology obscure, probably a prehistoric loanword ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1421). For a parallel semantic development in Romance cf. [cognate set 905](cog-905) from Lat. fīcus 'fig'.

Comment: sporadic Slavic ?*kob(-)ě/it-
Justification: Polish kobieta is a Polish-only innovation (originally the word was abusive). It has no certain etymology despite of many attempts to explain it ([Boryś 2005](src-259):241). It is often linked to kobyla 'mare'. [ESSJa](src-458) links the lexeme to *kob- 'divination, fate', so the original meaning could be 'witch'. However, all etymologies are highly speculative.

Hellenic and Armenian lexemes generally derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe' ([NIL](src-274) 307-311, [Beekes 2010](src-66):101-102, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):416, [Olsen 1999](src-180):27, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 267-268).
Loanword from Middle High German spilen ([Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Rejzek 2001](src-593):587, cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:696).

From Ancient Greek σύρω, remodelled as a -νω present in Modern Greek varieties ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1259); probably further derived from PIE *tu̯er- 'sweep' although the details of the stem formation remain debated (cf. [Vine 1999a](src-719):570-571, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1424-1425).

Romance lexemes from Latin rotella 'little wheel' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):610, [DCECH](src-423) V:85-86), a diminutive formation to Latin rota 'wheel' and further to PIE *ret- 'run' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):527, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 507).

Comment: Khwarazmian with prefix upa-
Loan from Iranian.
Justification: A loan from Iranic ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):99-100, [Olsen 1999](src-180):864). [MM: Proto-Armenian *anoi̯ʃ-i-].
Loan from Turkish kötü 'bad'.
Loanword from French respirer ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived to a Proto-Balto-Slavic verbal root *renk- 'to gather'; no certain further etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):439-440, [Derksen 2015](src-353):376, [ALEW](src-352) 842-843, 867-868, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 506). For proposed connections in the older literature, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1155.

Lithuanian júoktis 'to laugh' is derived from juõkas 'laugh, laughter'; probably a German loanword (cf. Prussian jōk 'joke') according to [Derksen 2015](src-353):214; cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) who considers there to be no good etymology.

Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit ākāśá- 'sky' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):45 no. 1008), to be further connected with Vedic √kāś- 'to be visible, appear' and further to PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ([EWAia](src-172) I:344-345, [LIV²](src-141) 383-385).
According to [Adams 2013](src-345):548, to be derived from PIE 2.*u̯el- 'spin, roll' ([LIV²](src-141) 675).
No plausible etymology ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:101).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:500). For Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):657, no. 11258.

Comment: Loan from Sanskrit, cf. Vedic nā́raka-/nāraká-, Pali naraka-

Justification: A loan from Middle English batte, in turn borrowed from Old French batte ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):31)

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10187; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Goidelic ([Lucht 2007](src-151):241).
No certain etymology outside of Goidelic ([Lucht 2007](src-151):241).

Comment: original meaning "snake"

Justification: For the root ref. form, cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):578 assuming an unextended root form, probably to be connected with IE *(s)k̑ʰei̯d- ([LIV²](src-141) 547-548); cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:37-38, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):578-579, [Matasović 2009](src-50):343 for further discussion.
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult, possibly further derived from PIE *pr̥-sth₂-o/i- ([Catt 2014](src-336); cf. also [EWAia](src-172) II:100-101, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):474).
No generally accepted etymology (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 744-745).
First attested in Middle English, further origins obscure, cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84) for further discussion.
Loan from Kâta-vari
Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic múkha- 'mouth, face'. No secure etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:360, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):585 no. 10158).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *Hi̯eu̯dʰ- 'to set in motion' ([EWAia](src-172) II:418-419, [Cheung 2007](src-83):176-177, [LIV²](src-141) 225-226).

Comment: root cī- 'to attempt, fight', no further etymology

Justification: Lexemes continuing a derivative of Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'air', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):237, [EWA 5](src-398):1488-1491, [Kluge 2011](src-397):586, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):328, 342).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhan- 'to speak' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):534 no. 9383), further IE root etymology disputed, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:244, [LIV²](src-141) 69-70 for further discussion.

In all likelihood an old loanword into Iberian Romance from the medieval forerunner of modern Basque eskerr, although it cannot be ruled out that the current Basque lexeme has not been influenced by the Romance forms (cf. [DCECH](src-423) III:469-472 for further discussion).
Of uncertain etymology, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):920-921 and [Adams 2013](src-345):687-688 for discussion of various proposals.

No certain etymology, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):471-472, [HAB](src-740) II:62-64, [Clackson 2017](src-673):110 for further discussion. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)rkin-i-].

Portuguese from Latin ad noctem 'at night' ([Williams 1962](src-572):84-85, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):491), from PIE *nekʷt- 'night', a t-stem derivative to PIE *negʷ- 'become dark' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):416-417, [NIL](src-274) 504-513).

Comment: from Vedic varṣám n. 1. ʻrain ʼ (RV+), pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV), 2. ʻyear' (ŚB) (root vr̥ṣ-), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 446, no. 1139: Pali vassa- m. n. ʻrainʼ, pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ, Prakrit vāsa- m. (or < vārṣa-), varisa- m. n. - NB. New Indo-Aryan forms are Sanskritisms - ultimately cognate with 'rain' in cognate set 1612
loaned into Armenian as քարշ kʿarš, cf. [cognate set 627](cog-627)
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷels- 'to draw a furrow' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:319-320, [LIV²](src-141) 388-389).
No known etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:32, [Matasović 2009](src-50):309).
Loanword from Turkish but 'thigh, rump' (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):899).
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Avestan pūiti- 'rottenness', Middle Persian pwtk' 'foul, rotten' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):256, [Olsen 1999](src-180):913). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰut-o-].

Hellenic lexemes to be derived from the same root as Ancient Greek φθείρω 'to ruin, destroy' < *dʰgʷʰer-i̯e/o- 'flow away, disappear' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1198, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1569). The onset cluster ψ- found in some Modern Greek dialects has probably come about via contamination with Modern Greek ψύλλα 'flea' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1626).
Apparently a loan from Tungusic according to [HAB](src-740) II:437. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsa(-)tsuk-a-].

Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic ślakṣná- 'slippery, smooth, soft' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):738), further to PIE *slegh₂snó- ([EWAia](src-172) II:673), probably to be abstracted to a more basic root *(s)legh₂- (cf. Ancient Greek λαγαρός 'slack, loose').

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):446, [Orel 2003](src-388):334, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):485, [Kluge 2011](src-397):800). For the root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555).

From PIE *seh₁dʰ-i̯o-, a derivative of PIE *seh₁dʰ- 'to reach the goal, be successful' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):99-100, [Olsen 1999](src-180):186, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:722-723, [LIV²](src-141) 517).
From Indic *ṭōkk- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):304, no. 5476. No further etymology.

Tocharian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *deu̯k- 'to pull' ([LIV²](src-141) 124, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):982, [Seebold 1970](src-556):503-505, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):346, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):515, 525).
From Vedic kapā́la- 'skull, cranium' ([Turner 1931](src-69):79, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):137 no. 2744), further etymology disputed (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:300).
Loan from Persian cf. [cognate set 1831](cog-1831)

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511 no. 9092-9093). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps originally a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit √phal- 'to burst, split' with an irregular labial vowel -u- (cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:398).

Often assumed to be a loanword from an unattested Lat. adj. excurtus (similarly cf. OHG kurz, kurt, etc. < non-prefixed Lat. curtus in [cognate set 292](cog-292)), alternatively inherited from Proto-Germanic *skurta- to Proto-Germanic *skertan- 'cut off' and perhaps further to be connected to PIE *skerd⁽ʰ⁾- and comparable to Lith. skérdėti, OIr. sceirtid (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 558 s.v. ?*skerdʰ- 'schneiden, stechen' (?), [Orel 2003](src-388):346, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):444.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *orbiti 'do, work', a derivative of *orbъ 'servant, slave' and ultimately derived from PIE *h₃erbʰ- ([ESSJa](src-458) 32:116-118, [Derksen 2008](src-81):373).

The Brythonic words in the meaning 'snow' in this set are sometimes compared to Old Irish arg 'drop' and connected to a root *sperg- or *spreg-, but this lexeme is only marginally attested. A better etymology for the Brythonic words would be a connection with the IE root *h₂erg̑̑- 'white, bright, shining' via Proto-Celtic *argi̯o- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:88, [Matasović 2009](src-50):41-42). Because of the uncertainties over the proposed Old Irish cognates, this latter etymology has been followed in this class, but note that it is not mentioned s.v. *h₂erg̑- in [NIL](src-274).
Probably a loanword from Brythonic, cf. Welsh cwyn 'complaint' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:18-19), but cf. the discussion of [Le Mair 2011](src-749):177.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek σύρω, remodelled as a -νω present in Modern Greek varieties ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1259); probably further derived from PIE *tu̯er- 'sweep' although the details of the stem formation remain debated (cf. [Vine 1999a](src-719):570-571, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1424-1425).

Comment: cf. Middle Persian kamar "waist, belt, girdle"; Horn (1893:193) relates this word to Av. kamarā- "belt".

Justification: Loanword from Turkish göğüs 'chest'.
Anatolian lexemes from PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):803-805, [LIV²](src-141) 105-106).
Lexemes from Proto-Tocharian *m⁽’⁾æy-, further IE root etymology uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):777-778 for further discussion.

Hellenic lexemes, originally from a derived adjective in *-nā to Ancient Greek σέλας 'light, brightness', i.e. Proto-Greek *selásnā- (cf. Lesbian σέλαννα 'moon'). Further etymology obscure ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):955, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1318-1319).
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Chechen kujg 'hand' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:644).
Loanword into Middle English from Old French montaigne ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Etymology disputed: either to Ancient Greek. ῥίς 'nose' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):480, cf. [cognate set 2356](cog-2356)) or Ancient Greek. θίς 'heap, dune' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *ter- 'to speak' ([ALEW](src-352) 1076-1078, [LIV²](src-141) 630-631

Eastern Romance lexemes from Latin *pullius 'young animal' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):565 no. 6826), further to PIE *putslo- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):544, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):502-505; cf. Ved. putrá- < *put-lo-).

Etymology for these lexemes follows that of [Weiss 1994](src-700):143-145 and [de Vaan 2008](src-54):639-640 to *u̯eh₁- over the older proposed etymology to *u̯egʷ- (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):745-746). Romanian ud 'wet' < Lat. ūdus may belong to this class but could also belong to PIE *u̯egʷ- in [cognate set 5276](cog-5276), cf. discussion in [cognate set 8427](cog-8427).
Romance lexemes from Latin inflāre 'blow into, inflate, swell' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):362), further to PIE *bʰleh₁- 'blow' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):226-227, [LIV²](src-141) 87).

Comment: Unknown etymology.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian krem 'to bear, to carry'. Further etymology uncertain. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ki/ur-].
From Ancient Greek ἴσος 'equal' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):284). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):470, [Beekes 2010](src-66):600-601 for various proposals.
Derived from Latin complēre 'to fill, complete' (cf. [DCECH](src-423) II:290), further to PIE *pleh₁- 'be filled, become full' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):472-473, [LIV²](src-141) 482-483).
A loan from Old French jalne ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:26).

Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Loan from Latin caelum 'sky' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):225-226, [Huld 1984](src-571):107, [Orel 1998](src-105):360).

Romance lexemes from Latin levāre 'to lift up, raise' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):405-406, cf. [DCECH](src-423) III:636-638), a derivative of Latin levis 'light in weight' and further to PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light (in weight)' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):336).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes generally considered to be cognate, although the precise reconstruction debated; some taboo distortion is likely to have occurred in some branches ([Sihler 1995](src-290):163, [Katz 1998](src-456); cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1134-1135, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1535, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):153, [EWAia](src-172) I:157, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):44 no. 994, [ALEW](src-352) 40-41, [Derksen 2015](src-353):55, [Derksen 2008](src-81):388, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):42).
More precise origins uncertain, but possibly a loanword from Greek (cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):257 and discussion in [cognate set 6209](cog-6209)).
Certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking ([ALEW](src-352) 933, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 562). Identical to 'fly_V' in [cognate set 2273](cog-2273).
Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 386-388 to a causative-iterative stem *kʷolh₁-éi̯e- derived to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn'.
Possibly derived from a putative PIE *stemH- 'to push', cf. [ALEW](src-352) 983-984, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):611 for further discussion.
Etymology outside of Celtic obscure, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:253, [Lucht 2007](src-151):329-330, [Matasović 2009](src-50):227-228 for further discussion.
A derivative of Tocharian tsäm- 'to grow', in turn derived from PIE *demh₂- 'to build' (cf. ref Adams 2013}:804, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):984-987).
Root etymology uncertain, perhaps to Proto-Iranic *bauǰ- 'to release, free, open; save, deliver' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):18-19, [Samadi 1986](src-724):43).
A secondary semantic development from Modern Greek νερό 'water'. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'water' in [cognate set 1563](cog-1563).
Goidelic lexemes continuing PIE *stei̯gʰ- 'to rise, stride' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:57-60, [Matasović 2009](src-50):376, [LIV²](src-141) 593-594).
Cf. Skt. caṭaka- ~ *caṭikā- 'sparrow', Prakrit caḍaa ~ ciḍiga ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):248 no.4571. Of uncertain origin, possibly onomatopoeic ([KEWA](src-399) I:368).
Loanword from either Latin sphaera or Norman French spere ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:177)
Uncertain etymology (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). See further discussion below.
Of obscure origin, first attested in Middle English ME culle(n), kulle(n), kille(n), kylle, etc. ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Loanword from Turkish meyve 'fruit', in turn a loanword from Persian mive 'fruit' (cf. [Dawkins 1916](src-452):623).

Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ([LIV²](src-141) 334-335, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):313-315, [EWAia](src-172) II:666-667 [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):730 no.12598, [Cheung 2007](src-83):356-357, [Matasović 2009](src-50):208). The parallel verbal root *k̑leu̯s- 'listen to' is a secondary verbal root abstracted from a desiderative formation from *k̑leu̯- 'hear' already in the protolanguage (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 336).

Comment: Preserved -d- in Modern Indic presupposes parallel loans from Sanskrit nadīḥ, cf. [cognate set 808](cog-808).
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit nadī- 'river'

Indic lexemes continuing Vedic ramyà- 'to be enjoyed, beautiful' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):616 no. 10636), further derived from PIE *h₁rem- 'to be calm' ([EWAia](src-172) II:435-436, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 252-253).

Romance lexemes from Latin levāre 'to lift up, raise' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):405-406), a derivative of Latin levis 'light in weight' and further to PIE *h₁legʰ-u- 'light (in weight)' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):336).
Loan from Low German (cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:258).
Etymology unclear, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:266-268 for further discussion.

Romance lexemes from Latin portāre 'carry' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):554), further probably a denominal verb to Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'a passage, crossing' and to PIE 1. *per- 'come through, cross' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):482-483, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 472-473).
Of uncertain origin (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:546-547 for various proposals; not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79) or [Olsen 1999](src-180)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰam-ii̯o-].

Generally compared to Lat. torqueō from a causative-iterative stem *torkʷ-éi̯e/o- 'twist' ([Aura Jorro 1993](src-303):366-367); whether this is to be identical with Ancient Greek τρέπω, τροπέω (cf. [cognate set 5106](cog-5106)) is less certain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1132-1133, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1503-1504).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3245

Justification: Loan from Latin pallaca (Late Latin *placca) 'concubine; girl' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):582).

Derived from Old Breton mauu 'young man, servant' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):498), further connected to Old Irish mug 'boy, servant' and generally compared to lexemes from Proto-Germanic *magu- 'boy, relative' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:70-71, [Matasović 2009](src-50):274). Further etymology uncertain; the lexemes may well have been substratum borrowings in the Western Indo-European languages (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):240, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):347 for discussion of the Germanic comparanda).
Etymological connections outside of Germanic unclear (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):976, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):584).
A derivative of PIE *klep- 'to (secretly) steal, hide' ([Smoczyński 2005](src-686):33-34, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 940-941, [LIV²](src-141) 363-364).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic skandhá- 'shoulder, upper part of back', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):786 no. 13627, [EWAia](src-172) II:750).
Loanword from Turkish yuvarlak 'round'.

Cf. Old Lithuanian regė́ti 'to see', further etymology uncertain. [LIV²](src-141) 498 considers a possible derivation on the basis of an essive formation ?*r̥gʰ-h₁é-, but this is not fully certain (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 855-856 for further discussion).
No clear etymology outside of Balto-Slavic; probably further connected to Lithuanian píepala 'quail (coturnix coturnix)'. Cf. discussion in [ALEW](src-352) 766.

Comment: Loans in Kurdish would be old, viz. before *rd/rz > ł in Kurdish vs. l in Persian.

Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *gaHz- 'to run, start', probably further to PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eg̑ʰ- 'to enter (water), wade' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):96, [LIV²](src-141) 183, cf. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):111).

Comment: parallel Sanskritisms, cf. vicāra- m. 'pondering' (MBh.), Prakrit viāra- m. 'thought'

Justification: Loanword from Old Russian думать 'to think' ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:223).

Denominal from Armenian xorh 'thought', probably an Iranian borrowing but there is no certain etymology (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):624, [HAB](src-740) II:409). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xorh-].
As to the semantic development (relative) pronoun 'how, what kind' > 'strong, hard') cf. Latin 'qualitas' (cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) I:218).

Comment: jugded Sanskrit loan (NARI) by Turner (1931: 341), Buck gives "fem. der. fr. NAR- 'man'" (Buck 1949: 83)

Justification: Originally a root-noun in the sense *'visible, outer form' > '(outer) body; skin' (cf. Hittite tu̯ekka- 'body, person') from PIE *tu̯ek- 'be visible' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:684, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):346 no.6087, [LIV²](src-141) 654).

Baltic lexemes as through from PIE *greng̑ʰ- 'to turn' ([ALEW](src-352) 360-361, [LIV²](src-141) 191; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):305-306). The reconstructed root is restricted in attestation to Germanic and Baltic.

Comment: loan from Persian, because old *t would appear as t.
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13358 s.v. Vedic sāráyati

Justification: Root assignment to PIE *kʷer- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 391-392, [IEW](src-49) 641-2). Alternatively, the IIr. cognates assigned to this root might be with *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' (cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).
Loan from Turkish kanat 'wing'.

Comment: cf. Urdu lexeme 26095; bāl-forms via *barza-/bazra- ? Note the similarity of bāl-forms with the well-attested Hamito-Semitic *bal- root "wing, feather" (Orel/Stolbova 1995: 52) with a short vowel.

Justification: No known etymology outside of Goidelic ([Lucht 2007](src-151):254).
Loan from Kâta-vati kk′ař.
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian дише, Bulgarian дишам 'breathe'.
Parallel loans from Persian ماهى / māhī 'fish'.

Comment: cf. Persian سفت seft
Justification: Parallel loans into Indic from Persian.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):450, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):415 for various proposals.

Romance lexemes continuing Latin in-tendere 'to stretch out, stretch forth, extend' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):366 no. 4483, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:740-746). The IE root is either *ten- 'to stretch, extend' or *tend- 'to wear down', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 626-628, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):612 for further discussion.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'muzzle', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):374, not in [Boutkan & Siebinga 2005](src-82)).
Loanword from early Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic rót 'root' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:98 for various proposals.
Linked by Horn (1893: 160) to the Sanskrit verb śak- "to be able", cf. also śakti- "power" etc.

Generally further connected with Classical Armenian lerk 'hairless, bald' and sometimes compared with Old Irish lerg 'surface, level' (cf. [Pedersen 1909](src-307):105), but this proposed etymology is quite uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):965, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):244). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), cf. [HAB](src-740) III:555-556.

For the provisional root ref. form, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):114-115, but this IE root reconstruction is uncertain; it is possible that we are dealing with a contamination of two separate roots (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 199, 358-359 s.v. ?*gʷʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen' and *keu̯dʰ- 'verbergen').

Etymology outside of Italic uncertain, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):380, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):360 for a survey of proposed extra-Italic cognates. For the Romance lexemes cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):429.

Iberian Romance lexemes, probably to be derived from Latin rāpum 'turnip' ([DCECH](src-423) IV:744). Further etymology uncertain, possibly an early non-Indo-European loanword (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):514, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):564, [ALEW](src-352) 875 for further discussion).

Comment: Proto-Albanian loan (cf. Std. zgavër  'cavity, cave', also indicated by inflection) from Vulgar Latin *skavare (cf. Ital.scavare)

Justification: Loanword from Turkish göl 'lake'.
Indo-Iranic lexemes to be connected with the same root found in Vedic úru- 'wide' ([EWAia](src-172) I:226-227), cf. 'wide' in [cognate set 3090](cog-3090) regarding the root reconstruction *h₁u̯erH-.

Possibly cognate with Hittite peššii̯e/a- 'throw', but the connection is disputed; cf. [cognate set 8675](cog-8675) for further discussion and references. Otherwise only Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:144-145, [LIV²](src-141) 242-243).

Comment: could be derived from *fra-dmās- with fra- > ha-, assimilation fo dm > dn and subsequent loss of d

Justification: Loanword from Turkish puslu 'misty, hazy'.

Comment: Loan from Middle High German
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4344
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit guḍa- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):224 no. 4182, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):233 no. 4344). Further etymology uncertain, possibly an Austroasiatic loanword (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:338).

Either a direct borrowing from Iranic or a secondary denominal verb from a borrowed substantive vaz 'leap, jump' (cf. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):242, [Olsen 1999](src-180):908). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯az-].

Comment: Baltic goes back to *met-
Justification: IE root identification uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 641-643, [Derksen 2015](src-353):307, 314 for further discussion.

The Classical Armenian present harkane- : aorist har(e)- go back to a suppletive pair in Proto-Armenian. The present stem may be derived from *h₃erg-, cf. Hitt. ḫark- 'perish', ḫarnik- 'destroy' ({ref LIV² 301, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):215-216 for further discussion). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kn̥-i̯o-, a derivative of PIE *ken- 'new, fresh' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):609, [Beekes 2010](src-66):616). As a verbal root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 351.

Comment: Gharib suggests *yaunikā- for Sogdian

Justification: Without clear correspondences outside of Greek ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:236-237, [Beekes 2010](src-66):951-952).

Without clear etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):703). Cf. [Hill 2003](src-735):128 for a recent attempt to connect with Germanic, but also the critical appraisal of [de Vaan 2008](src-54):630).
Semantic identification not fully certain, therefore etymology also uncertain (cf. [Melchert 1993a](src-377):173).
Parallel loans from Turkish toz 'dust'.

Comment: 'un-seasonable'Strand 1998; g < #VkV
Justification: Etymology uncertain, either an early loan from early Indic akāla- 'wrong time, unseasonable' or directly continuing Indic *ud-ghāra- 'pouring out' ({ref Strand 1998, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):1 no. 11, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):92 no.1977).
A loanword into Brythonic from Latin tostus 'grilled, burned', cf. Welsh tost 'severe, harsh, hard' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):732).
