Loanword from Italian lago 'lake'.
According to [Adams 2013](src-345):731-732 to be derived from PIE *smer-(u̯)o- 'fat, grease'.
Romance loanword, cf. Standard Italian coda 'queue, tail'.
Root reconstruction difficult. A contamination between two (possibly related) roots *teu̯h₂- and *teu̯k- is a possibility. Cf. 'fat' in cognate set 6104 for further discussion.
Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):944, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:280). [MM: Proto-Armenian *stu(-)u̯er-a-].

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5607 s.v. *ḍhōṭṭa-

Justification: Rom. ud is from Lat. ūdus 'wet, moist' (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85) s.v. ud). The IE root etymology remains unclear. The traditional etymology of Lat. ūdus is to PIE *u̯egʷ- 'make damp (so [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):745-746, with references to earlier literature, tentatively also [de Vaan 2008](src-54):648; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 662-663, [IEW](src-49) 1118), but [Weiss 1994](src-700):141-143 makes a convincing case that a derivation to PIE *u̯eh₁- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 715-717 s.v. *u̯eh₁-r-. *uh₁-r- 'Wasser'; [IEW](src-49) 80f., [EIEC](src-657) 636) may also be a strong possibility. The prevailing majority opinion seems to judge the connection to *u̯egʷ- for Lat. ūdus to be more likely than *u̯eh₁- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):639-640 s.v. ūmeō and notes to [cognate set 1578](cog-1578)), albeit still uncertain.

Comment: Loan from early Scandinavian

Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *luftu- 'air', without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):237, [EWA 5](src-398):1488-1491, [Kluge 2011](src-397):586, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):328, 342).
Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *porxъ 'dust' and Proto-Slavic *pьrxъ 'dust' from PIE *pr̥s-o- (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):413, 428).

Etymology uncertain. Perhaps an expressive variant of Old Irish eitte 'feather', or a derivative of the verb cel- 'hide, cover' and subsequently contaminated with OIr. eitte ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:116).
Loanword from Kâta-vari.

Comment: Loanword from Sanskrit punḍra- via Kâta-vari.

Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √har- 'to carry, bring' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):808 no. 13980). No certain etymology outside of Indic ([EWAia](src-172) II:803-804), [LIV²](src-141) mechanically ?2.*g̑ʰer- 'to take, get'.
According to [Adams 2013](src-345):706-707, a fossilised feminine accusative singular of the gerund śwālle ‘suitable for eating’ from śu- 'eat' from PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H-eh₂-.

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑rei̯H- 'to excel, be excellent' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):400-401, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):98, [EWAia](src-172) II:665-666, II:669-670, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 337).
Continuing Old English tacan, an early borrowing from Scandinavian, cf. Old Icelandic taka 'to grasp, seize', etc. ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Compared by [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):12 with Sanskrit ā-khid- 'seize', if so from Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰād- ~ *kʰid- which may formally reflect PIE ?*k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂d- 'to tear, squeeze', although further cognates outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 344). [Not in [Cheung 2007](src-83)].
Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 557-558, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):440-441. Possibly an extended form of the root *(s)ker- 'to cut', cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):487.

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse skógr; no certain etymology outside of Germanic. Traditionally derived from a root *(s)kek- / *skeg- 'springen; lebhafte Bewegung' ([IEW](src-49) 922-923, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):497). Not in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Comment: the Arabic noun is used as a verbal stem in some languages

Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit jāṅgala- 'jungle, wild forest'.
No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1328-1330, [Derksen 2015](src-353):522).
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi ḍag′ara.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 13036 s.v. Sanskrit saṃsāra- m. 'undergoing transmigration', 'secular life, the world', from sar-

Justification: Nuristani lexemes for 'woman', continuing compounds containing the word for 'daughter' (cf. Kâmviri ǰʹü 'daughter'), continuing PIE *dʰugh₂ter- 'daughter' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):370 no. 6481, [EWAia](src-172) I:737-738).
Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit kakkhaṭa- 'hard, solid' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):128, no. 2587). No further etymology.
This class encodes Proto-Indo-Iranic *kárna- 'ear'. The Khowar and Kalaṣa-alâ lexemes represent light verb constructions. Cf. 'ear' in [cognate set 768](cog-768) for further etymological discussion/
Etymology unclear; [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:114 suggests some bird names, e.g. Persian šīšū, šīšak 'a kind of partridge' as potential cognates (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian корен 'root'.
Etymology difficult, [Meyer 1891](src-585):153-154, [Orel 1998](src-105):152, [Holm 2011](src-130):73, [Hyllested 2012](src-684):73-81 for various proposals and further discussion.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰeng̑ʰ- ([NIL](src-274) 13-15, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1159-1160, [EWAia](src-172) II:220-221, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):518, [ALEW](src-352) 115-116).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4411

Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):41, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:99-100, [LIV²](src-141) 72).
To be derived from Vedic √kar- 'to make, do' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):147, no. 2900, [KEWA](src-399) I:176, [EWAia](src-172) I:307-309).
A verbal derivative of Ancient Greek φῦσα 'breath, bellows', further connections outside of Greek unclear (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1599-1600)

Comment: loan from Persian ران cf. [lexeme 47728](lex-47728)
Borrowing from Arabic?

Justification: Possibly of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):48).
Cf. OCS vrъzǫ 'tie' from PIE *u̯erg̑ʰ- (cf. [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 1:188-189, [LIV²](src-141) 688).

A derivative of Portuguese apertar 'tighten, press, clamp', from Latin appectorāre 'press on the chest' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):44), further derived from Latin pectus 'chest'. For connections elsewhere in Indo-European, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):491, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):453, and further discussion in [cognate set 4015](cog-4015).

Romance lexemes from Latin domina 'mistress, lady', the feminine equivalent to Latin dominus 'master of a household' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):245-246), further derived from Latin domus 'house' < *dom-u-, cf. PIE *demh₂- 'build' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):177-179, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 114-116).

Etymology in this class follows [Hamp 1960](src-668):276, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):180-181, [Orel 1998](src-105):125 to PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to become old'; but cf. also discussion of [Huld 1984](src-571):66, [Holm 2011](src-130):89-90.
Cf. Classical Armenian mēǰ- 'the middle; back' < PIE médʰ-i̯o- ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):466-467, [NIL](src-274) 465-466).

Derivatives from PIE 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):234, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:44-45, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 556-7), PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (to pieces)' ({cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560) is often considered to be a dental-enlarged form of this root.
Etymology outside of Indic uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) II:667, [EWAia](src-172) II:369). For Middle and Modern Indic forms cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):591, no. 10250.
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian песок 'sand'.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4272 s.v. 'foot, leg, knee'; cognate with [cognate set 4586](cog-4586); related to [cognate set 7597](cog-7597)?
Justification: As though from Indic *goḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee'; further connections unclear, perhaps related to *khuṭṭa- 'leg' in [cognate set 9629](cog-9629) ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):229 no. 4272).

To be derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound' ([LIV²](src-141) 187); possibly originally an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ([ALEW](src-352) 331-332). Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 210-211.
East Baltic lexemes, without certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 623-625, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):422-423 for further discussion).
Khwarazmian hwβ would appear to continue a present stem *hauba-, but there is no certain etymology (cf. [Samadi 1986](src-724):92-93, [Cheung 2007](src-83):299-301).
Old French fesse, from Latin fissus 'split' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 3:581-582), the past passive participle of Latin findere 'to split' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):221).

Comment: Unknown etymology. (e)i̯-n-
Justification: Of uncertain etymology.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *tu̯erH- 'to catch' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):501, [ALEW](src-352) 1143, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 656).

Comment: cf. Young Avestan tiγra-, Old Persian tigra- 'sharp' < Proto-Indo-Iranian *tigrá-, compare Vedic tigmá-, cf. Maryhofer EWAia I, p. 668f.
re-sanskritized? not among Turner 1962-66, no. 9827f. mánuṣa- and manuṣyà-

Justification: Pāli pabbata 'mountain' from Vedic párvata- (adj.) 'stony', (n.) 'mountain, mountains, stone', as though from PIE *péru̯n̥to-, cf. Hitt. peru- 'stone' ([EWAia](src-172) II:99, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):668-669).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit pānīya- 'water' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):456 no. 8082), a derivative of Vedic √pā- 'to drink' and further to PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ([EWAia](src-172) II:113-114, [LIV²](src-141) 262).

Armenian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯g- 'to belch, vomit' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):764, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):714-715, [Derksen 2008](src-81):441-442, [Boryś 2005](src-259):536, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 509).
Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit or Prakrit challī- 'bark' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):274, no. 5005). Of non-IE origin, possibly Dravidian or Munda (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:405-406).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian мазен 'smooth'.

Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *lh₂eiuo- or *leh₂i-uo- 'left' ([ESSJa](src-458) 15:29-31, [Derksen 2008](src-81):275), cf. Ancient Greek λαιός 'left', Latin laevus 'left' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):824-825, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):323).

Comment: cf. Bailey (1979: 420) who connects NP čap with Sogdian sʾpt deriving both from *k̑am- "to bend over" (cf. *kamp- in LIV 342). However, while Sogdian requires the input *k̑e, NP requires *ke.

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Ossetic ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:507).

Root_Gloss: 'to hit, to meet with, to come together'

Justification: Romance lexemes from or derived from Latin mollis 'soft' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):463); the Iberian Romance lexemes are secondarily derived to a de-adjectival verb *molliāre 'make soft' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):463, [DCECH](src-423) IV:181-182). Further to PIE *meld- 'be/make soft' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):386, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 431).

As though from a Sanskrit compound *kṣāradhānikā 'receptacle for ashes' (kṣārá- 'caustic substance', dhā́na- 'container'; cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):191, no. 3677). Further connections outside of Indo-Iranic are uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:430, [KEWA](src-399) I:288).

Comment: egg (of hen) < "round"
Buck 1949:226 from IE *skeu/*keu 'perceive, hear'

Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √yā- 'to go, advance, set out, travel', further to PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- ([EWAia](src-172) II:407-408, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):604, no. 10452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 309-310.

Comment: Not related to bāzu-forms, because *b would appear as β. Cheung (2007: 430) puts the Sogdian word to the verbal root *waz- "to carry, drive".

Justification: Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from a PIE root *men- ([KEWA](src-399) II:575-576, [ESSJa](src-458) 20:158-161, [Derksen 2008](src-81):330). Quite possibly (but not certainly) also cognate with Proto-Germanic *mannan- in [cognate set 8248](cog-8248), cf. further discussion in that cognate set.
Parallel loans from Persian نمک / namak 'salt'.
Loanword from Kâta-vati.

Lexemes from Proto-Iranic *či̯au̯- 'to move, go', and ultimately from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:307-308, [Cheung 2007](src-83):40-42, [EWAia](src-172) I:552-553, [LIV²](src-141) 394-395).
Lexemes continuing an Iranic root *Hrab/f-, further connections outside of Iranic uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):184-185).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin pilus 'hair' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):538 no. 6508), further etymological connections uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):507, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):465).
Parallel loans from Persian مرد / mard 'man, person'.

Baltic lexemes, to judge from cognates such as Ved. śā́kha- 'branch', probably continuing an ablauting h₂-stem, like PIE *k̑ók-eh₂- ~ *k̑ek-h₂- (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1003-1005, [Derksen 2015](src-353):439).

Comment: see 3414 for the discussion of etymology

Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *swimman- 'to swim, float', further etymology uncertain ([Seebold 1970](src-556):491-492, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):501).
Loan from English river
No secure etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:314-315). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):143-144, no. 2830.

Albanian forms since [Meyer 1891](src-585):23-24 compared with Greek φαίνω 'appear', a remodelled nasal-present stem *bʰ-né/n-h₂- to PIE 1. *bʰeh₂- 'shine' ([LIV²](src-141) 68-69, [Huld 1984](src-571):43, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):97-98, [Orel 1998](src-105):22).

Comment: cognate with OHG dorn 'thorn', etc., cf. IEW 1031; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 664
Justification: Indic lexemes generally considered cognate to OHG dorn 'thorn', etc. < *tr̥-no-; perhaps further derived from PIE *(s)ter- 'be rigid', cf. Gk. στερεός 'stiff, hard' but this is less certain ({ref {EWAia} I:664, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1031),
Etymology uncertain. Considered a loanword from Slavic according to [Meyer 1891](src-585):206 and others, alternatively an inherited lexeme (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571)82-83}, [Orel 1998](src-105):197).

Romance lexemes from Latin infūsum (Giovanni Abete, p.c.), the past passive participle of Latin infundere 'pour in' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):363). Further to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯d- 'pour', possibly a post-PIE enlargement of *g̑ʰeu̯- 'pour' for phonotactic reasons ([LIV²](src-141) 179-180n1, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):249-250). Root assignment in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) in reconstructing a separate root *g̑ʰeu̯d-.

Etymology uncertain. Possibly a blend of PIE *spek̑- & *derk̑- (cf. [Meillet 1936](src-644):135, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):228, [Clackson 2017](src-673):105-106); alternatively backformed to a root aorist etes < *dek̑-/dk̑- (cf. [Schmitt 1981](src-655):146, [LIV²](src-141) 109-112).
Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):787-789, [Adams 2013](src-345):529-531 for further discussion.

Comment: Loan from East Caucasian
Justification: No clear connection to the inherited Iranic or Indo-European words for salt, probably a loan from East Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:310-311).

Indic and Balto-Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *bʰei̯h₂- to get scared' ([LIV²](src-141) 72-73, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:245-246, [ALEW](src-352) 112-113, [Derksen 2015](src-353):89, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:163-164, [Derksen 2008](src-81):50).

Romance lexemes from Latin lūridus 'pale yellow, lurid' (([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 5:465-470, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):420), further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):371, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):354).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯āstra- 'pasture, grass' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):93 [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):403, cf. [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):1414, 1416).
No certain etymology (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 990-991).
Loan from English round.
Root etymology uncertain; probably either PIE *leg̑- 'gather' or PIE *leu̯k- 'shine' (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):836-839, [Adams 2013](src-345):596-597).
Parallel loans from Arabic حلو / ḥulw 'sweet, nice' (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:461).
Loan from Standard Italian fumata 'smoking, a smoke'.

IE root etymology disputed. The Italic and Romance lexemes in this class might be connected with the lexemes from Proto-Germanic *dragan- in [cognate set 2839](cog-2839) via PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- but this would require the assumption of an irregular dissimilation of aspirates and devoicing in initial position. Alternatively some Celtic cognates are formally possible (cf. Old Irish tethraig* 'ran away, receded'), but note that the required reconstruction *tre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- violates Indo-European root structure constraints. Cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):626-627 and [LIV²](src-141) 154 for further discussion.

Comment: No certain further etymology no matter numerous proposals (cf. ESSJa).

Justification: Etymology outside of Celtic disputed; cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):66, [Matasović 2009](src-50):144-145 for various proposals. Root ref. form follows [Matasović 2009](src-50).
Romance lexemes from Latin battuere 'hit, beat' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):85), of obscure origin ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):68).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9742; further etymology unclear, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 294

Justification: Connections outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):153-155 for various proposals.
Loan from Romanian.
Generally considered a loan from Latin penna 'feather, wing, pinion' ([Orel 1998](src-105):315, [Holm 2011](src-130):62), but cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):62 who attempts alternative etymologies.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11004 and s.v. lag-
Justification: As though from Sanskrit lāgayati 'lays on', the causative stem to √lag- 'to stick, attach'. Further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):638 no. 11004, [EWAia](src-172) II:473)
Loan from Germanic.
Perhaps from PIE *u̯élk̑-u-, if cognate with Skt. valśa- ‘sprout’, OCS vlasъ ‘hair’, Russ. vólos ‘hair’ ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):997).
For the root etymology, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):909-910, with references to further literature; cf. also discussion by [Adams 2013](src-345):658-660.
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. [cognate set 1171](cog-1171).

Derivatives from Proto-Indo-Iranic *bʰau̯H- 'be, exist' < PIE *bʰeu̯h₂-/*bʰu̯eh₂- ([EWAia](src-172) II:255-257, 268, [LIV²](src-141) 98-101, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):545 no. 9556-9557, [Henning 1971](src-681):34).

Comment: Past. Part. used as adjective 'good'

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):417, [Derksen 2015](src-353):343-344, [Boryś 2005](src-259):424, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):435-436). The verbal root is preserved in Baltic (cf. Lith. pam̃pti 'swell').
Etymology in this class follows [NIL](src-274) 122-124; cf. also the discussion of [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:123, [Matasović 2009](src-50):107.

Comment: blend of *gadda- 'sediment, mud, dirt' with gandhá- 'smell' or Middle Persian and Persian gand 'bad smell' (?); cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4011 and 4014
Cognate with 'blow' lexeme 31051

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):271, [EWA 5](src-398):195-199 for further discussion).
Of onomatopeic origin, first attested as Middle High German snūfen, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):819 s.v. New High German schnauben 'to sniff, snort' for further discussion.

Comment: strangely enough similar to [cognate set 2839](cog-2839)

Justification: Lexemes based on loans from Latin numerus 'number', cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):538).

Continuing Medieval Greek σκιάζομαι 'to be frightened' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):462, cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):498), denominal to Ancient Greek σκία 'shadow'. For further discussion of the etymology of this root, cf. 'shadow' in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058).
Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):308 no. 5512 *ṭhēḍḍ- 'push' with variants 2. *ṭhēll- . 3. *ṭēll-. Further etymology unclear.
Cf. Vedic dvā́ra- 'door' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):381 no. 6663), further from PIE *dʰu̯er- with an irregular dissimilation of the initial aspirate (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:764-765).
Romance lexemes from Latin lārgus 'generous, bountiful' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):399), further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):342, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):327).

Iberian Romance lexemes as though from Latin *sucīdus 'dirty', cf. Latin suc(c)īdia 'side of pork' derived from Latin sūs 'wild boar; pig' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):694, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):670, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):603). For the reconstruction of the Indo-European word for 'wild boar; pig', cf. the discussion of [EIEC](src-657) 425.
Loan from Old French roont ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):632).
Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯k̑-/*u̯oi̯k̑- 'house' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1055-1056, [EWAia](src-172) II:584-585, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 669-670).

Comment: < *śāṭa- ~ *śāda- 'falling, rotting', different blends of Vedic -śada- 'falling' with Sanskrit śāta- m. 'fallout' (śātana- n. 'the cutting off') and MIA -saṭá- (Pali); cf. Vedic (AV) parṇa-śadá- m. 'falling of leaves' ~ Pali paṇṇa-saṭá- 'heap of fallen leaves'; Turner 1962-66, no. 12267, 12381, 12386, Mayrhofer KEWA III, p. 323; ultimately from PIE *k̑ad- 'fall', cf. ²LIV, p. 318 (IEW 516) - ATTENTION: Maithili साराब is VERB

Justification: Possibly cognate with Anatolian lexemes for 'bad' in [cognate set 3299](cog-3299) (so [Adams 2013](src-345):555-556; tentatively mentioned but not explicitly rejected by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):420-422). Alternatively a loan from Old Turkish ([Peyrot 2016](src-676):327-335).

Comment: Gharib (1995: 454, #11143) derives the Sogdian word from *δrām.

Justification: IE root etymology unclear. [LIV²](src-141) s.v. ?*dʰreb-, considers the forms to be possibly connected with OCS drobiti 'to splinter, pulverise' but regards this connection as uncertain. [Seebold 1970](src-556) and [Kluge 2011](src-397) see no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. [Kroonen 2013](src-165) derives from via a backformation to iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip' and accepts a root etymology with OCS drobiti, but reconstructs from *dʰrebʰ- to avoid reconstructing PIE *b.
Probably a loanword from Turkic, but not fully certain (Oleg Belyaev p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:259-260).
Light verb constructions 'to become ice' with loanwords from Persian برف / barf 'snow' as the semantic-bearing head, cf. 'ice' in [cognate set 7952](cog-7952).

Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- ([HED A+E/I](src-406):431-435, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):404, {ref {EWAia} I:424, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:230-231, [Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):276).
Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ([LIV²](src-141) 458, [EWAia](src-172) II:76-77, [Derksen 2008](src-81):392, cf. [Rix 1976](src-586):278-279).
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *věděti 'know', a derivative of PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see, catch sight of' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):518, [LIV²](src-141) 665-667).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):23 for a conjectural loanword hypothesis from Persian.

Comment: uncertain.
Justification: Of uncertain origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):941), [HAB](src-740) II:666-667). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kurts-i-].

Etymology uncertain. Attempts to relate to PIE *h₂ek̑-mōn in [cognate set 7058](cog-7058) are made with great difficulty (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):183-184, [Boutkan 1998](src-669):113-115, [NIL](src-274) s.v. *h₂ek̑-), although this connection is still frequently assumed in secondary literature (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165)).

Comment: Controversial, explained either as loanwords from Latin tendere or as inherited verbs, based on PIE *ten- 'to span, to stretch' (LIV 626). Perhaps related to [cognate set 2837](cog-2837), see citations in class for further references.

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Germanic, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):252, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):192-193.
Romance forms based on Latin flō, flāre 'to blow', ultimately derived from PIE *bʰleh₁- 'blow' (cf. {ref {de Vaan 2008}:226-227, [LIV²](src-141) 87).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3624; Pali kiliṭṭha- 'soiled, morally impure'; LIV, p. 363 (IEW 602)

Justification: Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *séh₂u̯el-, sh₂(u)u̯en- (?), *sh₂un-, *sh₂ul- 'sun' ([NIL](src-274) 606-611, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):516, [EWAia](src-172) II:742, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):782 no. 13574, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:246-248, [ALEW](src-352) 892, [Derksen 2015](src-353):390, [Derksen 2008](src-81):479-480, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):463-464, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):570, [Matasović 2009](src-50):324). For an influential analysis of the nominal formation cf. [Beekes 1984](src-677).

Modern Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √kart- 'to cut (off), split, break', ultimately from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut up' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):145 no. 2854, [EWAia](src-172) I:315-326, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).
Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish druimm 'back'. Further etymology unclear, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:203-204 for various suggestions.

Sometimes considered with cognate with PIE *h₂ost- in [cognate set 519](cog-519) but the details  remain unclear (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):239, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:167-173 for further discussion). This cognate set is otherwise restricted to Slavic.
Etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword or of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:337, 329-330).
Parallel loans from Persian گرم  / garm 'hot'.
Uncertain, loan from Iranic (cf. [cognate set 68](cog-68))?

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ([LIV²](src-141) 439, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:318-319, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):578-579 no. 10066, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:19, [Matasović 2009](src-50):259). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this class, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):378-379.
Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594 no. 10286, further to PIE *meld- 'to become soft' ([KEWA](src-399) II:675-677, [EWAia](src-172) II:386-387, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 431).
Loanword from Sanskrit tvác- 'skin, bark'.

Comment: re-sanskritized forms of the respective inherited forms, cf. cognate set 6949 - note that this phenomenon is different from a simple loan event

Justification: If a derivative from Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'consume' (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):504) then perhaps to be linked with 'eat' in [cognate set 27](cog-27), 'drink' in [cognate set 3691](cog-3691).
Loan from Turkish murdar 'unclean' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Uncertain origin. Suggested to be a blend of the roots found in Greek σφάζω 'kill' and κτείνω 'kill' [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):227, or the root of Greek σφάζω 'kill' and the PIE root *gʷʰen- [Watkins 1995](src-674):521 (cf. [Clackson 2017](src-673):104-105, 112-113). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *span-].

Derived from Indic *kaṇṭa- (3) 'backbone, podex, penis' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):131-132, no. 2670). Perhaps identical with Skt. kaṇṭa- 'thorn' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):131, no. 2668), of uncertain further etymology (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:146).
Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *bītan- 'to bite, be sharp', further derived from PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split, cleave' ([LIV²](src-141) 70-71, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):65, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):68).

Comment: Listed by Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru to be a Latin loan in Welsh so ultimately deriving from [cognate set 867](cog-867). Alternative forms with initial h- are likely to be inherited, whereas these ones, with initial s- are borrowings.
Justification: Brythonic lexemes derived from a loan event from Latin siccus 'dry' (cf. Vendryes et al. 1959–1996} S:60, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):142-143)
Apparently a derivative of Latin cuppa 'cup, bowl' according to [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):223. Further etymology obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):158-159, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):155).
From Latin ambulāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):33 no. 412), further to PIE *h₂elh₂- 'go aimlessly, randomly' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):38, [LIV²](src-141) 264).
Gk. κοντός 'short' appears to derive from the same root as Ancient Greek κεντέω 'to sting, goad', for further discussion cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):563, [Beekes 2010](src-66):672-673.
Etymology uncertain, cf. [MacKenzie 1990](src-680):108 for suggestions and references to further literature.
Romance lexemes from Latin vīcīnus 'neighbour' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):777), further to Latin vīcus 'village, block of houses' and PIE *u̯ei̯k̑- 'settlement' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):675).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit taḍāga- 'pond, tank, (artificial) lake', further etymology obscure ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):320 no. 5635, [KEWA](src-399) I:470).
Parallel Sanskritisms, cf. [cognate set 754](cog-754).

Lexemes in this set coded for Proto-Slavic *čьrnъ 'black' < PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾r̥s-nó- (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 4:155-157, [Derksen 2008](src-81):92). For further etymological discussion, cf. [cognate set 1111](cog-1111) 'black'.
From Ancient Greek τρέχω 'run' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):510). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'run' in [cognate set 5027](cog-5027).

Greek and Armenian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ei̯d- 'to swell' ([LIV²](src-141) 258-259, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1053-1054, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):61). Albanian forms in [cognate set 8292](cog-8292) might be cognate to this set but ultimately uncertain, cf. discussion in that cognate class.

Very similar in form and meaning to Ancient Greek γλυκύς 'sweet', but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. Perhaps the Italic and Greek lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):186-187, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):182). Cf. further discussion in [cognate set 5055](cog-5055).
Etymology outside of Tocharian unclear, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):176 for a survey of various proposals.

Possibly related to Germanic [cognate set 647](cog-647) and Armenian [cognate set 8305](cog-8305) lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 947 (Baltic material), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1371 (Greek material), [Seebold 1970](src-556):440-441, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):458-459 (Germanic material), [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:69-70, [Matasović 2009](src-50):281 (Celtic material), [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):484 (Armenian material).
Shortened from 'white head', cf. older Polish białogłowa 'women'. Cf. 'white' in [cognate set 1190](cog-1190) for further etymological discussion.

Romance lexemes from Latin āēr 'air' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):18), an early loanword in Latin (already attested by Ennius, late 3rd - early 2nd c. BCE) from Ancient Greek ἄηρ ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):11).

Reflecting Proto-Celtic *bal-ni- 'to throw away, die', further derived from PIE *gʷelh₁- 'to throw' ([LIV²](src-141) 208, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:98, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):211-212, [Matasović 2009](src-50):53).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *hu̯ar- 'to consume, eat', further connections uncertain ([Cheung 2007](src-83):147-150, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 609).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:500). For Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):657, no. 11258.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10063 s.v. māra- m. ʻdeathʼ (VarBr̥S.), ʻkillingʼ (Rājat.); New Indo-Aryan words meaning ʻstriking, blowʼ from mārayati which continues the polysemy of Vedic hánti (han-) 'beat, slay, kill'; cognate with [cognate set 712](cog-712)

Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *médʰ-i̯o- 'middle, located in the middle' ([ALEW](src-352) 625-627, [Derksen 2015](src-353):309).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:188-189 s.v. Latvian sit 'to hit' for further discussion.
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):418, [LIPP 2](src-294):639).

The root etymology in this cognate set follows [LIV²](src-141) 154 to PIE *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'to haul, to pull', cf. also [Kroonen 2013](src-165):99, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):93-94, [Seebold 1970](src-556):160-162.
Loan from Turkish yeşil 'green' ([Holm 2011](src-130):64).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rái̯as-, an s-stem noun formed to Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rai̯-'to stretch, extend', cf. Vedic √jray- 'id.', further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:606-607, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):449).
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; perhaps to Lat. grossus 'fat' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:79, [Matasović 2009](src-50):74, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):273).
Probably a loanword from Middle Iranian ([Adams 2013](src-345):48).
Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁- 'to be hot' ([Untermann 2000](src-279):54-55, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):60, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257).

Indo-Iranic lexemes from Sanskrit lóhita- 'red' (Ved. róhita- 'red') with semantics generalised from 'red' > 'any red substance' > 'blood' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):650, no. 11165), further derived to PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- 'red' ([EWAia](src-172) II:471).

Cf. Old Lithuanian paũta 'egg, testicle', considered a vr̥ddhi-derivative to the Proto-Balto-Slavic word for 'bird' *put- (cf. 'bird' in [cognate set 1109](cog-1109)), but further etymology uncertain ([ALEW](src-352) 745-746).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *rekti 'to speak, say', further derived from PIE *rek- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):433, [LIV²](src-141) 506).

Italic lexemes, generally considered derivatives from PIE *pleu̯-mo-, a derivative of PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float'. An alternative possible reconstruction is *pleu̯k-smo- and connected with the extended variant *pleu̯k- which is only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic, cf. [cognate set 2263](cog-2263) ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):516, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):474, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 487-488).
Originally 'mountain' ([ESSJa](src-458) 7:29-31, [Derksen 2008](src-81):177-178; cf. [cognate set 80](cog-80) for further etymological details).
Cf. Sanskrit kaṭhiná- 'hard, firm', probably a loanword from Dravidian (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):132 no .2650, [KEWA](src-399) I:144).

Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):578-579 no. 10066 Vedic māráyati (1) 'kills', the causative stem formation to Vedic √mar- 'to die', further to PIE *mer- 'to disappear, to die' ([EWAia](src-172) II:318-319, [LIV²](src-141) 439-440).
Indo-Iranic lexemes reflecting an original u-stem *di̯éu̯- ~ *diu̯- 'sky, day' to PIE *dei̯- 'be bright, shine' ([NIL](src-274) 69-81, [EWAia](src-172) I:750-752).

Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯et- 'year'. For the connection of Iranic lexemes, cf. [Szemerényi 1951](src-705) and further [EWAia](src-172) II:495. For Baltic, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1228, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:497-498. For Italic, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):672-673, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):775 no. 9291 & 9292.

Originally a possessive adjective formation to Vedic pakṣá- 'wing' > pakṣín- 'winged'; no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:62). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):430, no. 7636.
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to grind, crush' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):392, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):260, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 432-433).

Connections outside of Armenian unclear; occasionally proposed to Gk. ξηρός 'dry' (cf. [cognate set 1471](cog-1471)), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):182, [Olsen 1999](src-180):965 [Beekes 2010](src-66):1035-1036, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):546).

From PIE *rei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'bind' via Proto-Celtic *rig-e/o- ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):546-548, [Matasović 2009](src-50):311-312, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):546-548, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 503), but cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):161, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):64.

Precise connections outside of Germanic are disputed. For the purposes of cognacy, this class follows the reconstruction of [LIV²](src-141) with possible but uncertain connections to ?*g̑ʰeHb- (cf. OIr. gaibid), but cf. the hypothesis of [Kortlandt 1992](src-683):104-5, followed by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):172-173, who suggests a remodelling of earlier *ga-ef- from *k̑o(m)-h₂ep-.
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ([Falileyev 2000](src-240):76); root ref. form follows [Deshayes 2003](src-309):316.

Comment: The alleged similarity with cognate 503 is probably accidental. Korn (2005: 189) seems to follow Horn (1893: 121) who derives these words from the PP of the Old Iranic verb *drang- "make strong/firm". Cf. Cheung (2007: 76) *dregʰ-.

Justification: Quite likely (but not certainly) cognate with Proto-Germanic *grasa- 'grass' in [cognate set 230](cog-230); cf. note by Scarborough in citations for further discussion.
No certain etymology outside of Germanic (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):207, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):123, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):152).

No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic; proposed etymologies outside of Indo-Iranic rely on comparisons with hydronyms which are not wholly reliable comparanda (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:8-9, [LIV²](src-141) 448). For Middle and Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):399, no. 6943.

Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'worm' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):397, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):600). Perhaps further connected to PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' (cf. [cognate set 348](cog-348) for further discussion).

Comment: Pashto would simplify /xt/ > /t/. Kurdish: Vxt > v̄t.

Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *kyjь 'stick, club', a jo-derivative to *ky- < PIE *kuh₂- with regular laryngeal metathesis from zero-grade *kh₂u̯- (full-grade PIE *keh₂u̯- 'hit, split', cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 13:257-258, 12:10-11; [Derksen 2008](src-81):265, [LIV²](src-141) 345-346).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5424, presumably of non-Aryan origin.
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a stem *ṭakk- 'cut, break', cf. Sanskrit ṭakkarā 'a blow on the head' first attested in Rājataraṃgiṇī (12th c. AD). Further etymology uncertain (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):300 no. 5421, 5424; [KEWA](src-399) I:455).
Etymology outside of Greek unclear, possibly a prehistoric loanword (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):90-91, [Beekes 2010](src-66):106).
Parallel loans from Persian daryāb; cf. 'lake' in [cognate set 2771](cog-2771) and 'sea' in [cognate set 2011](cog-2011).

Indo-European root etymology disputed. Either to *deh₂u̯- in [cognate set 8388](cog-8388) (so [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:8-9, [Schrijver 1995](src-305):316), or *dʰegʷʰ- in [cognate set 368](cog-368) (tentatively [LIV²](src-141) 133-134). [Matasović 2009](src-50):92-93 gives both etymologies under different lemmata. Cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):180.

Comment: cf. Turner 1931: 534, 1962-66, no. 10539 s.v. rakta- ʻcoloured, dyedʼ (ŚB), ʻredʼ (ŚāṅkhGr̥.), n. ʻbloodʼ (Mn.), °aka- ʻredʼ (VarBr̥S) (√rañj-), Pali Prakrit ratta-, Rom. rat m.; cf. [cognate set 1814](cog-1814); LIV, p. 587
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit rakta- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):610, no. 10539; [EWAia](src-172) II:424-425, [LIV²](src-141) 587).

From Latin grossus 'fat, thick' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):330-331), further etymology unclear (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):273), formerly connected by [IEW](src-49) 485 with Celtic *brasso- in [cognate set 4355](cog-4355).
Germanic lexemes from PIE *dʰu̯n̥s-tó-, derived from PIE *dʰu̯ens- 'to scatter, to crumble' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):109, [LIV²](src-141) 159).

Possibly an unextended form of the root *u̯eh₂dʰ- found in Latin vādo, -ere 'to go, walk, rush' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):196; cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):86). The alternative proposed etymology to *⁽g̑⁾ʰeh₁- 'to come, arrive' depends on whether the Indo-Iranic lexemes (Av. za-zā-mi 'to leave' Skt. já-hā-ti 'to leave, abandon') are to be connected with the Germanic and Armenian ones (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:813-814, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):196 for further discussion). The root etymology here follows [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), but cf. [LIV²](src-141) 196 s.v. *gʰeh₁- and 644 s.v. *u̯eh₂dʰ- 'durchschreiten'.

Generally agreed that the Baltic and Slavic forms are cognate, but there is debate as to how the Proto-Balto-Slavic word is to be reconstructed. Cf. discussion in [Derksen 2008](src-81):523, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:181-189, [Derksen 2015](src-353):195-196, [ALEW](src-352) 1332-1333.

Romance forms based on the past passive participle of Latin balneāre 'to bathe' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):74-75), a nominal verb from Latin balneum 'bath, place for bathing', an old loanword from Ancient Greek βαλανεῖον 'id.' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):65, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):195).

Comment: The Tocharian words derive either from ie. *dʰeu̯H- or *dʰu̯eh₂-, cf. cognate set 2463. On of these roots might in fact be the basis for ie. *dʰu̯ens- from which the Germanic 'dust'-words are derived (cf. [cognate set 2464](cog-2464)), but they cannot be assigned the same cognate class on this level of analysis and regarding the state of the art concerning root extensions. -  Also cf. 'ashes' cognate set 2463 and 'smoke' in [cognate set 123](cog-123).
negation of baš "good", which Cabolov (2001: 155) explains as a Turkish loanword: baš 'head' > 'main' > 'good' (cf. German 'Kopf/Haupt' > 'haupt-' as with 'Hauptsache').

Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594 no. 10286, 10287, further to PIE *meld- 'to become soft' ([KEWA](src-399) II:675-677, [EWAia](src-172) II:386-387, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 431).

Comment: cf. Sanskrit (Dhātup.) kaḍḍati, Turner 1962-66, p. 133, no. 2657; loan from a substrate (Munda or Dravidian), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p 144; perhaps related to [cognate set 6387](cog-6387)
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):133 no. 2657. Sanskrit (Dhātup.) kaḍḍati 'is hard'. [KEWA](src-399) I:144 groups with kaṭhiná- 'hard, firm' as part of a group of probable loans from Dravidian (cf. Tamil kaṭṭu 'hardness').

[Rohlfs 1964](src-587):288 considers the Italiot Greek words to be borrowings from Romance. Note, however, that AGk. λάκκος does exist, and might possibly be derived from *l̥ku̯o- (PIE *laku- or *loku-, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):827 s.v. λάκκος and further discussion in [cognate set 8246](cog-8246)). It is difficult to exclude in principle the possibility of contamination or blending of inherited material with that of local Romance varieties. Similarly cf. Engl. lake in [cognate set 5612](cog-5612) which may well be a semantic calque from Romance.
Parallel loans from Sanskrit samudrá- 'gathering of the waters, sea, ocean', cf. [cognate set 730](cog-730)

Comment: Sardinian forms formerly with Balto-Slavic lexemes in [cognate set 1109](cog-1109). ALEW doubts cognacy outside of Balto-Slavic. This needs to be double-checked. (-MJCS 19.10.2017).
Origin unclear.
Justification: Commonly assumed to be a borrowing from Latin locusta 'grasshopper', but this is semantically unconvincing; rather, of uncertain origin ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):445).

Root etymology disputed. Traditionally to IE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 21-22, [Buck 1949](src-47):1069, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):806-807), but this is difficult from a morphological point of view. Alternatively [Narten 1986](src-722):204-214 has proposed a comparison with Ved. √akṣ- which could allow a Greek zero-grade formation *h₃k̑s- > ὀξ-, but this proposal has not been met with widespread acceptance (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1089).
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):418, [LIPP 2](src-294):639).

Comment: Considering the Parthian form gwyʾw and the ZMP form gwbyʾ, one may reconstruct a bilabial glide. There is a possibility that this word is a compound of gauu- "cow" and a second element, cf. Old Ind. *Hyavas- "pasture" or  yáva- "wheat".

Justification: From Ancient Greek τύπτω 'to hit, beat' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):563). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'hit' in [cognate set 7794](cog-7794).

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

Possibly from a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic. Lat. plūma might be based on the *pleu̯k- root, but alternative derivations from unextended *pleu̯- are also possible, cf. [cognate set 999](cog-999).
Possibly from PIE *bʰleu̯dh₂- if the comparison with Ancient Greek φλυδάω 'to be soft, weak' is correct (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):67, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1579-1581 s.v. φλυδάω and φλιδάω).

Root etymology uncertain, probably connected in some way with Armenian gam 'to come' from PIE *gʰeh₁- according to [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):95-96 (cf. [cognate set 580](cog-580)); [LIV²](src-141) 668-669 suggests deriving from a nasal present stem *u̯i-n(e)-h₁- to *u̯ei̯h₁- 'sein Augenmerk richten auf, trachten nach'. See [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):95-96 for further discussion. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), cf. [HAB](src-740) I:567-568.
Denominal verb derived from Kashubian jachta 'hunt' (n.), a loanword from German Jagd ([Boryś & Popowska-Taborska 1994-2010](src-601) 2:327-328).

[Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):393-394 considers the root to be an m-extended form of *seh₂- 'bind', but even if so Skt. sā́man- 'song, hymn' < *sh₂óm-en- demonstrates that such a formation must have already been of PIE date. The root ref. form for this class has therefore been given as *sh₂em- [Not in [LIV²](src-141).]

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 180, no. 3471; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 401: "schwerlich zu trennen von jav. (°)gaēsa-", perhaps a blend with *káisra- > Vedic (YV+) késara- n., but phonologically unclear; Indic forms constitue a cognacy subclass *gáića- (*káisra-?)
Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic kéśa- 'hair of the head', difficult to separate from Young Avestan gaēsa- although there is disagreement over the voicing of the initial velar; [EWAia](src-172) I:401 suggests a contamination of an original *géśa- the Indic lexemes with Vedic késara- 'hair, mane'. For Middle and Modern Indic, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):180 no. 3471.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *pakšá- 'wing, pinion', further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain unclear ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):429-430 no. 7627, [EWAia](src-172) II:62).
Lit. 'not-good', cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):106, cf. 'good' in [cognate set 9287](cog-9287) for further etymological discussion.
Slavic lexemes derived from the zero-grade stem of PIE 'earth' *dʰg̑ʰ-m- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 86-99, [Derksen 2008](src-81):545, [Boryś 2005](src-259):755).

An intensive formation to Proto-Germanic *ϸrug-. The root occasionally compared to Lith. trū́kti 'break, tear in two' (cf. [EWA 2](src-386) 813-815, but this connection is not fully certain (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1118-1119).

Comment: cf. Geiger, W. (1941): An Etymological Glossary of the Sinhalese Language. Colombo, p. 47, no.687: "The initial k for g shows Tamil influence."

Justification: This set is coded for PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'swell', whence Proto-Germanic *balgi- 'skin bag' > 'belly, stomach' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):49), Proto-Celtic *bolgo- 'sack, bag, stomach' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):70, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236). NB: Welsh: North botwm bol 'button-belly' is a calque from English belly-button.

In all likelihood the lexemes can be accounted for via PIE *h₂elbʰ-o- 'white', however the reflexes of this form are restricted to Italic, Greek, and potentially also Albanian (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):20, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):32). For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):26.

Traditionally derived to PIE *mag̑- 'to spread, smear' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 3:613, [ESSJa](src-458) 18:23-25, [LIV²](src-141) 421). Cf., however, [Derksen 2008](src-81):304 s.v. Proto-Slavic mazati 'smear, anoint' with an alternative proposed etymology to Lithuanian mė́žti 'manure, muck out', etc.

Origin uncertain. Since [Pedersen 1906](src-746):379 connected with Greek γοργός 'grim, fierce, terrible', Old Irish garg(g) 'raw, wild' (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:552, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):392), but this proposed etymology is rejected by [Beekes 2010](src-66):283, [Matasović 2009](src-50):151. Not in [Olsen 1999](src-180) or [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Comment: Pashto zanāna, must be a loan if from *gʷen-, because *ǰ > ž

perhaps PIE *li̯ú-, if *li̯ > Vedic y but Germanic l-, cf. 'liver' (if from *li̯ekʷ- ~ *li̯ep- but not *Hi̯ekʷ-); Proto-Germanic *lūs < *li̯ú-s etc. with reanalysis of the ending -s (?) (R.P.); not fully clear.
Justification: Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

The cognacy in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) to PIE *(s)teup- after [Oettinger 1979](src-649):417, 535, [Hajnal 1995](src-380):127. Note however disagreement of [Melchert 1994](src-368):242, [Neumann 2007](src-414):384-385, comparing Gk. στυφελίζω suggesting a root-variant *(s)teubʰ- (after [IEW](src-49) 1034; not in [LIV²](src-141)). According to [Beekes 2010](src-66):1418-1419, however, Gk. στυφελίζω has no secure connections outside of Greek.
Indo-Iranic lexemes probably continuing PIE ?*pē(n)s- ([EIEC](src-657) 499, but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:114-115).
Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *pē(n)s-u-ko-, for further discussion cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):398, [EIEC](src-657) 499.

Comment: (< Lat. dūcere 'to lead'?)

Justification: There are two widespread hypotheses as to the etymology of this root. It has been assumed that it is a loan from Germanic *óƀāt-. However, it seems that the exact source of this (Proto-Slavic) loanword has not been identified. There are also phonetic issues (*-o-, -ť-) which should be explained if the loanword hypothesis is accepted. Another possibility is to assume a derivation from PIE root *h₂u̯eg- 'grow, rise, become large' > PS *(o-)voktĭ > *(o-)voť-. Then the word would be related to German wachsen 'grow' etc., cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 566.
[Kroonen 2013](src-165):234 reconstructs Proto-Germanic *hnefan- as though from *knep-on-, but does not provide any cognates justifying an extra-Germanic etymology.

Perhaps cognate with Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- 'neck', although there remains some uncertainty over formal aspects of the etymology ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):162-163, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):234-235), [van Windekens 1976](src-76):225-226).

From Proto-Germanic *lūka- (with secondary lengthened grade), beside OHG liochan from Proto-Germanic *leu̯ke/a- based on PIE *leu̯g- 'lösen, brechen' (cf. [EWA 5](src-398) 1345-1347, [LIV²](src-141) 415-416. See [Seebold 1970](src-556):337 for references to older literature.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯ab/f- 'to call, utter (sing, speak, etc.)', without clear etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):401, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):94).
Learned re-introduction (or adaptation) of Ancient Greek ὑγρός 'wet', lacking the characteristic loss of initial unstressed vowels found elsewhere in Modern Greek (cf. [Andriotis 1999](src-271)).

Traditionally the words for 'louse' in Celtic and Germanic [cognate set 8267](cog-8267), Baltic [cognate set 8266](cog-8266), Slavic [cognate set 8265](cog-8265), and Indic(-Nuristani) [cognate set 7396](cog-7396) have been connected together as PIE *lū̆s (gen. *luu̯-ós) with frequent taboo deformations (so IEW 692). This may be possible, but given the wide range of unexplained sound-changes in several branches involved, it is better to split by individual branches. An exception is made for Celtic and Germanic, since their proto-forms (respectively Proto-Celtic *luwā and Proto-Germanic *lūsz, which could well be originally be an enlarged variant stem) appear to be least controversially different from the other branches compared. Cf. the standard etymological dictionaries cited in the individual classes for further discussion on the difficulties of postulating an original PIE stem accounting for all of these individual classes.

Comment: Mayrhofer (EWAia I 240) assume a relation with OInd. ū́dhan- "coldness".
Justification: A connection with Vedic ū́dhan- 'coldness' is assumed by [EWAia](src-172) I:240, but further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain unclear.

The IE root etymology of Proto-Germanic *daujan- given here follows [LIV²](src-141) to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):90-91 (but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of [Kluge 2011](src-397):919 s.v. Tod).
Loanword from Calabrian mbuttare 'throw, push, introduce'

Comment: denominal word, cf. poh "aware, intelligent"
Justification: Denominal verb based on Pashto poh 'aware, intelligent', a loanword from Lahnda *poh- which in turn continues Old Indic prabodha- 'awakening, knowledge' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):491, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):491 no. 8699).

Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.
Loanword from Italian manco 'useless' (cf. also Albanian: Arbëresh manka 'left' in [cognate set 8517](cog-8517)). [Not in [Rohlfs 1964](src-587)]

Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. There are some proposed possible cognates in Baltic, but these comparisons depend on the internal semantic reconstruction of Proto-Germanic *narwa-, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):421, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):383. The proposed cognacy to the Baltic lexemes is rejected by [ALEW](src-352) s.v. OLith. *nérti (II). In the Iranic literature, the Germanic forms are sometimes connected to Indo-Iranian *nāraka- < PIE *ner- following [IEW](src-49) 976, however this view is not followed in the most recent etymological dictionaries (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:37 s.v. nāraka- 'Hölle, Unterwelt'); cf. further discussion in [cognate set 3247](cog-3247).

Root etymology and connections outside of Italic disputed, cf. [Meiser 2002](src-738):112, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):329-330 for further discussion. For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):401.

Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.
Possibly (but not certainly) cognate with Latin grāmen 'grass' in [cognate set 8369](cog-8369). Cf. discussion in citations below.

Germanic and Celtic lexemes reflecting a u-stem noun *u̯idʰ-ú- with the zero-grade of the root. For the reconstruction given, see [ALEW](src-352) s.v. Lith. vidùs, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):585, [Matasović 2009](src-50):420.

Possibly cognate with 'bite' in [cognate set 4968](cog-4968) if IE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth' is ultimately derived from *h₁ed- *'bite' → 'eat', cf. notes to 'tooth' in [cognate set 328](cog-328) for further discussion. In any case the denominal verbs in [cognate set 4968](cog-4968) are a secondary replacement from the inherited primary verbal stem derived from *h₁ed-.
Loan from Albanian shkrumb 'black ashes, anything burned to ashes' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):423-424).
Loanword from West Germanic ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):624, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:12-15).

Comment: Cf. eDIL s.v. as-beir (www.dil.ie/4383)
Justification: A compound of Old Irish -beir 'bear, carry' (< PIE *bʰer- 'carry', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77) with the preverb ess-, es-, e-, as- 'out of' (< PIE *(h₁}eg̑ʰ-s 'out of' adv., cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) 205).

Often considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488), however the *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 789-790, [Derksen 2015](src-353):363, [EWA 3](src-441):385-388).

Perhaps a primary verbal adjective in *-to- to the IE root *(s)leup- 'schlaff herabhängen' (IEW 964f.) only otherwise attested in Germanic and Baltic, cf. [Faltings 2010](src-698):372-374. Etymology otherwise obscure.

Romance lexemes in light verb constructions using on Latin pavor 'fear' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):520, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 8:86), further probably to a root *peu̯- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):451, cf. [IEW](src-49) 827, not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Comment: Unknown etymology.
Justification: No known etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):962, cf. [HAB](src-740) I:624-625). [MM: Proto-Armenian *daṙ-in-].

Originally denominal to Classical Armenian xowpʿ-n 'cover', further etymology uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:423, [Olsen 1999](src-180):211, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):350 for various proposals). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xupʰ-].

Tocharian, Hellenic, and Albanian lexemes from PIE *sh₂eu̯- 'to rain' ([LIV²](src-141) 545, [Adams 2013](src-345):796, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1541, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):380-381, [Orel 1998](src-105):413-414); note the zero-grade of the root was *suh₂- by laryngeal metathesis ([Jasanoff 1978a](src-646):89n7, 90n11).

Etymology uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):941, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:56-57). Perhaps a blend of an Iranic loanword and an element connected to the Germanic 'neck' words according to [Pisani 1934](src-675):55, cf. [Clackson 2017](src-673):112. For further discussion cf. [HAB](src-740) and note by Macak to this class. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *par-].

Etymology outside of Italic disputed; most recently [de Vaan 2008](src-54):687-688 favours a return to an etymology to PIE *gʷelh₁- 'hit, throw' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 208, without Italic lexemes connected) as proposed by [Müller 1926](src-737):213, but rejected by [Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954](src-175) II:828. Cf. also [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):570-571. For the Romance lexemes, see [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):788.

Armenian lexemes generally connected to Germanic and Balto-Slavic lexemes for 'frozen snow' or 'hoarfrost', although the precise nominal stem formation in Armenian is not fully understood ([Olsen 1999](src-180):137, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):567-568; cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:176-177 for older proposals). Note, however, [ALEW](src-352) 1019, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):223 not do not explicitly connect the Armenian lexemes.

Possibly otherwise to be reconstructed as an s-stem neuter *kīkos-; further etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:95-96). [Matasović 2009](src-50):204 considers the words of expressive origin with an original semantic development from '(female) breast' > 'meat', although [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) considers the semantics to have developed in the opposite direction on the basis of compounds in Middle Irish.

Etymology uncertain. The etymology given by [de Vries 1977](src-468) relies on the outdated theory of root-extensions as in [IEW](src-49). Additionally, the etymological connection of the comparanda given by [de Vries 1977](src-468) are questionable (cf. s.v. Gk. ἀλθαίνω in [Beekes 2010](src-66), s.v. Ved. √ardh- in [EWAia](src-172)). Consequently, the basis upon which the traditional proposed etymology of Old Norse aldin rests, remains uncertain. Not in [Orel 2003](src-388) or [Kroonen 2013](src-165).
Continuing a derivative of Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick, club' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):350 no 6128). No certain further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) I:692, [KEWA](src-399) II:11-12).

Hellenic lexemes from the collocation σταχτή (κονία) 'distilled (ashes)', from the process of distilling ashes to produce lye (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1324), further to Ancient Greek στάζω 'drop, let fall' from PIE ?*steh₂⁽g̑⁾- (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1388, [LIV²](src-141) 592.

Comment: The Avestan context is about firewood "which is called nǝmaδka". Bartholomae (1904: 1068) connects this word to nǝmata- in comparison to Old Indic avatká- of avatá-. nǝmata- is interpreted as brushwood ('Reisig') and derived from the verbal root "nam" i.e. 'to bow'. If this is correct, the PIE origin would be the verbal root "nem".
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *namadkā-.

Romance lexemes derived from Latin coactāre 'press together' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):188-189, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:809), a derivative of Latin agere 'to drive' from PIE *h₂eg̑- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):30-31).

From Classical Armenian lełi 'gall', generally considered of uncertain etymology (cf. {ref HAB II:275), but cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):440 who suggests a reconstruction *g̑ʰelh₃iom 'yellow (substance)' > †jełi which could have been subject to a tabooistic deformation or influenced by semantically related leard 'liver'. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *leł-io-].

Traditionally derived from PIE *mud-so- ([Matasović 2009](src-50):281, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:65, [IEW](src-49) 742) in comparison to Greek μύσος 'filth', however the etymology of the Greek form is unclear (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):985).

No clear etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:42, [Matasović 2009](src-50):66; cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):103-104). For various suggestions, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:42. Root ref. form for this class follows [Matasović 2009](src-50):66.

Hellenic lexemes in the meaning 'round' as a derived relational adjective from Ancient Greek κύκλος 'circle, ring, wheel' < PIE *kʷe-kʷl-o- 'circle; wheel', a derivative to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):798-799, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388).

Two variants within Celtic: W croen points to Proto-Celtic *krokno-, while the Goidelic and Breton forms point to a variant *krokkeno- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:243-244; [Matasović 2009](src-50):226). Further etymology less certain; traditionally from an extended variant of *(s)ker- 'cut' (cf. {ref IEW 938-940), but the derivation is formally difficult (cf. the entries in Vendryes et al. and Matasović).

Comment: Iranian loanword.
Justification: Loanword from Iranic (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):906, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:195-196). [MM: Proto-Armenian *seu̯-o-/-i-].

Etymology disputed. Traditionally derived to PIE *u̯reh₁g̑- 'break, tear' ([Orel 1998](src-105):377, [LIV²](src-141) 698), but [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):994 consider this unconvincing semantically and suggest alternatively a possible connection to rā-, the suppletive aorist to Albanian bie 'hit; fall'. In either case the verb must be a *-sk̑e/o- derived present stem.

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian xmem 'to drink, to imbibe'. Further origins uncertain, probably a more recent loanword on the basis of dialectal variation but the exact source is difficult to establish ([HAB](src-740) III:122-123, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):467) Not in [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558), [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xi/um-].

From Old Irish gelach 'moon', derived to the Old Irish adj. gel 'fair, white, bright, shining' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):259-260), further to PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):156, [EIEC](src-657) 654).

While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of providing a root reference form for this cognate set, we have followed the analysis of [Beekes 2004](src-702), cf. also [Beekes 2010](src-66):470-471) s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-. For the lexemes in this class cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):259, [Beekes 2010](src-66):470-471, [ALEW](src-352) 1174-1175, [Derksen 2015](src-353):485, [Derksen 2008](src-81):513, 536. (–MJCS). The first vowel is irregularly reduced in Slavic, cf. Slavic večer- 'evening' with a regular reflex. (–LJ).

Germanic lexemes generally connected to a marginally attested strong verb *hwelban- ~ *hwelfan- ([Seebold 1970](src-556):281, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):318, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):265). The cognates within Germanic are generally connected to Gk. κόλπος 'bosom; womb; hollow space, pocket' to a reconstructable root *kʷelp- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):262; cf. also [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174), [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270), [Beekes 2010](src-66) s.v. Gk. κόλπος), although not acknowledged by [Seebold 1970](src-556). Root not in [LIV²](src-141), probably due to its marginal attestation as a strong verb in Germanic.

Originally a participle to the weak verb 'to stretch' (OE streccan), possibly to be further derived from *strak(k)a- 'tight, taut' ([Orel 2003](src-388):380), but cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):559-560, who considers that the adjective may have been back-formed from the verb. Further etymology uncertain.
Loanword from English 'to cuff', i.e. 'to strike, buffet' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Comment: Adams (1985, Die Sprache 31, p.12) “In pąsta- we have an exocentric derivative in *-to-, meaning ‘characterized by [base noun]’, regularly built on the oblique stem. For both the semantics and the morphology we might compare Latin arbor ‘tree’ and arbustum ‘vineyard planted with trees’.” He assumes a development of *poums → *pōms → *pōs, cf. EWAia II p.144 assuming a PIE *péu̯mōs.

Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic disputed; cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):336 s.v. Goth. *swinϸs. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):577-578 s.v. PGmc. *swenϸa- favours a comparison with IE *seg̑ʰ- 'overpower, seize' (LIV² 515-516), cf. ad loc. for references to further literature. For older comparisons to Lith. siunčiu 'send', cf. [IEW](src-49) 1048, reconstructing *su̯ento-, *sunto- (but qualifying the entry "nur Germ.?").
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:109 for a summary of older attempts at an etymology in [IEW](src-49).

IE root etymology unclear. [LIV²](src-141) s.v. ?*dʰreb-, considers the forms to be possibly connected with OCS drobiti 'to splinter, pulverise' but regards this connection as uncertain. [Seebold 1970](src-556) and [Kluge 2011](src-397) see no clear comparisons outside of Germanic. [Kroonen 2013](src-165) derives from via a backformation to iterative *drupp/bōn- 'to drip' and accepts a root etymology with OCS drobiti, but reconstructs from *dʰrebʰ- to avoid reconstructing PIE *b.

From Proto-Indic *vedhati 'pierces' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):701, [Strand 1998](src-431)), further to Indo-European *u̯edʰ(h₁)- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:496-497, [LIV²](src-141) 660). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Comment: Origin uncertain.
Justification: From Classical Armenian kṙowim 'to fight', denominative to kṙiw 'fight'. Further etymology uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):16, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:670-671, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):431 for various proposals). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79) [MM: Proto-Armenian *kiṙiu̯-].

Originally a derived adjective from Latin uireō 'to be green', no further etymology ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):739, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):681-682). For the Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):782.
[Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) suggests a possible loanword from Old English céce 'fauces, mouth, cheek' (> Engl. cheek).

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected since [Meillet 1936](src-644):36 to Greek χαλάω 'to slacken', but this etymology requires postulating an initial voiceless aspirate *kʰ-, and given that voiceless aspirates are no longer reconstructed for PIE this etymology should be abandoned ([Clackson 1994](src-319):144-145, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1608-1609). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xał-].
From Proto-Brythonic *oepr ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):543) or *ẹ̄pl-V- or *ẹ̄pr-V- ([Schrijver 1995](src-305):221) (the latter is preferable, BI).

Tsakonian lexemes based on a new present stem backformed from the Ancient Greek suppletive aorist stem ἔδραμον to the old present stem τρέχω ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):215-216), further to PIE *drem- 'to run' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):351, [LIV²](src-141) 128).

Armenian lexemes reflecting a root *derg̑ʰ- 'turn (oneself)' together with Albanian dreth ([Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):110-111, [LIV²](src-141) 146, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):193, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):234). Possibly a Schwebeablaut variant of *dʰre⁽g̑⁾ʰ- 'pull, drag' in which case to be further connected with 'walk' in cognate set 5824, 'run' in [cognate set 5027](cog-5027) 'pull' in [cognate set 2839](cog-2839), 'carry' in [cognate set 5330](cog-5330).

Comment: This could be the name of a specific snake. If derived from garz- 'to lament', it might a kind of viper (similar to the puff adder, e.g. the Persian False Horned Viper).

Justification: This set is coded for the Welsh botwm 'button' a loan from Middle English botoun 'button' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)). NB: Welsh: North botwm bol 'button-belly' is a calque from English belly-button.

Romance lexemes from Latin machināre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):423), a denominal verb to Latin machina 'machine, mechanical device', in turn an early loanword from (West) Greek μᾱχανᾱ́ 'id.' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):376).

Comment: The root means "to laugh". The semantic connotation to "prostitute" goes via "to flirt", i.e. "to smile at" someone.

Justification: Loan from Iranic, cf. Av. karš- 'drag, plough' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):257, [HAB](src-740) IV:562-563). [MM: Proto-Armenian *karʃ-].
Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 557-558, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):440-441. Possibly an extended form of the root *(s)ker- 'to cut', cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):487.

Loanword from Lat. asper 'rough' as a transferred adjective in the phrase nummi aspri 'rough coins', the original semantic development to 'white' appears to have been '(rough) silver' → 'silver-white' → 'white' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):223-224, [Beekes 2010](src-66):154, cf. [cognate set 1565](cog-1565)). In Italiot Greek the semantics further developed 'white' → 'white ash' → 'ash'.
From Classical Armenian kayṙi, of uncertain origin ([HAB](src-740) II:507-509, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):380). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

The Goidelic forms in this class from Old Irish bél 'lip; (pl.) mouth' are doubtlessly connected to Middle Welsh gwefl 'lip', but the reconstruction of a Proto-Celtic preform is difficult ([Matasović 2009](src-50):419), cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:29 for a survey of older, unconvincing suggestions.

Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *xand- 'to laugh' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):442-443). In view of the Nuristani cognates to this root (cf. 'laugh' in [cognate set 68](cog-68)) we reconstruct Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰand-.
A secondary formation to Welsh synnwyr 'sense, wisdom, sensibleness', borrowed from Latin sentīre 'to perceive' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236).

From Proto-Celtic *kʷrīyet- 'clay, earth, mud'; perhaps be further connected to Lat. crēta 'chalk' but further connections obscure ([Matasović 2009](src-50):182-183, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:224).

Possibly related Germanic [cognate set 647](cog-647) and Celtic [cognate set 8304](cog-8304) lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. For further discussion, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 947 (Baltic material), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1371 (Greek material), [Seebold 1970](src-556):440-441, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):458-459 (Germanic material), [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:69-70, [Matasović 2009](src-50):281 (Celtic material), [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):484 (Armenian material).

Romance lexemes from Latin portāre 'carry' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):554), further probably a denominal verb to Proto-Italic *porto/ā- 'a passage, crossing' and to PIE 1. *per- 'come through, cross' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):482-483, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 472-473).
Probably an onomatopoeic formation, but cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):522 for some proposed cognates outside of Armenian.
Denominal to Classical Armenian pʿor 'hole, cavity; belly'. Further origin unknown ([Olsen 1999](src-180):942, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:519). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰor-].
Loanword from Iranic, cf. Sogdian krm’yr 'red' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):167, [HAB](src-740) II:558-559, [Olsen 1999](src-180):887). [MM: Proto-Armenian *karmir-a-].

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek τραγῳδέω 'to take part in a tragic drama; speak in tragic style, declaim' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1442), a denominal verb to Ancient Greek τραγῳδός 'singer and dancer in the tragic choir, tragic actor'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1498 for various suggestions.

Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'spine, back' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1207). Further etymology outside of Greek disputed; older literature compares to Lith. ražis 'stubble', from a preform *urág̑ʰ-i-, although the supposition of such a form would require postulating *a ~ *ā ablaut (with a full or lengthened grade in ῥᾱχός or ῥηχός) (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1180, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):968-969, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1277-1278).

Comment: < Vedic úpaviśati 'approaches' (RV), 'sits down' (ŚB), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 105, no. 2245: "Contamination with vásati"; for Maithili cf. no. 2249
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic úpaviśati 'approaches' (RV), 'sits down' (ŚBr.), a derivative of Vedic √veś- 'to enter, enter in or settle down on, go into' and further to PIE *u̯ei̯k̑- 'to enter, step in' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):105 no. 2245, [EWAia](src-172) II:584, [LIV²](src-141) 669-670).

Hellenic lexemes from PIE *dér-mn̥ '(flayed) skin, leather' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):265-266, [Beekes 2010](src-66):318; a derivative of PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' cf. [LIV²](src-141) 119-121).

Comment: Extended root *h₁ei̯- (of the "facere" type), attested in Albanian only.

Justification: Possibly related to Celtic [cognate set 8304](cog-8304) and Armenian [cognate set 8305](cog-8305) lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible. Possibly related Germanic [cognate set 647](cog-647) and Celtic [cognate set 8304](cog-8304) lexemes meaning 'smoke', but reconciling the forms attested from different branches to a single root etymology is not currently possible.
