For further discussion, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 947 (Baltic material), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1371 (Greek material), [Seebold 1970](src-556):440-441, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):458-459 (Germanic material), [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:69-70, [Matasović 2009](src-50):281 (Celtic material), [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):484 (Armenian material).

From Proto-Germanic *slihta-, an adjective derived to the strong verb *sleikan- 'to creep, sneak' ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):512-513, [Seebold 1970](src-556):428-429), traditionally considered to be an extended form of the root *(s)lei̯- ([IEW](src-49) 663-664; cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):428-429, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):314), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 566-567 for the revised reconstruction of a separate root *(s)lei̯g̑- 'smear, make smooth'.
Derived from Classical Armenian kełt 'filth'. Further etymology obscure ([Olsen 1999](src-180):963, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:570-571). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kełt-].

Uncertain etymology. Typically explained as a blend of *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' and *dluku- 'sweet', *su̯eh₂du- 'tasty' or *saldu- 'salty' ([Clackson 2017](src-673):113, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:546). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰałtsʰ-u-(r)].

Ultimately from a diminutive formation from Ancient Greek πέσκος 'skin, rind', no clear etymology outside of Greek, cf. [Andriotis 1999](src-271):1168, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):890, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1180.

From Latin tālem 'of such kind' acc.sg., ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):705 s.v. talis), further from PIE *teh₂li- 'such', either an adjective derived to the pronominal stem *teh₂- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):605) or a univerbation of a decollective adverb *téh₂-h₁ with a deictic particle *li (so [LIPP 2](src-294) 490).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):1001 s.v. Zahl; [Kroonen 2013](src-165) postulates *dolH- following [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80) who compares the Germanic forms via ON telja, OE taljan 'to tell' with Hitt. tallii̯e/azi 'to pray, evoke (a deity)'. The connection between the Germanic words and the Hittite verb as well as Greek δόλος 'bait, trick' is accepted by [Kroonen 2013](src-165). However, the situation may be more complex with several similar roots side by side, cf. the new entry of *del(H)- ‘ziehen, anziehen’ in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) where it supposes the Hittite and Greek forms to belong together but not the other words mentioned here.
Connected to Proto-Iranic *kart- 'to cut' by some scholars, however this is difficult to justify semantically (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):243-244 for discussion and references to further literature).

Connection to a common root *gʷʰreh₁- follows [LIV²](src-141) 221 and [Beekes 2010](src-66):1121, but cf. the reservations of [EWAia](src-172) I:520. For Modern Indic lexemes attached to this set, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):244, no. 4520, p.245 no. 4531; [KEWA](src-399) I:362. For this Hellenic lexemes in this cognate set, this class encodes the compound element -φραίνομαι.

Many sources link the Slavic lexeme to PIE *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)' [LIV²](src-141). The meaning 'to heat' in Lithuanian kùrti is assumed to arise through an ellipisis of the objects in phrases like 'make a fire'. The Slavic lexeme and the Germanic ones are, however, not listed in LIV [LIV²](src-141).
Nor the Slavic lexeme, neither the possible Germanic cognates show any traces of the 'make/do' meaning. Moreover, PS *kuriti has a specified meaning and refers clearly to burning with smoke (pleas note that the Gemanic meaning referring to the 'coal' fits here semantically very well). The Baltic etymology seems to have some formal issues. It seems reasonable to join the view of [Derksen 2008](src-81) and {Kroonen 2013} and assume a root distinct from *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)', *kerH- or *kerh₃-.

Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Generally compared with Baltic material via Lith. klaũpti 'kneel down', etc. (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 364, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):229, 232), but the connection is uncertain on semantic grounds (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 502-503}).  For older hypotheses, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):259-260, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):382-383.

Welsh lexemes continuing PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):181-182, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'worm' in [cognate set 172](cog-172).

From Latin grossus 'fat, thick' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):330-331), further etymology unclear (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):273), formerly connected by [IEW](src-49) 485 with Celtic *brasso- in [cognate set 4355](cog-4355).

Romance lexemes from Latin testa '(pot)sherd, shell' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):719-720, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/1:272-283). For the semantic development, cf. similarly within Germanic: NHG Kopf 'head' < MHG kopf 'drinking vessel; skull' in [cognate set 3857](cog-3857). Latin testa 'earthenware vessel, potsherd' is may very well be a prehistoric loanword as suggested by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):617, but this hypothesis remains conjectural as there is no known candidate for a source lexeme.

Generally assumed to be a compound based on Old Irish rét 'thing' ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):290, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:22-23). Old Irish rét is occasionally compared to Sanskrit rátna- 'possession', but this etymology remains doubtful ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:22-23, [Matasović 2009](src-50):309-310, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:428-429 s.v. rátna-).
Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:13, [Matasović 2009](src-50):185); cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) for a survey of older proposals.

To be connected to the same root as Classical Armenian hogi 'spirit, soul', hewam 'I pant, puff; am breathless', probably from a formation *p⁽ʰ⁾eu̯H-io- ([Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):466, [HAB](src-740) III:115-116, [Olsen 1999](src-180):441). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).
Etymology uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:516-517, for further discussion cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):442-443). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰoʃ-i-/-o-].

Hellenic, Armenian, Baltic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃ed- 'to catch scent of (intr.), begin to smell' ([LIV²](src-141) 296, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1121, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):420, [ALEW](src-352) 1154, [Derksen 2015](src-353):482, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):425-426.  For this Hellenic lexemes in this cognate set, this class encodes the compound element *ὀσ-.

Perhaps from IE *kai̯to- ([IEW](src-49) 521) if inherited and comparable to Germanic terms found in Goth. haiϸi 'field', Engl. heath, etc. These forms are, however, restricted to Celtic and Germanic and we may be dealing with borrowing or (independent) borrowings from a prehistoric NW European substratum language (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):198).

Modern Armenian lexemes from Classical Armenian krak 'fire, flames', further origin uncertain, perhaps an Iranian loan ([HAB](src-740) II:678-679, [Olsen 1999](src-180):943), cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):378; cf. s.v. for less likely proposed Indo-European etymologies). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kur-aka-].
As though from Proto-Iranic *kāra- 'people, army' via an intermediary sense 'social group, family' > 'house', cf. Old Persian kāra- 'people, army' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):39).

Comment: The semantic development in Slavic is 'something that waves, nods' > 'plant, flower' (> 'bouquet (Czech)', 'ponytail (Polish)' etc).
Justification: The etymology suggested by [ESSJa](src-458) points to PIE *keh₂u̯- but is less convincing semantically.
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 4: 9-10; 9: 110-111, [Derksen 2008](src-81):218-219 for further discussion).
Without clear etymology outside of Germanic; proposed Baltic cognates could well be loans from Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):410; [ALEW](src-352) 878-879; cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):379-380).
No clear etymology outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):20). For older proposals to Lat. albus 'white' in [cognate set 955](cog-955), cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):100.

Arguably from the original aorist stem to the Classical Armenian suppletive present : aorist pair harkane- : har(e)-. The aorist stem may be derived from 3. *per-, cf. Lithuanian per̃ti 'hit with a bath brush', Latv. pḕrt 'hit', OCS pьrati 'hit; wash' ({ref LIV² 473, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):215-216 for further discussion). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Romance lexemes derived from Latin pēnsāre 'to weigh' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):526, [DCECH](src-423) IV:503-504), further to be connected to PIE 2. *spend- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):457, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 578).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek κοιμάομαι 'go to bed' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):690-691), a secondary denominal verbal formation from an unattested noun *κοιμή or *κοιμός to the same root as the Ancient Greek primary verbal derivative κείμαι 'to lie' from PIE *k̑ei̯- 'to lie' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):509-510, [Beekes 2010](src-66):633-634, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 320).

Comment: TJ: probably identical to set K "*men", cf. Wakhi "mak"
Justification: Etymology uncertain, perhaps related to Avestan maγa- 'cavity' + -k? (cf. {MacKenzie 1990}:115).
As though from Latin *mūkyāre, a denominal verb from a stem *mūc- (cf. Old Irish múchaim 'I hide'), cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443):6/3:197, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):471).

Root only found in Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):381-382, [LIV²](src-141) 316-317, cf. also discussion in [ALEW](src-352) 409-410). For the Slavic forms in this class the initial consonant is a part of a prefix (*ot-), which was subsequently was morphologically re-interpreted in the history of Slavic (*ot-jut- > *o-tjut- > *o-ťut-).

From the original aorist stem to the Classical Armenian suppletive present : aorist pair harkane- : har(e)- (cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):471). The aorist stem may be derived from 3. *per-, cf. Lithuanian per̃ti 'hit with a bath brush', Latv. pḕrt 'hit', OCS pьrati 'hit; wash' ({ref LIV² 473, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):215-216 for further discussion). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek ἀέρας, a new α-stem morphologically remodelled from Ancient Greek ἀήρ, ἀέρος 'mist, haze, clouds, atmosphere', and ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eu̯s-er- ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):70, [Beekes 2010](src-66):27).

Formerly connected to Gk. ἔρχομαι 'go' via *r̥gʰ- (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:15-16, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):285), now a separate root *h₁erg̑ʰ- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 238-239, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):548-550).
Etymology unlikely to be with Iranic *nā̆xa- as Persian nāxun ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):56).

Extra-Germanic connections uncertain. Often compared to Lith. mìlšti(s) and other Balto-Slavic forms with various degrees of confidence of the etymology (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):255, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):403). [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):453 suggests possibly related ('eventuell'). No lemma for Lith. mìlšti(s) in [ALEW](src-352) or [Derksen 2015](src-353).
Light verb construction, literally 'to make wind' with semantic head bād 'wind' a loanword from from Persian (cf. [cognate set 3436](cog-3436)).

Romance lexemes from Latin spissus 'laborious, slow, dense' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):674). Further etymology uncertain; generally compared to the family of lexemes around Greek σπίδιος 'extensive, wide' and Lithuanian 'swarm (of bees)' (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):643, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):581). The proposed Baltic connections should be rejected because the root requires an unvoiced dental and is semantically remote (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 959). The proposed Greek connections might still be possible, but the original semantics of the forms are uncertain (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1382).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974), cf. Kâta-vari: Eastern: kâk′ok puṇuk [?] which is however sorted under puṇuk < *puṇra-.

Justification: Denominal verbs to Albanian mend 'mind', a borrowing from Latin mentem 'mind' (acc.sg.) ([Meyer 1891](src-585):274, [Huld 1984](src-571):91, [Orel 1998](src-105):256).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *legʰ- 'to lie (oneself) down' via Slavic *ob-log- 'wrap, belay' (cf. [Rejzek 2001](src-593):419, [ESSJa](src-458) 28:17-18, [LIV²](src-141) 398-399).

Comment: probably related with Parthian wiδān "tent"

Justification: Traditionally considered a derivative of a putative PIE *(s)plei̯g̑ʰ- 'spread the legs' according to [IEW](src-49) 1000, but the proposed cognates justifying this root reconstruction are very uncertain (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:131-132, [KEWA](src-399) II:387, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1211).
From PIE *treu̯d- 'to strike' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):630, [LIV²](src-141) 651-652; cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):704).
Probably to be derived to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):626-628, [Adams 2013](src-345):626-628, with references to further literature), but not fully certain (Ron Kim, p.c.).

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit śuṇḍā- 'elephant's trunk' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):725, no. 12516). Further etymology uncertain; probably a loanword from a non-Indo-European source (cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:354 for discussion of various proposals).
Etymology unlikely to be with Iranic *nā̆xa- as Persian nāxun ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):56).
No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:58); [LIV²](src-141) 456 mechanically reconstructs PIE ?2. *neu̯d- 'stoßen' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 767).

Albanian and Italic derivatives from PIE *lei̯g̑- 'to bind'. In this set only Albanian lidh may be a primary verbal derivative, while the Italic and Romance forms probably denominal in origin ([LIV²](src-141) 403, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):86-87, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):242-243, [Orel 1998](src-105):226-227, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):341, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):407-408).

Comment: Cf. Lith. pur̃vas 'dirt', Latv. pùrvs 'swamp'
Justification: No certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 404, 829).

From Old Irish olc and generally further connected with PIE *u̯ĺ̥kʷo- 'wolf' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):400, [McCone 1985](src-760):173–175; cf. also [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:20 for references to older literature).
Loanword from Italian foglietto 'slip, small piece of paper'.

Lexemes derived from the Proto-Germanic. strong verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke' ([Seebold 1970](src-556)379-380, [Kluge 2011](src-397):748, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):406, 410). No further accepted etymology outside of Germanic, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 299](cog-299).

The origin is obscure. It could be derived from an onomatopoeic interjection. An areal spreading is also not to be excluded. It can not be even assumed that the lexeme or the interjection it is hypothetically derived from had been present already in Proto-Slavic. Cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 13:81, 139, [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 3:160, 167-170, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 2:433-434 for further discussion. [Cf. also Indic *kutta- in [cognate set 1599](cog-1599), Iranic *kuti- in [cognate set 3186](cog-3186)].
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian плива 'to swim'.

Hellenic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes traditionally reconciled to a basic root *lei̯- 'smooth', although the Celtic forms here may also require s-mobile (cf. ([IEW](src-49) 662-664, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):103, [Matasović 2009](src-50):346, [Beekes 2010](src-66):844, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):336-337). The Germanic forms derived from PIE *slei̯g̑- 'smear, make smooth' in [cognate set 8680](cog-8680) might be an extended form of this root. See further discussion in that cognate class.

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek ὀμαλός 'equal, level, smooth' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):973), further to be considered a derivative of PIE *sem-, cf. Ancient Greek ὀμός 'common, one and the same, equal, similar, level' < *som-o- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):799-800, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1074-1075).

Comment: For the discussion on the further etymology of PS *koza and its relationship to PIE *ag̑- (cf. Old Indic ajā́) see [ESSJa](src-458): 12: 19-21 and 1: 103-104.
Justification: Lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *koza 'goat', and originally in the sense 'goat leather'; further etymology uncertain but probably a Turkic loanword ([Derksen 2008](src-81):242, [ESSJa](src-458) 12:35-36).

From Latin mūsculus 'muscle' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):476), a derivative of Latin mūs 'mouse', from PIE *mūs, (gen. mūsós) (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):424, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):396-397). Precise stem analysis difficult; the attested languages consistently show a non-ablauting nom.sg. *mūs, but it is unclear whether this is inherited as such from PIE, or the result of secondary compensatory lengthening from laryngeal loss (e.g., [de Vaan 2008](src-54):396-397 assuming a stem *muH-, cf. also [EIEC](src-657) 387 assuming *mūs < *mus-s).

Russian glaz 'eye' has without any doubt a PS origin (*glazŭ '(small, round,) smooth stone' with a semantic development that has parallels in Slavic, cf. Russian expressive šary 'eyes' < 'ball(s)' or Polish expressive gały 'eyes' < 'ball(s)'). However, the further etymology is uncertain.

Etymology in this class follows [NIL](src-274) 122-124; traditionally (but dubiously) connected to Greek τυφλός 'blind' ([IEW](src-49) 264, followed by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:210-211, [Matasović 2009](src-50):107-108, against which cf. [NIL](src-274) 123n4).
Etymologically obscure (cf. [Henning 1971](src-681):29).
Probably a loan from Persian xandīdan 'laugh' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):95).

Comment: The Persian develoment would have been *siš < *ϑiš < *k̑u̯is or *ϑiš < *siš < *k̑u̯is, cf. Klingenschmitt (2000: 202).
Horn (1893: 85) suggests a relation to Avestan tauruna- "young", Old Indic táruṇa- "jung, zart" (probably via "fresh"). Kurdish and Kumzari suggest a simplification of *rn > r.

Justification: Albanian lexemes generally connected with PIE *bʰerh₁g̑- 'shine, gleam' ([LIV²](src-141) 92), but the precise stem derivation is uncertain (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):27, [Huld 1984](src-571):40, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):90-91, [Orel 1998](src-105):17, [Holm 2011](src-130):88-89).
No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Seebold 1970](src-556):162).
May go back to a root etymon *lei̯g- if connected with Baltic words connected with Lith. lýgus 'even, flat, similar' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):336-337, [ALEW](src-352) 584-586).

Generally derived from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, consider' ([LIV²](src-141) 141-142, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):132-133, [Orel 1998](src-105):64-65, [Holm 2011](src-130):68-69, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):969).
Loanword from Calabrian Italian manca 'left-hand' (cf. also Greek: Italiot μανκούσο 'left' in [cognate set 6082](cog-6082)).

From Old Irish caithid 'use, spend; hurl, throw'; the diverse semantics of the verb make the etymology difficult to explain. Probably further connected to Gaulish cateia, glossed in Servius's commentary to the Aeneid (7.741) as a 'tela gallica' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:24; cf. [Delamarre 2003](src-157):110).

Romance lexemes from Latin mansio 'a staying, a remaining; lodging' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):433, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 6/1:234). Further to PIE 2. *men- 'stay, wait' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):362, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 437).
Loan from Romance *era < Latin āēr ([Meyer 1891](src-585):96, [Huld 1984](src-571):62, [Orel 1998](src-105):89).

A European isogloss with proposed cognates also in Italic and Slavic; cf. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):212-213 for further discussion. The Germanic forms in this class may go back to Proto-Germanic *salwo- as though from PIE *solH-u̯o- (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):466-467, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):425), while the Celtic forms require a Proto-Celtic derived stem *salāko- (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:15-16, [Matasović 2009](src-50):319).
Loan from Middle Low German scharp, scherp 'sharp' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):806).
Etymology outside of Goidelic uncertain. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):104 proposed an etymology to a root *krei̯- 'split', but this was rejected by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:222.

Comment: Wakhi šiš might belong here as well. The assimilation of siš > šiš is frequently attested (for Balochi examples cf. Korn 2005: 180).

Justification: Indic lexemes from Vedic jáṅghā- 'leg', further derived from PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ([EWAia](src-172) I:564, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):280 no. 5082, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 175–176).
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 522-523, [Derksen 2015](src-353):219, 256-257 for further discussion.

Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic takrá- 'buttermilk with a third part of water' (n.), *'bitter' (adj.) with further semantic developments 'sour' > 'rotten' > 'old' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):319, no. 5617), further to Vedic √tañc- 'to coagulate' from PIE *tenk- ([EWAia](src-172) I:611-612, 614-165).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 572-573; cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):354-355, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1012-1013, [EWAia](src-172) II:769-770, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):39, [Cheung 2007](src-83):348-349, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):411, [Matasović 2009](src-50):348).
Loan from Latin *camba ~ gamba 'leg' ([Huld 1984](src-571):80, [Orel 1998](src-105):177, [Holm 2011](src-130):63).
Loanword from Romance *manctus ([Orel 1998](src-105):242). On the semantic development within Romance from Latin mancus 'maimed, crippled' > 'left', cf. discussion in [cognate set 2071](cog-2071).

Possibly to be connected with PIE *s⁽k̑⁾eH- in [cognate set 7189](cog-7189), but the stem-formation in Celtic is difficult to reconcile (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):342-343, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).
Sabellic lexemes continuing a comparative formation derived to PIE *(h₁)ner- ([Untermann 2000](src-279):492-493, Scarborough, p.c.).

Romance lexemes as though from Latin *captiāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):157), a secondary derivative from Latin capiō 'to take', ultimately from PIE *keh₂p- 'grasp, snatch' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):89-90, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 344-345).

Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain; possibly further to IE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom, blossom' (so [IEW](src-49) 122, [Matasović 2009](src-50):61; cf. 'leaf' in [cognate set 252](cog-252), but rejected by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:50-51, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):75). The proposed connection with Latin folium 'leaf' is uncertain (cf. 'leaf' in [cognate set 8247](cog-8247)).

PS *rępŭ does not have any certain further IE etymology and cognates. In any case, I do not see any serious reason to treat PS the lexemes with the meaning 'tail' and lexemes referring to various creaky or crackling sounds as two separate etymona. Note that reflexes of *rępiti refer often to playing string instruments (and especially bowed string instruments) and there are also some attestations referring to whiping. That makes, in my opinion, a very good link to 'tail'. We have doubltess an ideophonic root here.

Comment: original meaning "to sting, stab"; Cheung (2007: 362) translates with "game; entertainment; joke" (probably: stab > kill while hunting > game > play) and considers the possibility of a loanword.

Justification: IE root etymology disputed. Two main possibilities: Either to (1) PIE *h₂enh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 297-298, so [Huld 1984](src-571):63, [Orel 1998](src-105):91, and others), or (2) to PIE *h₂ei̯d- ([LIV²](src-141) 258-259, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):256-257, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):171-172).
Etymology uncertain (for various proposals cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):442-443, [DCECH](src-423) III:878-881).

Origin uncertain. Of unknown origin according to [Olsen 1999](src-180):936. Some Caucasian parallels exist (Archi гьоти 'grass', Udi xod 'tree') although [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):342-343 rather consider it more likely that these are loans from Armenian. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *xot-o-].

Comment: cf. MP kumīg "stomach"
Derivation within (and therefore further connections outside of) Germanic uncertain.
Justification: Connections outside of Germanic uncertain. Frequently considered a derivative of the strong verb *hinϸan- 'grasp, seize' with the original sense of the word being *'grabber', but there are no clear morphological parallels for the stem formation, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):255-256, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):176-177, [Kluge 2011](src-397), [Kroonen 2013](src-165):207-208, 227 for further discussion.
Loan from Turkish keskin 'sharp' (cf. [Dawkins 1916](src-452):684).

Comment: cf. Proto-Indo-Iranian *dʱā́rā- f. 'blade, cutting edge' > Vedic dhā́rā- f. 'id.'; cf. Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 789; parallel Indic noun to adjective derivations
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic dhā́ra- 'blade (of a sword, knife)' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):389 no. 6793), further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰā́rā- 'id.', but without certain comparisons outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:789).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic síndhu- 'river; the Indus', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):774 no. 13415, [EWAia](src-172) II:729-730).

Continuing Proto-Germanic *flaka- 'flat'. Traditionally considered to be a *-g- extended form of the root *pelh₂- (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):199), alternatively [Kroonen 2013](src-165):143-144 proposes cognacy to Greek πλάξ, -ακός 'plane, plain; flat stone, board table' < *pl̥k-; Lithuanian plãkanas, Latvian plakans 'flat' < *plokono- (cf. also [ALEW](src-352) 785-786, reconstructing *pleh₂k- 'mit flacher Hand schlagen, klatschen').

Uncertain origin. Possibly an Iranian loanword (perhaps) via (inner-Armenian) *ba(δ)r-ii̯o/a- (cf. Skt. bhadrá- 'blessed, fortunate; happy; Av. hu-baδra- 'extremely happy'); cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):436. Cf. [HAB](src-740) I:422-424. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *bar-i̯o-].

Comment: Bailey (1979: 19b)  connects this word to Saka ā̮ye 'ground, sole of foot' from āy- with Av. āi. He mentions a reconstruction by Morgenstierne (1942) proposed for NP xāk from *āhaka- 'ashes', which is followed by Klingenschmitt (2000: 213, fn.77).

Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *√tej- 'to sharpen' from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'prick, be sharp' ([EWAia](src-172) I: 645, 668-669, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 592-593). For Middle and Modern Indic lexemes attached to this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):332-333, no. 5839.

The sources are, in general, consistent as to further IE cognates of PS *gniti 'rot'. A minor formal issue is, however, the reconstruction of the underlying PIE root. In [Derksen 2008](src-81) a form with initial *g̑ʰ- is given, the other sources give a form with *gʰ-, e.g. [ESSJa](src-458): 177, [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 205, [Boryś 2005](src-259): 168, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 1: 153, cf. also [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 183. A question is, if PS *znojĭ 'heat, sweat' is related. If so, a variation *g̑ʰ- / *gʰ- should be assumed, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81): 546, [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 740, [Boryś 2005](src-259): 744.

Previously considered without a clear etymology by [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:164-165), see now [LIV²](src-141) 538-539, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):605-607, [Matasović 2009](src-50):360 to PIE *seu̯h₁- 'incite, set in motion'.

From PIE *meu̯h₂ or *meu̯h₃- according to [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):587-588 (cf. Gk. μῡ́ω 'to close the eyes'; [Oettinger 1979](src-649):161ff.); the proposed Greek comparandum is listed under ?*meu̯s- in [LIV²](src-141) (only Greek), and may formally reflect either *meu̯H- or *meu̯s- (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):988).

Comment: not found in Korn 2005, onset speaks in favour of a loanword

Justification: From PIE *(s)lei̯-, perhaps via an extended variant *(s)lei̯b- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 566 s.v. ?*(s)lei̯b- 'scheifen, gleiten', only Germanic), cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:134, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):458, [Matasović 2009](src-50):239, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236).
A loanword from Dardic languages ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):47, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):637, no. 10991 *laṣṭi- 'stick').
As though from Latin *trīnicāre 'divide into three' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:277-285). Further to PIE *trei̯- 'three' (cf. [cognate set 146](cog-146)).

Indic lexemes, probably originally *lavaná- 'cutting' derived to Vedic √lav- 'cut' < PIE *leu̯H- 'cut off, release' ([EWAia](src-172) II:475-476, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 417). For the Middle and Modern Indic forms attached to this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):637, no. 10978.

From Proto-Iranic *tanč- 'to twist (together), become narrow, dense, constrict', further to PIE *temk- 'to become firm, coagulate' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):377-378, [LIV²](src-141) 625, cf. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):82).
Loan from Italian liscio 'smooth'.

NB: The Hittite lexeme is somewhat dubious in this meaning (cf. [CHD P](src-404), s.v.); Etymology unclear: According to [HED PA](src-412), from the same stem as Hitt. partāu̯ar 'wing' from PIE *(s)per- in [cognate set 5101](cog-5101), cf. also cautiously Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, p.506; however unconnected by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):646-647.
To be connected with Old Irish uis 'sweet, suitable, appropriate', but further etymology obscure ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:21-22).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic nāḍī́- 'tubular stalk of any plant' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):404-405, no. 7047). Further etymology difficult, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:127-129 for various possibilities.

The original meaning was 'a part of the body an animal can chase away (literally 'sweep away') insects with', cf. direct attestations of this motivation in [ESSJa](src-458) 28:141-142. There is no commonly accepted etymology outside of Slavic; all further proposals have formal issues ([Derksen 2008](src-81):389, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):440, cf. also [Boryś 2005](src-259):406-407, [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 4:897-898, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

Derived from Old Irish cas 'curly, woven, twisted'; formerly proposed to PIE *kes- 'to comb' (so [IEW](src-49) 585, but the -a- vocalism is difficult to account for ([Matasović 2009](src-50):194; cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:44-45 for a survey of earlier hypotheses.

Traditionally to PIE *sem- 'one, a unity' (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):715, with references to earlier literature), but alternatively to PIE *(s)k̑ens- (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):925-926, [EWAia](src-172) II:836). The traditional etymology is not impossible, although the initial ṣ- is unexpected, and does not account for the root final *-s- (Ron Kim, p.c.), therefore the latter etymology is more preferable.

Armenian denominal verbs from Classical Armenian ors 'hunt, catch; hunted animal, game'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with Greek πόρκος 'a kind of fish trap' (cf. {HAB} III:588, [Olsen 1999](src-180):13), but disputed by others (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):164 and [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):544 for further discussion and alternative propsals). [MM: Proto-Armenian *ors-].

Romance lexemes from Latin occīdere 'strike down, knock down' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):495), possibly further to PIE *kh₂ei̯d- 'hit, beat' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 360, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):79-80) for further discussion).
Connections outside of Albanian uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):120, [Orel 1998](src-105):481, [Holm 2011](src-130):55-56 for various attempts at an IE root etymology and further discussion.

Comment: complex verb, no etymological information on Sarikoli 'kat' in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007); maybe metathesis < *tak ?

Justification: Probably a loanword from Dravidian, cf. Tamil kaluḻ- 'become turbid', Kannada kaluhe 'dirt' ([KEWA](src-399) I:182).

The history of the Slavic lexeme(s) for 'shadow' is complicated. It can not be excluded that we deal here with one single etymon. However, we had to assume irregular phonetic changes, contaminations and taboo-deformation in this case. It is also possible that we deal here with two or three independent etyma even from the most deep etymology perspective. Only PS *sěnĭ has a convincing further IE etymology and cognates that are relatively unproblematic from the phonetic point of view. PS *těnĭ and *stěnĭ can be derivatives of / results of a contamination with PIE *temH- 'dark' [LIV²](src-141): 624 or PIE *stei̯h₂- 'stiffen' < probably PIE *steh₂- 'stand' [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 472.

Celtic and Indic lexemes from a root *g̑ʰers-/*g̑ʰres- ([EWAia](src-172) II:823), traditionally considered to be derived from an s-extended form of the root *g̑ʰer- 'short, small, slight' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 443, [de Bernardo Stempel 1999](src-733):68n57; not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)).

Comment: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974), surely identical with Wakhi bayd; cf. Arabic beyt "verse (consisting of two half verses)"

Justification: Attestation restricted to West Germanic, without clear comparisons outside of Germanic (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):406, [Kluge 2011](src-397):794).
Loanword from Latin sella 'seat, saddle' ([Orel 1998](src-105):407).
For the root ref. form as *(s)k̑eNs- with s-mobile, cf. discussion in [cognate set 5451](cog-5451).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 19b)  connects this word to Saka ā̮ye 'ground, sole of foot' from āy- with Av. āi. He mentions a reconstruction by Morgenstierne (1942) proposed for NP xāk from *āhaka- 'ashes', which is followed by Klingenschmitt (2000: 213, fn.77).
Justification: Identical to a word for 'ashes' with special development of the semantics
Etymology unknown. [Melchert 1994](src-368):132 compares Lat. surcus 'twig, sprout', but [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):792-793 argues that the Latin comparandum is a ghost word.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek χονδρός 'granular, coarse' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1604-1605). Further etymology unexplained, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1268-1269, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1643 for various hypotheses.

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed [LIV²](src-141). Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66). I assume the root *peu̯H-, cf. PG *fūla- 'filthy, foul' [Kroonen 2013](src-165). The meaning 'dust' could develop from 'rotten wood'. Cf. [Rejzek 2001](src-593).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *deh₁- 'to bind' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):321-322, [LIV²](src-141) 102, cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):338).

Of uncertain origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):942), traditionally connected with Proto-Slavic *bedro- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 96, [HAB](src-740) IV:101, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):642). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *port-o-].
From Ancient Greek ἀ-κάθαρτος 'un-cleansed' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):604); no further etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):478-479; [Beekes 2010](src-66):614-615)

Italiot τσ̌υλι(μ)μένο (< *κυλι(σ)μένος), the passive participle of τσ̌υλίω /τσ̌υλλίτζω ‘to roll (on a dirty surface), to make dirty’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c., cf. [Rohlfs 1964](src-587):282-283). Further etymology disputed: possibly to IE *kʷel(h₁)- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):598, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388), but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):800, who sees the word based on a substratum borrowing.
Internal reconstruction points to a root *tu̯eh₂p-, *ti̯eh₂p- or *⁽k̑⁾i̯eh₂p- ([LIV²](src-141) 361 reconstructs *Ki̯eh₂p-), but no cognates are known outside of Greek ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1324).

The IE root etymology for this class is disputed. It seems equally plausible that the Italic forms from Lat. folium can go with either the Germanic and Greek words for 'leaf' from *bʰleh₃- in [cognate set 252](cog-252), or with the Celtic words for 'leaf' from *dʰal(h₁)- in [cognate set 1025](cog-1025); cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):244; [de Vaan 2008](src-54):230. For the Romance lexemes in this class cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):293-294.
Loanword from Modern Persian γaš(š) 'stupor, deceiving'(?) ([Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):37).
Loanword from Latin sella 'seat, saddle' ([Orel 1998](src-105):407).
Parallel loans from Arabic خراب / kharāb 'destruction, ruin' (via Persian?).
Loanword from Persian rušt 'brightly coloured' ([Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):69).

The Hittite stem is paradigmatically suppletive; this cognate set is coded for 3.sg.pres.act. tēzzi < *dʰeh₁-ti ≠ ter-/tar- (< PIE *ter- 'to speak'), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):857–858, 870–871; [LIV²](src-141) 136-138.
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *seh₁dʰ- 'to reach the goal, be successful' ([EWAia](src-172) II:722-723, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):773 no. 13401, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 517).

Etymology outside of Anatolian disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in [cognate set 7599](cog-7599) ([LIV²](src-141) 229, [Adams 2013](src-345):107, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. [Adams 2013](src-345):107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.

From Classical Armenian šowkʿ 'shadow', further etymology uncertain ([HAB](src-740) III:541, cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):595 for a more recent proposal). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), no etymology given in [Olsen 1999](src-180):17. [MM: Proto-Armenian *ʃukʰ-o-].

Etymology uncertain. [HED A+E/I](src-406):260-261 suggests to *ei̯-gʰ- ([IEW](src-49) 296) : Lith. eigà 'a going', Gk. οἴχομαι 'go off, be gone', ἴχνος 'footstep, track', TochB yku 'gone', thus egdu < *ei̯gʰ-tu- 'a going' > 'leg' by metonymy, but this is speculative. No lemma in [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80).

Generally considered a loanword from South Slavic, possibly via the Ikavian dialect of Serbo-Croatian ([Jokl 1923](src-751):177, 187-188, [Orel 1998](src-105):229, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):247), but cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):87 who proposes an IE etymology. (Not in [Demiraj 1997](src-369)).

Etymology disputed. In spite of phonological and morphological difficulties, generally connected to Tocharian lexemes in [cognate set 7599](cog-7599) ([LIV²](src-141) 229, [Adams 2013](src-345):107, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):542-543). The reconstruction *h₁ai̯-, however, is unusual from the reconstructed *-a- in the root. *h₂ei̯- would work for the Tocharian lexemes, but initial or medial *h₂ should have been preserved as -ḫḫ- in Hittite, and therefore this reconstruction is unsatisfactory. [Adams 2013](src-345):107 reconstructs a root *h₄ei̯-, but the reconstruction of a phoneme *h₄ (an a-colouring laryngeal which left no traces in Hittite) is not commonly accepted. In view of the phonological difficulties in connecting of the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):614-616 prefers to split the Anatolian cognates as a derivative of Hitt. ēpp-/app- 'seize' with an ablauting suffix *-ói̯-/-i-´ (i.e. 3.sg. h₁p-ói̯-ei, 3.pl. *h₁p-i-énti). While the semantic connection between the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes for a root 'give' is tempting, the difficulties of reconciling the root etymology from a phonological and morphological point of view, it is methodologically more preferable to split the Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes into separate cognate sets. Proposed cognacy between the two classes has been set at 4/6 – small majority view.

Latin cōgitō 'to think, consider', a derived frequentative/intensive form of Latin agō 'to drive' < PIE *h₂eg̑- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):15-18, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):30-31). For the Romance forms in this class cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:838-842, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):192.

Comment: From Lat. narrāre.
Justification: Romance lexemes from Latin narrāre 'to relate, tell' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):481), further to PIE *g̑neh₃- 'know' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):267, [LIV²](src-141) 168-170).
Parallel loans from Turkish pis 'filthy, dirty'.
Loanword from Tajik vayron 'destroyed, devestated', cf. Middle Persian awērān "devastated".

Comment: Sanskritisms, cf. Old Bengali chāa ~ chāva 'shade', Hindi chāī̃, see Turner 1962-66, p. 257f., no. 5027
Justification: Parallel loans from Sanskrit chāyā- 'shadow'.

Romance lexemes from Latin mancus 'maimed, crippled' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):431), perhaps further derived from Latin manus 'hand' in [cognate set 888](cog-888) (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):382, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):361 for further discussion).
Probably based on a loanword from Latin crucem 'crosswise, askew' ([Orel 1998](src-105):183); earlier [Meyer 1891](src-585):188 supposed a loan from Latin cortīna 'round vessel, cauldron'.

The history of the Slavic lexeme(s) for 'shadow' is complicated. It can not be excluded that we deal here with one single etymon. However, we had to assume irregular phonetic changes, contaminations and taboo-deformation in this case. It is also possible that we deal here with two or three independent etyma even from the most deep etymology perspective. Only PS *sěnĭ has a convincing further IE etymology and cognates that are relatively unproblematic from the phonetic point of view. PS *těnĭ and *stěnĭ can be derivatives of / results of a contamination with PIE *temH- 'dark' [LIV²](src-141): 624 or PIE *stei̯h₂- 'stiffen' < probably PIE *steh₂- 'stand' [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 472.
Loanword from Latin saburra 'sand; ship's ballast' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):420, [Orel 1998](src-105):527).

Modern Greek and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷei̯- 'to gather, pile' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 378-379, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):458, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1216, [Derksen 2008](src-81):89, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:112-115).

Slavic innovation (maybe taboo-motivated) without certain etymology. There are two most popular hypotheses on its etymology: 1) *demh₂- 'build' > 'wood used/good for building' > 'oak'; 2) *dʰu̯eh₂- 'smoke' > 'dark' > 'tree with dark wood'. [ESSJa](src-458) links it to *dʰeu̯b- 'deep' > 'lowland tree'. None of the versions seems to be really convincing.

Comment: Loan from Turkish
Justification: Loanword from Turkish kafa 'back of the head' ([Huld 1984](src-571):106, [Orel 1998](src-105):353, [Holm 2011](src-130):72-73).

Of uncertain etymology ([Olsen 1999](src-180):963, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:556-557), but cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540) considering a possible Iranian loanword, following the suggestion of [Bailey 1979](src-320):65. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).

Romance lexemes from Latin iocāri 'to joke, jest' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):374, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 5:36-41), a denominal verb to Latin iocus 'joke, jest' and further to PIE *i̯ek- 'speak' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):308, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 311).

Comment: lex., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3228; Prakrit kuḍa- m. 'tree'

Justification: Lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ([LIV²](src-141) 439-440). Note that the semantic extension 'to disappear' as a euphemism 'to die' appears to be a post-Anatolian innovation, where the Hittite cognate mer-/mar- retains the original meaning 'to disappear' (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):8).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974)
Justification: Etymology uncertain. [Not in [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325)].
Loanword (source?), well attested among Pamir languages; cf. Nuristani Vâsi-vari: Paṣki "li-" [cognate set 7909](cog-7909). Cf. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):42.
Possibly a loan from Indic? (cf. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):62).
Loanword from Persian سایه / sāyeh 'shadow'.

Always written using the Sumerograms LÚ.ŠU.GI, but probably to be related to Hitt. mēḫur 'time, period', from which a stem *meḫuu̯ant- can be reconstructed on the basis of derived vocabulary ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):568-569, cf. derived factitive verb meḫuu̯andaḫḫ- 'to make old; to age', etc.). Further root etymology disputed. According to [Eichner 1973](src-641):53-107, ultimately to PIE *meh₂- 'to be at the right time'; [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):567-568 to *mei̯h₂- 'disappear' (= [LIV²](src-141) 1. *mei̯H- 'gering werden, verschwinden sein'), or to *meh₁- 'measure' (semantically better, but formally more difficult). [Yakubovich 2011](src-642):277-279 argues to *meh₁-, with the presence of Hitt. -ḫ- explained by secondary epenthesis.

Lit. 'to throw, cast out'. Cognacy is coded for the verbal head cuir 'throw' from Old Irish -cuirethar (cf. eDIL); synchronically suppletive to fo·ceird 'throw' within Irish but from the same Indo-European root ([LIV²](src-141) 353-355, cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):401-403), for older hypotheses cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:276-277.

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66).

Comment: Schmitt (2014: 278): "Offenbar handelt es sich um eine jüngere Ersatzbildung für ein Erbwort und am wahrscheinlichsten um eine -ka-Ableitung von heteroklitischem *vaz-r̥/*vaz-n- „Kraft, Größe“; es gehört dann letztlich zu der Wurzel idg. *u̯eǵ „kräftig sein/werden“." Schmitt emphasises that connections to vazra- "weapon" are to be discarded.

Justification: Perhaps PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the BSl. acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):243, [Derksen 2015](src-353):231-232), but connections outside of Balto-Slavic ultimately uncertain; perhaps PIE *kʷend- according to [ALEW](src-352), but likewise extra-Balto-Slavic connections uncertain. Cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 12:65-66.

Origin uncertain, traditionally connected with PIE *peh₂u̯- 'few; little', but the connection is phonetically difficult to justify (cf. discussion in [Olsen 1999](src-180):165). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰokʰ-u-(r)].

Romance lexemes from Latin eruncāre ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):258), further to PIE *h₃reu̯k- 'to dig, pluck (out)' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):530, [LIV²](src-141) 307).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed  [LIV²](src-141). Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66).

Romance lexemes from Latin pulsāre 'to strike, beat' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):566-567), secondary from Latin pellere 'beat against, push, strike', further to PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):455-456, [LIV²](src-141) 470-471).

Root etymology disputed. Either to *h₁es- 'throw' ([LIV²](src-141) 2. *h₁es-; cf. [Kimball 1987](src-725); [Kimball 1999](src-726):215, 391; [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):670-671 with references to earlier literature), alternatively others (cf. [Melchert 1994](src-368):133) see a connection with the Hittite verb šii̯e/a- 'to shoot' and šai- 'to press' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 1. *seh₁(i̯)-). Cf. also [HED PE, PI, PU](src-413) 27-37, Tischler, Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar, Vol. 2, pp.581-584.
Loanword from Italian mangiare 'to eat'.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, to chop' ([LIV²](src-141) 555, [Derksen 2008](src-81):233, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:18-20).
Etymology uncertain, doubtful suggestion as though from Proto-Iranic ?*xā(ha)xa- by [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):79.
Parallel loans from Persian صاف / sāf 'smooth', ultimately from Arabic.
Loanword from Calabrian Italian uχχare 'to blow up, swell'.

A derivative from Latin marcere 'be withered' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):436), perhaps further to PIE *merk- if related to Vedic √marc- 'damage, hurt' and Hittite markii̯e/a- 'to disapprove of, refuse' (so [de Vaan 2008](src-54):364-365), but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:323-324, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):559).

Latin and Romance lexemes derived from PIE *peh₂u̯- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):448, 450-451, although note that Catalan poc directly continues Latin paucus 'few, small in number', not Latin paruus 'small' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):519).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed  [LIV²](src-141). Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'to tear (up)' ([LIV²](src-141) 510, [Derksen 2008](src-81):442).

Romance lexemes from Latin lanceāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):396), a denominal verb to Latin lancea 'lance'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly a Celtic loanword ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):339-340).
No clear etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):389, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):555. For older proposed connections to Baltic material, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):525.

Comment: cf. Khowar tseq and Khotanese d͜ze̤i̯ṇa; maybe same stem but different suffix? Some West Iranic languages have diminutive suffixes with -l-. (Wakhi ʒ seems to stand for d͜z)
no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974)

Justification: Loan from Venetian.
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi čʹum 'skin, hide'.

A denominal formation originating in Middle English. There are some possible correspondences, cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):57 for some proposals and references to older literature, but ultimately no clear etymology outside of Germanic. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):74-75 does not provide comparanda to support a root reconstruction *bʰreh₁- (not in [LIV²](src-141)).
Loanword from either Italian or Venetian mosca 'fly'.

Romance lexemes from Latin sabulum 'sand' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):619). Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.

Generally derived from PIE *h₁ep- 'grasp, seize' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):79, [Orel 1998](src-105):157, [Holm 2011](src-130):64, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):978, [LIV²](src-141) 237); perhaps further connected to Anatolian lexemes in [cognate set 7598](cog-7598) if the etymology of [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):614-616 is correct, but this remains disputed (cf. notes in that class).

Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 676, [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and [Matasović 2009](src-50):427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.

IE root etymology uncertain. According to [Orel 1998](src-105):145) to PIE *selk- (tentatively cf. [LIV²](src-141) 530-531); according to [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):974-976) a straightforward derivation from PIE *selk- is impossible and may represent a contamination of *selk- (cf. [cognate set 451](cog-451)) and *h₂u̯elk- (cf. [cognate set 5274](cog-5274)); alternatively Schumacher & Matzinger suggest possibly *sk̑ek- with contamination of -l- in the Old Tosk form of the root (see now [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Some aspects of the root reconstruction are disagreed upon (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):383 s.v. Lat. mītis), but generally the cognacy of the Celtic and Italic lexemes are agreed. [Matasović 2009](src-50):278-279 suggests an alternative etymology s.v. Proto-Celtic *moyni- 'treasure, precious object' for potentially connected lexemes (W mwyn 'mild, tender, gentle', MoBret. moan 'tender, thin', OCo. muin 'thin' < *mēnV- < *meyHnV-), but is cryptic as to whether OIr. mín also should belong to this alternative etymology (not mentioned under the lemma for *moyni-).

The Goidelic forms in this class are from a compound imm·beir < Proto-Celtic *ambi- (preverb) 'around' (< PIE *h₂(e)mbʰi- or ámbʰi) + *ber- 'carry' (< PIE *bʰer-), cf. {Schumacher 2004}:218-233, [Matasović 2009](src-50):62, [LIV²](src-141) 76-77, [LIPP 2](src-294) 36.
Denominal verbs from a Germanic loanword *stakka 'stake, vine stake' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):678, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:195-206).
Loanword from Venetian casar 'to hunt'.
Loanword from Venetian rosso.
Loan from Venetian.
Loanword from Venetian.

Comment: check for an PIE etymology

Justification: Origin uncertain according to [Olsen 1999](src-180):942, a loanword from Caucasian according to [HAB](src-740) II:470-471. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsux-o-].
Loan from Italian serpente 'snake'.
Loanword from Venetian dolze 'sweet'.
Loanword from Italian nuotare 'to swim'.

Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Gk. καπνός 'smoke' ([ALEW](src-352) 545-546, [Derksen 2015](src-353):268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10187 s.v. 11./12. *moṭṭ(h)a- 'big, fat'; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
Some sources (cf. Derksen) suggest that the Polish word is an East Slavic (Ukrainian) loanword. The attestation is relatively late and there are some not fully certain phonetic clues.

Justification: Romanian neted is from Latin nitidus 'bright, shining' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), but further connections outside of Italic are obscure ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):442, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):410).

Indo-Iranic lexemes generally connected to Latin orbus 'deprived of, childless, orphaned', Greek ὀρφανός 'orphaned' ([EWAia](src-172) I:119-120, [KEWA](src-399) I:52, cf. also [Weiss 2006](src-672):256n30, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):433, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1113-1114).

Romance lexemes as though from Latin *nōdicāre 'to knot' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 7:169, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):489), a verbal derivative from Latin nōdus 'knot'. Further root etymology uncertain, possibly to Germanic lexemes meaning 'net', cf. Gothic nati, Old Icelandic nót 'net' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):412, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):384, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):263-264 for further discussion).

A formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, originally in the sense 'chat, prattle', later generalised as the generic verb 'to say' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):615-616, [Beekes 2010](src-66):827-828).
Parallel loans from Arabic ﺣﺴﺐ / ḥasiba 'to reckon, count'.
Loan from Italian penna 'pen, feather, quill, plume'.
Loanword from Venetian.

Etymology uncertain; [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):101 suggests *fšatā- 'combed' (?); if so cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):92 for a further root etymology to Proto-Iranic *fšan- 'to drag, tear, split'? Further etymological connections uncertain.

A probable Mediterranean substratum word ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:42-43, cf. also [Falileyev 2000](src-240):22, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):373). Perhaps cognate with Armenian kʻar in [cognate set 651](cog-651), but ultimately uncertain. Cf. notes in that class for further discussion. If this is the same substratum word as in Armenian, it is difficult to determine whether this was a single loan event or parallel loan events.
Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vaṇṭa- 'tailless' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):655, no. 11236), further etymology obscure (cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:131, [EWAia](src-172) II:206).

Comment: cf. Marathi ṭaṇaka (7579); Morgenstierne (1974: 82) quotes H. W. Bellew: Vocabulary of Sarigh Culi, etc., in Forsyth, Report on a mission to Yarkund 1873, Calcutta 1876 with "teyáng".
*b would > Sarikoli v; Sarikoli b < *p/V_V; cf. Persian bū < Middle Persian bōy

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic, although a connection with Germanic words for 'fox' (cf. OHG fuhs) remains worth considering ([EWAia](src-172) II:140, [KEWA](src-399) II:298; cf. also discussion in [Kroonen 2013](src-165):157-158). For Middle and Modern Indic cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):467, no. 8249.

Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):131).

Origin uncertain. Since [Pedersen 1905](src-747):220 connected with OIr. carrac 'rock', further compared to Classical Sanskrit karkara- 'hard, firm', Greek κάρκαρος 'prison' by [HAB](src-740) IV:558-560, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):778. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):685-686 considers a substratum loanword which is also shared with Germanic via pre-Proto-Germanic *karko/u- *'stony rise (where cultic rites were practiced)" (> OE hearg, OHG harug, OIc. harg), comparable to Armenian Kʻarkʻē the name of a mountain of religious importance. Cf. also [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:42-43 who rather assumes a Western Mediterranean substratum origin for the proposed Celtic cognates. If this is the same substratum word as in Celtic and/or Germanic, it is difficult to determine whether this was a single loan event or parallel loan events.

Comment: related to xvaēδa- swet? < PIE *su̯ei̯d ? EWAia 799 (Vol. II)

Justification: From Ancient Greek ὀξεῖα, the feminine stem of Ancient Greek ὀξύς (adj.) 'sharp' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):411). Root etymology disputed. Traditionally to IE *h₂ek̑- 'sharp' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 21-22, [Buck 1949](src-47):1069, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):806-807), but this is difficult from a morphological point of view. Alternatively [Narten 1986](src-722):204-214 has proposed a comparison with Ved. √akṣ- which could allow a Greek zero-grade formation *h₃k̑s- > ὀξ-, but this proposal has not been met with widespread acceptance (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1089).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat' ([NIL](src-274) 486-488, [Beekes 2010](src-66):947).

Armenian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *leh₂- 'to bark'. The assignment of Armenian forms to this class follows [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):104-105, [LIV²](src-141) 400-401 (not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)); for Iranic cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:443, [Cheung 2007](src-83):306.
Loanword from Venetian caldo 'hot'.
Loanword from Arabic رمل / raml 'sand' (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:190).

No certain etymology. All existing hypotheses need special assumptions that are not impossible but hard to prove (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:80, 83, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 6:203, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 4:267).

As though from Latin *plantāre, a verbal derivative from Latin planta 'sole of the foot' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):546), further to PIE *pleh₂- 'be flat, even' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):470, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):512, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).
Etymology uncertain. For various proposals and further discussion, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):86, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):240-241, [Orel 1998](src-105):211-212, 222, [Holm 2011](src-130):79).

No clear etymology. Perhaps from PIE *h₃st-dʰ- (cf. Gk. ὀσφύς 'loins') an extension of PIE *h₃ost- 'bone' but this remains an uncertain conjecture ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):10, [Olsen 1999](src-180):149).
An isolated archaic r/n-stem, probably connected with Vedic dhánuṣ- 'bow' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):210, [EWAia](src-172) I:773-774).
Balkan loanword from Albanian or Thraco-Dacian (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), [Schulte 2009](src-736):252).
Probably a borrowing from Slavic, cf. Serbo-Croatian vrtjeti 'spin', Bulgarian въртя 'turn' + prefix în- (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).
Loan from Middle German komen 'to come' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):271-273).
Indic lexemes derived from PIE *Herd- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 223-224, [EWAia](src-172) I:117-118). For Modern Indic lexemes connected to this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):60, no. 1340.

Within Albanian borë 'snow' is generally linked to bie 'fall' following [Jokl 1916](src-667):93, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):45-46, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):106-107, [Orel 1998](src-105):32. For etymology of Alb. bie < PIE *bʰerH-, cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):966 and further references in [cognate set 388](cog-388).

Romance lexemes are based on a denominal verb derived from Latin *colpus 'strike, blow' (Classical Latin colaphus) ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):193), further a loanword from Ancient Greek κόλαφος 'slap, buffet' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):131).

Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *pleh₂g- 'to beat'. There is anomalous devoicing of the velar in Slavic, but the two variants *pleh₂g- and ?*pleh₂g- are accepted to be the same root by [LIV²](src-141) 484-485). Cf. also [Derksen 2008](src-81):402, [Boryś 2005](src-259):443, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):469-471.
Loanword from Old French crier ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

The IE etymology for the lexemes in this class follows [Schrijver 1995](src-305):170-171, also followed by [Matasović 2009](src-50):73, and [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), occasionally connected by others to Lat. marcēre, cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):170 for further discussion.

Khowar gaan 'wind' from Old Indic gandhá- 'smell, scent' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):221, no. 4131). To be separated from comparable lexemes in Iranic (cf. Av. gaiṇti- 'bad smell', Parthian gndʾg 'stinking' etc.), but no secure connections outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:461-462).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek ἐξερέω 'I speak out, utter' with semantic shift to 'spew out, vomit' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):948), further to PIE *h₁reh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 251, but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):391-392).

Comment: *(h₃)lig-o-
Justification: Connected since [Meyer 1891](src-585):245 to Greek ὀλίγος 'few, little', Lith. ligà 'illness', cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):87, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):243, [Orel 1998](src-105):227.

Origin uncertain (cf. [HAB](src-740) III:341). Perhaps related to Classical Armenian mowx 'smoke' of uncertain etymology (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):33 and further discussion in [cognate set 8305](cog-8305)). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *moxir-o-].
Derived within English, with metathesis, from Middle English drit + -y suffix, probably originally a loan from Old Norse drit 'excrement' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Romance lexemes from Latin curtus 'short' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):225, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:1585-1588); further root etymology uncertain, either to 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' ([LIV²](src-141) 556-557, [IEW](src-49) 938-940) or to *kʷer- 'cut (off), incise' ({ref LIV² 391-392, [IEW](src-49) 641-642). The former etymology is preferred by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):158, whereas the latter by [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):160-161).

A probable loanword from Syriac qəlāfāʼ 'folium libri', qəlāfəθā 'cortex, squama, putamen mali granata' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):932), but cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):398 who less plausibly argue for an Indo-European origin. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kełeu̯-o-].

Comment: In Avestan attested by darz- "to attach, fasten".

Justification: Although there are some possible formal issues, I find the comparison to PS *smykati, *smukati, derived from PIE *(s)meu̯k- 'glide, slide', very attractive.

Comment: a PIE variant is cognate/2394/
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Albanian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ód-r̥-, *u̯ed-en- 'water', a heteroclite r/n-stem derived to PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([NIL](src-274) 706-715, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):987-988, [Adams 2013](src-345):627-628, [Beekes 2010](src-66):5126-1527, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):401-402, [Orel 1998](src-105):482-483, [EWAia](src-172) I:215-216, [ALEW](src-352) 1185-1186, [Derksen 2015](src-353):488, [Derksen 2008](src-81):523, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575-576, [Untermann 2000](src-279):815-816, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:21, [Matasović 2009](src-50):394).

No certain etymology outside of Albanian, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):69, [Huld 1984](src-571):50-51, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):82, [Orel 1998](src-105):65, [Holm 2011](src-130):82 for various proposals and further discussion.
the Sogdian form is a compound "bird-born", since Mazanderani has been put here as well, the "bird"-component will be given as root reference form
Loan from German Krampel, Krämpel 'claw' ([Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

Light verb construction with French debout as the semantic-bearing morpheme, from Old French de + bot, the latter derived from an Old Low Franconian loanword *bōtan 'strike, hit' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:219, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):109).

Cf. discussion s.v. Old Lithuanian stãbas 'graven image, idol' < ?*stobʰ-ó-  in [ALEW](src-352) 967. The status of this IE reconstruction remains uncertain, cf. Proto-Germanic *staba- 'stick' in [cognate set 2980](cog-2980) and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):471.

Comment: Mayrhofer (EWAia II 658) suggests a PIE extended root *(s)k̑eu̯-bʰ. Klingenschmitt (2000: 205) *huu̯-apah- "gutes Werk verrichtend", cf. Old Ind. sv-ápas- 'gut wirkend' (Mayrhofer EWAia I 84), then identical with 3165.

Justification: Italic lexemes from PIE *mei̯H- 'to diminish' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):381-382, [Untermann 2000](src-279):477-478, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 427). For Sardinian, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):459 s.v. 5594 Lat. minus.

Modern Indic lexemes as though from Vedic kumārikā́- 'girl', cf. Vedic kumārá- 'child, boy' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):170, no. 3303). Further etymology uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:368-369 for various uncertain proposals).

In [ESSJa](src-458): 3: 103 it is claimed that this word can be native. The support were East Slavic dialectal but referring to various kinds of 'onion' or 'beet', cf. also PS *buta, *butati, *butiti. However, it is possible that we deal with two different etymona here.

A probable North Caucasian loanword, cf. Khinalug k’ɨtʰ-ɨr 'nose' ([Asatrian 2014](src-741):147-148). No etymology in [HAB](src-740) IV:577-578, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):783, [Olsen 1999](src-180):942. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kʰitʰ-a-].

Comment: Loan from Latin
Justification: Generally regarded as a loan from Latin arēna 'sand' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):295, [Orel 1998](src-105):370-371), but cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):76-77 for a tentative proposal to the lexemes from PIE *h₁er- (cf. NHG Erde, etc. in [cognate set 207](cog-207)).
Romance lexemes from Latin sentīre 'to sense, feel' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):645-646), further to PIE *sent- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):554, [LIV²](src-141) 533).

Most often interpreted as containing PIE *dʰeh₁- 'put' ([LIV²](src-141): 136-138), cf. [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 688, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4: 255, see below. An alternative is to compare is with PIE *Hou̯Hdʰ-, cf. Russian udit' 'swell, fill with' and PS *vymę 'udder' and English udder, cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 149, [Derksen 2008](src-81): 507, 534-535 and {Boryś 2005}: 663. This latter etymology seems to be more attractive, however in light of the shortness of the root (2 phonemes) and the lack of any IE cognates with a similar meaning, it remains speculative.

Similar to Iranic *kutī̆- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Iranic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also [ESIJa](src-331) IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.

Generally derived from a (collective?) formation *lēg-i̯a- to PIE *le⁽g̑⁾- 'to drip, trickle' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):70, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):297, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:282-283, [IEW](src-49) 657, [LIV²](src-141) 397). Possibly cognate with Modern English lake if not a loanword from Old French (cf. further discussion in [cognate set 5612](cog-5612)).

Comment: How do we know Megleno-Romanian was not directly borrowed from Turkish?

Justification: [Adams 2013](src-345):219 suggests a possible connection to Proto-Germanic *klāwo- 'claw' but this remains uncertain. For the proposed Germanic cognates, cf. discussion in [Kluge 2011](src-397):496-497, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):292.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm, hot' ([LIV²](src-141) 219-220, [Derksen 2008](src-81):178-179, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:42-43).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Pace [Kluge 2011](src-397):215, the etymologies of proposed Greek and Italic cognates are themselves quite uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1052, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1400).

Generally derived as though from PIE *gʷʰe/oidʰ-i̯o- and connected with Slavic lexemes for 'liquid, watery', although some debate remains over the more precise aspects of the stem formation in Armenian (see [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):210-211 for detailed discussion, cf. also [HAB](src-740) I:550-551, [Olsen 1999](src-180):811).

Comment: IE *bu 'imitation of a muffled sound' (Buck 1930: 2.113)

Justification: Etymology uncertain, see [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):683 for a critical discussion of earlier proposals. [HED PE, PI, PU](src-413):146 considers a connection to Lithuanian pùsti 'swell', but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 831-833 s.v. pùsti 'anschwellen' and pū̃sti 'wehen, blasen' against any clear correspondences outside of Baltic for the proposed comparandum.

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Medieval Greek ὀψές, with final -ς taken on analogy to (ε)χτές 'yesterday', from Ancient Greek ὀψέ 'a after a long time, at length, late' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1626), further from PIE *h₁op-s-, cf. *h₁ep- 'on' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1139).
Loanword from Germanic *brekan- 'break' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:267, cf. French broyer 'grind').

Comment: Perhaps an Iranian loan. Denominative of ուռ owṙ 'swelling, tumor', cf. CA ուռնում owṙ-nu-m (intr.) 'I am swollen, bloated; (fig.) grow proud"; ուռուցանեմ owṙ-owcʿ-an-e-m (tr.) 'I swell; stuff'; ուռոյց owṙ-oycʿ 'swelling; blister', etc.
Justification: Modern Armenian lexemes derived from Classical Armenian owṙnowm. Further etymology obscure. Probably to be connected with Armenian owrowk 'leprosy' according to [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):257, which in turn may plausibly be considered an loan from Iranian. cf. Sogdian βrʾwkʾ 'leprous' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):188; cf. also [HAB](src-740) III:606-607 for older hypotheses). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(u̯)uṙ-].
Romance lexemes from Latin petra ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):531), an old loanword from Ancient Greek πέτρα 'rock; cliffside' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):504)

Traditionally derived from Lith. pìlti 'to pour (out); to fill' and further to PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill, become full' ([ALEW](src-352) 773-775, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):460, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):592-593).
Loanword from Romance *fluctulāre < Latin fluctuāre ([Orel 1998](src-105):101, cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):63, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):172-173, [Meyer 1891](src-585):109).

Comment: identical with the Romanian word that was loaned from Turkish (6544)
Justification: Loanword from Modern Persian, ultimately from Turkish.

From Ancient Greek κύανος ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):285), the name of a dark blue substance, 'enamel, lapis lazuli, blue copper carbonate', attested already in Mycenaean via ku-wa-no. Possibly an early loanword from an Indo-European Anatolian language, cf. Hittite kuu̯anna(n)- '(blue as) copper, ornamental stone' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):594-594, [Beekes 2010](src-66):793).

First securely attested as Middle English dogge, generally considered to be of unknown etymology (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84). Cf. [Gąsiorowski 2006](src-707) for a recent attempt to derive Old English *docga from the colour adjective dox (gloss) 'dark haired, dusky'.

Traditionally conjectured to be a derivative to PIE *h₂ek̄- 'to be(come) sharp' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):632, [IEW](src-49) 18), but this etymology is no longer continued by the more recent handbooks (cf. [NIL](src-274) 287-300; not in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165)).
Identical to Standard Albanian trup 'body, trunk', a loanword from Slavic  *trupъ 'id.' (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):438-439, [Orel 1998](src-105):467).

Continuing a derivative of Vedic √rap- 'to talk, chatter' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):614 no. 10620). Further etymology outside of Indic uncertain, possibly of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:432-433, not in [LIV²](src-141)).

Celtic lexemes traditionally derived to PIE *leu̯k- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 687), but better to *leh₂p- after the analysis of [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):194fn40, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 402, [Lucht 2007](src-151):76.

The etymology is considered as uncertain and relatively many different IE comparanda are given, cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 3: 315, [Boryś 2005](src-259): 613, [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 74. However, the hypothesis of [Derksen 2008](src-81): 35, 466 is attractive and has been adopted here. For the semantic development see also [cognate set 7765](cog-7765).

As though from PIE *solH-i- ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):709-711). Cf. however [HED SA](src-699) alternatively considering connections to other vocabulary from a Hittite stem *sall- 'swell, expand' to be ultimately connected with Proto-Germanic *swellan- (but cf. 'swell' in [cognate set 315](cog-315), generally considered without certain etymology). Cf. also Tischler Hethitisches Etymologisches Glossar 2/1:767-775 for further discussion.

The etymology is disputable and not entirely clear, cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 1: 15, [Boryś 2005](src-259): 28 or [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 74. However, the hypothesis of [ESSJa](src-458), considered also by [Derksen 2008](src-81): 35, is attractive. For the semantic development see also [cognate set 7765](cog-7765).

The root of the Hittite formation is generally compared with Ved. párvata- 'mountain' < *pér-u̯n̥-to- (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):668-669, [HED PE, PI, PU](src-413):23-26; cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:99).
Romance denominal verbs as though from Latin *mattea 'club' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):445), further etymology uncertain, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):366-367 for various proposals.

Generally connected with Baltic words for 'sea', cf. OLith. jū́ra 'sea', etc. ([Olsen 1999](src-180):50, [ALEW](src-352) 423), although this etymology is disputed by [Kortlandt 1998](src-742):15 (= [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):122) on the grounds that the proposed Baltic cognates cannot be separated from Sanskrit vā́r 'water'. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:134-136.
No clear etymology outside of Italic, possibly a loanword from an unknown Mediterranean source (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):340-341, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):326).

Albanian lexemes to be compared with OHG questa 'tuft', Serbian gvȍzd 'forest' and derived from PIE *gu̯osd(o)- ([Jokl 1912](src-750):204, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):69, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):187-188, [Orel 1998](src-105):133-134, [Holm 2011](src-130):69).
Derived from Tocharian B krāke 'dirt, filth', which may in turn be a loan from Khotanese khārgga- 'id.' ([Adams 2013](src-345):229-230).

Cf.
