Standard Modern Greek ανασαίνω, from Medieval Greek ἀνασαίνω, formed as a denominal verb in -αίνω from the Ancient Greek abstract noun ἄνεσις 'loosening, relaxing' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):131), further to Ancient Greek ἵημι 'to send away, let go, throw' from PIE *Hi̯eh₁- 'to throw' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):581-582, [LIV²](src-141) 225).

Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50); no etymology given in [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), cf. [Henry 1900](src-348):50-51 for various older proposals.

Comment: cf. Old Vedic káṇa- m. 'grain of corn' (AV), later 'drop of water' via 'particle', Turner 1962-66, no. 2661
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):133 no. 2661 s.v. Vedic káṇa- 'grain of corn', further etymology unclear ([EWAia](src-172) I:291.

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body' ([NIL](src-274) 444-448, [ALEW](src-352) 520-521, [Derksen 2015](src-353):255, [ESSJa](src-458) 13:67-70, [Derksen 2008](src-81):254).

Cognacy in this class follows [ALEW](src-352) 423, but cf. [Kortlandt 1998](src-742):15 (= [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):122) who rejects the etymology with Armenian, assuming that Baltic initial j- is secondarily acquired (similarly cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):215).
Anatolian and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰedʰh₂- 'to pierce; to dig' ([LIV²](src-141) 66, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):654-655, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):229).

The Modern Greek forms are from prefixed προ-ωθέω with various sound laws and analogical changes applied (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1317), ultimately to IE *u̯edʰh₁- 'push' ([LIV²](src-141) 660, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1676-1677). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Romance lexemes from Latin camba, gamba 'horse's ankle' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):143, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:111-120), most likely to be a loanword from Ancient Greek καμπή 'a bending, winding' in the technical language of horse veterinarians and breeders ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):267).

No certain etymology outside of Italic; previous proposals to Old Icelandic sax Old High German sahs 'knife' are unsatisfactory semantically and formally (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):597, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):541 for further discussion).
Lexemes derived from Hittite ištamān- 'ear', further from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Gk. στόμα 'mouth', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):411-413).
From Classical Armenian hartʿ 'flat, even, level', further etymology uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):964, cf. [HAB](src-740) III:58-59).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *mysliti, a denominal formation to Proto-Slavic *myslь 'thought, idea'. Within Slavic literature, *myslь is generally further compared to Ancient Greek μῦθος 'word, discourse, story' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):337, [ESSJa](src-458) 21:47-50, [Boryś 2005](src-259):344), although within Hellenist literature Greek μῦθος is generally considered without certain etymology (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):718-719, [Beekes 2010](src-66):976 for further discussion). The etymology of Proto-Slavic *myslь is remains therefore uncertain.

Comment: Original meaning "to find". Cheung (2007: 413) sorts Balochi under *u̯ai(H)n-, but does not explain the origin of -d-. Cognacy coding follows Korn (2005). Note that some Iranic forms of cognate set 1969 may actually belong here.

Justification: From Classical Armenian gawazan 'rod, stave', a loanword from Iranic *gavāzan- 'oxgoad' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):872, [HAB](src-740) I:525-526). [MM: Proto-Armenian *gau̯azan-a-].
Loan from Old French dous ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):199).

Comment: cf. IEW 951ff.

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):417, [Derksen 2015](src-353):343-344, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):435-436).

Perhaps PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾ond- (with Winter's Law accounting for the Balto-Slavic acute) or *k⁽ʷ⁾onHd⁽ʰ⁾- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):243, [Derksen 2015](src-353):231-232), but connections outside of Balto-Slavic ultimately uncertain; perhaps PIE *kʷend- according to [ALEW](src-352) 464-465, but likewise extra-Balto-Slavic connections uncertain. Cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 12:65-66.
To be derived from PIE *i̯et- 'to place oneself (firmly)' ([Orel 1998](src-105):158, 343-344, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):979).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'become warm, hot' ([NIL](src-274) 196-199, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:42, 55-56, [Derksen 2008](src-81):178-180; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 219-220).

Comment: Buck (1949: 1176f.) derives this word from "*noi-bho- from the root seen in Ir[ish] niam ‘brilliance’, Lat. nitēre ‘shine, glitter’.” For the inner-Iranic development with extension nai̯u̯aka- and accent shift see Klingenschmitt (2000: 212f.).

Justification: Probably an early loanword from Persian/Tajik (cf. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):108).
Parallel loans from Modern Iranic, cf. Persian شیرین / širin 'sweet'.

Brythonic forms from Proto-Celtic *kalona- ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):361). No certain etymology outside of Celtic. Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50); no etymology given in [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), cf. [Henry 1900](src-348):50-51 for various older proposals.

This class is coded for Walloon jambe, from Latin camba, gamba 'horse's ankle' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):143, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:111-120), most likely to be a loanword from Ancient Greek καμπή 'a bending, winding' in the technical language of horse veterinarians and breeders ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):267).
A derived adjective from Old French çucre 'sugar', in turn a loanword from Arabic sukkar 'sugar' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 19:161-164).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Traditionally assumed to be a derivative in *-dʰro- to PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' and connected with OCS vedro 'nice weather' ([IEW](src-49) 82; cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):649, [Derksen 2008](src-81):513), but cf. the discussion of [Kroonen 2013](src-165):583-584.

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected with PIE *Horgʰi-, cf. Alb. ergjëz 'nit'; Lith. érkė 'tick, mite' ([IEW](src-49) 335, cf. [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):603). This is remotely plausible, but the development of the Armenian form is irregular or phonetically unexpected, presumably due to taboo deformation. Cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):81 and [ALEW](src-352) 265 respectively for the proposed Albanian and Lithuanian cognates. [MM: Proto-Armenian *odʒil-o-/-a-].

Comment: Note that the original Slavic meaning was 'good'. The meaning 'sweet' in some South Slavic languages is a later innovation.
Justification: Etymology outside of Slavic uncertain ([ESSJa](src-458) 2:174, [Derksen 2008](src-81):51-52). Some attempts have been made to connect the root to the same found in 'white' < PIE *bʰelH- (cf. [cognate set 1190](cog-1190)), but the additional *-g- found on the stem lacks a convincing morphological explanation.

Exact derivation of the Tocharian B word from the PIE root debated, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):590 and [ALEW](src-352) 560 s.v. lãšišas. Cognates in other branches specifically mean 'salmon' (cf. [EIEC](src-657) 497 for further discussion).

Probably to Latin mīca 'small grain, crumb' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):456, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further etymology difficult. The best recent proposal is of [Nyman 1987](src-739), who argues for an original meaning 'grain of salt' and derives from the same root as Latin micō, -āre 'to quiver, dart, flash' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):378, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):402).

Comment: original meaning "to pour", Sarikoli with prefix *abi-

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):424, [Orel 1998](src-105):514-515 for various proposals and further discussion.

Etymology outside of Greek unclear; possibly with 'ice' in [cognate set 4901](cog-4901) (cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:28-29, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):588-589, [Beekes 2010](src-66):786). [Adams 2013](src-345):236 attempts to connect Tocharian B krośce to the Greek forms, but this is formally problematic (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):786).
Loanwords, either borrowed directly from Old French conter, or a denominal formation within Breton based on a loanword from Old French conte ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):413)

Derived from PIE *u̯edʰ(h₁)- 'hit, strike' ([Malzahn 2010](src-341):876-877, [Adams 2013](src-345):641, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 660). Reconstruction of the final laryngeal is not secure (cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Hellenic lexemes from PIE *stéh₃-mn, *sth₃-mén-s, cf. Hitt. ištāman- 'ear', Av. staman- 'snout, maw' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1058-1059, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1408, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):411-413).
Slavic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ([NIL](src-274) 185-189, [Derksen 2008](src-81):563, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):278).

Comment: cf. Morgenstierne (1974: 40): "kawg S[arikoli] (bur.) spring, well. - Lw. < W[akhi] kïk, kūk < *xāka-."
Justification: Quite regularly development of older *kōl from Turkic köl < *kȫl 'lake', either Uzbek (standard ko'l) or Kyrgyz (standard köl). Cf. Shughni qůl 'lake' with a similar development.
[Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):82 gives no etymology outside of the Shughni group.

From Classical Armenian gēš 'corpse, carrion, dead body' (subst.); 'bad, ill' (adj.), further etymology uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):944; not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79), for older etymological proposals cf. [HAB](src-740) I:550, [IEW](src-49) 1134).

Etymology outside of Brythonic uncertain. Traditionally connected to a PIE root 2. *lem- ([IEW](src-49) 675), but not in [LIV²](src-141) or [Schumacher 2004](src-304). For probable cognates in Breton cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Deshayes 2003](src-309):459 (without comparing Welsh lexemes).
Hittite ḫātant- 'dry' is originally an participle derived to PIE *h₂ed- 'to dry up' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):328-329, [LIV²](src-141) 255).

The etymology is obscure, probably of onomatopoeic origin ([Skok 1971-1974](src-589) 1:84-85). No certain etymology outside of Slavic: the etymology proposed in [ESSJa](src-458) 1:118-120 is ingenious but speculative.
Probably of expressive or onomatopoeic origin ([DCECH](src-423) IV:484-486, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):544).
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *du̯eh₂- ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):904-905, [EWAia](src-172) I:739, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):370 no. 6497).
Etymology in this class follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):974 to PIE *seh₂⁽g̑⁾-, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Comment: Original meaning probably "Hülle, Decke". Note that Persian requires accent shift to *páu̯astā- for *áu̯a > ō and au̯á > awa (Klingenschmitt 2000: 214f.).

Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *xšnau- 'to hear', further from PIE *ksneu̯- 'to whet, sharpen', presumably via an intermediary sense *'to sharpen (the ears)' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):456-457, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 373).

Indo-Iranic lexemes generally connected to Proto-Germanic *agla- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:46, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):10, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):4-5). For the root etymology to PIE *h₂egʰ- 'become afraid, sad', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257.

Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯š- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Vedic √ghoṣ- 'to sound'), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ([Cheung 2007](src-83):115-116, [EWAia](src-172) I:518-519; [LIV²](src-141) 200 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s-).
No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:451-452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 359-360). Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):203, no. 3865.

Hellenic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see' ([LIV²](src-141) 665-667, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):379-380, [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):403-404, [Derksen 2008](src-81):521, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):676).
Although some IE comparisons can be disputable, the link to PIE *gʷerH- is formally and semantically convincing.
Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)keu̯h₁- 'to apprehend, behold' ([LIV²](src-141) 561, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:134-136, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):91).
Loanword from Iranic (via Persian?), cf. [cognate set 2456](cog-2456), [cognate set 9297](cog-9297).

Not in [Deshayes 2003](src-309), but an obvious recent loan from French poitrine (< Late Latin *pectorīnus 'belonging to the breast', a derivative of Latin pectus, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):521).

Probably of onomatopoeic origin; the older proposed loanword hypothesis from Old High German tūmōn (cf. e.g. [Buck 1949](src-47):671) is questionable for formal reasons (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):747, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:403-409 for further discussion).

Connected by [Matasović 2009](src-50):427-428 to Slavic and Germanic words for 'wood' (cf. [cognate set 3130](cog-3130)) following [IEW](src-49) 1138-9, but since this explanation this on postulating different root-extensions to a base root *u̯el-, *u̯elə- in [IEW](src-49) this remains somewhat tenuous.

From Latin planta 'plant' (Giovanni Abete, p.c., cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):546), further to PIE *pleh₂- 'be flat, even' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):470, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):512, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).

Comment: original meaning "people"; Sarikoli with adjectival suffix *-aina-.

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 480, [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):191 for further discussion.

Anatolian, Hellenic, and Armenian lexemes from PIE *du̯ei̯- 'to fear, be afraid' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):308, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):268). For the inclusion of Luvian k(u)u̯ai̯a- in this class, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 130.

Possibly cognate with Tocharian B yolo 'bad', Gk. ὀδύνη, Arm. erkn, OIr. idu (cf. [Schindler 1975](src-723), [Watkins 1982](src-378), [Adams 2013](src-345):555-556), but these connections are uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):420-422, and more recently specifically regarding the Tocharian lexemes [Peyrot 2016](src-676) and further discussion in [cognate set 7558](cog-7558)).
North Germanic lexemes from ON dáligr 'wicked, harmful, miserable' (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):73-74; no lemma in [Heidermanns 1993](src-697), [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Most of the scholars ascertain that the etymology of PS *kut- is obscure. The etymologies of [ESSJa](src-458) and [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260) assume PIE roots (root extentions) not supported by [LIV²](src-141). The etymologies are also hardly convincing semantically (the issue is, however, caused to a great extent by the semantic span within attested Slavic lexemes belonging here). Thus, they are not accepted here.

Comment: possibly "to do under", then čēr < *hača adari 'from down'

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):325-326, [ALEW](src-352) 896-897 for further discussion.

Cf. Old Lithuanian plùnksma 'feather' ([ALEW](src-352) 802). Generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic.

Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre' ([EWAia](src-172) II:525-526, but cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):526). For Modern Indic forms in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):666, no. 11418.

Etymology uncertain. Formerly compared with Hittite karawar 'horn', Tocharian A kror, Tocharian B (oblique stem) krorīyai 'crescent, horn of the moon' via PIE *gʰréh₁u̯r̥ (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):155, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):182), but these proposed cognates may also be derived from PIE *k̑er- (cf. [cognate set 2457](cog-2457)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *(e)łdʒ-iu̯r-].

Probably continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *zai- 'to set in motion, impel' (cf. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):109-110, [Cheung 2007](src-83):461). Further connections outside of Indo-Iranic doubted by [EWAia](src-172) II:802-803, [LIV²](src-141) 174; cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):462 for proposed nominal cognates outside of Indo-Iranic. [LIV²](src-141) 174 mechanically reconstructs ?*g̑ʰei̯- 'to set in motion, drive'.

An Indic and Balto-Slavic isogloss ([EWAia](src-172) I:397-398, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):179 no. 3451, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:155-157, [Derksen 2008](src-81):92, [Derksen 2015](src-353):247). Because cognates are only found in languages that have undergone the satəm merger, the original identity of the velar as a plain velar *k or labiovelar *kʷ cannot be more precisely determined.

Origin uncertain, perhaps from *m(u̯)elh₂- 'grind' (cf. młel 'chaff, dust', mamowł 'press(ing machine))? Cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):953, [HAB](src-740) III:331-332. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *muł-].

Some sources assume a derivation from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- and a relationship to Latin moveō, movere, cf. the citations below.
However, this etymology is virtually not present in Slavic etymology dictionaries, cf. the citations below and [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 398, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 185-186, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 3: 26 where a different set of IE comparanda is given. Although the proposed Greek comparanda rather do not belong here [Beekes 2010](src-66): 950-951, 991, 974, 975-976, other IE comparisons as with Old Indic mū́tram 'urine', Proto-Celtic mūno- 'urine' and Lithuanian máudyti with a PIE reconstruction *meu̯H- (and without giving Latin moveō, movere etc. as a cognate) is accepted in branch-specific dictionaries, see [KEWA](src-399): 663-554, [Matasović 2009](src-50): 281, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 378.
PS *myti could not derive directly from PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁-. An irregular phonetic change or another special change would have to be assumed here.
Thus, the connection to PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- is not accepted here.

Comment: a loan, because **k̑lou̯ni- > *sr° > Sarikoli x̌

Justification: This cognate class codes Albanian hedh 'to throw' which may be regularly derived from PIE *skeu̯d- 'to propel (forth)' ([LIV²](src-141) 560); the Modern Albanian variant hjedh was semantically distinct in Old Albanian and is to be derived instead from *(s)kedh₂- 'to shatter, disperse' ([LIV²](src-141) 550, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) and [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):976 for further discussion. For older discussions connecting to PIE *(s)keu̯d-, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):150, [Huld 1984](src-571) 72-73, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):197-198, [Orel 1998](src-105):143-144. For the Slavic forms attached to this class, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 13:252-254, [Derksen 2008](src-81):265 (not in [LIV²](src-141)). Regarding the proposed cognacy to Proto-Germanic *skeutan- 'to shoot, dash' ([LIV²](src-141) 560), cf. discussion in [cognate set 8120](cog-8120).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007)

Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ([LIV²](src-141) 218-219, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:800-801, [Cheung 2007](src-83):244-245).

Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: No certain etymology ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):426-427, [Orel 1998](src-105):520-521, [Holm 2011](src-130):66-67).

To maintain the connection with Lat. albus, Gk. ἀλφός, etc. (cf. [cognate set 955](cog-955)), one must postulate reconstructing a fourth laryngeal that is a-colouring but lost in Anatolian (i.e. *h₄elbʰo-); alternatively one could reconstruct *albʰo- with an original *a in the root but this likewise a less satisfactory solution (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):169).
Etymology unknown (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Comment: unclear why Cheung suggests k instead of k̑ despite his reference to LIV; ki̯ > čy and k̑i̯ > ϑy/sy would both result in Sogdian š

Justification: Connections outside of Greek unclear; occasionally proposed to Arm. čʻor 'dry' (cf. [cognate set 5006](cog-5006)), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):182, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1035-1036, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):546).
Loan from Balkan Romance *padulem (< Latin paludem 'swamp'), cf. Romanian pădure 'forest' ({ref Meyer 1891:360, [Orel 1998](src-105):353).
Etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) I:427).
Etymology outside of Greek uncertain; reminiscent of Lat. silva 'forest' but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1154-1155, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1529-1530).
Etymology uncertain; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):878-879 for a speculative proposal based on a possible etymological figure.

Comment: hrīsa- n. ‘brushwood’ http://iedo.brillonline.nl/dictionaries/lemma.html?id=21497

Justification: No etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):626, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):564).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *truxlъ 'rotten' and ultimately derived from PIE *terh₁- 'to rub, bore' ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:239-240, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 632-633).

Origin uncertain. Traditionally thought to reflect PIE *sm̥-doru- lit. "together-tree/wood", which is, however, both formally and semantically quite speculative ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):95-96, [Olsen 1999](src-180):939, cf. [HAB](src-740) I:211). [MM: Proto-Armenian *antaṙ-i-].
Germanic and Slavic lexemes generally derived from PIE *u̯ergʷ- 'to throw' (cf. {ref LIV² 689, [Derksen 2008](src-81):515, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):581).

From Old Norse kasta, generally connected to ON kasa 'to bury in a cairn', kǫs 'heap, kǫstr 'hill', without a clear etymology outside of (North-)Germanic ([de Vries 1977](src-468):303, 342-343; cf. for various proposals in older literature). No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 9106; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin

Justification: Possibly to be connected with Ancient Greek ἰσχίον 'hip-joint' ([HED A+E/I](src-406):424-425), but this is disputed (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):602-603). In view of the phonological similarity and the areal proximity of the languages it could be possible that both Greek ἰσχίον and Hitt. iškiš- are both independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):402).

Etymology outside of Indic uncertain. Possibly to be connected with Proto-Slavic *ę̄drò 'kernel, core' ([EWAia](src-172) I:162), but cf. the scepticism of [Derksen 2008](src-81):157-158. For Middle and Modern Indic, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):50, no. 1111.
This lexeme is derived from PS *šum- and has an onomatopoeic origin. Therefore, further IE cognates are uncertain.

Comment: on words ending in °x: Bailey (1979: 111a) assumes a -xa- suffix for this word. Klingenschmitt (2000: 203) calles this "Suffixtausch" of *-xa- and *-ka-.

Justification: Scots Gaelic can, from Old Irish canim 'sing' ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):68, further to PIE *⁽k̑⁾an- 'sing' ([LIV²](src-141) 342-343, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):387-390, [Matasović 2009](src-50):187-188).

Etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):975, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1287-1288; cf. [IEW](src-49) 1159 for unconvincing older proposals to Germanic lexemes via OHG rīban, etc.).

Comment: original meaning is "strike"; Kurdish entries should be rechecked

Justification: Romance forms from Latin quirītare 'to make a public outcry' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:1484), a verbal derivative to Latin quirīs, -ītis 'name for Rome's citizens in their peacetime function'; further origins obscure (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):559, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):509-510).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek δασύς 'thick with leaves, thickly wooded' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):333). Often further compared to Lat. dēnsus 'thick, close, compact' but the comparison is formally problematic and therefore there is no clear etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):253, [Beekes 2010](src-66):305).
Loan from Medieval Latin pāgānus 'non-Christian, pagan'. It is difficult, however, to determine when the lexeme was originally borrowed (cf. [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 4:472-473).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *lixъ 'superfluous, incorrect' and generally further derived as though from PIE *lei̯kʷ-so- (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 15:99-102, [Derksen 2008](src-81):278, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 2:505, [NIL](src-274) 451-453).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 285) discussing Saka bīma- "rock" suggests a verbal root *vai- "to cut" (cf. Cheung 2007: 407). Cf. Av. vaēma- "Felsspalte, Felskluft".

Justification: Etymology outside of Goidelic difficult to establish with certainty. Cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:143-144 for previous proposals and further discussion.

Indic lexemes from Vedic bā́hya- ʻexternal, being outside' (AV), via 'foreign, strange' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):521, no. 9235. Further to PIE *bʰeg̑ʰ- according to [EWAia](src-172) II:220 on the basis of proposed Balto-Slavic comparanda (Lith. bè, Latv. bez, OCS bez 'without', cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):38a), but more recently cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):38, [ALEW](src-352) 101-102 without connection to the Indic lexemes.
Of uncertain origin ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 373, [EWAia](src-172) I:437, [KEWA](src-399) I:289 for discussion of potential Slavic comparanda). [LIV²](src-141) reconstructs as though from ?*k⁽ʷ⁾su̯ei̯bʰ- 'to swing (oneself)'.
Root cognacy outside of Slavic uncertain ([Derksen 2008](src-81):494, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4:183, [Boryś 2005](src-259):77, 84 for various proposals.

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *goditi 'please', further derived from PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ([ESSJa](src-458) 6:188-190, [Derksen 2008](src-81):172, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):206, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 195).
It is difficult to decide whether the Armenian forms continue PIE *nedih₂- or reflects *nēdih₂- ([Olsen 1999](src-180):84), cf. also [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):502-503 who reconstructs *ned-o-.
Derived from Proto-Germanic *minwizan- 'smaller', a derivative of PIE *mei̯H- 'become small, recede' ([Faltings 2010](src-698):393-394, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):412, [LIV²](src-141) 427).
Loanword from Turkish orman 'forest, woods'.
Loan from Arabic ورد / warad 'rose'.

As though from PIE *k̑éh₁k⁽ʷ⁾o- 'mowed grass'; The Old Prussian form shows some unexpected deviations from the East Baltic cognates (Lith. šė́kas 'grass, hay', Latv. sȩ̂ks 'freshly cut grass as cow-fodder'). Cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1017 for further discussion.

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974) and Cheung (2007), the latter noting Sarikoli pïrx- "to vomit" (p.298)

Justification: Further connections outside of Slavic are uncertain ([ESSJa](src-458) 8:123, 160-161).

Derived from Vedic sr̥ṣṭá- 'released' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):783, no. 13578), further derived from Vedic √sarj- 'to let go or fly, discharge, throw, cast, hurl' and ultimately from PIE *selg̑- 'to release, throw' ([EWAia](src-172) II:709, [LIV²](src-141) 528-529).
Etymology uncertain, perhaps related to PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):171).

Simplified from the phrase 'ums Leben bringen', cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):940. Further IE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally analysed as a conflation of the roots *bʰer- 'to carry' and *h₁nek̑- 'take, receive' (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):136-137, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):77).

Comment: lit. "milk", Iranic adjective formation *xšīraina-

Justification: Pace [Deshayes 2003](src-309):687 who assumes a borrowing via French estachier, a direct borrowing from Germanic *staka- 'stake, picket' seems more likely from a phonological point of view (Britta Irslinger, p.c.).

Generally derived as a causative to the same root as Armenian ankanaim 'I fall' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):280, cf. [HAB](src-740) II:128), ultimately from PIE *sengʷ- 'to go down, sink'. Cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):280 for further discussion.

In works on Germanic etymology, the etymology outside of Germanic is generally considered uncertain (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):417-418, [Kluge 2011](src-397):804, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):445), but cf., however, [LIV²](src-141) 560 connecting with PIE *(s)keu̯d- '(vor)antreiben'.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *þrinhan-; further IE root reconstruction in this set follows [LIV²](src-141) 649, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):365 to *trenk- 'to push', but cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):547 who argues for a root reconstruction *trenkʷ- on the basis of ON þryngva.

I find the etymology presented in [ESSJa](src-458) as to the underlying PIE root *kʷer- and its original meaning 'make, do, create' (probably derived from a more primitive meaning 'cut', see [LIV²](src-141)) convincing.
However, I think that the proposed order of the semantic development is unconvincing and that the reconstructed connotation of the *kresati with 'life' is unnecessary. Words referring to the look of humans and animals are very often derived from verbs meaning 'make, create, form, give birth', cf. PS *tvoriti 'make, create', Polish tworzyć 'make, create' and Polish twarz 'face' > twarzowy 'about a clothing a person looks pretty in' (cf. also Polish potwór 'monster' > potworny 'horrible, ugly'), PS ličiti 'to form, to shape' (< PIE *lei̯H- 'pour', also originally 'formed by casting', cf. [cognate set 1223](cog-1223)) and PS *lico 'face', Polish śliczny 'beautiful', Macedonian ličen 'pretty' or PS *roditi 'give birth', Polish rodzić 'give birth' and Polish uroda 'look, beauty' (cf. also Russian urod 'monster, ugly person' > urodlivyj 'ugly'). We can assume a similar development in PIE *kʷer- > PS *krasa. The meaning 'red' in Russian is a later development from 'beautiful' and not the opposite way. It is limited to Russian, where the meaning 'red' is attested much later (11th century vs. 15th century) than 'beautiful' [Černyh 1999](src-599): 1: 440.

In origin a verbal adjective to Tsakon. λεχούκ̔ου 'lay (a child) in bed; incubate, warm (smth.)' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); the verb is derived from Ancient Greek λεχώ 'a woman in childbed, a woman who has just given birth' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):353). Further to be connected to Ancient Greek λέχος 'bed', λέχεται 'lie down in bed' from PIE *legʰ- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):852-853, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 398).

Comment: *bʰeu̯t- violates IE root structure constraints. This etymology is impossible. (–MJCS, 11.07.2018).
Justification:
The etymology and further IE cognacy is not entirely clear.
The most Slavic etymology dictionaries point to a relationship to Latin re(-)futo and Old Norse bauta etc. However, there were a formal issue with the final consonant of the PIE root then, cf. [LIV²](src-141): 82 and [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 253-254. A root *bʰuH- 'hit' wit different extentions could be assumed here [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 253, cf. also [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) and [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) cited below. However, Kroonen points that "the original root-final consonant cannot be identified as *d, but only as *t or *dʰ" [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 56. If the final consonant were *t, Slavic forms could be formally related without any additional assumptions (as root extentions). This view is addopted here.

Connections outside of Germanic uncertain ([Seebold 1970](src-556):241, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):160-161, [LIV²](src-141) 202), but cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):187-188 for proposed connections in Indic and Celtic.

Denominative verb to TochB śerwe 'hunter', further etymology disputed. A popular analysis (Jasanoff apud [Nussbaum 1986](src-544):8, followed by [Ringe 1996](src-695)) considers TochB śerwe to a vr̥ddhi formation from PIE *k̑er-u̯o- 'stag' (*k̑er-, cf. 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457), 'head' in [cognate set 53](cog-53)), but other analyses are possible (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):694-695). Proto-Tocharian root ref. form *śerwë follows Ringe (1996:11).

Comment: with Slavic
Justification: Related to Latvian makņa 'swamp, boggy place', cf. Lith. maknà 'id.' ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) I:399-400). Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic uncertain, possibly to Armenian mawr 'mud' (cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):301). Cf. also Proto-Slavic *mokrъ 'wet, damp' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):322, [ESSJa](src-458) 19:144). [Not in [ALEW](src-352)].
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):434, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [LIV²](src-141) 305-306).

Comment: Korn (2005: 142 fn. 348) discusses a derivation of *mū "to bind", Old Ind. mū́ta- "basket", but it is not certain whether MIr. has *mūd or *mōd (Klingenschmitt 2000: 196 argues for MP mūy).

Justification: Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):55, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):273-274, [Derksen 2008](src-81):114-115, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:99-100, [LIV²](src-141) 153).
Parallel loans from Arabic قديم / qadim 'old'.

The Germanic forms from PGmc. *wenistra- are in all likelihood derivatives from PGmc. *weni- 'friend' as a taboo replacement as 'the friendly side' (cf. similarly motivated replacements in Gk. ἀρίστερος 'left', Lat. sinister 'left'); cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):623, [Orel 2003](src-388):455, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):579. For the IE root reconstruction, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 682-683.

Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 676, [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and [Matasović 2009](src-50):427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic.

From Old Norse pústr 'slap in the face' (n.) 'to pant, blow' (vb.). Probably further connected in some way with Middle Low German puster 'bellows', poesten, puysten 'blow' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):429).

Generally attempted to be derived (as though) from IE *dʰrus-ko/eh₂- to a root *dʰreu̯s- 'herabfallen, abbröckeln', and cognate with a primary verb attested in Germanic (cf. Goth. driusan, OE drēosan, OS driosan 'to fall'), cf. [ALEW](src-352) 234, [Derksen 2015](src-353):142, [LIV²](src-141) 157-158.

PIE root etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared with North Germanic lexemes in the meaning 'dust; small bits' etc., which with Slavic cognates (cf. OCS měla 'lime', Ru. mel' 'sand-bank, shoal') one may reconstruct a common root *(s)melH-. This root might be identical with PIE *melh₂- 'to grind' with s-mobile (cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):414-415), or alternatively connected with Germanic words for 'small' ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):842-843, 846-847; but cf. discussion in [cognate set 5112](cog-5112), without Baltic lexemes connected).
Romance forms from Latin spurcus 'dirty' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):676), further connections uncertain, perhaps to Latin spurius 'bastard'? (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):645).

Earlier literature (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):22) connects Proto-Germanic *samda- [cognate set 284](cog-284), Greek ἄμμος [cognate set 8262](cog-8262), and Lat. sabulum [cognate set 8263](cog-8263) together from an original stem *samdʰo-. This etymology is followed in some recent literature (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):11, 101) where the connection between these classes can be maintained through a reconstruction *sámh₂dʰos. On the other hand, Beekes in [EIEC](src-657) objects to this reconstruction on the basis of difficulties within Greek and the necessity to reconstruct IE *a. The Armenian forms in [cognate set 8261](cog-8261) are sometimes also connected to the Germanic, Greek, and Italic ones, but alternative explanations are also possible (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):149-150). It may well be possible that we are dealing with a European substrate loan into Late-IE which could be accounted for by *samh₂dʰo- (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):426), but the details remain quite unclear. As a consequence of the difficulties in reconciling all the proposed cognacy relations between these four branches, it is preferable to split them into separate cognate sets.
Etymology outside of Italic unclear ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):691-692, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):620, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):724 no. 8737).
Parallel loans from Arabic قرمز / qirmiz 'kermes insect; red', ultimately a loan itself from Iranic (cf. [cognate set 1163](cog-1163)).

Slavic lexemes considered cognate with Ancient Greek µῆλον 'small cattle, goat, sheep' < *meh₁lo- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):300 arguing for the Slavic forms reflecting an o-grade root form *moh₁-lo-, cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 17:173-177). Further connections with Proto-Germanic *smala- 'small' might be possible, but remain uncertain (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):517-518, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):456 and further discussion in [cognate set 8298](cog-8298)).

Lexemes from Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯o- 'to hit; to slay'. Further etymology uncertain ([Matasović 2009](src-50):345), cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):583-587 setting up either PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ- following [Schrijver 1995](src-305):178. [Not in [LIV²](src-141)].

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):45 for various proposals). [Kroonen 2013](src-165):39 considers a root etymology *h₂ed- for an old PIE word for a type of cereal grains.

Old Norse kasta is generally connected to ON kasa 'to bury in a cairn', kǫs 'heap, kǫstr 'hill', without a clear etymology outside of (North-)Germanic ([de Vries 1977](src-468):303, 342-343; cf. for various proposals in older literature). No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Originally 'stone' (cf. Lith. uolà 'rock') and traditionally connected with the same root as Lithuanian vélti 'to tumble, tousle' to PIE *u̯elH- (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1214-1215, [Derksen 2015](src-353):481 for further discussion).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):209-210, [ESSJa](src-458) 8:208-211, and [LIV²](src-141) 223 for further discussion).
Iranic and Slavic lexemes from PIE *tengʰ- 'to pull' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):391-392, [Derksen 2008](src-81):493). For the root reconstruction, cf. discussion in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).
Probably to be connected with Latin stringere 'to bind fast, tighten' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):891, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 603-604).

Etymology uncertain, perhaps a secondary full grade teik- to tik-, which could be the zero-grade form of PIE *tek- 'to stretch out the hand' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1084-1085). If so, perhaps further connected to 'right' in [cognate set 7113](cog-7113).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Baltic, Germanic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *péh₂-u̯r̥, *ph₂-u̯én-, an inherited r/n-heteroclitic nominal stem (cf. [NIL](src-274) 540-545, [EIEC](src-657) 202, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):613-614, [Adams 2013](src-345):421-422, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1260-1261, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):426-427, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):151, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):500).
Denominal formation to a loanword from Latin campus 'field' in the sense of 'place for fighting' (cf. [EWA 5](src-398):368-370, [Kluge 2011](src-397):468).
Loanword from Polish ([Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607):53).

Comment: cf. Turner 1931: 534, 1962-66, no. 10539 s.v. rakta- ʻcoloured, dyedʼ (ŚB), ʻredʼ (ŚāṅkhGr̥.), n. ʻbloodʼ (Mn.), °aka- ʻredʼ (VarBr̥S) (√rañj-), Pali Prakrit ratta-, Rom. rat m.; cf. [cognate set 6611](cog-6611)
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from *rakta- 'coloured, dyed', the past passive participle to Ved. √raj-¹, Iranic *ra(n)ǰ- ultimately from PIE *(s)re⁽g̑⁾- 'to colour (smth.)' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):610, no. 10539; [EWAia](src-172) II:424-425, [Cheung 2007](src-83):313-314 [Henning 1971](src-681):46, [LIV²](src-141) 587).

Anatolian, Hellenic, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ([LIV²](src-141) 218-219, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):485-486, [EWAia](src-172) II:800-801, [Cheung 2007](src-83):224-225).

Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound'; possibly in origin an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ([ALEW](src-352) 331-332). Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 210-211.
Iranic lexemes reflecting denominal formations to PIE *(s)por-no- 'wing, feather' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):297, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:97).

Romance lexemes from Latin ūstulāre (on the unexpected initial br-, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):757, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 14:75-82), a secondary form of Latin ūrō derived from PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, singe' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):755, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):645, [LIV²](src-141) 245).
Continuing Middle English smellen, smüllen, further etymology uncertain ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Of obscure origin, probably a prehistoric loanword (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):420, [Beekes 2010](src-66):530 for discussion of various hypotheses). The different dialectal forms point to either a Proto-Greek or borrowed source form *tʰalak⁽ʰ⁾i̯a (vel sim.).
Of obscure origin, perhaps to Ancient Greek ἐξ-(αν)αλίσκω 'consume' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Proto-Slavic *kŭrkŭ is occasionally compared to Vedic kŕ̥kāṭa- 'joint of the neck' (so [ESSJa](src-458) 13: 209-211, 218-219, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):313, cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):223), although the etymology of the Indic comparandum is generally considered without certain etymology (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:256-257 and [EWAia](src-172) I:388-389). Consequently the further connections of Proto-Slavic *kŭrkŭ must remain uncertain.

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974)

Justification: Root reference form for this class tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 562, but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 933-935 for further discussion.

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *vyja 'neck'. Further etymology obscure ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) I:373, [Polański 1962-1994](src-600):1034). Possibly cognate with Hittite u̯eḫ- 'to turn (oneself); to patrol' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 663), but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):993-996 with an alternative etymology for the proposed Hittite comparandum.

Denominal verbs derived from Classical Armenian kar 'rope, string'. Further origins uncertain ([Olsen 1999](src-180):955); perhaps originally a loanword from Caucasian, cf. Georgian ḳerva 'to sew' ([HAB](src-740) II:541-542). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kar-].

Comment: similarity to 5163 in using "night" for 'yesterday'

Justification: Modern North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse kortr, a loan from Middle Low German (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):327 s.v. kortr, kurtr).

Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₃óh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'mouth' ([NIL](src-274) 387-390, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):166-167, [EWAia](src-172) I:181-182, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):436).

Romanian ceață, from Latin caecus 'blind' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further to be connected with Old Irish cáech 'one-eyed', Goth. haihs 'id.' via PIE *⁽k̑⁾eh₂i-ko- or similar ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):82, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):79).

Verb derived from Spanish pelear 'fight' (n.), in turn derived from Spanish pelo 'hair' regularly from Latin pilus 'hair' ([DCECH](src-423) IV:461-463, 465). Further etymological connections uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):507, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):465).
Anatolian and Italic lexemes from PIE *sekH- 'to divide, separate' ([LIV²](src-141) 524), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):695-697, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):545).

The IE root etymology of the Balto-Slavic forms in this class is disputed: the two main candidates are either to PIE *h₃eh₁-s-, *h₃h₁-és-os 'mouth' ([NIL](src-274) 387-390) or to ?*h₃óu̯st-o- 'mouth, lip' ([NIL](src-274) 390-391, [Derksen 2008](src-81):509, [Derksen 2015](src-353):481-482). The root reference form for this class tentatively follows the Balto-Slavic reconstruction of [Derksen 2008](src-81) and [Derksen 2015](src-353).
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- 'to look, seek after' ([LIV²](src-141) 668-669, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:509-510, [Cheung 2007](src-83):411).
No certain etymology, perhaps to be connected in some way with the lexemes from Latin ūstulāre in [cognate set 9342](cog-9342), but this remains uncertain (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):757).

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit kāla- 'dark-blue, black' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):157, no. 3083). Etymology uncertain, but probably a loanword from Dravidian ([KEWA](src-399) I:203, [EWAia](src-172) I:343, cf. [Burrow & Emeneau 1984](src-756):139 for Dravidian parallels).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around, roll' ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:351, [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) I:181-182, 212-213, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 691-692).

North Germanic lexemes from Old Norse hræðast 'to fear' (vb.) or light verb constructions based on Old Norse hræðr 'fear' (n.). No certain connections outside of North Germanic (not in [Orel 2003](src-388), [Kroonen 2013](src-165); [de Vries 1977](src-468):263 reconstructs a Germanic stem *hrēð-).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *krīdlo- 'wing', further derived from PIE *(s)k⁽ʷ⁾rei̯- 'to describe a circle' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):247, [ESSJa](src-458) 12:152-154, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 562).

Traditionally Lithuanian burnà 'mouth' and Armenian beran 'mouth' have been connected etymologically (cf. {ref {Hübschmann 1897}:429, [Olsen 1999](src-180):297, [ALEW](src-352) 152, [Derksen 2015](src-353):106). Although this etymology is accepted, further morphological analysis and the isolation of an IE root remains unclear; further connections have been postulated to derive an n-stem noun from the same root underlying Lat. forō, -āre 'bore' OHG borōn 'bore', from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80), but these connections are not fully clear (cf. [ALEW](src-352)). However, if with [Derksen 2015](src-353):106), who notes that if the Slovak perna 'lip' belongs with the Baltic forms, then the usually reconstruction to a root *bʰrH- is in doubt. As [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353), and [Olsen 1999](src-180) are in agreement about the cognacy, it has been accepted for this class, although the precise IE root etymology is in question. [NB: Arm. beran 'mouth' is not discussed in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).]

Generally considered to be of IE origin, but the precise IE etymology is disputed. From PIE *ment-, if [Kroonen 2013](src-165):376-377's reconciliation of the two earlier possible etymologies from [IEW](src-49) (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):261) is correct. Etymology outside of Germanic otherwise uncertain; cf. [Boutkan & Siebinga 2005](src-82) for extensive discussion of alternative hypotheses.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4671ff.

Justification: Etymology uncertain. According to [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):300 to an Indo-European root *lel- 'to move, to shake' (not in [LIV²](src-141)) comparing Vedic lelāyati 'to move to and from; shake' (but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:480 assigning to PIE *rei̯H-, also not in [LIV²](src-141)); Lithuanian leliúoti ‎'to swing', etc. (cf. [HAB](src-740) II:292).

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Perhaps to the PIE word for 'liver' *(H)i̯ekʷ-r/n-, if certain irregular sound changes took place (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):565, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):336). An alternative possibility is an original meaning 'fat', if compared to the root of Gk. λιπαρός 'oily, fatty, greasy' if in Germanic an adjective was substantivised as similarly in Romance from Lat. (iēcur) fīcātum (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):565; [EWA 5](src-398):1082-1084).
Romanian merge 'to go' from Latin mergere 'to sink' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85), further to PIE *mesg- 'to plunge, sink' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):375, [LIV²](src-141) 441).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kъnęgъ 'ruler, duke, regent', a loan from Germanic *kuningaz 'king' ([Boryś 2005](src-259):268-269, [Polański 1962-1994](src-600):876-878).

North Germanic lexemes traditionally compared with PIE *tep- 'be warm, hot' ([IEW](src-49) 1069-1070, cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):418, [de Vries 1977](src-468):606-607), but not accepted by [LIV²](src-141) 629-630 s.v. 1. *tep-. Not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Comment: Sarikoli and Cappadocian Greek both loaned this word from a Turkic language, though obviously not the same

Justification: From Classical Armenian zist 'thigh, flank', probably to be interpreted as a compound of Proto-Armenian collocation *(ə)z- < PIE *h₂mbi̯V 'around, about' and *hist-o- < PIE *si-sd-e/o- 'to sit' ([HAB](src-740) II:96, [Olsen 1999](src-180):72, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):275).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10459 s.v. yā́nam n. ʻgoing, vehicleʼ (RV), Prakrit jāṇa- n. ʻriding, driving, vehicleʼ; for le cf. [cognate set 6587](cog-6587) < PIE *lembʰ-

Justification: No certain etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):95, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):89, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):153 no. 1628).

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 92-93, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):46 for further discussion. Older etymological works assumed a connection to PIE *h₃nebʰ- in [cognate set 5026](cog-5026), cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):33.

Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: From Classical Armenian kangnem 'to raise, lift up; get up, rise again', further root etymology uncertain, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):607, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):381 for various proposals. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). [MM: Proto-Armenian *kang-(u)n-].

Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷreu̯Hg̑ʰ- ([ALEW](src-352) 356, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594). This root is not reconstructed by [LIV²](src-141), nor are any comparanda outside Balto-Slavic given by [Derksen 2008](src-81), [Derksen 2015](src-353), but the comparison with AGk. βρῡ́χω 'grind the teeth' < *gʷruHg̑ʰ- appears reasonable formally and semantically (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):244).

Comment: Originally based on a compound of må (< Lat. malum) + sir 'pur' (Walloon Wiktionary).

Justification: Cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) for [LIV²](src-141) 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben'. The Celtic lexemes in this set have been tentatively assigned to the new root *u̯elh₂- 'beat, hit' assuming a semantic development 'beat, hit' > 'wound' > 'blood'. See further [Lucht 2007](src-151):65, [Matasović 2009](src-50):410.
Loanword from Low German kerl 'man' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):865-866).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green'. Regarding the irregular correspondence of the initial velar in Lithuanian and Old Prussian, see [Derksen 2015](src-353):169-170 (but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 309). For individual branches cf. [Dawkins 1916](src-452):661, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1638, [EWAia](src-172) II:805-806, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):809 no. 13990, [ALEW](src-352) 309, [Derksen 2015](src-353):169-170, [Derksen 2008](src-81):565-566, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):174).

First attested via Very Old Latin duenos (CIL 1.4) prior to the Latin sound change *du̯- > b- (cf. also Faliscan duenas [gen.sg.f.]) permitting the reconstruction of Proto-Italic *du̯eno-; further connections uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):73, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):73-74 for further discussion). For Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):106 no. 1208.

Comment: From Lat. de 'from' parte (abl. of pars, partis 'part').
Justification: An adverb based on the Latin phrase dē parte ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), from Latin pars, partis 'part' a late inner-Latin derivative to the same root as Latin pariō 'to give birth to, bear' derived from PIE *perh₃- 'to provide' (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):485, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):445-446, 448, [LIV²](src-141) 474-475).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 1858
Justification: Sinhalese osananavā 'to carry', as though from Sanskrit *ut-śrāpayati > ucchrāpayati 'raises' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):85), further derived from Sanskrit √śray- 'to lean' and ultimately from PIE *k̑lei̯- ([EWAia](src-172) II:665, [LIV²](src-141) 332-333).

For the root reconstruction, see [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) for [LIV²](src-141) 679 *u̯elh₃- 'schlagen' separated into two roots *u̯elh₂- 'rupfen, reißen' and *u̯elh₃- 'sterben', cf. also [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):945-946.

Etymology uncertain. Traditionally considered a derivative of a root *terp-, an extended form of the root *ter- 'to bore' exclusive to Balto-Slavic ([IEW](src-49) 1078, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:376), but cf. [LIV²](src-141) 632-633 now reconstructing *terh₁- for the assumed base root.

Romance lexemes from Latin herba 'a small plant or herb' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):344), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):291-292, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):269-270, 282 for further discussion).

Possibly cognate with Proto-Germanic *mūlan- 'mouth' and Proto-Germanic *munϸa- 'mouth' according to [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:611-612, although cf. discussion in [cognate set 6017](cog-6017), [cognate set 262](cog-262) regarding uncertainties to the etymologies of the Germanic forms.

Attempts at an Indo-European etymology (cf. [IEW](src-49) 392, [HAB](src-740) II:446-447) are unconvincing ([Olsen 1999](src-180):936). The best etymological proposal so far is the suggestion of a Hurro-Urartian loanword, cf. Urartian ṣârə 'orchard'; Hurrian sarme 'wood' (cf. [Diakonoff 1985](src-743):600). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsar-o-].

Balto-Slavic lexemes, related to the common words for '(finger)nail' widely found elsewhere in Indo-European via a derived feminine stem *h₃nogʷʰ-eh₂ (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):354-355, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164, [ALEW](src-352) 681-682, [Derksen 2015](src-353):327).

Modern Greek βουνό 'mountain' from Ancient Greek βουνός 'mountain, hill' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):275), further etymology outside of Greek uncertain ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):190, [Beekes 2010](src-66):231-232).

Germanic lexemes, generally considered a compound of Gmc. *ǣ- 'weg, fort' and the stem of the Germanic verb *maitan- 'schneiden', with a -jōn- suffix for forming a nomen agentis, cf. [EWA 1](src-383):203-204, [Kluge 2011](src-397):38, 613. Cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):24 for alternative hypotheses for the reconstruction of the initial prefix.

Comment: With nasal infix.
Justification: From Proto-Slavic *gręsti 'go' and usually further derived from a PIE nasal-infix present *gʰri-n-dʰ- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 203, [Derksen 2008](src-81):188, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:123-124).

Comment: Loan from Belarusian
Justification: Loan from Old Belarusian blagij 'shame, miserable, bad' prior to the spirantisation of /g/ > /h/, cf. Modern Belarusian благі / blahi 'bad' ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):65-66, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):45-46).
Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' (cf. [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):192, [ALEW](src-352) 495-496, [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Germanic lexemes generally connected to Balto-Slavic lexemes, cf. RuCS dъlbsti 'to scoop, chisel', Lith. (nu-)del̃bti 'to cast down one's eyes', to PIE *dʰelbʰ- 'dig, excavate' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):92, [LIV²](src-141) 143), but cf. the reservations of [Seebold 1970](src-556):153.

Denominal to Classical Armenian tʿiw 'number'. Further origins uncertain; either to be connected with Sanskrit tavá- 'strong, powerful' to a root *teu̯h₁- (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):23) or a borrowing from Hurro-Urartian, cf. Hurrian tiw- 'to say, speak', tiwə 'word; deed', (cf. [Diakonoff 1985](src-743):599). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tʰiu̯-].

From Proto-Tocharian *kər(ə)n-, proposed by [Adams 2013](src-345):173-174 to be based on an unextended root variant *kreu̯- to PIE *kreu̯s- 'hit, beat' ([LIV²](src-141) 371, [IEW](src-49) 622), and accepted by [Malzahn 2010](src-341):575-577.
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):418, [LIPP 2](src-294):639, cf. [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 5:577-581, 586-584).
Old Prussian lexeme derived from PIE *u̯orgʰó- 'outcast, ostracised' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1189-1191, [Derksen 2015](src-353):489-490).

The dubious semantics of the Hittite lexeme make etymological identification difficult (cf. [CHD L-N](src-403):253). For various uncertain proposals, cf. [Tischler 1991](src-457):210-211, [HED M](src-410):124-125.
Anatolian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([NIL](src-274) 706-715, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575-576, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):1015-1016).
Lexemes derived from a Proto-Balto-Slavic root *lop-; no certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2015](src-353):273, [ESSJa](src-458) 16:56-57, 16:77).

Since [Jokl 1911](src-661):14-15 generally derived from PIE *dʰeu̯b- and compared with Germanic 'deep' words, cf. Goth. diupiϸa, ON dýpt, although there is some uncertainty over the stem formation in Albanian (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):50, [Orel 1998](src-105):61-62, [NIL](src-274) 124n16).

Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vārdala- vārdala- 'rainy day, bad weather' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):674, no. 11567), further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:195 for various proposals.

Traditionally compared with Avestan pāšna- 'heel', Sanskrit pā́rṣṇi- 'id.' via a (dual?) preform *pāršnā, but the proposal is not without formal and semantic difficulties, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):67.

Hellenic lexemes traditionally considered a derivation to the same root as Ancient Greek τρέχω 'to run' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1130), but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1501 considering this explanation semantically unconvincing, with aspects of the word formation also unclear from an IE point of view.

Generally derived to PIE *k̑eHs- 'to instruct, advise' ([LIV²](src-141) 318, [Holm 2011](src-130):77, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1001, pace [Orel 1998](src-105):480 who assumes a connection with PIE *k̑eNs- ([LIV²](src-141) 326, cf. [cognate set 464](cog-464)).

Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit vr̥kká- 'kidney', apparently a semantic development from 'kidneys' > 'heart' > 'chest' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):698, no. 12064). Possibly further to Vedic √vart- 'turn, roll' < PIE *u̯ert- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:571-572).

Comment: "to darken, make dark, stain"; consider Turkic kül "ashes", but it is not clear whether Turkic #k can be rendered by Iranic #x (maybe via *q). Kurdish ɫ / ḷ point however to *rd/rz (if not secondary), which would make a derivation from *xwṛta- "consumed" possible. However, the Kurdish vowels point to a historically long vowel (if not loan). Cf. Classic New Persian xwāl "soot (for the production of ink)" < xwārϑa- "substance for colouring" (taken from Rastorgueva/Edelman 2007: 481, Etymological Dictionary of Iranian languages, hu̯ar- „smear“). Note, however, LIV p.609 *su̯el- "schwelen, brennen", which would be equally good.

Justification: derivation *u̯i-u̯āha-ka (cf. Nyberg 1974: 217 on Middle Persian), cf. Avestan vah- "weilen; to stay" (Bartholomae 1904: 1394)

Comment: Horn (1893: 201) suggests a derivation from the verbal root 'wart' "to turn". If so, all those languages that would preserve *#w would have to have loaned this word from languages like Persian.

Justification: A borrowing from Old French poldre, itself ultimately from Latin pulverem, ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):596).
Loan from Syriac, cf. Classical Armenian hašiw < Syriac ḥəšīḇ, 'considered, calculated' ([HAB](src-740) III:43, [Olsen 1999](src-180):932). [MM: Proto-Armenian *haʃiu̯-].

Etymology uncertain. Perhaps to be connected to Armenian cał- 'laugh' (< PIE *g̑elh₂-) 'to laugh' on the basis of the Hesychius gloss γελεῖν· λάμπειν, ἀνθεῖν 'shine, bloom', but this is uncertain (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):128, [Olsen 1999](src-180):459, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):336 for further discussion). [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsał-ik(-u/an)-].

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit stabdha- ʻfirmly fixedʼ, originally the past passive participle to Ved. √stambh- 'to affix, secure' and ultimately from PIE *stembʰH- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):788, no. 13676; cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:754, [LIV²](src-141) 595-596).

Certainly to an IE root *men-, but it is not certain whether this is yet another independent root *men- or etymologically related to existing formations (cf. 1. *men- 'einen Gedanken fassen' ([LIV²](src-141) 435-436, [IEW](src-49) 726-8), 2. *men- 'bleiben, warten' ([LIV²](src-141) 437, [IEW](src-49) 729), or 3. ?*men- 'emporragen' ([LIV²](src-141) 437-438, [IEW](src-49) 726)).

East Romance lexemes for 'heart' from Latin animus 'soul, spirit, heart' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further from PIE *h₂enh₁-mo- 'breath' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):43, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 267-268).

Originally a denominal formation from Ancient Greek ταῦρος 'bull' in the sense of 'pull like a bull' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1446), further to be connected with Latin taurus 'bull', Lithuanian taũras 'auroch', Old Prussian tauris 'bison', OCS turъ 'buffalo', etc. ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1455-1456, cf. also [ALEW](src-352) 1081-1082).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:68-69, [IEW](src-49) 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ([Matasović 2009](src-50):205, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, [EWAia](src-172) II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).

Germanic lexemes appearing to continuing derivatives of a PIE root *greng̑ʰ- 'to turn', although the evidence for this root is restricted to Baltic and Germanic ([de Vries 1977](src-468):330, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):305-306, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 191).
No etymological information in [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):114.

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁eg̑ʰ-(e)r-o-, cf. Arm. ezr ‘edge, border, bank’ (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 271, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:33-34, [Derksen 2008](src-81):148, [Derksen 2015](src-353):158-159, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):247-248).

Etymology difficult. Comparisons are typically made with Proto-Germanic *hringa- 'ring, circle' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):251, [ESSJa](src-458) 13:25-27, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):247, [Kluge 2011](src-397):768). As [Kroonen 2013](src-165):247 points out, however, the necessary reconstruction of *krengʰ- violates IE root structure constraints and may well point to a post-PIE origin for the Germanic and Slavic lexemes. Inexplicably, Kroonen also appears to consider that the lexemes are also related to Proto-Germanic *kringa- < PIE *greng̑ʰ- (cf. [cognate set 9606](cog-9606)). An alternative possibility would be that both the forms as though from *krengʰ- and *greng̑ʰ- were independent loan events from a third source although without any firsthand knowledge of a substratum source this solution is speculative.
Lit. 'not-good'. Further etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, cf. discussion under 'good' in [cognate set 678](cog-678).
Contrarary [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):275, probably an onomatopoeic formation (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 3:762-764).

From Ancient Greek λακτίζω 'kick with the heel or foot' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):347), a derivative to λάξ (adv.) 'with the heel or foot' without convincing IE etymology (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):619, [Beekes 2010](src-66):831-832).

Anatolian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *su̯ep- 'to fall asleep' ([LIV²](src-141) 612, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):787-789, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):667-668, [EWAia](src-172) II:791, [Cheung 2007](src-83):145-147, [Derksen 2008](src-81):481, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):489, [Seebold 1970](src-556):482-483).

Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):964). Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79). For older, now untenable proposed etymologies to Germanic *narwa- 'narrow', cf. [HAB](src-740) III:439-440, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):565, and further comments by MM in the cognate class citations. [MM: Proto-Armenian *neɫ-o-].
Root etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):109, [Orel 1998](src-105):386, [Holm 2011](src-130):81, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):994-995 for various proposals and further discussion.

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indic *khucc-, possibly an extended form of the same root found in Vedic √skav- 'to tear, pluck'? ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):205-206, no. 3890; for Ved. √skav- cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:751). Further origins uncertain.

The etymology and further cognacy is obscure. It can be derived from PIE 2*(s)ker- 'scratch, cut off, shear' ([LIV²](src-141): 556-557), cf. [EWAia](src-172): 537 and [Kroonen 2013](src-165) or *ser- 'knot together' [LIV²](src-141): 534, [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 557-558 and [ESSJa](src-458): 8: 75. See [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) for a summary of existing hypotheses.

From Proto-Slavic *morzъ 'frost' and to be connected with Albanian mardhë 'frost, ice', from PIE *merg̑⁽ʰ⁾-o- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):326, [ESSJa](src-458) 20:10-14, 21:163-165, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):256, [Orel 1998](src-105):245).

From Latin spīna 'thorn, prickle; spine' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):673). Further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):642, cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):692-693). [de Vaan 2008](src-54):580-581 (following [IEW](src-49) 981-982) suggests a possibly cognate relationship to Slavic lexemes, e.g. Ru. спина 'back', but it is not certain whether these forms are actually root cognate or loanwords from Latin (cf. discussion in [cognate set 2059](cog-2059)).

Cf. Lithuanian nókti 'to hunt, pursue; follow'. Etymology outside of Baltic disputed. According to [Kortlandt 1994](src-704) (followed by [Derksen 2015](src-353):336) from PIE *h₂nek̑-, but this root etymology has not been met with widespread acceptance elsewhere (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 282-283; [ALEW](src-352) 708).

Derived from the Proto-Germanic. strong verb *reukan- ~ *rūkan- 'to smoke' [Seebold 1970](src-556):379-380, [Kluge 2011](src-397):748, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):406, 410. There is with no further accepted etymology outside of Germanic, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 299](cog-299).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):41, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:99-100, [LIV²](src-141) 72).
Root etymology uncertain, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):109, [Orel 1998](src-105):386, [Holm 2011](src-130):81, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):994-995 for various proposals and further discussion.
Etymology outside of (East) Baltic obscure, see [IEW](src-49) 986, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:256 for various older proposals. Cf. also [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):859 s.v. Lith. spalvà 'colour'.
Loanword from Middle Low German swâr 'heavy' ([Polański 1962-1994](src-600):802).

The etymology of the East Slavic term is unclear. One of the most widely accepted hypotheses links it to Slavic *polx- 'fear, frighten' and further to PIE *pelh₁- (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):410). It is semantically convincing. However, a phonetically regular reflex should have -olo- then, e.g. Russian **polohoj. A solution is to assume a borrowing from Polish płochy (or a phonetic conforming at the Polish word). However, such a borrowing would be very isolated. Further, the Polish-like form of the root has been attested (in derivatives) already from 14th-15th centuries and it is spread in all East Slavic dialects. Another solution is to assume a contamination with ploskij 'flat'. The probability is disputable. Still another solution is to assume an irregular phonetic change driven or supported by the frequency. The phonetic circumstances are very favourable in this case. The (hipothetical) missing vowel was unstressed and East Slavic stress is dynamic and relatively strong (at least nowadays). Further, it stand between a stop and a liquid. In sequences / pR / there is always a short (prothetic, unphonological) vowel with a quality resembling the next vowel. An unstressed and therefore short, etymological vowel in / pVR / can be very easily interpreted as a prothetic, unphonological vowel articulation (and, in fact, vice versa), especially in cases as *polox- with two identical vowels. Further, we can deal with a dialectal, northern Russian feature in this case which could spread as a lexicalized inter-dialectal borrowing (cf. [Zaliznâk 2004](src-596):39-41). Note that the oldest, precisely located attestations of plox-forms are found in texts from northern Russia. A combination of some of the given solutions is also conceivable.

A probable Greek-Albanian isogloss (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 362, [Orel 1998](src-105):353-354, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):993, [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) I:865, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):538 [Beekes 2010](src-66):709).

Generally considered a zero-grade derivative of Proto-Germanic *bautan- 'to beat' with an original meaning 'blunt, truncated thing' ([EWNl](src-757)), further possibly to be derived from an IE root *bʰeu̯d- 'to beat' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):56, [LIV²](src-141) 82).

Root reference form for this class follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) to PIE *mei̯gʰ- 'to close the eyes, blink', cf. also [LIV²](src-141) 427, [ALEW](src-352) 644-645, [Derksen 2015](src-353):315-316, [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):240, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):395-396 for further discussion.

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Traditionally considered a labial-extension to the root *dʰu̯eh₂- 'make smoke' ([IEW](src-49) 247-248, [Orel 2003](src-388):68, [Kluge 2011](src-397):180; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158). Alternatively [Kroonen 2013](src-165):88 sets up a derived noun to PGmc. *dimpan ~ *dempan- 'to fog' < *dʰembʰ- (cf. MHG dimpfen 'to smoke, steam' Elfdalian dimba 'to smoke', Nw. demba 'to smoke'; but cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):180 who considers the MHG form a backformation to MHG dampf, not in [LIV²](src-141).).

Comment: Uncertain etymology.
Justification: Etymology disputed; the best etymology would tentatively appear to be some sort of derivative to PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'burn, glow' (so [Huld 1984](src-571):132, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):206, but cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):460, [Orel 1998](src-105):518 for alternative proposals).

Indic lexemes possibly to be connected with Vedic √khod- 'thrusts (penis) into' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):209, no. 3934; no certain etymology outside of Indic for Ved. √khod- cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:456).

Comment: proposed relation to PIE *u̯ebʰ- "to weave" rejected by Cheung (2007)

Justification: Traditionally postulated to a root *ser- 'red' ([IEW](src-49) 910-911, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):763), although this etymology is no longer accepted by [ALEW](src-352) 891. Cf. also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):534, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:155-156.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *kau̯p- 'to pound, beat'; further etymology uncertain (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):249-250, [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:570-571).
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *gōda- 'suitable, good', a derivative of PIE *gʰedʰ- 'to fit together' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):162-163, 184, [EWA 4](src-415):694-697, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 195).

Boeotian καλϝός shows that the Proto-Greek stem for the adjective was *kalu̯o-, but there is no secure etymology beyond of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):486-487, [Beekes 2010](src-66):626-627).

Romance lexemes derived from French gauchir 'to warp, deform', originally a loanword from Old Low Franconian *wenkjan 'to waver, falter' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 17:555-560 for further discussion).

Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'to make smoke' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):895, [EWAia](src-172) I:795, [ALEW](src-352) 243, [Derksen 2015](src-353):145, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:203, [Derksen 2008](src-81):132, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):249, [Matasović 2009](src-50):111, [Irslinger 2002](src-299):61; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158).

IE inherited status uncertain. Certainly there is enough comparative material between Italic, Germanic, Greek, and Albanian to posit a (European) IE word *skeh₂p-, but due to the geographical proximity of the branches the possibility of (independent?) early loanwords cannot be entirely excluded (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):408, [Huld 1984](src-571):114, [Orel 1998](src-105):421, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):546, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1350 for further discussion).

Comment: maybe < *dreuH-so- ? cf. Cheung (2007: 79-80)

Justification: Loanword from Polish budynek 'building', itself ultimately a loanword from Middle German buding 'building' ([Boryś 2005](src-259):45).

IE root etymology disputed: either (1) to PIE h₂ek̑- 'sharp' and connected with OCS ostьnъ 'sharp point', or (2) to PIE *Host- 'bone' and cognate with Hitt. ḫāstai-, Skt. asthi-, Gk. ὀστέον, Lat. os, etc. ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:80-81).

Etymology disputed. [Orel 1998](src-105):496 and [LIV²](src-141) 620-621 assign the verb to *tekʷ-, against which cf. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1001-1002. [Holm 2011](src-130):57 also rejects *tekʷ-, instead suggesting *dʰgʷʰei̯- 'hinschwinden, sterben' as a more plausible alternative. [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1001-1002 propose a speculative etymology to a root *dekʷs-.
Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek *ζαβρός / *ζαρβός (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):530 for further discussion).
Romance lexemes from Latin (com)battuere ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):85, 196), of obscure origin ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):68).

Romance lexemes from Latin luctāre 'to fight' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):418), a frequentative verb based on PIE *lu⁽g̑⁾-to- 'bent' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):350, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 416 s.v. 2. *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'biegen').

Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin perna 'haunch, ham together with the leg' ([DCECH](src-423) IV:538-539). For the IE reconstruction given, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:123-124; for a proposed derivation to a verbal root *TsperH- 'to kick with the foot', cf. [Lubotsky 2006](src-560) and the discussion of [de Vaan 2008](src-54):460-461.
Loanword from Indic? (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):149 no. 2922).

Traditionally considered cognate with Proto-Germanic *hakan- 'hook' ([ESSJa](src-458) 10:109-110, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 2:275, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):387), although extra-Germanic connections to the Germanic comparanda are doubted by [Kroonen 2013](src-165):203 on the basis of formal difficulties. [Not in [Derksen 2008](src-81)].

Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *erþō-, generally considered a dental-stem to a PIE root *h₁er- seen elsewhere in Ancient Greek ἔρα 'earth', Welsh erw 'field', cf. also the Old High German hapax ero 'earth' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):18, [Kluge 2011](src-397):253-254, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):118-119, cf. also [Beekes 2010](src-66):449).

Leaving the most unconvincing hypotheses (like the one linking to a hardly if ever attested interjection ps) aside, it still remains obscure which PIE root the Slavic lexeme belongs to. It applies also to a part of (potential) IE cognates, the differentiation between the reconstructed PIE roots relevant here is generally far from clear, cf. [NIL](src-274). Therefore, it is most reasonable not to go beyond the Slavic in the reconstruction.

Modern Greek forms from Ancient Greek στρογγύλος 'round, spherical' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1343). Generally connected to Ancient Greek στράγξ 'squeezed out drop' and further to OHG strang ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174): II:810-811, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1064-1065}), although the semantic connection within Greek not overly persuasive ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1415). Further etymology outside of Greek therefore uncertain.

The etymology and further cognacy is uncertain. For the discussion on the nativity of PS *melko 'milk' and its relationship to PIE *h₂melg̑- 'to milk' see [ESSJa](src-458): 18: 87-88 (the authors claim that PS *melko 'milk' is not derived from / related to PIE *h₂melg̑- 'to milk').

Etymology outside Slavic uncertain, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 3:44-45, [Boryś 2005](src-259):40-41, [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 1:381-382, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 1:265 for various proposals.

Comment: Emmerick/Skjærvø (1982: 55) follow Henning's suggestion to derive the Khotanese word from *drigu- (cf. Avestan drigu- "arm, bedürftig, schwach"). The Avestan word is considered an Iranian innovation by Mayrhofer (EWAia I: 68): "Konträrbildung zu dem ererbten indoiran. *ádhri-gu-, aus irriger Auffassung *a-dhrigu-".

Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *met-. Further IE root etymology disputed: either to PIE ?1. *met- 'mähen' ([LIV²](src-141) 422) or ?2. *met- 'abmessen' ([LIV²](src-141) 422) ([Derksen 2015](src-353):313-314, [ESSJa](src-458) 18:105-108, 112-115, [Derksen 2008](src-81):308-309); [ALEW](src-352) 639-641 doubts connections outside of Balto-Slavic.

Comment: Cheung (2007: 20) mentions a suggestion by Rastorgueva/Edel'man (2003: 159) to sort the Khotanese verb to *bād < PIE *bʰēdʰ-, viz. *pati-/api-bād-. They also suggest (not mentioned by Cheung) that this word could derive from api-šad- "oppress" < had "sit" (cf. Emmerick 1968: 85).

Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Rejzek 2001](src-593):638, [Králik 2015](src-638):589 for discussion of various hypotheses.

Generally connected to PIE *sokʷo- 'juice of plants and fruit' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):196, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1042, [Huld 1984](src-571):67, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):181-182, [Orel 1998](src-105):129, [Holm 2011](src-130):53).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂stḗr-, *h₂ster- ́ 'star' ([NIL](src-274) 348-354, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):326, [Adams 2013](src-345):701, [Beekes 2010](src-66):156-157, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):120-122, [Clackson 2017](src-673):110, [EWAia](src-172) II:755-756, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):330 no. 5798, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):322, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):478, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):585, [Matasović 2009](src-50):355). For a proposed deep etymological connection with PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry up/wither by heat' cf. [Pinault 2007](src-327).

Comment: probably via New Persian غایب
Justification: Parallel loans from Arabic غایب, probably via New Persian غایب 'hidden'.

Two possibilities: Either (1) as a loan from Romance *notāre (with irregular root vocalism from Lat. natāre 'swim', so [Meyer 1891](src-585):311, [Orel 1998](src-105):301), or – perhaps better – (2) directly derived to PIE *(s)neh₂- (so [Huld 1984](src-571):148, [Holm 2011](src-130):83). No discussion in [Demiraj 1997](src-369) or [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364).
As though from Sanskrit *baluvā-, cf. Sanskrit baluha- only attested by lexicographers ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):535, no. 9407). Further etymology uncertain ([KEWA](src-399) II:483).

Root etymology disputed (cf. esp. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):257-258); possibly related to cognates from PIE 2. *h₂er- ([LIV²](src-141) 270-271, so [Hamp 1965](src-666):140, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):983), but alternative etymologies are also possible (cf. also [Meyer 1891](src-585):261, [Jokl 1911](src-661):53-54, [Huld 1984](src-571):89-90, [Orel 1998](src-105):246).
Loanword from Slavic trajati, cf. Serbo-Croatian trȁjati 'to last, continue' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).

Root etymology follows [LIV²](src-141) 274, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):975-976, tentatively also [Huld 1984](src-571):72. However, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):140-141 who proposes to PIE *h₁ed- 'eat', and [Holm 2011](src-130):59-60 who rejects all previously proposed etymologies.
