Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *uḍḍīyate ~ *uḍḍayate 'flies up' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):77, no.1697), further derived from Vedic √day-ⁱ (1) 'fly'; no further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) I:700, [KEWA](src-399) I:460).

Slavic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *tengʰ- 'to pull' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):494, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):551, [ALEW](src-352) 1110-1111) For the root reconstruction, cf. discussion in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).
Cf. Proto-Iranic *hu̯ah- 'to strike; thresh; [inch., intr.] to become tired' with no certain etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):141-143).
No certain etymology outside of Indic ([EWAia](src-172) II:201-202), for Middle and Modern Indic cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):508, no. 9051).

A transferred adjective from the noun phrase iēcur fīcātum 'fig-stuffed liver' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 3:490-493), further etymology uncertain; Latin fīcus 'fig' appears to be a Mediterranean Wanderwort, cf. Attic Greek. σῦκον, (Boeotian τῦκον )'fig', Armenian. tʻowz 'dried fig' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):232, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):218). A similar lexical replacement also occurred in the history of Greek (cf. [cognate set 1505](cog-1505)).
Originally a loanword in Old Norse from Middle Low German spīsen ([de Vries 1977](src-468):536).

The forms in this class from Proto-Germanic *spīwan- are generally compared with similar verbs denoting 'to spit' found elsewhere among the Indo-European languages ([LIV²](src-141) 583-584, reconstructing *spti̯eu̯H-, cf. non-Jena 175 'spit' in cognate set 305). Reconstructing a common IE root for these forms, however, is extremely difficult, as the forms in various branches likely underwent deformations or reformations among individual daughter languages due to onomatopoeia or phonotactic reasons. Within Germanic these forms are more-or-less regular from *spīwan- / *speiw-a- (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):450-452, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):468).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing an Ancient Greek denominal verb μυρίζω 'to salve, perfume', derived from Ancient Greek μύρον 'salve, perfume' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):903). Perhaps further cognate with Germanic Celtic words 'to smear, fat' (OHG smero 'smear', OIr. smi(u)r 'marrow') < *smer-u-, but a Semitic loanword may well be equally as likely; cf. AGk. μύρρα 'myrrh, sweet-smelling word of the myrrh plant', Aram. mūrā, Heb. mōr, Arab. murr 'myrrh' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):983).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin strictus 'narrow' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):686 no. 8305, cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 12:298). The further PIE root etymology is difficult as Latin strictus, probably represents a blend / contamination of PIE *strig- 'to brush, strip', and *strengʰ- 'to tie' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):591-592, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 603-604).

Generally connected to Lith. vir̃bas 'twig, rod', Rus. верба (OCS връба) 'willow' from a zero-grade fromation *u̯r̥b-, and Lat. uerbera '(rods for) punishment', uerbēnae 'twigs of the laurel' from the full-grade *u̯erb- ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:636-637, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):964), but [Beekes 2010](src-66):1269-1270 is inclined to believe the word is of substratum origin.

From Proto-Germanic *grundu- 'floor' (Old Frisian grund); further etymological connections problematic, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):161, [Orel 2003](src-388):144, [Kluge 2011](src-397):378, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):192 for various proposals and further discussion.

Latvian lexemes generally connected with Lithuanian kúokas 'club, stick'; further etymology uncertain. Traditionally connected with PIE *keu̯- 'to bend' with a velar extension -k- ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:413-414, cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):306, [IEW](src-49) 589), but more recently cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):324 regarding the etymology uncertain. [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353), [ALEW](src-352)].

Very similar in form and meaning to Latin dulcis 'sweet', but a common proto-form cannot be reconstructed. Perhaps the Italic and Greek lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):228-229, [Beekes 2010](src-66):227-228). Cf. further discussion in [cognate set 7772](cog-7772).

In spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. [Hamp 1972](src-575)). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):322, [Beekes 2010](src-66):299-300) generally follow the proposal of [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574), assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'.

Comment: perhaps from vad- 'raise one's voice, sound, speak', vádati (RV)

Justification: A semantic extension from Proto-Germanic *burzda- 'board; table'. Further etymology uncertain. Traditionally compared to a root *bʰerdʰ- 'to cut' ([IEW](src-49) 138, [de Vries 1977](src-468):50) but only uncertainly postulated as ?*bʰerdʰ- in [LIV²](src-141) 77-78. Alternatively [Kroonen 2013](src-165):74, 86 proposes an etymology comparing a secondary zero-grade form *bruzda- > ON broddr 'tip, edge, shoot', OHG brort 'point, margin' and Old Irish brot 'goad, spike' from an o-grade formation to a postulated root *bʰrezdʰ-.
Generally derived from PIE *bʰerH- 'work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80, cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):43-44, [Orel 1998](src-105):24-25, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):966).

Occasionally considered a loanword from Ancient Greek δάκρῡμα (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):336). Elsewhere, in spite of numerous phonological and morphological difficulties, often assumed to be root-cognate with Latin lācrima 'tear', Armenian artaswr 'tear', OHG zahar 'tear', Ved. áśru-, TochA ākär, Hittite išḫaḫru 'tear(s)', etc., (cf. [Hamp 1972](src-575)). The Leiden dictionaries (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):322, [Beekes 2010](src-66):299-300) generally follow the proposal of [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574), assuming a common pre-form for the Greek and Latin forms as a nominal compound *dr̥k̑-h₂k̑ru- 'eye-bitter' containing the roots *derk̑- 'catch sight of, look at' and *h₂ek̑- 'be sharp'.
Of uncertain etymology (Giovanni Abete, p.c.).

Etymology disputed. Originally proposed a loanword from Latin sequor 'follow' by [Meyer 1891](src-585):408 and followed by [Holm 2011](src-130):86; alternatively considered since [Jokl 1911](src-661):80-82 to be connected with Albanian shteg 'path', cognate with Greek στοῖχος 'row, line' and derived from PIE *stei̯gʰ- (followed by [Huld 1984](src-571):114, [Orel 1998](src-105):421; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 593-594, without Albanian). [Not in [Demiraj 1997](src-369), [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364)].
Of onomatopoeic origin from the interjection 'joj, joh' (cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595):232, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).
Loan from Wakhi diγ̌ə́r, digə́r 'fingernail' ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):662, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):146-147).

Slavic forms from Proto-Slavic *koren- 'root' and generally connected within Balto-Slavic to Lith. kẽras 'tree-stump, stub, bush, shrub', etc. Further connections outside of Balto-Slavic are uncertain (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):237, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:62-65, [Derksen 2015](src-353):238, [ALEW](src-352) 478 for discussion of various proposals).

SMG κολυμπώ, etc. from Ancient Greek κολυμβάω 'dive headlong (like a κόλυμβος-bird)' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):701), a denominal verb to κόλυμβος 'little grebe, podiceps minor'. Further etymology obscure ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):559, [Beekes 2010](src-66):741).

Cf. also Lith. į́sas 'short'. Baltic lexemes from Proto-Baltic *insa-. Further etymology outside of Baltic uncertain, traditionally connected to Ved. iṣṇāti 'drive, propel' from PIE *h₂ei̯sh₂- 'to invigorate; to drive, propel' (cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):225, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):187). [Not in [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain. Appears to be a derivative from Lithuanian úodas 'mosquito', which is in turn traditionally derived from the same root of Lithuanian ė́sti 'to eat' < PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat', but many uncertainties remain regarding this etymological connection. Cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):704, [ALEW](src-352) 1150-1151, [Derksen 2015](src-353):480 for further discussion.

The etymology is obscure. Although a single etymology of all Slavic lexemes listed in the citations below is formally and semantically possible, it can not be excluded that we deal here with more than one etymon (also with loanwords) with possible later mergers and contaminations. In any case, the hypothesis about an ordinary (Middle) German loanword in the case of the Sorbian, Polish and Czech lexemes for 'ball' seems to be at least an oversimplification.
However, even if we accept a single native etymon here, it is complicated to establish its further etymology and IE cognates without additional assumptions.
Cf. a semantically related PS leeme *gula, e.g. Polish gula 'bump'. Accordingly, expressive deformations are also possible.
In all likelihood a loanword but of uncertain origin (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):87-88, [Orel 1998](src-105):234).
Denominal formations to Vedic mr̥gá- 'wild animal'; further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:370-371).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *leh₃u̯-'to pour; to wash' ([LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) and [Melchert 2011](src-690):127-132; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):511-513, [Beekes 2010](src-66):872-873, [Meyer 1891](src-585):237, [Huld 1984](src-571):85, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):230-231, [Orel 1998](src-105):210, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):980, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):330-331).

Cf. Proto-Iranic *kau̯š- 'to fight, struggle, kill', further derived from PIE *keh₂u̯- 'to beat; to split' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):251-252, [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:525-526, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 345-346).
From Latin gula, probably of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):284-285, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):275 for further discussion).
Derivative from PIE *peu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'to pierce, sting', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 480, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):499 for further discussion.
Identical to 'liver' in other Slavic languages ([Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1714, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 6:72-73, [Derksen 2008](src-81):158).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing derivatives of Ancient Greek παλαίω 'to wrestle' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1024), and probably further to be derived from PIE *pelh₂- 'to approach, draw near' ([LIV²](src-141) 470-471, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1145).

The etymology is not entirely clear due to possible expressive deformations and contaminations.
I adopt here the view of [ESSJa](src-458), see below. However, it has to be treated with caution. Another possibilities, proposed in [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) (see below), are a relationship to PIE *trenk- (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259): 641 and [LIV²](src-141): 649) or to cognate/4961/ (without certain further etymology).
Modern Indic and Slavic lexemes from PIE *h₁enter- 'inner part' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):158, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:72-73, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):16-17 no. 357, [EWAia](src-172) I:76-77, I:166-167).

Traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *kwasta- 'pine brush', Albanian gjeth 'foliage' < *gu̯osd-o- ([ESSJa](src-458) 7:185-186, cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):227 and discussion to Albanian words for 'leaf' in [cognate set 3390](cog-3390)), but considered to be of uncertain etymology according to ([Derksen 2008](src-81):196). The traditional etymology has been tentatively accepted here.

The most promising etymology derives from a zero-grade form of PIE *seh₁- comparable to full-grade forms found in Celtic, Italic, and Germanic, cf. Old Irish sír 'long', Latin sērus 'belated, slow', Proto-Germanic *sīϸu- (so [Jokl 1911](src-661):28, [Orel 1998](src-105):133, but cf. the reservations of [Huld 1984](src-571):68-69).

No certain cognates outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. Latv. dižs 'great'). Commonly conntected with PIE *dei̯h₂- 'to light up' (LIV² 108, IEW 183f.), which is however problematic, as Winter's lengthening is lacking ([ALEW](src-352) 204-205; not in [Derksen 2015](src-353), cf. also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):107-108).

Etymology outside of Greek unknown, possibly to PIE *h₂eu̯- 'to perceive' if a de-adverbial formation as though from *h₂ou̯is-i̯é- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1059-1060, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):785-786).

Anatolian and Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *h₂erg̑- 'brilliant, white' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):307, [Adams 2013](src-345):52-53). For non-target Hellenic and Indic lexemes in this class cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):125, [EWAia](src-172) I:116.

Generally further connected to Greek ἀχλύς 'mist, darkness' and Armenian *ałǰ- in ałǰutʻiwnkʻ 'darkness' ([Derksen 2015](src-353):555, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):184, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):37-39 for further discussion).
Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *sīro- 'long' < PIE *seh₁-ro- 'long lasting (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:115-116, [Matasović 2009](src-50):337).
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *treu̯H- 'to rub; to use' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):496-497, 499; [Boryś 2005](src-259):640-641, 644).
From Ancient Greek *ἀνεμόω 'blow' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):110), a derivative to ἄνεμος 'wind', further to PIE *h₂enh₁- 'blow' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):101-102, [LIV²](src-141) 267-268).

Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either (1) to *kolso- underlying the Germanic and Italic lexemes in [cognate set 265](cog-265), or (2) to PIE *kʷelh₁- ([LIV²](src-141) 386-388) as a reduplicated formation (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 433-434). The latter explanation is favoured by [Derksen 2015](src-353):220. Both proposed etymologies are not precise correspondences and require special pleading to explain the deviations so that it is difficult to favour one etymology over the other (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 434 for further discussion).
Cf. 'take' in [cognate set 5227](cog-5227).

Greek, Armenian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from an original m-stem noun *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´-; based on the ablaut patterns attested among the daughter languages a basic root *g̑ʰei̯- can be abstracted ([NIL](src-274) 162-169, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1619-1620, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1599, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):434-435, [EWAia](src-172) II:815-816, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):815 no. 14096).

A derivative of Portuguese apertar 'tighten, press, clamp', from Latin appectorāre 'press on the chest' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):44), further derived from Latin pectus 'chest'. For connections elsewhere in Indo-European, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):491, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):453, and further discussion in [cognate set 4015](cog-4015).

Slavic lexemes to be further connected with dialectal Lithuanian pìršys 'chest (of a horse)', but further connections outside of Balto-Slavic remain uncertain. Traditionally further compared to Vedic párśu- 'rib' (cf. e.g. [Boryś 2005](src-259):431), but this connection remains unclear for formal reasons ([Derksen 2008](src-81):429, [Derksen 2015](src-353):358, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:100-101).

Cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) s.v. *g̑ʰés- 'gestern' for extensive discussion of the attempted reconstructions of forms in this class, also [NIL](src-274) s.v. *dei̯-, *di- under ?*(g̑ʰ)-di-es (with discussion in footnotes 6-18). The cognacy of the lexemes in this class is not disputed, however there remains much disagreement in the literature how the forms are derived in the attested languages from a common reconstruction. The two most commonly held hypotheses include (1) derivations related to the Germanic word for 'day' (cf. [cognate set 200](cog-200), not without its own problems in derivation) as *dʰg̑ʰ-i̯es- (zero-grade root + comparative suffix or endingless locative) or (2) a compound of the Indo-European deictic *g̑ʰo- ~ *g̑ʰ- (cf. LIPP 2 275-276) in the zero-grade + the root *dei̯- ~ *di- 'shine' ([NIL](src-274) 69-81, cf. esp. fn6), which underlies words for day in many other branches (cf. [cognate set 375](cog-375)). For a recent extensive discussion of these and other hypotheses, cf. LIPP 2 269-270. For individual branches, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1692, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):138, [Orel 1998](src-105):68, [EWAia](src-172) II:822, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:313-314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):175-176, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):283, [Matasović 2009](src-50):155). Cf. also [Schindler 1977](src-689) and [Puhvel 1987](src-588) for further discussion on aspects of the IE reconstruction.
No certain etymology outside of Slavic, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 14:249-252, [Derksen 2008](src-81):274, [Boryś 2005](src-259):280 for further discussion of various hypotheses.

Connections outside of Albanian unclear. The two main hypotheses connect the word either (1) to Germanic and Balto-Slavic words for 'sound' < *g(o)l-so- (so [Orel 1998](src-105):138, cf. [IEW](src-49) 350), or (2) with the IE inherited word for 'tongue' *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- (so [Huld 1984](src-571):71, [Holm 2011](src-130):85).
Slavic lexemes generally derived from PIE *kreu̯H- 'to heap up; to cover' ([LIV²](src-141) 371, [Derksen 2008](src-81):254). For older hypotheses, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 13:71-72.

Modern Greek χρονιά 'year' from Ancient Greek χρόνος 'time' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1613-1614), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1277-1278, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1613-1614 for discussion of older but unconvincing attempts at an IE etymology).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fahsa- 'hair of the head' as though from PIE *pok̑-s-o-, cf. Ancient Greek Gk. πέκος 'fleece' < *pek̑-es-, derived from PIE 1. *pek̑- 'to pluck (wool or hair)' ([Orel 2003](src-388):89, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):122, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1164, [LIV²](src-141) 467).

There is no consensus etymology outside of Slavic (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 7:146-149, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):216, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):353, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 1:463, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)). Against the older proposed comparisons to Latin grandis 'big', Ancient Greek βρένθος 'pride', cf. respectively [de Vaan 2008](src-54):270, [Beekes 2010](src-66):237-238.
Probably of onomatopoeic/imitative origin (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511, no. 9090; [KEWA](src-399) II:307).

Since [Meyer 1892](src-752):18 compared with Armenian jag 'small bird' with various proposed reconstructions to reconcile the comparison (for further discussion cf. [IEW](src-49) 409 s.v. *g̑ʰāgʷʰ-, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):429-430, [Holm 2011](src-130):52-53, and [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):239 most recently proposing a pre-form *g̑ʰu̯eh₂gʰV-). Alternatively [Huld 1984](src-571):135-136, [Orel 1998](src-105):525 assume that the forms are an Oriental Wanderwort comparing also Persian zāq 'chough', but cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):52 rejecting this hypothesis on the grounds that it is not a typical case of a Wanderwort. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):430 remains unconvinced and instead suggests an onomatopoeic origin.
Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰeHbʰ- 'to be fitting, suitable' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):109-110, [LIV²](src-141) 135-136, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 5:45-46).

Comment: Sims-Williams (2000: 232f., quoted from Korn 2005: 132) suggests *su̯l̥g̑ʰ-su- in order to explain Bactrian χοζο. Korn (l.c.) assumes *su̯elk̑s for xwaš-forms.

Justification: Loanword from Turkish χob 'beautiful', ultimately from Persian hūb 'beautiful' ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 4:284).

It is unclear whether Josef Elfenbein apud [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):38 is implying that Pashto kāl 'year' is cognate with the Indic lexemes in this class, or that it is a loanword. If cognate, together with the Indic lexemes from Vedic kālá- 'time, point in time' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):157, no. 3084) they would point to a Proto-Indo-Iranic *kālá-. The cognacy of these forms has been tentatively accepted here for now. No further certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:343 for a discussion of the main possibilities.
A probable loan from Wakhi ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):662, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):188).
Slavic lexemes generally derived from a causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to seat (oneself)' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):202-203, [ESSJa](src-458) 8:49-52, [LIV²](src-141) 513-515).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-European *mleu̯h₂- 'to speak' ([LIV²](src-141) 446-447, [EWAia](src-172) II:235-236, [Cheung 2007](src-83):274-275).

The vast majority of Slavic etymology dictionaries assume or accept the etymology presented in [ESSJa](src-458): 112, cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 2: 508; [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 351; [Boryś 2005](src-259): 302-303; [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 2: 152; [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594); [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602): 277-278; [Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603): 3: 449; [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607): 6: 25; {Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989}: 772-773. The hypothesis of {Machek 1968}: 328, assuming a relatedness to Polish polować 'hunt' does not stand up scrutiny (it is impossible phonetically, morphologically and philologically).
According to the mainstream hypothesis, PS *loviti is related to Lithuanian lavùs 'dexterous', Greek Attic λεία (*λᾱϝιᾱ), Doric λᾱία 'gain', Latin lucrum 'gain', Gothic laun, Old High German lôn 'reward' and Old Irelandic folad 'richness', lúag 'praise' and derived from PIE *leh₂u 'aquire by fighting' (for the root reference form see [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 349-350 or [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 329).
However, [Derksen 2008](src-81): 286 does not mention this etymology at all, claiming "To my knowledge, there are no cognates outside Balto-Slavic". The Slavic lexeme is not listed among cognates of the relevant words by [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 329, [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 349-350 and [Matasović 2009](src-50): 397-398. According to [Beekes 2010](src-66): 188, who compares Greek ἀπολαύω with Latin lucrum and Gothic laun, "the appurtenance of OCS lovъ 'catch, chase', loviti 'to catch, chase' would require *lh₂eu-, which is an improbable formation".
The etymology is accepted by [de Vries 1961](src-214): 347-348 and [Lehmann 1986](src-179): 228-229. The mainstream hypothesis is accepted here, although the case needs further investigation.

Derivatives from Proto-Slavic *poļe 'field' (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):460, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602):486-487, 506, [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 8:137), and further to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ({ref NIL 562-564, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):411). Taking into account the distribution and a rather non-trivial semantic derivation, one could expect, that this form developed in one of these languages and was diffused into the other. However, the source language is impossible to determine phonetically or morphologically.
Etymology uncertain (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1269 for further discussion). [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353). cf. also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):765].

Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *u̯et- 'year' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):1014-1015, [Beekes 2010](src-66):476-477, [Huld 1984](src-571):129-130, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):419-420, [Orel 1998](src-105):509, [EWAia](src-172) II:495).

The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated (cf. esp. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):819-821, [EWAia](src-172) I:728-729), the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is, however, generally agreed (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):819-821, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):184-185, [Orel 1998](src-105):130, [EWAia](src-172) I:728-729, [ALEW](src-352) 392-393, [Derksen 2015](src-353):199-200, [Derksen 2008](src-81):133, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):360-361, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):327, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):348). The reconstructed root form for this class follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Romance forms from Latin cīrcā, an adverbial form of Latin cīrcus 'circle; circus' ([DCECH](src-423) II:42). Further probably a loanword from Ancient Greek κίρκος, κρίκος 'ring' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):122-123, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):115).

Hittite āššu-/āššau̯- 'good' is generally connected to Ancient Greek ἐΰς 'good, brave, noble' and Ved. sú- 'good' < *h₁su-, but the details of the inner-Anatolian stem formation is still debated ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):223-225).

The link to PIE *terkʷ- is formally and semantically attractive. An alternative etymology points to PIE *(s)ter- 'hard(en)', cf. [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598), however it has formal and semantical issues (cf. [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 4:227)

Romance lexemes from Latin gȳrāre 'to turn around in a circle' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):335), a denominal verb from Latin gȳrus 'circle', a technical term borrowed from Ancient Greek γῦρος 'ring, circle' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):286).
IE root etymology difficult. This class tentatively follows [Beekes 2010](src-66):1503-1504, [LIV²](src-141) 650 s.v. *trep-, but cf. also [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1132-1133.

Neapolitan avutà as though from Latin *voltāre 'to turn' (Giovanni Abete, p.c., cf. Meyer-Lübke 1935}:789), an unattested intensive/iterative formation to Latin voluō 'to turn' and further to PIE 2. u̯el- 'to turn, roll' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):752, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):689-690, [LIV²](src-141) 675).

No certain etymology outside of Baltic; perhaps to be connected with Lithuanian leĩlas 'slender', but the semantics of the comparison are difficult (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 580). Traditionally to a root 2. *lei̯- 'eingehen, abnehmen, schwinden; mager, schlank' in [IEW](src-49) 661-662, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:525.

Generally connected with Vedic ásita 'dark coloured, black' and Young Avestan āhita- (if meaning 'spotted, unclean'). Further etymology unclear (cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):482, [EWAia](src-172) I:146).
Etymology obscure (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):200 for discussion)

As [Derksen 2008](src-81): 228-229 points out, there are two candidates for the root etymology: PIE *kelH 'rise, rise above' [LIV²](src-141): 349 and *kʷelh₁- 'turn, rotate' [LIV²](src-141): 386-388 (reconstructed as *kʷel(H) by Derksen). From the formal, phonetic point of view there can not be any clue in Slavic. Moreover, the proximity of two proto-meanings (having the concept of movement in common) makes it in my opinion impossible to raise any convincing semantic arguments even in external comparisons with other IE forms. Cf. [ESSJa](src-458): 10: 133. Therefore, any strict decision would be speculative.
Authors of the Slavic etymology rather tend to see *kʷel(H) here, see [Boryś 2005](src-259): 243 or [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594).

Etymology disputed. Possibly to PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- ([IEW](src-49) 541-2) if one follows [Orel 1998](src-105):200, 482 to Alb. thyej 'break' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 319-320, without Albanian lexemes listed); older etymologies (e.g. [Meyer 1891](src-585):185, [Jokl 1911](src-661):94) suggest a borrowing from Lat. convertere. The verb is not discussed in [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364).

Two variants *kʷr̥mi- and *u̯r̥mi- in the same meaning 'worm' are generally reconstructed for PIE. The variant *u̯r̥mi- attested in Germanic and Italic might have been secondary from *kʷr̥mi- (cf. {de Vaan 2008}:665), but it may also be possible that the two lexemes were a rhyming pair already in Indo-European poetic language (cf. [Watkins 1987](src-696):288). Cf. also [Demiraj 1997](src-369):225-226, [Orel 1998](src-105):197, [EWAia](src-172) I:394-395, [ALEW](src-352) 493-494, [Derksen 2015](src-353):246, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:171-172 [Derksen 2008](src-81)93-94, [Matasović 2009](src-50):181-182.

Iranic and Italic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'to suckle' ([MacKenzie 1990](src-680):110, [EWAia](src-172) I:797, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):210, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):281, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 138-139).

Parallel loans from Indic lexemes continued by Sanskrit haḍḍa- 'bone' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):807 no. 13952, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):35). The Pashto form represents a diminutive and matches Gawarbati haḍoki.
Loan from Iranic *ā(w)yak ([Morgenstierne 1936](src-701):666).

Indic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *(s)kend- 'to shine' ([EWAia](src-172) I:528-529, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):252 no. 4661, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):199-200, [Orel 1998](src-105):146-147, [Holm 2011](src-130):70-71; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 554).

Comment: This seems to be a compound with the first part "or" being the actual word for "cloud" (given variously as orǝ́, owrǝ́, warǝ́, which derives from common *nebʰ- (cf. NP abr).

Bielmeier (1979: 189 in: Historische Untersuchung zum Erb- und Lehnwortschatzanteil im ossetischen Grundwortschatz, Frankfurt/Bern/Las Vegas: Lang) argues against the assumption that lenk is a loan from Caucasian languages and discusses the possibility of an IE origin by comparing it with Lithuanian leñgvas 'light' and Germanic *lenhw-ta-z (cf. Gothic leihts).

Justification: An i-stem adjective derived to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, wide' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):620-621, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).

Traditionally connected with Lithuanian al̃pti 'to be weak; to crave, to yearn after', but without any certain correspondences outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 35-36, [Derksen 2015](src-353):52, [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:264-265).

From Ancient Greek σαχνός 'tender' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), often further assumed to be connected to σώχω, ψώχω 'to rub down' but the details of the derivation are unclear; further etymology outside of Greek lacking ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):991, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1314).

Comment: Loan from Dravidian

Justification:
The ingenous and popular etymology as *dus-di̯u- 'bad sky, bad day' is kept here. However, is should be born in mind that this etymology is considered to be doubtful or at least not the only thinkable by many scholars, cf. the citations below and [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 1: 521-522, [Rejzek 2001](src-593): 129, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 1: 100.
One of the most widespread alternative etymologies assumes a relationship to PG *duska- 'drizzle(?)', see [Kroonen 2013](src-165): 111.

Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ([IEW](src-49) 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):97-98, [Derksen 2015](src-353):530-531, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89, [Kluge 2011](src-397):907 for further discussion.

No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:763). For Modern Indic forms cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):792 no. 13734. Cf. parallel loans from Sanskrit into Modern Indic in [cognate set 5789](cog-5789).

From Latin repōnere 'to put back, down; replace' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 10:269-270), further probably derived from PIE *tk̑ei̯- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 643-644, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):479 for discussion of the stem formation in Italic).

Cf. Latvian sēta 'fence', generally considered to be a derivative of PIE *seh₂(i̯)- 'to tie, bind' ([Karulis 1992](src-534):175, for further discussion on the root reconstruction, cf. [cognate set 3055](cog-3055)).

It is assumed of the Polish word to be a loanword from Czech (which can be further a loan from German). If it is true, the Kashubian word is most probably a loanword from Polish. An additional survey would be needed here. The Czech lexemes have probably also a complicated history. A contamination of two different etymona (on of which can be a loanword) is probable. Cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):677, [Rejzek 2001](src-593):698.

Comment: *č > Sarikoli c (ts)
from root *k̑eh₃-, expected output would be hīne etc.

Justification: Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Lith. kvė̃pti 'breathe' ([ALEW](src-352) 545-546, [Derksen 2015](src-353):268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison (cf. Chantraine 1968–1980}:494-495, [Beekes 2010](src-66):638-639).
Romance lexemes with nominal *ped- (from Lat. pēs, pedis) as semantic-bearing morpheme in a light verb construction. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'foot' in [cognate set 225](cog-225).

Romanian alerga, as though from Latin *allargāre, a verbal derivative of lārgus ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):28, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further etymology uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):342, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):327).

A derived verb from Modern Greek γούλα 'throat, neck' (cf. SMG αναγουλιάζω 'feel sick, be inclined to vomit', [Babinotis 2010](src-382):116), in turn a loanword from Latin gula 'throat' (cf. 'neck' in [cognate set 6065](cog-6065)).

Derived from the same root as Proto-Slavic *drāpati 'scratch', ultimately from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 1:465, [Derksen 2008](src-81):115, 136, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 128-129).
Possibly a compound of σ̌ομό (< θερμό) ‘food’ + ἐλατός ‘driven’, cf. Tsak. γαϊδουρο-άτα (< -ἐλάτης ‘driver’) (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further etymology uncertain.

Often connected with the family of Ancient Greek πείρω 'pierce, run through' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 472-473 s.v. 1. *per- 'hindurchkommen, durchqueren') with a velar extension to the root, but the root and stem formation remains nonetheless obscure (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):934-935, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1229-1230).

Etymology uncertain. For a conjectural proposal to the family of words surrounding Lithuanian ùpė 'river' < PIE *h₂ep- 'water', cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1169. [Not in [ALEW](src-352) or [Derksen 2015](src-353).]

Comment: derived *-tá- participle/adj. from Proto-Indo-Iranian *d(ʱ)arj́(ʱ)- '(be/become/make) fix, solid', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 371, no. 6508, Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 706f.
Justification: Indic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *d⁽ʰ⁾arjʰ- 'to fix; be firm, strong', further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):371 no. 6508, [EWAia](src-172) I:707-708).

Hellenic and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived traditionally assigned to a root *peth₁- 'to fall' ([LIV²](src-141) 477-478, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):905-906, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1195-1196). See now [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) considering a more basic PIE root *pet- 'to fall; to fly' merging also 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' ([LIV²](src-141) 479). Cf. also [EWAia](src-172) II:71-72).

From Latin ex-pōnere 'to put out, set forth' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further probably derived from PIE *tk̑ei̯- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 643-644, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):479 for discussion of the stem formation in Italic).

Comment: original meaning "dirt, dust"

Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- 'to blow' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):368, [Adams 2013](src-345):546, [EWAia](src-172) II:542, [ALEW](src-352) 1226-1227, [Derksen 2015](src-353):496, [Derksen 2008](src-81):519-520, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):587, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):662-663, [Matasović 2009](src-50):47, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 287).

Comment: *č > Sarikoli c (ts)

Justification: Root etymology in this class follows the proposal of [Jokl 1911](src-661):61-62 to an inner-Albanian connection with dhjes 'shit (on), ruin' to PIE *g̑ʰed- ({ref IEW 423; tentatively followed by [LIV²](src-141) 172, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):290-291); cf. alternatively [Orel 1998](src-105):287 following [Meyer 1891](src-585):301 assumes a connection to Albanian ndyj 'to make dirty, soil, to dip, immerse' connecting to Gk. δύω 'to sink, cause to sink, to plunge in' < *du̯eH- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 129-130, without Albanian).

From Ancient Greek ξηρός (adj.) 'dry' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):355), further connections outside of Greek unclear; occasionally proposed to Arm. čʻor 'dry' (cf. [cognate set 5006](cog-5006)), but this requires postulating a sound law in Armenian for which this is the only example (cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):182, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1035-1036, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):546).

Comment: Mayrhofer (EWAia I 415) mentions doubtful relation with an OInd. root kroḍ and Wurzelerweiterungstypus *°EU̯-s-d-. It may fit to Celtic *krou̯di- and Slavic *krǫt-?

Kroonen writes that the Germanic words may either be related to forms such as Greek κρατύς and Sanskrit krátu- (with Germanic showing Schwebeablaut) or related to Lithuanian kir̃sti 'to turn sour'. According to ALEW, this verb is derived from the PIE root *(s)kert- 'to cut, to cut in two'.In the EWA, the two explanations Kroonen mentions are actually unified, the root reconstruction being "uridg. *(s)kret- (oder [s]kert- [?])".The LIV² only has a root *(s)kert-.
Justification: Lexemes from Proto-Germanic *hardu- to be derived from PIE *kortú- from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (up)' (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):280-282, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):211).

No certain etymology. Traditionally compared to Lithuanian garbinỹs, garbìnis 'lock of hair', but the semantic distance makes this etymology doubtful ([ALEW](src-352) 295-296, cf. [IEW](src-49) 387 reconstructing *gerb-, but note that this reconstruction violates the known restriction on IE roots beginning and ending with voiced-unaspirated stops).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):219 no. 4104, [KEWA](src-399) I:332, [EWAia](src-172) I:480).
Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):767, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1037-1038; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.

Etymology uncertain. [Orel 1998](src-105):30 considers a loan from Latin molere; [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):967 consider the lexemes inherited, possibly but not certainly to be connected with PIE *melh₂- since the stem formation remains unclear.

Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):150-151 for discussion of various proposals. [Orel 1998](src-105):79 wants a connection to PIE *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dru- on the basis of the dialectal variant drusk 'oak', but the priority of this form is uncertain and could well be a contamination with the word for 'tree' in [cognate set 503](cog-503) (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):151).
Generally connected with Germanic words for 'dark' < *dʰerg- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:57-58, [Matasović 2009](src-50):96; cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):153, [IEW](src-49) 251).

Etymology outside of Baltic uncertain. Sometimes compared to Lithuanian gaĩla 'painful, unfortunate, pitiable', although the connection is uncertain due to the diverging semantics ([ALEW](src-352) 280-281, cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):161, accepting the etymology).

Lexemes in the meaning 'red' derived from IE *kʷr̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye. For Sogdian kyrm- 'snake, worm' > qyrmyr, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:394-395. There are some formal difficulties in reconciling Proto-Slavic *čьrvь 'worm, maggot' to PIE *kʷr̥mi-, but the cognacy is generally agreed (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 4:149-150, 169-170; [Derksen 2008](src-81):91-93 for further discussion), cf. also [cognate set 1163](cog-1163). See 'worm' in [cognate set 172](cog-172) for further etymological discussion.

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleth₂- 'become wide, spread oneself out' ([NIL](src-274) 564, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1205, [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451, [Olsen 1999](src-180):767, [EWAia](src-172) II:162-163, 179, [ALEW](src-352) 787-789, [Derksen 2015](src-353):362, [Matasović 2009](src-50):135, [LIV²](src-141) 486-487).
Generally connected with Lithuanian šùlas 'post, pole, stave' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):767, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1037-1038; cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1053-1054) from PIE *ksúlo- 'block of wood'.

Italic and Romance lexemes from Latin umbra, possibly to be further connected to Lithuanian ùnksna 'shade, shadow' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):639, [Derksen 2015](src-353):479, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1164) but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1147, 1149-1150, doubting connections outside of Lithuanian and with further discussion. Further connections outside of Italic consequently unclear.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; may be a formal match to Ancient Greek ῥίπτω 'throw' but the semantic match is quite difficult (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):565, [Kluge 2011](src-397):755, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):975, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1287-1288 for further discussion).

Cf. Lithuanian ràkti 'to stab, dig'; no further etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):498-499); traditionally compared to Vedic r̥kṣá- 'bald, bare' ([Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):694, [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:103, [IEW](src-49) 335) but cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:248 considering the proposed Vedic comparanda of dubious etymology. [Not in [ALEW](src-352), [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Two variants *kʷr̥mi- and *u̯r̥mi- in the same meaning 'worm' are generally reconstructed for PIE. The variant *u̯r̥mi- attested in Germanic and Italic might have been secondary from *kʷr̥mi- (cf. {de Vaan 2008}:665), but it may also be possible that the two lexemes were a rhyming pair already in Indo-European poetic language (cf. [Watkins 1987](src-696):288). Cf. also [Lehmann 1986](src-179):397, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):600).

The connection of the Baltic and Slavic lexemes to each other is generally agreed upon, but extra Balto-Slavic connections, and subsequently any precise IE root reconstruction, remain debated. [ALEW](src-352) (90-91 s.v. OLith. *bálti 'weiß, blass, bleich werden') suggests that a connection with PIE *bʰeh₂- 'shine' is not inconceivable; [Derksen 2008](src-81):40 and [Derksen 2015](src-353):80 postulate a root *bʰelH-. The reconstructed PIE root ref. form for this class follows that of Derksen, but it should be borne in mind that this form remains provisional as the morphological analysis of the Balto-Slavic forms and their proposed further IE connections have yet to be satisfactorily explained. Cf. also [ESSJa](src-458) 2:79-81.
Gk. κοντός 'short' appears to derive from the same root as Ancient Greek κεντέω 'to sting, goad', for further discussion cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):563, [Beekes 2010](src-66):672-673.

Cf. Latin *tāliare 'to cut' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):704-705), a derivative to Latin tālea 'a cutting, piece of wood'. No further etymology ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):673-674, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):605).

Etymology uncertain. [Meyer 1891](src-585):365 proposed a loan from Latin grandis 'large', rejected by [Jokl 1911](src-661):74 considering Alb. rëndë a participle of a now lost verb cognate with Lith. rė́ju 'put together' (followed by [Huld 1984](src-571):108. [Orel 1998](src-105):370 supposes a connection with a stem *raunta- derived from rashë, the aorist stem of bie 'fall', although his proposed further IE connections for this verb are uncertain (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):343 "Eine sichere etymologische Deutung für dieses ohne Zweifel uralte suppletive Verb ist nicht in Sicht.").
Loan from Turkic.

Despite some morphological difficulties, the formal and semantic relationships make a common origin of PS *xolkŭ, *xolstŭ, *pa-xolŭ and *xoliti ver plausible.
According to [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 554-555 the etymology of Lithuanian skaláuti 'wash, flush' is not entirely clear; it can belong to skeliù, skélti 'chop, split', derived from PIE *skelh₁- (cf. *skelH- [LIV²](src-141): 553). Smoczyński gives here only PS *ščelĭ 'aperture' as a Slavic cognate. The etymology is mentioned but not accepted by [KEWA](src-399): 288.
Thus, even if we accept an underlying *xol-, its further etymology is obscure.

Romance lexemes based on a denominal verb from Latin fīlum 'thread, string' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):286-287, [DCECH](src-423) III:361-362); further from PIE *gʷʰiH-(s-)lo- 'sinew, sinew thread'. The Italic forms require the reconstruction of initial voiced-aspirated *gʷʰ-, but other proposed cognates from Indo-Iranian and Greek suggest initial *gʷ- without aspiration (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):220; listed in [IEW](src-49) 489 with only Italic, Celtic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes connected).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):426-427, [Orel 1998](src-105):521, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1009-1010 for various possibilities and further discussion.

Comment: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 111)

Justification: From Proto-Germanic *kwēda- 'shit, excrement' (n.). 'bad' (adj.) ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):348-349), generally considered to continue a derivative from a PIE root *gʷeh₁dʰ- 'disgusting, gross' ([EWNl](src-757), [Orel 2003](src-388):229, cf. ALEW} 303-304, [Derksen 2008](src-81):160-161 [not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165)]).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974)

Justification: Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain. [Orel 1998](src-105):137-138 prefers a connection to Old High German jagōn (cf. [cognate set 243](cog-243)), which has no certain etymology outside of Germanic itself; [Demiraj 1997](src-369):191-192 who rejects the connection with the Germanic lexemes and suggests instead a connection with Lat. sāgiō 'spüren, ahnen, wittern', OIr. 'nachgehen einer Sache, suchen' to PIE *seh₂g- '(witternd) nachspüren'. If so, perhaps to be connected within Albanian to 'hear' in [cognate set 8546](cog-8546). Undiscussed, however, in connection to Albanian gjegj in [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):974-975.

From Hellenistic Greek πιάζω, analogically remodelled into the -νω class inflection ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1189, Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further to Ancient Greek πιέζω, of uncertain etymology (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):899-900, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1189 for various proposals).

Comment: probably via Persian

Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing a derivative of PIE *keh₂- 'to desire' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):227, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:334, [LIV²](src-141) 343).

Taking into account lexemes like Polish ryj 'snout' and Russian rylo 'snout' (that can be expressively used also for human mouth), both derived from PIE *reu̯H- 'dig' (the original meanig was probably 'pig snout'), there is no reason to doubt on the relationship of PS *rŭtŭ to PIE *reu̯H-. The alternative etymology is much worse from the semantic point of view.
Etymology outside of Anatolian uncertain ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):554).

The best IE etymology, is a derivation to *h₂u̯ers- 'rain' (so [Wackernagel 1888](src-670):129 = Kl.Schr. 1.632, tentatively accepted by [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):838-839, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1128). The hypothesis of substrate borrowing is a possibility but, given that there is no concrete extra-Greek comparison for it, gratuitous. For the purposes of cognacy Wackernagel's etymology has been followed here.

Comment: onomatopoetic? but cf. Turkish kuš "bird"

Uncertain if all of these belong together. Iberian lexemes are of uncertain origin, von Wartburg FEW suggests Lat. lixare for Fr. lexemes. Initial g- for Franco-Provençal seems unexpected for the suggested etymologies for other branches (isolated blend?). We may also be dealing with contamination/blending/expressive distortions. Class needs careful reviewing language by language (-MJCS 31.10.2017).

Justification: A derivative of Hittite iškii̯e/a- 'to daub, salve'. Further etymology unclear, cf. [Tischler 1983](src-578):404, [HED A+E/I](src-406):426-428 for various proposals.

Etymology outside of Hellenic uncertain, possibly to be connected with verbs φλέω 'to teem with abundance, abound' and φλύω 'to boil over, bubble up' as derivatives of PIE *bʰleu̯H- 'to overflow'; cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1214, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1580, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1546-1547.

Related to Luvian īš(ša)ra/i- 'hand' via an unattested derivative *išaru-/išaru̯a- 'right-hand' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):471-472, cf. [NIL](src-274) 170-173). For further etymological details cf. 'hand' in [cognate set 411](cog-411).

Comment: This is obviously a complex predicate with an element 'war' + light verb "to do". 'war' could mean "there" (< *awáϑra) and 'kawǝl' in the sense of "put" (cf. German 'hineintun' : "to put in").

Justification: Possibly to *h₁u̯ers-, if cognate with Vedic varṣá- 'rain', and Ancient Greek ἐέρση 'dew' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):971-972).

The etymology is disputable.
Greek σπόγγος and Latin fungus are considered to be (parallel) loanwords from a non-IE language (*spʰong-), cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66): 1385 and [de Vaan 2008](src-54): 250. Greek γαμφηλαί may be Pre-Greek or related to γόμφος, a cognate of PS *zǫbŭ 'tooth' [Beekes 2010](src-66): 260, 282.
Lithuanian lexemes like gùbti, gum̃ba, gùbo; gaũbti, gaubiù, gaubiaũ; gum̃bas with derivatives, referring, in general, to 'bending, folding' and various 'protrusions, bulges', are related to PS *gŭb-, *ɡub-, *ɡyb- [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 161-162, 207, 77 (addenda). (However, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) does not point to PS *gǫba directly.) Slavic and Baltic forms are derived from PIE *gʰeu̯bʰ-. As this root is limited to Balto-Slavic, it has been proposed, that is is a metathese-deformation of PIE *bʰeu̯gʰ-, cf. Gothic biugan 'bend' and Vedc paribhuját 'enfold'. See [Smoczyński 2007](src-531): 162 and [LIV²](src-141): 85-86, 188.
As it is convincing formally and semantically, I assume that PS *gǫba is derived from PIE *gʰeu̯bʰ-. Its further relationship to PIE *bʰeu̯gʰ- is not excluded but remains speculative.

Comment: Sarikoli with prefix *awa-?

Justification: An derivative of the root *u̯eh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'to break' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):939-940, [LIV²](src-141) 664-665).

Comment: Iranic forms that derive from MIr. *wind- would belong to cognate set 8643
Justification: The Iranian forms in this set are based on a secondary root *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' of denominal origin, already attested in Old Iranian (Avestan vaēnaiti, Old Persian vainatiy; cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):412-413). For the primary verbal root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 668-669 s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁-.

Etymology in this class follows [Oettinger 1979](src-649):523-524, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):195-196 to *h₃er-; but cf. [LIV²](src-141) assigning to *h₁er- (although [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) also listing *h₃er- as a possible root etymology).

Comment: From Old French escorce which itself either goes back directly to Latin or is a loan from Medieval Latin scorcia, cf. http://www.etymologiebank.nl/trefwoord/schors. Thus ultimately connected to [cognate set 182](cog-182).
Cheung (2007: 375) seems to prefer a derivation from *teh₂- "to flow, stream; to melt" partly "(certainly influenced by *tač)".

Justification: Romance forms from Latin computāre ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):199), further to PIE *pi̯eh₂- ([LIV²](src-141) 481-482), cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):451-452, 502 for an account of the stem formation within Italic.
Romance lexemes derived from Latin plānus 'level, flat' and further derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'id.' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 9:27, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):470, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).
Root etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):313, [Orel 2003](src-388):347, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):452 for further discussion.

Comment: Morgenstierne (2003: 64) *para-azna-

Justification: Romance lexemes continuing Latin dorsum 'back' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):247). The etymology as though from Latin *dē-uorsum is based on a popular etymology from Festus, but there are no better suggestions. If so, then the lexemes continue a derivative of PIE *u̯ert- 'to turn around' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):184, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):180, 667).

Comment: duuaraiti suggested to be derived from *dreu̯- with metathesis (also suggested by Cheung 2007: 84, or ϑu̯ar/tūr). However, since this root is also attested in its expected form drauu-/drūta- (daevic), this seems less likely. [but Schwartz JRAS 1966: 119ff. considers the latter to belong to dhreu̯- “deceive”]
Justification: Continuing Proto-Iranic *du̯ar- 'to run', further etymology difficult (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):83-84 for discussion).

The further connections of the Germanic adjective *ubila- 'bad' are debated. It is generally agreed that OIr. fel 'bad, evil' may be formally identical with the Germanic lexemes from earlier *upelo-, if the Celtic lexemes are not borrowings from Old French fel 'faithless, unfaithful, disloyal' (cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):637-638, [Matasović 2009](src-50):396, [Kluge 2011](src-397):938, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):557). Debated remain the further proposed connections to Hitt. ḫuu̯appa-, connected since [Juret 1942](src-714):71 and further advocated by [Watkins 1969](src-391):30, [Melchert 1988](src-416):233n1, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):369-371, but doubted or rejected by [Lehmann 1986](src-179):371, [Kluge 2011](src-397):938, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):557. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) tentatively reconstructs *h₂u̯óbʰh₁-/h₂u̯(é)bʰh₁- for the proposed Anatolian cognates.

From Ancient Greek μόλω, the aorist subjunctive to Ancient Greek βλώσκω 'go, come' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):381), further to PIE *melh₃- 'to come' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):223, [LIV²](src-141) 433-434).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to kindle; to burn' ([LIV²](src-141) 345, [Beekes 2010](src-66):618, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):480-481). For the root reconstruction with initial palatovelar *k̑- (rather than plain velar *k-) cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Etymology uncertain ([EWNl](src-757)). Often assumed to be connected in some way with Proto-Germanic *dragan- 'to draw, pull, carry' (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):506-507, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):522) but the sound changes necessary to make this connection are irregular.
Further etymology not yet ascertained (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:596).

Despite of the formal similarity of Polish miano and Kashubian miono with doubtless reflexes of PS *jĭmę, *jĭmene, the relationship of the former to the latter is far from clear. The main formal problem is the root vowel (*-ě- vs. *-e-). The lack of initial i- in miano, miono is, in general, not a crucial issue.
Some sources entirely ignore the formal problems [Derksen 2008](src-81), [ESSJa](src-458). Vasmer proposes a protoform *jĭměn- for Polish miano [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 130, however he does not explain the nature of this irregular lengthening.
Polish etymologists assume that imię and miano are two distinct etymona, the former being a reflex of a common IE lexeme for 'name' and the latter being a derivative of a verbal root referring to 'thinking', 'mentioning', 'considering as', 'giving a name' etc. Cf. {Boryś 2005}: 320. The formal anlysis is hindered by morphological levellings and conaminations. If Kashubian miono is derived from PS *měno, -o- has been taken from plural forms of *jĭmę, *jĭmene, cf. Polish imiona 'names'. According to the general policy, a cautious view is adopted here. As to the root reference form *men-, see [LIV²](src-141): 435-436.

Comment: original meaning "to smell badly, stink", note the MP term gannāg mēnōg "evil spirit" and note that the Zoroastrian hell is stinking badly.

Justification: Generally compared with Latin badius 'bay, chestnut brown', but without any further correspondences elsewhere in Indo-European; cf. [Lucht 2007](src-151) for extensive discussion of alternative proposed etymologies (cf. also [Matasović 2009](src-50):70, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:113, [de Bernardo Stempel 1999](src-733):358, [IEW](src-49) 104-105).

A Germanic and Balto-Slavic isogloss, therefore postulating a root reconstruction *skeu̯bʰ- to PIE remains uncertain ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):6, [LIV²](src-141) 560. Cf. also [Kroonen 2013](src-165):444-445 who additionally compares Sanskrit kṣóbhate 'to shake, tremble' and postulates a root *kseubʰ- with a metathesis occurring in the Balto-Slavic and Germanic forms; more skeptical to extra-Germanic connections cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):416-417).

Comment: Gharib (1995: 217 §5434) translates the Sogdian word mrγ by "wood, meadow" and relates it to mrγ- "straight, flat".

Justification: Romance forms from Latin plōrāre 'to cry, weep' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):548-549, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 9:76-79, [DCECH](src-423) III:732-733), further etymology unclear (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):516, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):473-474).

An adjective derived to Standard Modern Greek βρόμα 'stench', considered by [Babinotis 2010](src-382):279 to be a derivative of Ancient Greek βρομέω 'I make a noise' with a semantic change via the sense 'I smell bad' → 'I stink' perhaps via an intermediary sense 'I farted'. No further etymology.
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain. Cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):484, [Orel 2003](src-388):333 for a tenuous proposal to Av. kamna- 'few, little'. No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Ancient Greek βοάω 'to cry, shout' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):185), a denominal verb to Ancient Greek βοή 'cry, shout'. No certain further etymology, possibly an onomatopoeic formation (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):182-183, [Beekes 2010](src-66):224).
From Proto-Iranic *nau(H)- 'to cry, wail', further to PIE *neu̯(H)- 'to cry out, shout' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):284, [EWAia](src-172) II:23-24, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 456-457).
Loanword from Arabic (via Persian).
Uncertain, perhaps cognate with Ossetic xwyr, xwyra 'gravel, pebble' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:476, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:266).
Denominal adjective from Classical Armenian ałt 'filth'. Further etymology outside of Armenian disputed, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):39-40 for various proposals.

East Romance lexemes from Latin *sappere ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), originally a denominal verb from Latin sappa 'a kind of mattock'. Further etymology obscure; an Illyrian loanword? (Cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):801, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):594).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek στεγνός 'watertight, waterproof', originally as a substantive τὸ στεγνόν 'covered dwelling' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1325). Further derived from PIE *(s)teg- 'to cover' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1046, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1393, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 589).

Comment: the Sarikoli development of PIE *skobʰ- > PIr. *kap/f- is čov-/čift- (see Cheung 2007: 235)

Justification: A loan from early Scandinavian (cf. Old Norse skinn), already attested in Old English schynn, scynn, scin ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed. Traditionally considered a labial-extension to the root *dʰu̯eh₂- 'make smoke' ([IEW](src-49) 247-248, [Orel 2003](src-388):68, [Kluge 2011](src-397):180; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158). Alternatively [Kroonen 2013](src-165):88 sets up a derived noun to PGmc. *dimpan ~ *dempan- 'to fog' < *dʰembʰ- (cf. MHG dimpfen 'to smoke, steam' Elfdalian dimba 'to smoke', Nw. demba 'to smoke'; but cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):180 who considers the MHG form a backformation to MHG dampf, not in [LIV²](src-141).).

Iberian Romance lexemes derived from Latin amārus 'bitter' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):31-32, [DCECH](src-423) I:233-235). Further traditionally compared to Sanskrit amlá- 'sour, acid', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, cold', but many formal details remain unclear (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):25, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):37; cf. [EIEC](src-657) 69).

Comment: 'kindle, burn'
Justification: Secondary semantic shift from 'dry' > 'hard'. Etymology here follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1000 and [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), but be aware some scholars [Orel 1998](src-105):471, [Holm 2011](src-130):58-59, following [Meyer 1891](src-585):88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in [cognate set 7551](cog-7551) (cf. the skepticism of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):392).

Romance lexemes from Latin brūtus 'heavy, brute; brutish' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):121-122), generally considered to be a dialectal loanword from Sabellic with a labial reflex of initial *gʷ- from PIE *gʷr̥h₂-, cf. Latin grauis 'heavy' in [cognate set 6470](cog-6470) ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):76-77, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):76).

Etymology here follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1000 and [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), but be aware some scholars [Orel 1998](src-105):471, [Holm 2011](src-130):58-59, following [Meyer 1891](src-585):88 consider this set cognate with *h₂seu̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 285, without Albanian cognates listed) in [cognate set 7551](cog-7551) (cf. the skepticism of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):392).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek μακρός 'long' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):810), ultimately a zero-grade derivative *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):660-661, [Beekes 2010](src-66):895, [NIL](src-274) 478-481).

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek χῶμα 'earth thrown up, bank, mound' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1619), an abstract noun derived to the same root as Ancient Greek χώννυμι 'to heap up, raise, stuff with rubbish or earth' from PIE *g̑ʰeu̯- 'to pour' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1654, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1281, [LIV²](src-141) 179).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 478) relates the Saka word hāysiñä "fountain (?)" to the Sogdian word ʾwʾz, which he relates to Ossetic awazun etc. "to dam up". The latter is given by Cheung as a cognate of *waz-, which also means "to swim" in some Iranic languages.

Justification: The etymology pointing to PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'sew' is not commonly accepted, cf. also [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595): 41-42 and [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 4:434-435. It is, however, convincing formally and semantically (and has parallels).

Comment: loan from Pashto
with prefix apa-
Cheung (2007: 368) assumes a root su(m)p/b "to make up, beautify" together with the prefix ni- "down"
PIE form tentatively suggested by Cheung (2007: 361)

< Old Marathi tāṁbaḍā ʻredʼ, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 329, no. 5779 s.v. Vedic tāmrá- adj. ʻdark red, copper-colouredʼ (VS), n. ʻcopperʼ (Kauś), tāmraka- n. Yājñ. (√tam-), cf. PIE *tmHró- from *temH- 'be dark, dull, wan, mat, lacklustre, beamless, dim, tarnished' and 'faint', cf. ²LIV, p. 624 with note 1

Justification: Hellenic lexemes from a zero-grade derivative *mh₂k̑-ró-, derived from PIE *meh₂k̑- 'long, thin, tall' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):660-661, [Beekes 2010](src-66):895, [NIL](src-274) 478-481, cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):810).
Based on a loanword from Italian largo ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):291). Tsakonian αλάργα is treated as a separate loan event in [cognate set 6167](cog-6167).

Derived from PIE *pleh₃- 'swim, flow' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):147-148; as a verbal root cf. [LIV²](src-141) 485); in earlier literature reconstructed as a lengthened grade of *pleu̯- 'swim, float' (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):118-119).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 420) connects the Saka word samuvā "covering parts" with CS sʾpt 'left (< crooked) side' and derives both from PIE *k̑am- "bend over, cover" with reference to *kamp- (cf. LIV p.342, not in Cheung 2007). Bailey also puts NP čap here.

Justification: Loanword from French foie 'liver' (not in [Deshayes 2003](src-309)).
Loanword from Turkish sarı 'yellow' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):379).

Comment: Sanskritism, cf. Vedic varṣā́ḥ m. pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV) (root vr̥ṣ-)
Loan from Middle Low German

Justification: Based on Bret. bou(n)t, a loanword from Old French boute (deverbal from Old French bouter 'hit, push').

Comment: Cf. Meyer-Lübke 1935 9355 viria 'Armband'?

Justification: No precise correspondences outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):589, [Beekes 2010](src-66):786-787). The closest possible correspondences are in Balto-Slavic (cf. OCS kryti 'hide', Lith. kráuti 'heap' in [cognate set 5275](cog-5275)), but the connection is uncertain.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4969
Via Lat. restāre?

Justification: Romance lexemes from Lat. fuscus 'dark-coloured, dusky' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):308), further derived from PIE *dʰeu̯s- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):263-264, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):252).
Loanword from Italian contare 'to count'.
Loanword from Italian lordo 'dirty, filthy'.

Comment: Sarikoli PRS.STEM birēz-

Justification: Usually considered a loanword into Romance from West Germanic *bosk- 'forest' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):131, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 15/1:192-210).
Loan from Kâta-vari pařʹas 'dust'

Nuristani lexemes as though from Old Indic *ākṣundati 'tramples' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):46 no. 1030, [Strand 1998](src-431)), derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic √kšud- 'to disperse, scatter', further etymology uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:439).

Modern Greek lexemes derived from Ancient Greek φῶς, -τός 'light', ultimately a derivative of PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to shine' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1575, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1551-1552, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1168-1170, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 68-69).
Khowar kan < Old Indic kāṇḍa- 'single joint of plant' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):154, no. 3023), further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:336-337).
Parallel loan event from Middle Low German denken 'to think, remember' (cf. [EWA 2](src-386) 579).

Comment: cf. Sanskrit buk-kāra- m. 'the roaring of a lion, cry of any animal', bukkati 'barks' (Dhātup.)

Justification: Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):264, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):422, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):384 for various proposals.

From Latin saltus 'jump, leap; narrow passage, woodland' ([DCECH](src-423) V:321), further to PIE *sel- 'jump' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):590, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):535-536; for the root reconstruction cf. [LIV²](src-141) 527-528).

Comment: not found in Morgenstierne (1974); cf. Khwarazmian ǝkǝk

Justification: Brythonic lexemes based on a denominal formation (cf. Breton kouez m. 'a fall'), from Proto-Celtic *kei̯d- according to [Deshayes 2003](src-309):420) but with no correspondences given from Goidelic. Further etymology uncertain.
No known etymology ([ALEW](src-352) 663, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):406-407).

Cf. Latin ex-cutere ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):263 no. 2998), further to PIE *(s)ku̯eh₁t- 'to shake thoroughly, to startle' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):504-505, [LIV²](src-141) 563-564, cf. also [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):552-553).

From Latin tostum, cf. It. tosto ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):731 no. 8814), originally the past passive participle of Latin torreō, -ere 'to scorch, roast' from PIE *ters- 'become dry' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):624-625, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 637-638).
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1118-1119).
Of uncertain origin, perhaps a loan from early Scandinavian ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₃erg- ([LIV²](src-141) 301, [Matasović 2009](src-50):300), formerly reconstructed as *perg- ([IEW](src-49) 819, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) O:30).
Loan from Kâta-vari: Ktivi bʹos 'stem; gas; power'

Comment: not finally clear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic kāṣṭhá- 'piece of wood', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):159 no. 3120, [EWAia](src-172) I:345-346).

Romance lexemes from Latin fūstis 'stick, rod' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):308-309), no certain etymology outside of Italic ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):264; cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):253 for discussion of some recent proposals).
Loanword from Calabrian ficatu 'liver'.
As though from Sanskrit chadana- 'cover; leaf', a derivative of Vedic √chad- 'to cover', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):272 no. 4979, [EWAia](src-172) I:554-555).

Perhaps root cognate with Western IE words for 'tear' (Gk. δάκρυ, OHG zahar, Arm. artaswr, etc.), if both are based on earlier *h₂k̑ru- 'bitter' as a derivative from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'be/make sharp' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):391, cf. [Kortlandt 1985a](src-574):59-61 and further discussion in [cognate set 5111](cog-5111)).

Of uncertain origin (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):153-154, [HAB](src-740) IV:337-338), perhaps an Iranic loanword according to [Bailey 1979](src-320):387, [Jahukyan & Sargsyan 2010](src-540):711). [MM: Proto-Armenian *u̯iz-].

Etymology unclear. The proposal of [Orel 1998](src-105):115) is rather implausible from a semantic point of view. The etymology is otherwise uncertain (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):177-178 for further discussion).

Possibly related to TochB oko in [cognate set 2653](cog-2653), and Balto-Slavic and Celtic words in meanings variously 'fruit (of a tree), berry, acorn', but the exact etymological connection is uncertain because of problems in formal reconstruction. Cf. further discussion in [Kroonen 2013](src-165):18-19, [ALEW](src-352) 1151-1152, [Derksen 2008](src-81):27, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):25.
Root ref. form and analysis follows [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):358-360. For older proposals cf. [HED H](src-407):363-368.

Denominal to Classical Armenian mart 'fight, battle, combat'. Connections outside of Armenian uncertain, cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):81, [Olsen 1999](src-180):90. [HAB](src-740) III:289 for tentative speculations. Not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79).
Modern Greek lexemes continuing a loanword from Latin gula 'throat, gullet' into Hellenistic Greek, cf. Standard Modern Greek γουλιά ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):318).

Comment: maybe related to śikyà- n. (AV) 'rope-sling for carrying things', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12427f, see also s.v. *śikyadhara- m. 'hook at the end of the pole which carries the looped cord for holding the strings of a balance' or *śikyākāra-, Bi. Mth. sikahar 'net for hanging up pots &c. in a house'

Justification: Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek κοπτερός ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):689). Further root etymology in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 555 to PIE *(s)kep- 'to chop', but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):748-749.

A derivative of Latin campus 'field', cf. Italian campare 'to live' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):145-146 no. 1563). Traditionally further to an Indo-European root *kamp- 'bend, curve' in the sense 'broad, curved (valley)' > 'field' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 525, [LIV²](src-141) 342n1 'fraglich'). The necessity of reconstructing PIE *a (a root structure *kh₂mp- appearing unusual) has renewed the hypothesis that Latin campus is in fact a European substratum word from agricultural terminology ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):86, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):632-633).
Romance lexemes as though from Latin *mattea 'club' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):445), further etymology uncertain, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):366-367 for various proposals.

Originally a passive participle of Ancient Greek χυλόω 'convert into juice; extract the juice from' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). Further etymology difficult; traditionally connected the same root as χέω 'pour' < *g̑ʰeu̯, but long -ῡ- is unexpected for the zero-grade of this root and difficult account for (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1280, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1653).

Comment: Bailey (1979: 412 "ṣṣai") relates the Sogdian word to Yaghnobi čukēr-. Not in Cheung (2007).

Justification: Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xudъ 'small, thin' and generally further derived from PIE *k⁽ʷ⁾seu̯d- 'to scatter, to crumble into small pieces' (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 8:111-113, [Derksen 2008](src-81):205, [Polański 1962-1994](src-600):198-199, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

From Ancient Greek ἑστία 'hearth, fireplace, altar' ([Dawkins 1916](src-452):600), no further etymology (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):379, [Beekes 2010](src-66):471-472 for further discussion).

PS *guľati does not have a commonly accepted etymology. From the semantic perspective the hypothesis of [Boryś 2005](src-259): 196 (*geu̯h₂-, cf. [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) and [LIV²](src-141): 189) looks most convincinɡ, the -l-/-ľ-, however, needs a formal explanaition.
No certain etymology outside of Italic (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):686, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):615).

Comment: Loanword from Slavic.
Justification: A loanword into Medieval Greek from Old Slavic logŭ ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):786).
Loan from Turkish meyva 'fruit', ultimately from Persian mäyva 'fruit' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 3:718-719).

Comment: Loanword from Italian
Justification: Certainly a borrowing from Latin gula or Italian gola 'throat' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):126, although aspects of the loan chronology remain disputed (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):66, [Orel 1998](src-105):120, [Holm 2011](src-130):72).
Loanword from Anglo-Norman, cf. Old French, Middle French pousser 'to push' ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).
Loanword from Italian destra 'right'.
As though from Vedic √bhal- 'to expound, describe', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):535 no. 9406, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:482-483).
Loanword from English sharp.

Possibly from IE *smei̯d- 'to smear', cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):459, [LIV²](src-141) 569. See [Seebold 1970](src-556):437-438 for older unconvincing proposals to Lat. mittere (ruled out as phonologically implausible by [LIV²](src-141)).
No certain etymology, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):654 no. 11225, [KEWA](src-399) III:130 for further discussion.

Comment: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 26)

Justification: Of uncertain origin, unattested in Classical Armenian ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):366). [MM: < ⁽*⁾kəloɾ].

Pontic Greek άψιμο(ν) a derivative of the aorist stem ἄψ- to Ancient Greek ἄπτω 'to join, attach; kindle', cf. Medieval Greek άψιμο ‘fever’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; not in [Andriotis 1974](src-460)), further to PIE *h₂ep- 'to join, fit' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):120-121, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 269).

Comment: Original meaning is "claw", which develops to "hand" and "arm" / "wing".

Justification: Parallel loans from Persian بد bad 'bad'

Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *cappayati 'chews', imitative of the sound of chewing ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):253, no.4675). Cf. cf. Pāli capucapukāra- ʻmaking the sound of chewing'. No further etymology outside of Indic

Latin and Romance lexemes, traditionally compared to Sanskrit amlá- 'sour, acid', Old Icelandic apr 'sharp, cold', but many formal details remain unclear (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):25, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):37; cf. [EIEC](src-657) 69). For Modern Romance forms, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):31-32.
Apparently as though from Sanskrit aru- 'sun', only attested in lexicographical works ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):27, no. 612).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *stauba- 'dust', a derivative of the strong verb steuban- 'to scatter, drift', further etymology generally considered uncertain (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):474, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):328, [Kluge 2011](src-397):878, 884, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):475). Cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):478 s.v. *steuban- ~ *stūban- proposing a connection to Lithuanian siaũbti 'to dash about' via *tséubʰ-ié- (with metathesis of initial *ts- > *st-).
Probably to be derived from Vedic √sthā- 'to stand' ([EWAia](src-172) II:764-767).

Comment: PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split'

Justification: Loan from French pousser 'to push'.
Loan from English

As though from Sanskrit *gandhapūrikā-, an substantivised form of an adjective derived from gandhá- 'smell', and pūra- 'filling, making full' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):215, no. 4015. This class is coded for Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell', which appears to be the semantic bearing head of the original compound. Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:461-462).
Possibly a Dravidian loanword, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):353 no. 6173.
Generally derived to PIE *g̑i̯eu̯H- 'to chew' ([Adams 2013](src-345):691, 706, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 168).

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑u̯es- 'to pant, breathe heavily'. In this class Pāli sasati continues the primary verb < Sanskrit śvasati 'breathe heavily' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:677, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):740 no. 12761), the modern Indic forms are light verb constructions with the nominal semantic-bearing morpheme deriving from Skt. śvāsá- 'breath' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):740, no. 12769). For Elfdalian, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):266.

Many irregular developments, often assumed to be due to taboo deformation, but all the lexemes are generally assumed to come from a common Indo-European source. The metathesised stem *u̯orm- as found in Vedic, etc. is generally assumed to be a taboo-deformation while the forms found in Avestan maoiri-, Old Irish moirb are often assumed to be most closely reflect to the original ([EIEC](src-657) 24). For individual branches, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):630, [Beekes 2010](src-66):982, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):482-483, [EWAia](src-172) II:507, [ESSJa](src-458) 19:241-249, [Derksen 2008](src-81):326, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):359, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):243, [Matasović 2009](src-50):278.

Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₃ems- 'shoulder, upper part of the arm' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:461, II:227-228, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:37). Cf. Proto-Germanic *amsa- 'shoulder' ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):30, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):25), Ancient Greek ὦμος 'shoulder' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1679-1680).

Italic and Albanian lexemes from PIE *(s)ken(H)- ([Meyer 1891](src-585):152, [Huld 1984](src-571):74, [Orel 1998](src-105):147, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):115). Pace [de Vaan 2008](src-54) lexemes from Tocharian B kentse 'rust' are not to be connected (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):207). For Romance lexemes from Latin cinis, cineris, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):182 no. 1929. Cf. Ancient Greek κόνις 'dust' in [cognate set 6166](cog-6166).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *meg̑- 'big' ([NIL](src-274) 468-478, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):917-918, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):458-460, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):250-251, [Orel 1998](src-105):240, [EWAia](src-172) II:337-338, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):361-362, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):358-359, [Matasović 2009](src-50):253). For Tocharian lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this class, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):479-480.

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic *āpula- 'abundant' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):55, no. 1211), cf. Vedic vipula- 'extended, wide'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:557-558).

Umbrian pelmner from a Proto-Italic stem *pelp-men-, cf. Latin pulpa 'meat', pulmentum 'meat dish' < Proto-Italic *pelp-men-to-, pointing to a Proto-Italic root *pelp-. No further known cognates outside of Italic, however (cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):528, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):497-498).
Loanword from Dutch vlees 'meat'.
