Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes generally considered cognate, but the specific root reconstruction is difficult. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:216, [ALEW](src-352) 1204, [Derksen 2015](src-353):494, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):647, 662 for further discussion.
Slavic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰreu̯s- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:99-100, [Matasović 2009](src-50):81, [ESSJa](src-458) 3:33-34, [Derksen 2008](src-81):63).
Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰelg̑ʰ- 'to swell' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):49, [Matasović 2009](src-50):70, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 73-74).
Parallel loans from Persian (Arabic 'destruction')

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(H)regʰ- 'to straighten oneself'. For the root reconstruction, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 835-836, [LIV²](src-141) 498. See also [Derksen 2008](src-81):438, [Derksen 2015](src-353):374-375.

Armenian, Albanian, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived to PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):286-287, [Meyer 1891](src-585):413, [Huld 1984](src-571):154, [Orel 1998](src-105):315, 429, [de Vaan 2008](src-54), [Schrijver 1991](src-679):212, 495, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):516 no.6268, [DCECH](src-423) IV:342-343, [Matasović 2009](src-50):126, 129).

Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₂eu̯-i- 'bird' ([EWAia](src-172) II:507-508, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):659 no. 11304, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):65-66, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):65-66, nos. 827, 828, and 831). For Hellenic and Armenian lexemes attached to this class not in the target meaning, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):35, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):398-399).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deu̯k- ([LIV²](src-141) 124, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):181, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):250 no. 2785, {ref  [Matasović 2009](src-50):108).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)tei̯g- 'to prick, be pointed' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):330 no. 5806, [Bailey 1979](src-320):129, [EWAia](src-172) I:668-669; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 592-593).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₁ésh₂-r̥, *h₁sh₂-én-, a heteroclitic r/n-stem, generally assumed to be the inherited Proto-Indo-European word for 'blood' ([EIEC](src-657) 71, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):256-260, [Adams 2013](src-345):525, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):138, [EWAia](src-172) I:149, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):42 no. 971, [Derksen 2015](src-353):526, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):527-528, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):627, no. 7574)

Hellenic and Baltic lexemes generally connected with Indic lexemes in the meaning 'dirty' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):680-681, [Beekes 2010](src-66):923-924; cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):554, [EWAia](src-172) II:332-333).
Light-verb constructions construed with (parallel) loans of Arabic نفس / nafs 'breath'.

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂enh₁- 'to breathe' ([LIV²](src-141) 267, [NIL](src-274) 307-311, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):12-13, [EWAia](src-172) I:72, [Seebold 1970](src-556):78-79, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):26-27, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):38 no. 473, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):43, [Matasović 2009](src-50):35).
Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁nek̑- 'to take, to obtain' ([LIV²](src-141) 250-251, [Derksen 2008](src-81):350, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:19-23, [ALEW](src-352) 698-700).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived to Vedic √grabh- 'to take, seize' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):227 no. 4236), further to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize, grasp' ([EWAia](src-172) I:505-506, [LIV²](src-141) 201).

Tocharian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'to incinerate, consume by fire' ([LIV²](src-141) 133-134, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):802, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):138-139, [Orel 1998](src-105):68, [Holm 2011](src-130):55, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):970, [EWAia](src-172) I:712-713, [ALEW](src-352) 187-189).

Hellenic, Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deh₂u̯- ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):200, [Beekes 2010](src-66):298-299, [Cheung 2007](src-83):67-68, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:111-112). The connection of Irish: Gaelic dóigh to this class assumes that it is cognate with OIr. dó- 'burn' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:111-112, [LIV²](src-141) 104-105). There remains the possibility that there may have been contamination in the Middle Irish period with OIr. daig 'flame, blaze' derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'burn' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:8-9 s.v. daig, [Matasović 2009](src-50):93).
Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰreu̯s- ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):82, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):76, 80, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:99-100, [Matasović 2009](src-50):81).

Italic and Celtic lexemes generally assumed to continue earlier *pe⁽k̑⁾tu- 'chest', although the Celtic forms would appear to continue *pu⁽k̑⁾tu- with secondary *-u- vocalism in the lexical root (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):491, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):453, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:14-15, [Matasović 2009](src-50):130).
Assumed to be cognate with PIE *pe⁽k̑⁾tu- in [cognate set 4015](cog-4015) by Klingenschmitt (1968: 67).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- '(finger)nail' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):723-725, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1086-1087, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):254-255, [EWAia](src-172) II:4-5, [ALEW](src-352) 681-682, [Derksen 2015](src-353):327, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164, 170-173, [Derksen 2008](src-81):355, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):641, [Matasović 2009](src-50):36). Indo-Iranic forms go back to an aberrant *(H)nákha-; Indo-Aryan forms go back to nakhá- ~ *nakkha-; some show early nasalization due to blend with aṅgúri- ~  aṅgúli- 'finger, toe' (°-aṅgulá-) or aṅguṣṭhá- 'thumb'; aṅká- 'hook' (RV) and later aṅkurá- 'hooked' may also have played a role, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442), no. 6914 + 134f. 137f., 100, 109; Addenda 6914
Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to become cold, freeze' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):185, cf. [NIL](src-274) 416-417, [LIV²](src-141) 323).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Balto-SlavicLexemes derived from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ([LIV²](src-141) 232-233, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):992-993, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):437, [Beekes 2010](src-66):388, [EWAia](src-172) I:102, [Cheung 2007](src-83):154-157, [ALEW](src-352) 259-261, [Derksen 2015](src-353):151, [ESSJa](src-458) 8:247-248, [Derksen 2008](src-81):216).

Comment: denominal derivative, cf. Vedic gaṇá- m. 'row, crowd, entourage, a number of fellows' (RV+); see also 'think' in lexeme 25989; cf. JB+ gaṇáyati, Sanskrit gaṇayati ʻcountsʼ (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3993
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Sanskrit gaṇáyati 'counts' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):213 no.3993), a denominal formation to Sanskrit gaṇá- 'multitude, number, series', without further certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:458-459).

Anatolian, Indo-Iranic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry out (by means of heat)'. The Germanic forms in this class are generally connected to this group although the morphological derivation remains obscure, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):54, [EWA 1](src-383):365-366, [Kluge 2011](src-397):64, 260, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):38. Cf. also [Lubotsky 1985](src-755):6. For the IE root reconstruction, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 257-258, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):318-319; see also [EWAia](src-172) I:182-183). For Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes connected to this class cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):67 no.1476.

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' ([LIV²](src-141) 209-210, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):170-171, [EWAia](src-172) I:465-466, [Cheung 2007](src-83):98-101, [Seebold 1970](src-556):315-317, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):316, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):661, Meyer-Lübke 1935}:767 no. 9200).

Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to be cold, freeze' ([NIL](src-274) 416-417, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:641, [Cheung 2007](src-83):336-337, [ALEW](src-352) 1008-1009, [Derksen 2015](src-353):439-440, [LIV²](src-141) 323).
Probably loans from Old Indic kiṭṭāla- 'copper vessel' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):161 no. 3157).

Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑elH- 'to be cold, freeze' ([LIV²](src-141) 323, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:641, [Cheung 2007](src-83):336-337, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:64, [ALEW](src-352) 1008-1009, [Derksen 2015](src-353):439-440, ref NIL} 416-417).
Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pisk- 'fish', cf. [IEW](src-49) 796, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):142, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):467-468, [Matasović 2009](src-50):142.
Indo-Iranic lexemes generally derived from PIE *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- ([EWAia](src-172) II:374-375, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:117).

Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:154 and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion. For Middle and Modern Indic forms from Vedic áhar, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):44, no. 993.

Hellenic and Armenian lexemes as though from a PIE stem *Heh₂m-, an exclusive Greek-Armenian lexical isogloss ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):412, [Beekes 2010](src-66):518, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):156, cf. [Clackson 1994](src-319):96-97).

Many attempts have been made to try to relate the Indic words for 'day' from Ved. áhar ~ áhan- with the Germanic words for day (cf. esp. the heteroclitic stem common in North Germanic from PGmc. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- 'a full day, twenty-four hours' in ON dœgr, dœgn, Sw. dygn, Nw. døger, døgn, Da. døgn, etc.). The loss of the initial dental in Indo-Iranian is, however, anomalous. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:154 and [Kroonen 2013](src-165):97 s.v. *dōgera- ~ *dōgena- for further discussion.

Albanian lexemes generally connected with Germanic *tīdi- 'time', derived from PIE *deh₂(i̯)- 'to divide, split into parts' (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):51-52, [Orel 1998](src-105):516 with references to further literature; [Orel 2003](src-388):407, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):516); for verbal derivatives to the same root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 103-104.

Indo-Iranic, Slavic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' ([NIL](src-274) 698-700, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:623-624, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):323 no. 5679, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):81, [Derksen 2008](src-81):490, [Matasović 2009](src-50):375, [LIV²](src-141) 629-630).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *i̯eu̯- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):607 no. 10507, [EWAia](src-172) II:402-403, [LIV²](src-141) 314, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):423).

No certain etymology outside of Germanic. Earlier assumed to be from an IE root *b⁽ʰ⁾(e)ū̆- with an extension -g- (cf. [IEW](src-49) 100). For various other uncertain proposals, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):96, [EWNl](src-757) 1:395.
Modern Indic lexemes as though from *pēṭṭa- (with variant *pōṭṭa-) (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):475, no. 8376). No further etymology.

Comment: Cheung (2007: 345) suggests a derivation from PIE *skep- ‘to cut, split (with a sharp tool), make a crack’

Justification: Of uncertain origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):942, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:519). [MM: Proto-Armenian *pʰor-o-/-i-].
No certain etymology outside of Celtic ([Matasović 2009](src-50):385). For older proposals, cf. [IEW](src-49) 1024.
Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *wambō- 'womb, belly'. No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Lehmann 1986](src-179):393, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):572, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):674).
Romance lexemes from Latin pantex 'belly, paunch' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):510), no further etymology (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):479-480).

Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *latyo- 'day', as though a *-i̯o-stem derived from PIE *leh₁t-. Alternatively, an analysis as a secondary derivative to a primary t-stem from a hypothetical root *leh₁- remains possible; cf. note by Scarborough in the cognate class citations below for more extensive discussion.

Nuristani lexemes derived from a base *gharasya- 'sun's heat' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):239 no. 4440), ultimately to PIE *gʷer- 'to become warm' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:513, [NIL](src-274) 196-199, [LIV²](src-141) 219-220).
Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *rau̯k/č-, from PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):316, [EWAia](src-172) II:463-464, [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).
Modern Indic lexemes as though from *choṭṭa- 'small', further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):279 no. 5071).
Etymology uncertain, possibly identical with Proto-Germanic *baina- in 'bone' ([cognate set 191](cog-191)) and 'leg' ([cognate set 71](cog-71)), cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):113.
Loanword from Persian kōbal, gōpal 'cudgel' (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:393).

Etymology outside of Greek difficult; probably to IE *gres- (or *gras-) 'devour' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 192, [IEW](src-49) 404) with dissimilation of *-r- in the root from the suffix *-tēr- (so [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):211-212); but cf. the objections of [Beekes 2010](src-66):262.

Usually derived to PIE *bʰer- 'carry' [Meyer 1891](src-585):27, [Huld 1984](src-571):40-41, [Orel 1998](src-105):18 (but cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):92, [Holm 2011](src-130):51-52 with some skepticism).

Comment: with variants, cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 316f., no. 5589ff., 5598f.; substrate?

Justification: Loanword from Old French ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):405).
Tsakonian lexemes as though from Ancient (Doric) Greek *φοῦσκα 'lower abdomen, stomach'; no certain further etymology ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):589), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1599-1600).
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *červo 'belly, intestine' ([ESSJa](src-458) 4:82-83, [Derksen 2008](src-81):85-86) and further derived from PIE *(s)ker- 'to shear, scratch, cut off').

Comment: Cf. Semitic *lib-/lub- "heart"; *lap "spleen, liver, heart"
< *nāf 'navel' ?

Justification: From Latin follis 'bag, sack' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):294). Further connections outside of Italic not fully certain (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):230).
No satisfactory etymology (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):538, [KEWA](src-399) II:491-492, [EWAia](src-172) II:243-244).
Etymology unknown (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)).
Loan from Middle High German wamp ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595):279, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594)).

Comment: The PIE root means "to swell". Mayrhofer groups a number of lexemes together which match the semantic field of "(leiblilche) Auswüchse, Schwellungen" [protuberances].

Justification: The only plausible etymology outside of Anatolian is the proposed connection with Armenian argand 'womb' with the proviso that the Armenian sound laws permit it ([Čop 1955](src-580), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):733), but this proposal rejected by [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):130-131.

Semantic shift from Ancient Greek καρδία 'heart' ([Dawkins 1916](src-452):607), cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):644, [NIL](src-274) 417-423, and 'heart' in [cognate set 6458](cog-6458) for further etymological connections.

Etymology uncertain. Three main possibilities: Either (1) connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so [Orel 1998](src-105):269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- [cognate set 42](cog-42)), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so [Demiraj 1997](src-369):271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by [Meyer 1891](src-585):283-284, cf. [cognate set 2150](cog-2150)). Either of these sources could also have been contaminated with one another (cf. the discussion of [Huld 1984](src-571):93). Ultimately unclear.
Probable (parallel) loanwords from (Gascon) Occitan barrique 'barrel, wine cask' (cf. [DCECH](src-423) I:524-525).
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. also [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:528).
See also the independent loan of the same ultimate Greek source lexeme, via Latin and Norman 'French' into English at https://cobl.info[cognate set 9719](cog-9719).

Lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:208-210).
Loanword from Old French brum ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):144).

North Germanic lexemes continuing a basic stem *dim-, comparisons outside of Germanic are uncertain ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):151-152, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):77, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):96, 108).

Etymology outside of Tocharian obscure, probably connected within Tocharian to Tocharian A kātse 'near'. Cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):112, [Adams 2013](src-345):165-166 for various further discussion.

Indo-Iranic lexemes from Vedic áṅgāra- 'glowing charcoal' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):6-7, no. 125), probably further from a PIE nominal formation *ángol-/*angl- or *Héngol-/*Hengl- (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 41 s.v. OLith. anglìs 'coal'). A further connection to Vedic agní- 'fire' could be possible, but the details remain uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:48). For Nuristan languages, cf. [Strand 1998](src-431).

The widely accepted etymology linking the Slavic lexeme to uncertain PIE ?*lek- 'move the limbs' (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 14:145-148) is not entirely convincing. There is no internal Slavic evidence for *k and the hypothesis needs to assume an intensive morphological levelling. Cf. also [ALEW](src-352) 567-568, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):343, [Derksen 2008](src-81):271, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):323.

Certain comparisons outside of Balto-Slavic are lacking ([ALEW](src-352) 933, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 562). Identical to 'run' in [cognate set 6359](cog-6359). On the possibility of the connection of Lithuanian skrìsti 'fly_V' to this class, cf. discussion in [cognate set 9622](cog-9622).
Loanword from English '(to) fly' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Comment: Regular development of *bazu(ra)- is bāzul and bāsk in Balochi. The word for heart "zird" shows that *rd/rz does not develop to l in Balochi.

Justification:
Root reference form for this class tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 563, but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 933-934 regarding the possibility that the lexeme goes back to a secondary neo-root *(s)krei̯-dʰ- and connected to Latvian skrìet 'fly_V' in [cognate set 2273](cog-2273).
'
Brythonic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):537-538, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:145-146, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 572-573).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃mei̯gʰ- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1077, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):466, [EWAia](src-172) II:374-375, [ALEW](src-352) 649, [Derksen 2015](src-353):317, [ESSJa](src-458) 21:93-94, [Derksen 2008](src-81):338-339, [EWNl](src-757) 3:140, [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Romance lexemes derived from Old French breu, a loanword on Germanic *brod- 'broth' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443):297, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):118; elsewhere in Romance cf. It. brodo 'broth', broda 'soup', etc.)

Continuing a derivative of PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'to leave' via Indic udrēcayati 'causes to increase' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):96-97 no. 2061, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:457-458, [LIV²](src-141) 406-408).
Tocharian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):462-462, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):745-746, [Lucht 2007](src-151):165).

Lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):732 no. 12620, [EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331).
Loan from Italian volare 'to fly'.
Nuristani forms refect Old Indic *ut-sthā-ti (-Strand).
Light verb constructions, whose semantic heads are loans from Persian parvāz 'flight'.
Etymology outside of Iranic uncertain, the earlier proposal by [Bailey 1979](src-320):168 to PIE *der- 'to run' via an extended form *dr-ep(h)- is no longer tenable (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):75).
Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):615, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):549).
Parallel loans from Turkic (cf. [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) III:152, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 4:119).
Parallel loans from Middle Indic bána- 'forest' (< Vedic vána- 'forest') (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):657 no. 11258).

Comment: from *kuha- 'fog, mist' according to Turner 1962-66, p. 175, no. 3386, perhaps related to guh- 'hide, conceil' (?); unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing a stem *kuha-, further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):175 no. 3386).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ([LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389); cf. [LIV²](src-141) 476, [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):655-660, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1181-1182, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):286-287, 294, [EWAia](src-172) II:71-72, [Matasović 2009](src-50):129)

Many sources link the Slavic lexeme to PIE *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)' [LIV²](src-141). The meaning 'to heat' in Lithuanian kùrti is assumed to arise through an ellipisis of the objects in phrases like 'make a fire'. The Slavic lexeme and the Germanic ones are, however, not listed in LIV [LIV²](src-141).
Nor the Slavic lexeme, neither the possible Germanic cognates show any traces of the 'make/do' meaning. Moreover, PS *kuriti has a specified meaning and refers clearly to burning with smoke (pleas note that the Gemanic meaning referring to the 'coal' fits here semantically very well). The Baltic etymology seems to have some formal issues. It seems reasonable to join the view of [Derksen 2008](src-81) and {Kroonen 2013} and assume a root distinct from *kʷer- 'cut, (do/make)', *kerH- or *kerh₃-.
From Latin boreās 'north wind; north' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):107, cf. [DCECH](src-423) I:614), an old loanword from Greek βορέας 'north wind; north' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):73-74).

A register-loanword into Standard Modern Greek from Katharevousa (expected †μίχλη, vel sim.). A reflex of the expected word might be found in SMG μούχλα 'mould, mildew' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); cf. also respective entries in [Andriotis 1999](src-271).
From Old Norse mjǫrkvi 'thick fog', a variant of myrkvi 'id.', to be derived from PIE *mergʷ- (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):390, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):409-410, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):366).

From Ancient Greek δεῖσα 'slime, filth' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):202). Further etymology uncertain (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):259, [Beekes 2010](src-66):311 for references to conjectural hypotheses).

Italiot καμουλία < Medieval Greek καύμα, κάμα ‘excessive heat’ (Nikos Liosis, p.c.; cf. also [Rohlfs 1964](src-587):192). Further connected to the same root as Ancient Greek καίω 'to burn', to which cf. 'burn' in [cognate set 1461](cog-1461) for further etymological discussion.

Possibly to IE *kʷu̯ap- (or less likely *kʷu̯eh₂p-) if to be compared with Lat. vapor 'steam, exhalation', Gk. καπνός 'smoke' ([ALEW](src-352) 545-546, [Derksen 2015](src-353):268), but these connections are not fully certain due to several irregular sound-changes needed to justify the comparison.

Nuristani lexemes, to be connected with Vedic kákṣa- 'undergrowth' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):128 no. 2589). No certain further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:288).

Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:660-661; cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:383-384 for various older proposals). For Kashmiri šuh, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):723 no. 12485 śītá- 'cold' (i.e. the regularly past passive participle formed to Vedic √śyā-), for Nuristan languages cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):731 no.12614.
Romance lexemes from Latin gelāre 'to freeze', derived from Latin gelus, -ūs 'cold, frost, ice' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):317), further to PIE *⁽g̑⁾el- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):256).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'become firm' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):894-895, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1184, [LIV²](src-141) 461).
Etymology uncertain. [Not in [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325)].
Etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Germanic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 878-879, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):524).
Loanword from Turkish pus 'fog, haze'.

Brythonic lexemes generally assumed to be loanwords from Latin nūbilus 'cloudy, overcast' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [NIL](src-274) 502n15, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) N:8).

The Iranic lexemes in this class represent light verb constructions with Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ([ESIJa](src-331) I:140-143) constituting the semantic head. Cf. 'ice' in [cognate set 5932](cog-5932) for further etymological discussion.

Germanic and Celtic lexemes from PIE *preu̯s- ([LIV²](src-141) 493-494). The connection of the Celtic lexemes to this class follows [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):137, [Matasović 2009](src-50):140, but cf. doubts in [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:24-25, [EIEC](src-657) 287. For Germanic lexemes in this class, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):154-155.

Comment: There might be another root *merk⁽ʷ⁾- with a meaning pertaining to the same semantic field, cf. e.g. Ukrainian dialectal morokvá 'quagmire, swamp', Lith. mer̃kti 'to wet, to moisten (flax, linen)' and maybe as a cognate Latin marceō 'to be withered, droop', cf. also Derksen, EtymDictSlav 325f. s.v. *morky, ALEW 637 and de Vaan, EtymDictLat 364f. (Freiberg).
Justification: Albanian and Slavic lexemes from PIE *merg̑⁽ʰ⁾- ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):256, [Orel 1998](src-105):245, [ESSJa](src-458) 20:10-14; 21:163-165, [Derksen 2008](src-81):326, 342-343).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *deh₃- 'to give' ([LIV²](src-141) 105-106, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):331-332, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):595, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):154-155, [Orel 1998](src-105):157, [Rohr 2000](src-687):42-43, [EWAia](src-172) I:713-715, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):489 no. 8655, [Cheung 2007](src-83):45-47, [ALEW](src-352) 246-248, [Derksen 2015](src-353):146-147, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:194-195, [Derksen 2008](src-81):96, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):174-175). The connection of Gaulish dede to this class is tentatively accepted (so [Matasović 2009](src-50):86), but cf. the discussion of [Delamarre 2003](src-157):138-139 regarding the possibility alternatively deriving the Gaulish form from PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place'.

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):446, [Orel 2003](src-388):334, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):485). The 'Schenkel' from Middle High German onwards are diminutive formations ([Kluge 2011](src-397):800). For the root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555).

Romance lexemes derived from Latin glācies 'ice' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):322); Latin glaciēs 'ice' and Romance descendants superficially appear to be related to *⁽g̑⁾el- but it is difficult to establish a clear etymological relationship (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):275, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):263 for further discussion).

Derived from Armenian saṙn 'ice' and generally connected to Germanic and Balto-Slavic lexemes for 'frozen snow' or 'hoarfrost', although the precise nominal stem formation in Armenian is not fully understood ([Olsen 1999](src-180):137, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):567-568; cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:176-177 for older proposals). Note, however, [ALEW](src-352) 1019, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):223 not do not explicitly connect the Armenian lexemes.
A derivative of OIr. secc (adj.) 'stiff, rigid, hard', originally a loanword from Latin siccus 'dry' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:60), cf. [cognate set 4358](cog-4358).
Connections outside of Albanian disputed (cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):306-307, [Jokl 1911](src-661):63-64, [Orel 1998](src-105):296 for various proposals).

Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ([IEW](src-49) 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):601; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):234-235, [HED A+E/I](src-406):257-259, [Matasović 2009](src-50):435).

Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ([IEW](src-49) 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):601; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):234-235, [HED A+E/I](src-406):257-259, [Matasović 2009](src-50):435).
Baltic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃eu̯g̑- 'cold' ([ALEW](src-352) 76, [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:22, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:8, [Matasović 2009](src-50):301).

No certain etymology outside of Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):471, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 601-2 s.v. ?2. *steu̯d- 'kalt werden'). A connection with the more common homophonous root 1. *steu̯d- 'stoßen', 'to hit' might be possible, but is difficult to justify semantically (cf.  [LIV²](src-141) 601-602). The root reference form as PIE ?*steu̯d- tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141).
Origin uncertain, cf. [HAB](src-740) IV:463-464, [Olsen 1999](src-180):42, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):630-631 for various proposals. [MM: Proto-Armenian *tsʰurt-o-].

Etymology in this class follows [Orel 1998](src-105):105 and [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):974 to PIE *teh₂- 'melt, thaw', but cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):173-174, [Holm 2011](src-130):56-57 for proposals to PIE *tep- 'be warm, hot'. Cf. also [LIV²](src-141) 616, 630.

Comment: no etymological information in Morgenstierne (1974: 79)

Justification: Derived from Old Indic √oṣ- 'to burn' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):125), further to PIE *h₁eu̯s- 'to burn' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:281, [LIV²](src-141) 245).
No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 565, [Derksen 2015](src-353):277, [ESSJa](src-458) 14:91-92, [Derksen 2008](src-81):270).
Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:660-661; cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:383-384 for various older proposals).

Because the morphology of the related forms within Greek conform to the Caland system is suggestive that they are inherited from Indo-European, but there are no known cognates outside of Greek (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1295-1296, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1672-1673).

Albanian and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 162-169, [Derksen 2008](src-81):544-545, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):133, [Rohr 2000](src-687):124-125).

Further etymology outside of Tocharian unclear. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):182-183, [Adams 2013](src-345):236 attempt to connect Tocharian B krośce to the Greek forms, but this proposal is formally problematic (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):786).

Latin glaciēs 'ice' and Romance descendants superficially appear to be related to *⁽g̑⁾el- but it is difficult to establish a clear etymological relationship (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):275, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):263 for further discussion). For the Romance lexemes in this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):322.
Nuristani lexemes derived from the same root as Vedic yávasa- 'grass' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):603 no. 10436), further derived from PIE *i̯éu̯-o- ([EWAia](src-172) II:404).
Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic amā́ 'at home, in the house' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):25 no. 560). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:95.

Nuristani lexemes as though from Vedic rúh 'growth, spurting' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):624 no.10795), further to Vedic √rudh- 'to grow' from PIE *h₁leu̯dʰ- 'to rise, row' ([EWAia](src-172) II:467-468, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 248-249).
From Proto-Romance *pettia ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):532), generally regarded as a borrowing from Celtic (cf. Welsh peth 'thing, object')
Of uncertain etymology, perhaps a derivative to the same root as Latvian galēt 'to kill' (cf. [cognate set 2302](cog-2302)) with an original meaning 'killed animal' ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:285).

Comment: cf. Vedic nī́la- adj. 'dark coloured, dark blue, black blue, indigo' (also 'dark GRUE' = dark blue-green); further etymology unclear, cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 51, Turner 1962-66, p. 426, no. 7563; some forms analogically influenced by *lohila-, cf. Vedic róhita- ~ lóhita- 'red'
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic nī́la- 'dark blue, dark green, black' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):426 no. 7563). Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:51).

Indic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes, generally accepted as cognates, but a precise reconstruction of the original Indo-European proto-form remains difficult and controversial, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:44-45 [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):3 no. 55, [ALEW](src-352) 1145-1146, [Derksen 2015](src-353):478, [ESSJa](src-458) 32:30-33, [Derksen 2008](src-81):364, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):297 for further discussion. Possibly further connected to *Hengl- in [cognate set 6119](cog-6119), but the details remain uncertain.

Celtic lexemes from PIE *preu̯s- following [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):137, [Matasović 2009](src-50):140, but cf. doubts in [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) R:24-25, [EIEC](src-657) 287. Cf. 'freeze' in [cognate set 226](cog-226).

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)per- 'to fly' ([Adams 2013](src-345):383, [EWAia](src-172) II:97, [Derksen 2008](src-81):396, [Vasmer 1953-1958](src-178) II:343, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 579-580).
Indo-Iranic lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *sáras-, an s-stem to a root *sel- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:708, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):765 no. 13254).

Comment: cf. 9360 "freeze"; 9359 "cold"; 9361 "ice" and Cheung (2007: 39): "On *či̯aH³/čiH < (?) PIE *ḱi̯-, cf. *ǰi̯auH ‘to chew’ < PIE *ǵi̯euH-, see Rasmussen 1989: 114, no. 5. The variant *saiH/siH may derive from the variant *ḱ(e)iH-."
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *či̯aH-; further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:660-661; cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:383-384 for various older proposals).

Lit. 'congealed/frozen water'. Cognacy in this set is coded for Sinhalese දිය diya 'water' < Vedic udaká- 'water', further derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):89 no. 1921, [EWAia](src-172) I:215-216, cf. [NIL](src-274) 706-715). For the modifer 'congealed/frozen', cf. 'freeze' in [cognate set 7652](cog-7652).

Etymology uncertain. Possibly a loan from Germanic *jakulaz 'icicle, glacier' (so [Orel 1998](src-105):3-4), but cf. objections from [Demiraj 1997](src-369):74-75); cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):37-38 for various unconvincing alternative hypotheses.
Loanword from Arabic ǰamad 'ice, ice floe' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:486).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *flaiska-, without certain etymology outside of Germanic ([EWA 3](src-441):370-371, [Orel 2003](src-388):104, not in [Kroonen 2013](src-165)).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body, gore' ([NIL](src-274) 444-448, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):580, [Beekes 2010](src-66):774).

Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Old Indic *nigāti (ni- 'down' + √gā- 'to take a step'), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):410 no. 7165. Root etymology further to PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ([EWAia](src-172) I:482, [LIV²](src-141) 205).

Etymology uncertain, the lexemes have been attempted to be related to PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall', however this is phonologically problematic since one expects PIE *pe- to develop to he- in Classical Armenian, however cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):293-294 attempting to maintain the traditional etymology. Perhaps a loanword from an Indo-European Anatolian language (cf. Hitt. pattar- 'wing, feather')? See also [HAB](src-740) IV:498.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ([NIL](src-274) 526-540), cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):653-654, [Adams 2013](src-345):432, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1227-1228, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):534-535, [EWAia](src-172) II:77-78 [Kroonen 2013](src-165):152, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):462, [LIV²](src-141) 458).

Derivatives from Proto-Indo-Iranic *pau̯š- 'to blossom, bloom' ([EWAia](src-172) II:153, 171-172). No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. For the Modern Indic forms, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):470, no. 8303 and 8306.

Hellenic, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *mus- 'fly, gnat', cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):976, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):270, [Orel 1998](src-105):268, [ALEW](src-352) 673-674, [Derksen 2015](src-353):326, [ESSJa](src-458) 20:170-172, [Derksen 2008](src-81):330-331, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):397).

Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'to make smoke' ([EWAia](src-172) I:795, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):392 no. 8649, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):249, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):305 no. 3572).

The reflexes found in the individual languages reflect different generalised accent/ablaut classes of PIE *kʷetu̯or-, *kʷ(e)tu̯r̥-, *kʷ(e)tur- 'four'. For extensive discussion cf. [Eichner 1982](src-342):298-382, cf. also [Adams 2013](src-345):703, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1471-1472, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):546-547, [Orel 1998](src-105):173-174, [EWAia](src-172) I:526-527, [ALEW](src-352) 483-485, [Derksen 2015](src-353):241, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:97-98, [Derksen 2008](src-81):87, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):133, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):505-506, [Matasović 2009](src-50):179.
Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):6-10, [Bailey 1979](src-320):499, [MacKenzie 1990](src-680):112, [Matasović 2009](src-50):62).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁ei̯- 'to go' ([LIV²](src-141) 232-233, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):616-618, [Adams 2013](src-345):64-66, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1002-1006, [EWAia](src-172) I:102, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):23 no.497, [ALEW](src-352) 259-261, [Derksen 2015](src-353):151, [ESSJa](src-458) 8:247-248, [Derksen 2008](src-81):216, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):191-192).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *pénkʷe 'five', generally considered to be the Indo-European inherited numeral for 'five' (not attested in phonetic spellings in Anatolian languages). See [Eichner 1982](src-342):383-569 for extensive discussion, cf. also [Adams 2013](src-345):415-416, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1172-1173, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):409, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):315-316, [Orel 1998](src-105):316, [EWAia](src-172) II:65-66, [ALEW](src-352) 756-767, [Derksen 2015](src-353):351, [Derksen 2008](src-81):400, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):140, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):509, [Matasović 2009](src-50):176-177.

Armenian, Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *dṓm, (gen.sg. *dém-s) 'house' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):618, [EWAia](src-172) I:697, [ALEW](src-352) 684-686, [Derksen 2015](src-353):328, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:72-73, [Derksen 2008](src-81):113, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):178-179).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pleh₁- 'to fill, be(come) full' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1191-1192, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):309-310, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):327, [Orel 1998](src-105):335, [EWAia](src-172) II:156-157, [ALEW](src-352) 772-773, [Derksen 2015](src-353):356, [Derksen 2008](src-81):426, [Kroonen 2013](src-165)159, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):472-273, [Matasović 2009](src-50):132).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'green, yellow' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1638, [EWAia](src-172) II:805-806, [ALEW](src-352) 1285-1286, 1296, [Derksen 2015](src-353):511-512, [Derksen 2008](src-81):541, [Matasović 2009](src-50):160).

Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing different derivatives from PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):70, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):227-228, [Matasović 2009](src-50):67-68, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 88).

Comment: 'loins'
Justification: Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *lendʰ-u- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):276, [ESSJa](src-458) 15:48-50).
Anatolian and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₁u̯és-u- ([EWAia](src-172) II:533-534, [Starke 1990](src-373):352-353).
Lexemes from Proto-Celtic *klēyo- 'left', further derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:114-115, [Matasović 2009](src-50):207, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 332-333).

Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from Vedic khyā- 'to see', ultimately from PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ([EWAia](src-172) I:420-421, I:456-457; [LIV²](src-141) 383-385). For Marathi, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):48 no. 1074 *ācikhyati 'communicates'; for Nuristan languages, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):745 no. 12842 sáṁkhyāti (*saṁkśāti) 'reckons'.

Balto-Slavic lexemes, generally considered to be cognate with Armenian glowx 'head' ([ALEW](src-352) 289-290, [Derksen 2015](src-353):162-163, [Derksen 2008](src-81):176). The Balto-Slavic lexemes can be transparently derived from a reconstructable PIE *golH-u̯eh₂-, but many details of the Armenian form remain unclear (cf. further discussion and references in [cognate set 8243](cog-8243)).

Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *ha(u)beda- ~ *ha(u)buda- 'head' and Italic lexemes from Latin caput, generally considered root and suffix cognate, but further identification of an Indo-European root etymology remains controversial. A frequent suggestion is to PIE *keh₂p- 'to grasp, seize' found in Latin capiō, -ere 'id.' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):215, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):91). Alternatively a frequent comparison is made to Sanskrit kapā́la- 'cup, skull' with a different nominal suffix, but this cognate relationship remains uncertain ([Kluge 2011](src-397):530-531, [KEWA](src-399) I:155, [EWAia](src-172) I:300).

Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE 1. *k̑el- 'to hide' ([LIV²](src-141) 322-323, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):252-253, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):218, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:53-54, [Matasović 2009](src-50):199).

Tocharian and Slavic lexemes from PIE *k̑leu̯s- 'to hear, to listen to' ([LIV²](src-141) 336, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):250-251, [Derksen 2008](src-81):455-456). The root is probably a secondary verbal root abstracted from a desiderative formation from *k̑leu̯- 'hear' already in the protolanguage (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 336).

Lexemes from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯j́ʰ- 'to hide', no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:502-503, [Cheung 2007](src-83):117). [LIV²](src-141) 199 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- 'verbergen'.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from a basic PIE root *k̑er- (cf. [Nussbaum 1986](src-544) for extensive discussion of formations in the meaning 'head' and 'horn' derived from this root). Cf. also [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):456-457, [Adams 2013](src-345):235 [but cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):182 deriving to *gʰreh₁-u̯r̥], [Beekes 2010](src-66):676-677, [EWAia](src-172) II:653, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):259, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):136-137, [Matasović 2009](src-50):190-191).

Hellenic, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from a basic PIE root *k̑er- (cf. [Nussbaum 1986](src-544) for extensive discussion of formations in the meaning 'head' and 'horn' derived from this root), cf. also [Beekes 2010](src-66):641, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):237, [EWAia](src-172) II:638-639.
Baltic lexemes to be connected with PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' (cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):260, [Derksen 2015](src-353):229-230, 247-248, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, and Italic reflecting different derivatives from PIE *gʷerh₂- (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):173-174, [Adams 2013](src-345):230-231, [Beekes 2010](src-66):202-203, [EWAia](src-172) I:490-491, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):91 no.1962, [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:321, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):312, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):272, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):328 no. 3855).

Baltic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷelH- 'to suffer; to prick' ([LIV²](src-141) 207, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 286, 309, [Derksen 2015](src-353):170, [Seebold 1970](src-556):313-314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):315).
Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes from PIE *(H)seu̯-i̯o- 'left' ([Adams 2013](src-345):767, [EWAia](src-172) II:716, [Derksen 2008](src-81):487-488).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)per- 'to fly' ([EWAia](src-172) II:97, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):446 no. 7918, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 579-580).

Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to hit, split' ([LIV²](src-141) 345-346, cf. [Hackstein 1995](src-731):54-56, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):115-116, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):606-607, [Adams 2013](src-345):222, [Cheung 2007](src-83):251-252).
Nuristani and Iranic lexemes fom Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰand- 'to laugh' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):200 no. 3815, [Cheung 2007](src-83):442-443).

Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):140, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):212 no. 2292, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:214, [Matasović 2009](src-50):220).

Latin flāuus 'yellow', from PIE *bʰleh₃-u̯o-, a derivative of PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):225, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 88). For Old Irish blá attached to this class not in the target meaning, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:54-55).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑enu, *g̑neu- ([IEW](src-49) 381-382, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):467-468, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):129-130, [Adams 2013](src-345):205-206, [Beekes 2010](src-66):283, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):343-344, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):190-191, [Orel 1998](src-105):137, [EWAia](src-172): I:584-585, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):296, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):259, [Matasović 2009](src-50):162).

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pekʷ- 'to become ripe; to cook' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):430 no. 7641, [EWAia](src-172) II:46, [Matasović 2009](src-50):180, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 468).

Tocharian and Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):843-844, [Adams 2013](src-345):614). The Tocharian lexemes are generally considered to be based on an *mn-stem neuter to an IE root *lei̯- ([Ringe 1996](src-695):109, [Adams 2013](src-345):614), and connected to the complex of words surrounding Gk. λειμών 'wet, grassy place, meadow' λίμην 'harbour', and λίμνη 'lake', but cf. [van Windekens 1976](src-76):271-272 for older hypotheses.

The Tocharian, Hellenic, and Germanic lexemes in this class are generally considered derivations from PIE *bʰleh₃- 'to bloom', although certain derivational details remain disputed. Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 88, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):415, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1232-1233, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1596-1597, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):66). It is possible, but uncertain that Latin folium and the Romance lexemes continuing it belong here, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 8247](cog-8247).

Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Proto-Indo-Iranic kʰaru̯á- 'mutilated, imperfect' (cf. Ved. kharvá- 'mutilated' [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):201 no. 3832), possibly further connected within Indo-Iranic to Avestan kauruua- if the term means 'mutilated', further connections outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ([EWAia](src-172) I:448-449).

Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *u̯ei̯h₁- 'to look, seek after' ([LIV²](src-141) 668-669, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:509-510, [Cheung 2007](src-83):411, [Bailey 1979](src-320):309, [de Vries 1977](src-468):650-651, [Orel 2003](src-388):441, [Kluge 2011](src-397):978).

Armenian and Italic lexemes generally admitted to be cognates from a PIE s-stem *k̑ruH-s-, vel sim. In principle, however, the Armenian lexemes might be a loan from Iranic (cf. Av. sraoni- 'buttock, hip'). Cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):79, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):585-586, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):147 for further discussion.

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Sabellic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂nér- 'man' ([NIL](src-274) 332-335, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):103-104, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):61-62, [Huld 1984](src-571):100-101, [Orel 1998](src-105):304, [EWAia](src-172) II:19-20, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):406-407, [Untermann 2000](src-279):495-497).

Tocharian, Armenian, Albanian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes from PIE *mē(m)s- 'meat' ([NIL](src-274) 486-488, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):498, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):469-470, Demiraj 1997}:269-270, [Orel 1998](src-105):267, [EWAia](src-172) II:343-344, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):574 no. 9982, [ALEW](src-352) 638-639, [Derksen 2015](src-353):312-313, [ESSJa](src-458) 19:7-11, [Derksen 2008](src-81):315, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):369).
Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Vedic ánna- 'food' reflecting PIE *h₁éd-no-, cf. PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):18 no. 395, [EWAia](src-172) I:79-80).

Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *mer- 'to disappear; to die' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):452-453, [EWAia](src-172) II:318-319, 327-328, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):596 no. 9888, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 439-440).

Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *u̯iH-ró- 'young, powerful man' ([NIL](src-274) 726-729, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:569-570, [ALEW](src-352) 1252-1253, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):588, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):681, [Matasović 2009](src-50):423).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *i̯e/okʷ-r/n-, generally presumed to be the PIE inherited word for 'liver' ([NIL](src-274) 392-395, [EIEC](src-657) 356, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):522, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):306-307, [EWAia](src-172) II:391, [ALEW](src-352) 413-414, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):296).

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *meh₁- 'to measure' ([Adams 2013](src-345):503, [EWAia](src-172) II:352-353, [ALEW](src-352) 634-635, [ESSJa](src-458) 18:191-194, [Derksen 2008](src-81):312-313, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):365, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):373).
Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- ([Adams 2013](src-345):399-400, [EWAia](src-172) II:232, [Bailey 1979](src-320):299, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):8).

Celtic lexemes generally connected to PIE *leu̯⁽g̑⁾- 'bend' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):248), but cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):332 for a speculative proposal to *leu̯s- in connection to Lat. lūridus 'pale (yellow)' (Schrijver himself admits "a mere possibility").

Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰerg̑ʰ- 'to be(come) high, to rise up' ([NIL](src-274) 30, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):60, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):87, [Matasović 2009](src-50):77, [LIV²](src-141) 78-79).
Indo-Iranic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷerH- ([EWAia](src-172) I:487, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:29-31, [Derksen 2008](src-81):177-178, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 332-333).

Tocharian, Greek, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' ([LIV²](src-141) 215-216, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):683-684, [Beekes 2010](src-66):505, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):356-357, [EWAia](src-172) I:594, [Cheung 2007](src-83):222-223, [ALEW](src-352) 338-340, [Derksen 2008](src-81):652, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):685-686, [Matasović 2009](src-50):67).
Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯p- 'to stick' ([LIV²](src-141) 408-409, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):326-327, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):335-336).

Comment: < 'cooked'.
Justification: Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *pekʷ- 'to make ripe; to cook' ([ALEW](src-352) 477-478, [Derksen 2015](src-353):237-238, [Derksen 2008](src-81):393, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:255-256, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 468).

Armenian, Indic, Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'to hinder, restrict' ([NIL](src-274) 301-303, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):94-95, [EWAia](src-172) I:39, [Derksen 2008](src-81):388, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):28-29, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):42, [Matasović 2009](src-50):36, 214)

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃nebʰ- 'navel' ([NIL](src-274) 385-387, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1080, [EWAia](src-172) II:13-14, [Derksen 2015](src-353):562, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):380, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):639, [Matasović 2009](src-50):33)
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *men- 'to rise, stick up' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):388, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):502, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 437).

Comment: cf. Vedic purāṇá- 'prior, former, old', from purā́ adv. < *pr̥h₂éh₁ (instrumental, cf. purás < *pr̥h₂és etc.)
Justification: Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes derived from a PIE root *perh₂-, secondary to PIE *pr̥-, *pró-, *prí 'forwards, to the front' ([EWAia](src-172) II:146-147, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):469 no. 8283, [EWA 3](src-441):300-301, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):161, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294):653, 633).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *neu̯- 'new' ([NIL](src-274) 524-526, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):605, [Adams 2013](src-345):287-288, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1009, [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):479, [EWAia](src-172) II:25, [ALEW](src-352) 690-691, [Derksen 2015](src-353):330-331, [ESSJa](src-458) 26:9-13, [Derksen 2008](src-81):357, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):389, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):416, {ref Matasović 2009:293)

Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *nógʷt-/*négʷt- 'evening, night', a dental-stem derivative of PIE *negʷ- 'to become dark, dawn' ([NIL](src-274) 504-513, [LIV²](src-141) 449, cf. {ref {Beekes 2010}:1027, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):283-284, [Orel 1998](src-105):282-283, [EWAia](src-172) II:2-3, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):242, [ALEW](src-352) 683-684, [Derksen 2015](src-353):327-328, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:175-177, [Derksen 2008](src-81):355, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):381, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):416-417, [Matasović 2009](src-50):293-294). The Brythonic lexemes in this class are sometimes considered to be (parallel?) loanwords from Latin (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):293-294, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):539-540), but by others to be inherited (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):121, [NIL](src-274) 509n10). The assumption that these lexemes are inherited has been followed here.

Comment: Vedic -:nas(-a)- as a second member in compounds confirms *H in root onset, ergo PIE *Hnas-
Justification: Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes continuing an Indo-European word for 'nose' traditionally reconstructed as *(H)nā̆s- ([EIEC](src-657) 395, cf. [IEW](src-49) 755), although Leiden school of Indo-European reconstructs an ablauting s-stem *neh₂-s- (cf. [Kortlandt 1985b](src-640):119). The traditional reconstruction has been followed here for the purpose of a root reference form. For individual branches cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:30-31, [ALEW](src-352) 711, [Derksen 2015](src-353):336-337, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:212-216, [Derksen 2008](src-81):357, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):383, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):400)

Anatolian, Tocharian, Greek, and Armenian pexemes derived from PIE *sem- 'one (collective)' ([LIPP 2](src-294):671-679, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):750-751, [Adams 2013](src-345):721-722, [Beekes 2010](src-66):394, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):467-468).
Parallel loans from Persian تنگ / tang 'narrow'.

Celtic lexemes generally connected to Lat. pūrus 'clean, pure, undefiled', Skt. pūtá- 'purified', etc. since [Pedersen 1909](src-307):91 (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) U:26-27, [Matasović 2009](src-50):143). The PIE root is now reconstructed as *peu̯H- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 480 s.v. 1.*peu̯H- 'reinigen, läutern'), but cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):143 who alternatively suggests a connection to PIE *peh₂-u̯r̥- 'fire' and with an original meaning 'purified by fire', but this proposal has not been widely accepted.

The cognacy of these Germanic lexemes are difficult to assign. A majority view of scholars assign them with derivatives of one of the PIE *men- roots in [cognate set 76](cog-76), alternatively a minority view of scholars places it with other Germanic, Italic, and Celtic words for 'human' < *dʰg̑ʰ-mon- *'earthling' [cognate set 907](cog-907). The cognacy decision for these lexemes has therefore been to split these lexemes from the majority set into their own separate set, which has been appropriately indexed to the other existing sets.

Albanian and Indic lexemes derived from PIE *ten- 'to stretch' ([LIV²](src-141) 626-627, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):284-285, [Orel 1998](src-105):283, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):985, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):328 no. 5762, [EWAia](src-172) I:618-619).

Indo-Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *nebʰ- '(to become) wet, cloudy, vaporous' ([NIL](src-274) 499-504, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:13, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):400 no. 6955c, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):386, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):404).

Indo-Iranic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *nebʰ- '(to become) wet, cloudy, vaporous' ([NIL](src-274) 499-504, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:94, II:13, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):400 no. 6955c, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):299, [Untermann 2000](src-279):95-96).

Anatolian, Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *nebʰ- 'become damp, cloudy, misty' ([NIL](src-274) 499-504; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):603-604, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:71-72, [ALEW](src-352) 186-187, [Derksen 2015](src-353):118, [ESSJa](src-458) 24:101-104, [Derksen 2008](src-81):347-348, [Matasović 2009](src-50):288-289).

Slavic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl, seethe' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):606, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):524-525, [Derksen 2008](src-81):434-435, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 305-306).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *(h₁)reu̯dʰ- '(to make) red' ([NIL](src-274) 580-584, [EIEC](src-657) 480-481, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):570-571, [Beekes 2010](src-66):465-466, [EWAia](src-172) II:471, [ALEW](src-352) 847, [Derksen 2015](src-353):376-377, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594), [Kroonen 2013](src-165):406, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):527, [Matasović 2009](src-50):315, [LIV²](src-141) 508-509).

Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes reflecting different derivations from PIE *dek̑s- 'to be suitable' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):316-317, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):137-138, [Orel 1998](src-105):67-68, [EWAia](src-172) I:690-691, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):349 no. 6119, [ALEW](src-352) 199, [Derksen 2015](src-353):124, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:218-219, [Derksen 2008](src-81):100-101, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):512, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):168, {Matasović 2009}:97, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 112)

Iranic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ([EWAia](src-172) I:252-253, II:425, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):459, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):231, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):408, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):517-518, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):241 no. 2648, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 3:87-91, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 304-305).

Germanic and Italic lexemes reflecting PIE *h₂ekʷ-eh₂- 'water' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):7, [EWA 1](src-383):99-103, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):48, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):46). Pace [Kroonen 2013](src-165), the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by [Beekes 1998](src-709)), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. [EWA 1](src-383) 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)).

Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *peu̯H- 'to rot, to stink' ([EWAia](src-172) II:155, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:141, [ALEW](src-352) 834, [Derksen 2015](src-353):374, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):219, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):132, 158, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):501, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):570 no. 6878, 6887, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 480-481).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'to run away, flee' via the causative-iterative stem *bʰogʷ-éi̯e- 'to make run, flee' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 67, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1183-1184, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1559).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sal- 'salt' ([NIL](src-274) 586-590, [EIEC](src-657) 498, [IEW](src-49) 878-879, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):742, [Beekes 2010](src-66):177, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):24, 40-41, [ALEW](src-352) 887-888, [Derksen 2015](src-353):548-549, [Derksen 2008](src-81):461, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):425, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):535, [Matasović 2009](src-50):319). The root is difficult to reconstruct; the traditional reconstruction as *sal- has been followed here after [NIL](src-274), but note in order to avoid reconstructing PIE *a the Leiden school reconstructs a hysterokinetic l-stem: nom.sg. *séh₂‑l‑s, acc.sg. *sh₂‑el‑m, gen.sg. *sh₂‑l‑ós ([Kortlandt 1985b](src-640):119, [Beekes 1995](src-72):177, cf. also [Rieken 1999](src-317):424n2103). The Germanic forms in this set show an extension in *d which may be on analogy to *su̯eh₂d- 'sweet' [cognate set 5109](cog-5109), alternatively the *-d- might be explained as a compound with the root *deh₃- 'give' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 886-887 s.v. Old Lithuanian saldùs 'sweet' and further discussion in [cognate set 5157](cog-5157)).

Originally in the sense 'delta, confluence of (river) waters' with preverb sam- 'together with, along with' + *udra- 'water' ([EWAia](src-172) II:705, I:215-216, [NIL](src-274) 706-715; cf. the Skt. n-stem udan- abstracted from the original heteroclite -r/n-stem derived from PIE *u̯ed-). For the Middle and Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):764, no. 13236.
Baltic lexemes generally considered derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ([LIV²](src-141) 359, [ALEW](src-352) 463-464, [Derksen 2015](src-353):231).

Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *seh₁- 'to press in' → 'to sow' ([ALEW](src-352) 906-907, [Derksen 2015](src-353):392, [Derksen 2008](src-81):446, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):428-430, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):557, [Matasović 2009](src-50):336, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 517).

Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *kes- *'to arrange, put in order' → to comb, scratch' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):238, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:133-135; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 357). Perhaps also connected to Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):220 and further discussion in [cognate set 9647](cog-9647)).

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *si̯eu̯H- 'to sew' ([LIV²](src-141) 545, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:734, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):766 no. 13444, [Cheung 2007](src-83):136-137, [ALEW](src-352)  917-918, [Derksen 2015](src-353):400, [Derksen 2008](src-81):487, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):437-438, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):600, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):203 no. 2174).

Hellenic and Albanian lexemes derived from PIE *sper- 'to spread, scatter' ([LIV²](src-141) 580). The connection of Albanian lexemes to this class follows [Demiraj 1997](src-369):56, [Orel 1998](src-105):93, but more skeptically cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):78; for Hellenic, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1035-1036, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1379-1380, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1316).

Germanic and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *pel-. The Germanic forms in this class reflect *pel-no- ([EWA 3](src-441):122-126, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):135), while the Italic/Romance forms reflect an i-stem *pel-ni- ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):455, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):525 no. 6377).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11348 s.v. *varta- 'round stone', *'rolled / rolling stone', from PIE *uert- 'roll, rolled; turn, spin', cf. Skrt. vartula- 'round, circular', Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 156
Justification: Modern Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from Indo-Iranic *varta- *'turning around, circular object' → 'round stone', further to be derived from PIE *u̯ert- 'to revolve' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):661 no. 11348, [KEWA](src-399) II:154-156, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 691-692).

Indo-Iranic lexemes as though from PIE *slegh₂snó- ([EWAia](src-172) II:673, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:25-26), probably to be abstracted to a more basic root *(s)legh₂- (cf. Ancient Greek λαγαρός 'slack, loose'). Considered by [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:25-26 to be a variant of PIE *(s)lei̯- with a root-extension *-g̑-, but this conjecture remains uncertain.

The cognacy of the Germanic, Celtic, and Italic (cf. Lat. natrīx) lexemes is generally agreed, but the IE root etymology is debated. More commonly ascribed to PIE *(s)neh₁- 'twist, spin' ([LIV²](src-141) 571-572, [IEW](src-49) 973). Also possible, but less likely to *(s)neh₂- 'bathe, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 572-573, [IEW](src-49) 971-972). Cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):403, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):262, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):381, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) N:4-5, [Matasović 2009](src-50):284, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):402).

Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *kʷr̥mi- 'worm' ([EWAia](src-172) I:394-395, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:569, [Matasović 2009](src-50):181-182). Perhaps connected to PIE *u̯r̥mi- 'worm' (cf. [cognate set 172](cog-172) for further discussion).

Within Hellenic the root of the noun, *γλῶχ- / *glōkʰ 'point', is attested via γλωχίς 'end of a yoke strap, barb of an arrow, etc.', but there are no known cognates outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):229-230, [Beekes 2010](src-66):278).

Tocharian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *snei̯gʷʰ- 'to stick, adhere to' ([NIL](src-274) 622-625 [EIEC](src-657) 530, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):689-690, [ALEW](src-352) 951, [Derksen 2015](src-353):416, [Derksen 2008](src-81):457, [Kroonen 2013](src-165)460, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):409-410, [Matasović 2009](src-50):349, [LIV²](src-141) 573).

Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ([EWAia](src-172) I:252-253, II:425, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:350-352, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):408-409, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):566, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):517-518, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):241 no. 2648, [Thurneysen 1946](src-227):119, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:96, [Matasović 2009](src-50):308).
Anatolian, Albanian, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *mel(it)- 'honey' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):580-581, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):169-170, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) M:50-51).
Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *melino- 'yellow', a derivative based on PIE *melit- 'honey' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):263, cf. [EIEC](src-657) 271).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʰrebh₂- ([LIV²](src-141) 201, [EWAia](src-172) I:505-507, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):227 no. 4236, [Cheung 2007](src-83):119-121).

Indic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *lei̯kʷ- 'to leave' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):492, no. 8743, [EWAia](src-172) II:457-458, [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):451-452, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:161, [Matasović 2009](src-50):240, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 406-408).
Probably to be derived from the inherited word for 'honey' μέλι < PIE *melit- ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):370, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):925-926). Regarding the IE 'honey', cf. [EIEC](src-657) 271.

Tocharian, Indic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *su̯eh₂d- 'to make/become tasty' ([NIL](src-274) 670-675, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):795-796, [EWAia](src-172) II:788-789, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):503, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 606-607).
Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *men- 'to think' ([EWAia](src-172) II:305-306, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 435-436).

Albanian, Indic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *serp- 'to creep' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):183-184, [Orel 1998](src-105):130, [EWAia](src-172) II:710, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):766 no. 13271, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):558, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):648, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 536).

Albanian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷerH- ([Huld 1984](src-571):66-67, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):181, [Orel 1998](src-105):127, [Holm 2011](src-130):82, [EWAia](src-172) I:487, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):223 no. 4161, [ESIJa](src-331) 3:191-193 [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):187). Note Sinhalese gala appears to be a contamination of the inherited lexeme with Tamil kal 'stone'.

Anatolian and Baltic lexemes whose cognacy is generally agreed, but root reconstruction difficult. Cf. comments of [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):392-393. LIV¹ reconstructs *seh₂(i̯)-, [LIV²](src-141) *sh₂ei̯-. As a compromise between the two versions of LIV and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80), we give *seh₂(i̯)- as the root ref. form for this class. See also [Derksen 2015](src-353):397-398. For Indo-Iranic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:720-721.

Traditionally connected to Vedic khā́dati 'to chew, bite, eat, devour' ([HAB](src-740) III:317-318, [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):210), but there are no certain cognates for Vedic khā́dati outside of Indo-Iranic (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:451-452). See [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):323-324 for further discussion.

Comment: fr. ie. ken- 'scratch, scrape', ultimately cognate with Gr.: κὀνισ 'ashes' (Pokorny) and maybe also with 'scratch' in lexeme 18887

from PIE *h₂ek̑  'sharp, pointed; stone, rock'; cognate with 'stone' [cognate set 1179](cog-1179) - NB. sky (and daylight) was mythically seen as coming out of the rock (cf. the Vedic Vala-myth) and thus as originating from/being made from rock/stone.
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'stone' (gen.sg. *h₂k-n-és-), an *mn̥-stem nominal derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ([EWAia](src-172) I:137-138).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, fall' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):658-659, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1248, [EWAia](src-172) II:75-76, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):435-436 no.7721, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):138-139, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):458, [Lucht 2007](src-151):151-152, [Matasović 2009](src-50):129). For the root reconstruction *pet-, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Sanskrit khúra- without certain etymology, possibly loans from Dravidian (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):207 no. 3906; [KEWA](src-399) I:310, [EWAia](src-172) I:454, cf. [Burrow 1948](src-759):376). Perhaps further connected with lexemes as though from Sanskrit *khuṭṭa- 'peg, post' in [cognate set 9630](cog-9630), but these could also be parallel loans.
Nuristani lexemes as though from Indic *ḍagga- (2) 'defective' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):310 no. 5524).

Hellenic lexemes, traditionally connected with Baltic lexemes (Lith. ver̃pti, 'spin', Latv. virpêt 'spin with a spindle' ([IEW](src-49) 1156), but the evidence of Myc. e-ra-pe-me-na without initial *w- makes this etymology impossible ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):967, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1275-1276). Further etymology outside of Greek uncertain.

Hellenic lexemes whose root etymology is traditionally disputed between the near-homophonous roots *peth₁- 'to fall', 1. *peth₂- 'to spread out', and 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):931, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1225-1226, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 477-479). See now, however, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) merging *peth₁- 'to fall' and 2. *peth₂- 'to fly' into a single, more basic root *pet- 'to fly; to fall'. In view of this, the basic etymology to *pet- has been tentatively accepted here.

Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic √pat- 'to fall; fly' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):436, no. 7722), further from PIE *pet- 'to fall; fly' ([EWAia](src-172) II:71-72, [LIV²](src-141) 436, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8792 s.v. právahati, cf. pravāhayati 'causes to swim away'; for Kashmiri cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11612 (?) - different derivations
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing different derivatives and light-verb constructions derived from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to carry, drive' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):494 no. 8792, p.677 no. 11612, [EWAia](src-172) II:535-537, [Cheung 2007](src-83):429-432).

Indo-Iranic and Celtic lexemes derived from or in light-verb constructions with PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth'. The root etymology is traditionally considered to be to PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', however difficulties regarding the Greek comparanda (ὀδών 'tooth', νωδός 'toothless') have led the Leiden school of Indo-European reconstruction to consider an underlying root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' (cf. [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):77). If the traditional etymology is followed, then these lexemes would also be cognate with Old Irish ithid 'to bite, to eat' in [cognate set 6370](cog-6370) which is clearly derived from PIE *h₁ed- 'to eat'. For the lexemes in this class, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:693-694, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):352 no. 6152, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):170, [Matasović 2009](src-50):90). For further details regarding the etymology of PIE *Hd-ónt- 'tooth', cf. further discussion in [cognate set 328](cog-328).

Greek and Indic lexemes derived from PIE *denk̑- 'to bite' ([LIV²](src-141) 117-118, [EWAia](src-172) I:688, [Beekes 2010](src-66):299). Sometimes connected to these lexemes are also  Tocharian AB tsāk- 'to bite', but these lexemes are probably better explained via PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'to sting' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 142, [Ringe 1988-1990](src-592):71).

Comment: The q-forms make a loan from Turkic likely (cf. kapmak 'to snatch'). Abaev (apud Cabolov) suggestes an onomatopoetic formation and Vasmer (apud Cabolov) noted Slavic verbs like Ukrainian хапати 'to grab, snatch' considering them a continuation of a PIE root *khap-. On this see also Cheung (2007: 234f.) *kop-.

Justification: Probably a loanword from Latin capessere 'to seize, snatch at' ([Meyer 1891](src-585):176, [Orel 1998](src-105):164, [Holm 2011](src-130):53), but other Latin loan sources are theoretically possible.

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Nuristani, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *pet- 'to fly, to fall'. For the root reconstruction cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389). For individual branches cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):658-659, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1248, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):286-287, {Turner 1962–1966}:437 no. 7733, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):138-139, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):458, [Matasović 2009](src-50):126).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4711 s.v. Sanskrit carvati, carvayati ʻchewsʼ (Dhātup.); further etymology unclear (< *kerH-?), cf. Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 379, EWAia I, p. 547
Loan from English 'bite'.
Justification: A borrowing from English 'bite, bit' ([Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):36).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂ost-, the inherited Indo-European word for 'bone' ([EIEC](src-657) 77, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):325-326, [Adams 2013](src-345):48-50, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1119, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):533, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):82-83, [Orel 1998](src-105):11, [EWAia](src-172) I:150-151, [ESIJa](src-331) 1:232-234, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):436-437, [Matasović 2009](src-50):44-45). Perhaps cognate with the lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kost- with [cognate set 1114](cog-1114) but the explanation of the initial k- is unclear (cf. further discussion in that cognate set). The PIE stem is usually reconstructed with initial *h₂- on the basis of Greek ἀστραγαλός 'knucklebone' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):129), but the etymological connection of this word to the lexemes in this class is rejected by [Beekes 2010](src-66):157-158 who prefers to see Greek ἀστραγαλός as a substratum loanword.

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though from Sanskrit khúra- without certain etymology, possibly loans from Dravidian (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):207 no. 3906; [KEWA](src-399) I:310, [EWAia](src-172) I:454, cf. [Burrow 1948](src-759):376). Perhaps further connected with lexemes as though from Sanskrit *khuṭṭa- 'peg, post' in [cognate set 9629](cog-9629), but these could also be parallel loans.

Hellenic lexemes of uncertain etymology, perhaps from a PIE root *pneu̯- if cognate with Germanic lexemes attested by, e.g., Old Norse fnýsa 'sniff, snort' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):920, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1213-1214, [LIV²](src-141) 489).
West Germanic lexemes probably originally based on an onomatopoeic formation ([Kluge 2011](src-397):414, [EWNl](src-757) II:475).
Possibly parallel loans from Dravidian, see [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):206 no. 3894, cf. also 'knee' in [cognate set 2792](cog-2792), 'leg' in [cognate set 9630](cog-9630).

Brythonic lexemes, probably continuing a loanword from Latin cumulus 'heap' although the conservation of medial *-m- in phonetically difficult (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):422, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Anatolian, Hellenic, Albanian, Iranic, Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *déru- ~ *dóru- ~ *dru- 'wood, tree' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):849-850, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):262-263, [Beekes 2010](src-66):315-316, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):146-148, [Orel 1998](src-105):76, [EWAia](src-172) I:721, [ESIJa](src-331) 2:357-365, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:211-213, [Derksen 2008](src-81):99, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):522-523, cf. [IEW](src-49) 214-217).
Iranic and Germanic lexemes from a PIE heteroclite stem *i̯eh₁-r/n- ([EWAia](src-172) II:98-99, [ESIJa](src-331) 4:130-131, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):273).

Indo-Iranic and Baltic lexemes derived from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾eH(i̯)- 'to sing' ([EWAia](src-172) I:482-483, [Cheung 2007](src-83):94, [ALEW](src-352) 320-321, [Derksen 2015](src-353):174, [LIV²](src-141) 183). The Baltic forms show an extra *-d- added to the basic root, sometimes considered a root enlargement, but may be also accounted for via various other explanations (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 320-321 for further discussion).
Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *⁽k̑⁾an- 'to sing, sound' ([LIV²](src-141) 342-343, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):87-88, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):387-390, [Matasović 2009](src-50):187-188).
