Comment: unclear why Parthian bāšēd is sorted into this set (TJ)

Justification: Extra-Germanic etymology unclear. Possibly from PIE *gʷet- if comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite', but the comparison is not entirely clear; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 212, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):319, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):277-278, [Seebold 1970](src-556):318-320, [Olsen 1999](src-180):811.

Baltic and Germanic lexemes from PIE *nem- 'to portion out'. Cognacy in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) s.v. 1. *nem-, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):266-267), but [LIV²](src-141) 236 s.v. *h₁em-. It is possible that these two roots formed a rhyming pair in PIE (cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):357-359); cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):387 for an attempt to reconcile the Germanic lexemes to *h₁em- by assuming a reanalysis of the compound verb *gan-eman- < *kom-h₁em-e- as containing the perfective prefix *ga-: *ga-neman-.

Tocharian, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ([NIL](src-274) 287-300, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):5, [Orel 1998](src-105):86, [ALEW](src-352) 62, [Derksen 2015](src-353):64, [ESSJa](src-458) 36:63-66, [Derksen 2008](src-81):379, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):22, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):11 no. 134, 135).
Possibly parallel loans from Dravidian, see [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):206 no. 3894, cf. also 'knee' in [cognate set 2792](cog-2792), 'foot' in [cognate set 9629](cog-9629).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯an-na- 'to sound, play an instrument', further to PIE *su̯enh₂- 'to sound' ([LIV²](src-141) 611, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):607-609, [Matasović 2009](src-50):360-361).

Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *h₂ék̑-mon- 'stone' (gen.sg. *h₂k-n-és-), an *mn̥-stem nominal derivative of PIE *h₂ek̑- 'to be(come), make sharp' ([EWAia](src-172) I:137-138, [ALEW](src-352) 28-29, [ESSJa](src-458) 9:137-140, [Derksen 2008](src-81):220, [Derksen 2015](src-353):47-48, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):30-31).

Hellenic lexemes as though from PIE *ken(H)-is- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):562, [Beekes 2010](src-66):746-747, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):706, 1284, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):115). The connection of Albanian hi 'ash' to this class (cf. [cognate set 850](cog-850)) presupposes the reconstruction of an s-mobile root *(s)ken(H)- (cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):74, [Orel 1998](src-105):47).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *druko- 'bad', further connections uncertain (cf. {ref Vendryes et al. 1959–1996 D:198-199, [Matasović 2009](src-50):105-106).

The root etymology in this set tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 238 to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' via a stem formation *h₁r̥-sk̑é-, although formally the Hellenic lexemes may also reflect a secondarily thematised present stem *h₁erg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ- to *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'to climb, ascend' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):377, [Beekes 2010](src-66):468).

The root etymology in this set tentatively follows [LIV²](src-141) 238 to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' via a stem formation *h₁r̥-sk̑é-, although formally the Hellenic lexemes may also reflect a secondarily thematised present stem *h₁erg̑ʰ-/h₁r̥g̑ʰ- to *h₁erg̑ʰ- 'to climb, ascend' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):377, [Beekes 2010](src-66):468).

Comment: seng- 'thin, slender' and suffix -an
Justification: Goidelic lexemes from Old Irish sengán 'ant'. Etymology uncertain, perhaps to be connected with Proto-Germanic *swengwan- 'to swing' (so [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:85-86, but proposed connections for this verb outside of Germanic are rejected by [Seebold 1970](src-556):493, cf. {Kluge 2011}:836).
Etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):163 no. 3193, [EWAia](src-172) I:355-356).

Ossetic lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *pa(s)nu-ka-, cf. Av. pąsnu, Ved. pāṃsu- 'soil, dust, sand' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:449), further probably to PIE ?*pē(n)s- ([EIEC](src-657) 499, but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:114-115).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ([LIV²](src-141) 262, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1194-1195, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):277-279, [Orel 1998](src-105):324-325, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):990, [EWAia](src-172) II:113-114, [Derksen 2015](src-353):563, [Derksen 2008](src-81):401, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):71-72, [Matasović 2009](src-50):130).

Romance lexemes continuing *skĭna-, a loanword from Germanic *skĭna- 'small piece of bone, shin', cf. Germanic scina 'thin strip, shin' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):659 no. 7994, [DCECH](src-423) II:761-762).
Hellenic and Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *pleth₂- 'be(come) wide, broad' ([NIL](src-274) 564-566; cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1205, [Derksen 2008](src-81):404).

Romanian spathe is originally from Latin spatha 'beater, spatula', originally a loanword from Greek σπάθη 'broad blade (of wood or metal)', while the Iberian Romance forms are from Latin spatula, the diminutive of spatha  (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):612, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):638-639, [DCECH](src-423) II:733-734).
No certain etymology outside of Slavic.
Modern Indic lexemes as from Vedic pāṁsú- 'soil, dust, sand' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):452 no. 452, further probably to PIE ?*pē(n)s- ([EIEC](src-657) 499, but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:114-115).

Connections outside of Armenian uncertain. Within Armenian probably to be connected with Classical Armenian kuṙn '(anatom.) back; side', which in turn – if the original semantic meaning was 'curved/bending body-part' – may be related to Classical Armenian kor 'curved, crooked' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):376, cf. id. 382, 373-374). [HAB](src-740) II:669 offers no etymology. [MM: Proto-Armenian *kuṙ(-tʰ)-un-].

Root_Gloss: back side, something that is at the back side

Justification: Etymology outside of Tocharian uncertain, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):640 for discussion and suggestions.
Loan from Saṇu-viri gutʹu 'rump'.
No certain etymology outside of East Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 714, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):429).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin rēnēs 'kidneys' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):596), further etymology obscure ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):569-570, cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):519 for various suggestions).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):78 for suggestions.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *elhja- 'evil'; further etymology uncertain ([de Vries 1977](src-468):285). More recently cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):637-638 suggesting a connection to PGmc. *ubila- 'bad' in [cognate set 2195](cog-2195) under the assumption of some irregular sound changes; alternatively cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):117 tentatively suggests a connection with OIr. elc 'mischievous, capricious' via ?*h₁elk-o-. Root ref. form follows the reconstruction of [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *wanda- 'turned, twisted', further derived from PIE u̯endʰ- 'to twist, wind' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):554-555, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):654-655, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):573, 587, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 681-682).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin reus 'defendant, accused' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)) and also related to Latin rēs 'property, goods; thing, matter, affair', further to PIE *(H)reh₁- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):521-522 for discussion of the Italic stem formation; for the root reconstruction cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):520-521, [LIV²](src-141) 499).

Derivatives from PIE *(s)kert- 'cut (to pieces)' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):144-145, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):138, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560), often considered to be a dental-enlarged form of PIE 2. *(s)ker- 'shear, scratch, cut off' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 556-7).

No certain etymology outside of Germanic ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):346, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):375). Occasionally compared to Balto-Slavic lexemes, e.g. Lith. mãkas 'purse, pouch, scrotum', but the connection remains uncertain (cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):399).

Comment: from PIE *gʰreu̯d- 'to pound, to mash' (Kroonen 2013:187, Kluge 2002:375, ALEW 374; not in LIV²).
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *grauta- 'strong, thick, big', further from PIE *gʰrou̯d-o-, cf. the Germanic strong verb *greutan- 'to grind, crush' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):187, 189, [Kluge 2011](src-397):376-377, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):256, [Seebold 1970](src-556):242, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 374).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):47 for further discussion. For proposed connections to Wakhi lup and Indic and Nurstani lexemes, cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):227.

Italic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂merd- 'to hurt, mistreat' ([LIV²](src-141) 280, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):414, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):389, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):465 no. 5679, cf. [DCECH](src-423) III:143-145, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 6/3:126-129).

Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hu̯aǰ-, from Proto-Indo-Iranic *su̯aǰ-, cf. Ved. √svaj- ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:152-154). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:788, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 610-611 reconstructing ?*su̯eng- on the basis of the comparison of Old Irish seng 'schlank' < *'biegsam').

There are several different nominal derivations within Germanic here that are based on PIE *bʰei̯d- 'split' ([LIV²](src-141) 70-71); cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):66, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):115, 126-127, [Kluge 2011](src-397):127, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):58-59, [de Vries 1977](src-468):30).
Hellenic lexemes from PIE *pik̑-ro-, a derivative to PIE *pei̯k̑- 'to cut out, carve out' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):900-901, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1190, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 465-466).
Cognacy in this class follows [Demiraj 1997](src-369):200-201 deriving to PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'to kindle, ignite (smth.)', but cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):147.
Lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kortъkъ 'short', further derived from PIE *(s)kert- 'to cut (up)' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):236, [ESSJa](src-458) 11:99-104, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Tocharian lexemes, possibly to PIE *h₁ergʷ- via a derived stem *h₁r̥gʷ-ont- 'dark' (cf. Skt. rájanī- 'night', Gk. ἔρεβος 'darkness of the underworld', Arm. erek 'evening', Goth. riqis 'darkness'), but ultimately uncertain ([Adams 2013](src-345):101).
Iranic lexemes, ultimately derivatives from PIE *temH- 'to be dark' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):82, [EWAia](src-172) I:627). Cf. Avestan tąθra- ᾽darkness᾽.
Iranic lexemes reflecting Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćar(a)d-, cf. Vedic śarád- 'autumn; year'; no further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:616, cf. also [NIL](src-274) 415n7).

According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):469, to be connected with Baltic adjectives meaning 'red, ruddy' from a basic root *ser- ([IEW](src-49) 910-911). The extra-Baltic connections to the proposed comparanda in Lithuanian sar̃tas 'red-brown, chestnut (of a horse)', etc.  have been recently doubted by [ALEW](src-352) 891, but cf. [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):534.
Brythonic lexemes as though from Proto-Celtic *u̯ait-o- 'blood', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):130, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):295, [Lucht 2007](src-151):67n7).
Ossetic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *tau̯ká-, further etymology uncertain (cf.  [EWAia](src-172) I:670, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:309-310).
Tocharian A wräṣ 'breathe', a derivative of PIE 3. u̯er- 'to observe, perceive' ([LIV²](src-141) 685-686, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):892).

Pontic Greek ανασμαίνω from Ancient Greek ἀνασθμαίνω 'to breathe with difficulty', a denominal verb to Ancient Greek ἄσθμα 'short-drawn breath, panting' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):148). Older attempts to connect Ancient Greek ἄσθμα to ἄνεμος 'wind' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):122-123) are formally impossible ([Beekes 2010](src-66):148) as one would expect a base ἄνε- from the root *h₂enh₁-. Consequently, there is currently no known etymology outside of Greek.

From Sanskrit śoṇita- 'blood' created to Vedic śóṇa- 'red, crimson; purple' with the suffix -ita- on analogy to Sanskrit lohita- 'blood' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):732 no. 12625), further from PIE *k̑óu̯-no- 'shining' ([EWAia](src-172) II:656-657).
Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √yā- 'to drive, move oneself', ultimately to PIE *(H)i̯eh₂- (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):58 no. 1288, [EWAia](src-172) II:407-408, [LIV²](src-141) 309-310).

Derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331).
Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg' (unattested in Gothic), further etymology obscure (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):105-106, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):48).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *knuk(k)an- 'knuckle', perhaps a root-extended variant *g̑nu-g- to PIE *g̑enu-, *g̑neu- 'knee' but this is not certain (cf. discussion in [Kluge 2011](src-397):507-508, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):298).

Goidelic lexemes continuing an Indo-European stem *konh₂m-, cf. Ancient Greek κνήμη 'leg', Old English hamm 'ham' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:129-130, [Matasović 2009](src-50):211, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):723).
The root etymology in this set follows [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):673-674, assuming a prefix pe- 'away, thither' to verbal dā- 'take' < PIE *deh₃- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 105-106).
Denominal formation from Welsh cri 'cry', respectively a loanword from English cry ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Albanian lexemes generally derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ([NIL](src-274) 196-199, [LIV²](src-141) 219-220), although the stem formation of Albanian zjarr is uncertain (cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):62, [Orel 1998](src-105):525 and especially the detailed discussion of [Demiraj 1997](src-369):428-429).

Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯k- 'to shine, glow, burn' (Proto-Iranic *sauč- 'to burn, emit flames'). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps PIE *k̑eu̯k- if Greek κύκνος 'swan' is to be connected with an original meaning *'the brightly white (bird)' ([EWAia](src-172) II:655-656, [LIV²](src-141) 331, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):338-340, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:208-210).

[Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):195 suggested a connection to a basic root *ges- and to be compared with Latin gerere 'to carry, bear about' (past participle gestum), however the root etymology of Latin gerō, -ere is disputed. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):18-19 tentatively rehabilitates an old proposal by Osthoff to *h₂eg̑- via a perform *h₂g̑-és-, and this followed by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):259, but cf. the skepticism of [Walde & Hofmann 1938–1954](src-175) I:595-596, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):273-274. If the connection of Scottish Gaelic giùlain to a neo-root *ges- (< *h₂g̑-és-?) is to be maintained, this would be a unique Italo-Celtic lexical(-morphological) isogloss. Given the multiple degrees of speculation required to posit an ultimate root etymology to PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' for this exclusively Scottish Gaelic cognate set, the root reference form has been given as the Gaelic form itself.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *h₁urH-ú- 'broad, wide', presupposing a full-grade root *h₁u̯erH- (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):483-484, [EWAia](src-172) I:227, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:90-91, [Untermann 2000](src-279):310, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):645).

Root reconstruction follows [LIV²](src-141) 676, [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243. Cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1242-1243 s.v. OLith. vìlgyti and [Matasović 2009](src-50):427 s.v. Proto-Celtic *wolko- for different plausible accounts for the unexpected voiceless velar in Celtic cognates. Cf. also [Kluge 2011](src-397):994-995.

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek πάγος 'that which is fixed or firmly set; rock, ice' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1016), further derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm, stiff' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1141, 1184, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 461).

Iranic lexemes probably reflecting derivatives from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm, stiff' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):229-230, [Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):250-251, [EWAia](src-172) II:116, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 461).
East Romance lexemes from Latin recēns 'of recent origin, fresh' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further to PIE *ken- 'fresh, recent' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):516, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 351).

Etymology disputed. Either to PIE *k̑elH- (cf. 'cold' in [cognate set 14](cog-14), 'freeze' in [cognate set 1857](cog-1857)) or to PIE *g̑el- (cf. 'cold' in [cognate set 196](cog-196), 'ice' in [cognate set 6560](cog-6560)); cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:60.
Baltic lexemes, probably derivatives from PIE *kreu̯H- 'to heap up, cover' ([ALEW](src-352) 531-532, [Derksen 2015](src-353):256, 261, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 371).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *garj́ʰ- 'to lament'. Connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:475, 495, [Cheung 2007](src-83):111-112). [LIV²](src-141) 187 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾eRg̑ʰ-.

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₃neg⁽ʷ⁾ʰ- '(finger)nail' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1086-1087, [EWAia](src-172) II:4-5, [ALEW](src-352) 681-682, [Derksen 2015](src-353):327, [ESSJa](src-458) 25:161-164, 170-173, [Derksen 2008](src-81):355 [de Vaan 2008](src-54):641, [Matasović 2009](src-50):36). Indo-Iranian forms go back to an aberrant *(H)nákha-; some show early nasalization due to blend with aṅgúri- ~  aṅgúli- 'finger, toe' (°-aṅgulá-) or aṅguṣṭhá- 'thumb'; aṅká- 'hook' (RV) and later aṅkurá- 'hooked' may also have played a role, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442), no. 6914 + 134f. 137f., 100, 109; Addenda 6914

Comment: original meaning "to sharpen" via "peak" > "breast, chest"
Justification: Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Iranic *sainaka- (cf. Avestan saēni- 'top, peak'), ultimately derivatives from PIE *k̑eh₃(i̯)- 'to sharpen' via an intermediate sense 'peak; protuberance, top part' ([Korn 2005](src-344):384, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:199-200, [EWAia](src-172) II:627, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 319-320).

No certain etymology (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.), [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:414-415 proposes connections to PIE *(H)rebʰ-ró- (cf. Old Church Slavonic reboro 'rib, side', Old High German rippi, ribbi 'rib').

The IE root underlying the Germanic forms in this class is generally reconstructed as *⁽g̑⁾el- on the basis of Germanic and Italic correspondences (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 185). The reconstruction of a palatovelar or plain velar depends on whether one additionally accepts cognacy with Balto-Slavic forms (cf. Lith. gelumà 'frost', Ru. gólotь 'Glatteis'), cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):288-289, [Ringe 2017](src-703):109. The Germanic forms are considered by some scholars (cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):209) to be related to Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *xoldъ 'cold', but the correspondences of Slavic initial *x and medial *d to Germanic *k and *d is irregular. Consequently the connection of Slavic *xoldъ to the Germanic and Italic lexemes from IE *⁽g̑⁾el- must remain at least uncertain, if not outright rejected.
Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *tekti 'to flow, run', and further derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'to flow, run' ([Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:159, [Derksen 2008](src-81):489, [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

Italic lexemes continuing Latin numerāre 'to count', a denominal verb to Latin numerus 'number' and ultimately a derivative to PIE *nem- 'to apportion, allot' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):450-451, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):419, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):492, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 453).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ([ESIJa](src-331) I:140-143). Traditionally connected by [IEW](src-49) 301 to Proto-Germanic *īsa-, but this proposed cognacy remains uncertain, cf. [EWA 5](src-398):195-199, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):271.

Comment: For the onset cf. Persian *ai̯u̯a-ka- > yak.
Justification: Adjectival derivatives from Proto-Iranic *ai̯xa- 'ice' ([ESIJa](src-331) I:140-143). Further connections disputed, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 5932](cog-5932).

Derivatives of Proto-Iranic *tač- 'to flow, run, walk', further to PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, flow' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:286-287, [Cheung 2007](src-83):373-374, [EWAia](src-172) I:610-611, [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

A preverbal derivative of Ossetic cæwyn | cæun 'to go', from Proto-Iranic *či̯au̯- 'to move, go', and ultimately from PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:307-308, [Cheung 2007](src-83):40-42, [EWAia](src-172) I:552-553, [LIV²](src-141) 394-395).

As though from Vedic ā́sadati 'sits near, approaches' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):67 no. 1483), a derivative of Vedic √sad- 'to sit' and ultimately to PIE *sed- 'to seat oneself' ([EWAia](src-172) II:692-693, [LIV²](src-141) 513-515).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *sed- 'to sit (down), seat onself' ([LIV²](src-141) 513-515, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):926-927, [Beekes 2010](src-66):376, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):506, [EWAia](src-172) II:692-693, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):422 no. 7467, [Cheung 2007](src-83):125-126, [ALEW](src-352) 895-896, [Derksen 2015](src-353):391, [Derksen 2008](src-81):445, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):434, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):551-552, [Matasović 2009](src-50):325-326).

Comment: The Avestan form *(š)mar- is attested with the meaning "remember".
Justification: Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *hmar- 'to remember, recall; recount', further to PIE *(s)mer- 'to think about, remember' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):137-138, [EWAia](src-172) II:78-79, [LIV²](src-141) 569-570).

Derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *i̯at- 'to take up a position', arguably further to a PIE root *i̯et- ([Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):105, [Cheung 2007](src-83):214-215, [LIV²](src-141) 314-315, but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:394-395 skeptical of connections outside of Indo-Iranic).

Comment: The Pashto form ra-tlal literally means "to go hither" (cf. rā in Morgenstierne 2003: 69).
Justification: A derivative of Proto-Iranic *tač- 'to flow, run, walk' + preverb rā- 'hither' ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):81-82, [Cheung 2007](src-83):372-374), further to PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, to flow' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:610-611, [LIV²](src-141) 610-611).
West Germanic formation probably of onomatopoeic origin, cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):540 s.v. Standard High German kreischen.
Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *tekti, in turn derived from PIE *tekʷ- ([Derksen 2008](src-81):489, [Bezlaj 1977-2005](src-595) 4:159, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

Lexemes reflecting Proto-Germanic *wai̯nōn-, a weak verb presumably derived from Proto-Germanic *wai- 'woe'. Further connections among the Indo-European languages going back to a PIE interjection *u̯ai 'woe!' (e.g. Latin vae, Old Irish fae, Welsh gwae, etc.) may be possible, although parallel onomatopoeic formations cannot be ruled out in principle ([Kluge 2011](src-397):979, 975, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):566-567; cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):650, [Matasović 2009](src-50):405, [IEW](src-49) 1110-1111).

West Slavic lexemes as though from Proto-Slavic *ogonъ and derived from *o(b)-goniti sę 'keep off, drive off' in the sense of 'a part of the body an animal can swat away insects with' (cf. [Boryś 2005](src-259):383-384). Further derived from an o-grade form of PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ([ESSJa](src-458) 7:23, 196-197; [Derksen 2008](src-81):177, [LIV²](src-141) 218-219).

A derivative from Proto-Iranic *gard- 'to call', from PIE *g⁽ʷ⁾erdʰ- 'to hear, sound' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):106); possibly originally an IE light-verb construction *gʷer(H)- *dʰeh₁- 'to give tidings' ([ALEW](src-352) 331-332). Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 210-211.

[Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:591 supposes a connection to Sanskrit káuti 'cries'. The Indo-Iranic forms are traditionally connected to a wide range of sound-imitative words from a root *kā̆u-, *kē̆u-, *kū- according to [IEW](src-49) 535-536, but a parallel onomatopoeic origin may well be possible (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:274). [Not in [Cheung 2007](src-83).]
Loan from Sanskrit pr̥thivī́- 'earth'.

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Iranic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *gʷʰer- 'to become warm' ([NIL](src-274) 196-199, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):541-542, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):556-557, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):298, [Orel 1998](src-105):303, 525, [EWAia](src-172) I:513, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575). Most lexemes in this class (Greek, Armenian, Iranic, Germanic) reflect a PIE adjectival stem *gʷʰer-mó-. Albanian is only root-cognate with the rest of the forms and has a distinct stem formation (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):298 for further discussion).
Old Prussian lexeme, generally derived from PIE *lou̯k-sneh₂-, a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' ([Derksen 2015](src-353):561, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Armenian, Slavic, and Italic lexemes reflecting PIE *lou̯k-s-neh₂, a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine, be(come) bright' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):320, [ESSJa](src-458) 16:173, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):352, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).
Derived from Proto-Slavic *goniti 'chase, persecute', ultimately derived from *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ({ref ESSJa 7:23, 196-197, [Derksen 2008](src-81):177, [LIV²](src-141) 218-219).

Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *bānu-, connected with Vedic bhānú- 'light, beam' and ultimately derivatives from PIE *bʰeh₂- 'to sparkle, to shine' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:265-266, [ESIJa](src-331) 2:157-158, [EWAia](src-172) II:259-261, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 68-69, [NIL](src-274) 7-11).

According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):447, from Proto-Iranic *harta- or *hr̥ta- to an Iranic base *har- 'go up; pass'. Further root etymology uncertain: [Bailey 1979](src-320):447 suggests either to PIE *h₁er- 'to get (somewhere)' ([IEW](src-49) 326-9, [LIV²](src-141) 238) or *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ({ref IEW 326-9, [LIV²](src-141) 299).

Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off' ([LIV²](src-141) 144-145, [Beekes 2010](src-66):533-534). Older etymologies (cf. [Buck 1949](src-47):287) compare forms related to Skt. dhvān- 'dark', however the internal structure of the Greek derivatives θάνατος, θνῄσκω must be accounted for in terms of preforms *dʰn̥h₂-eto-, *dʰn̥h₂-sk̑e/o- respectively, thus [LIV²](src-141) reconstructs *dʰenh₂-.  The Modern Greek present πεθαίνω was backformed from Ancient/Medieval Greek aorist (ἀ)πέθανον, with replacement of -ανον with present morph. -αίνω and regular loss of initial unstressed ἀ-.

Precise root identification uncertain. [LIV²](src-141) 399 suggests a connection to *leh₁- 'nachlassen, (zu)lassen', but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 576 which also suggests the possibility of connections to the root *leu̯H- 'abschneiden, lösen' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 681-682) with a laryngeal metathesis.

Etymology outside of Tocharian disputed (cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):972). Several possible etymological proposals: [Adams 2013](src-345):792 derives the root from PIE *streu̯g- 'streichen, abwischen' ([LIV²](src-141) 605, without Tocharian); [Meillet 1911](src-584):461 assumed a k-extension of *sreu̯- 'fließen, strömen' ([LIV²](src-141) 588, without Tocharian); [Hackstein 2003](src-583):84 has preferred *su̯ergʰ- 'krank sein, sich sorgen' ([LIV²](src-141) 613-614, without Tocharian).
Loanword into Middle English from Old Norse deyja 'to die', replacing various Old English expressions steorfan, sweltan, or periphrastic wesan déad ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *graban- 'to dig', generally postulated to continue a PIE root *gʰrebʰ- 'to dig' ([LIV²](src-141) 201-202, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):185-186, [Seebold 1970](src-556):235-236). This lexical isogloss is, however, restricted to cognates in Germanic and Balto-Slavic and consequently it's PIE status remains uncertain. The potential relationship of this root to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' remains unclear (cf. [LIV²](src-141)).

Modern Romance forms from Latin (ex-)cavāre 'to dig (out)' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):172, 262), originally a deadjectival verb to Latin cavus 'hollow, excavated' < PIE *k̑ou̯H-ó- (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):101-102).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sweltan- 'to dwindle, starve, perish'. Further etymology uncertain, possibly to a PIE root ?*su̯eld- 'to starve, die' if to be connected with Armenian  kʻalcʻ 'hunger' < ?*su̯l̥d-sk̑o- (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):336, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):499, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 610).

The root etymology in this set follows [LIV²](src-141) 549 and the latter of the two possible etymologies suggested by [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1011 to a PIE root *skabʰ- 'to scratch, shave'. Cf. however [Beekes 2010](src-66):1342-1343 favouring a substrate origin.

A denominal formation to Welsh twrch 'hog, (wild) boar; mole' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)), further to Proto-Celtic *tworko- 'boar' from PIE *tu̯ork̑-o- 'cutter, boar', a derivative to PIE *tu̯erk̑- 'to cut' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):395, [EIEC](src-657) 425, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 656).
Derived from Old French crues, cf. French creux 'hollow'. Further etymology uncertain, perhaps Gaulish? (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 2:1362-1365).
The root reconstruction in this cognate set follows [LIV²](src-141) 307, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):828-829, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1113 for additional discussion.

Modern Greek lexemes from Ancient Greek κοιλία 'cavity of the body; thorax with abdomen', further derived from Ancient Greek κοῖλος 'hollow, hollowed out, spacious, deep' < PIE *k̑eu̯H- 'hollow' (cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):690, [Beekes 2010](src-66):730-731).

Comment: Formerly identical with Lat. tālis 'such', but probably formed independently from the same morphemes.
Justification: Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *teh₂li- 'as such' ([ALEW](src-352) 1115-1116).

Nuristani lexemes continuing a derivative of the same root found in Vedic turá- 'quick' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):335 no. 5874), further to PIE *tu̯er- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:684-685, [LIV²](src-141) 655).

Indo-Iranic lexemes, probably to be further derived from the same root as Vedic √vas- 'to live, reside, spend the night', and further to PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ([Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):300, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):676 no. 11591, [EWAia](src-172) II:531-532, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 293-294).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *kʷis-e/o- 'to see', a derivative of PIE *kʷei̯s- 'to perceive' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):431-434, [Matasović 2009](src-50):180, [LIV²](src-141) 381-382).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *drinkan- 'to drink'. Further etymology uncertain; a proposal to connect it with Lithuanian drė́gti 'to become moist, to thaw' to a basic root *dʰreg- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):103) has not been widely accepted ([Seebold 1970](src-556):165-166, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):94-95, [ALEW](src-352) 226-227).

The etymology of this root is not entirely clear.
The hypothesis about a borrowing from Gothic is rather speculative because the Gothic form *gataws itself is not attested and only reconstructed (as a nominal derivative of gataujan 'fulfil, act, accomplish') [ESSJa](src-458). The Albanian gat 'ready' etc. is most probably a loan from Slavic [Orel 1998](src-105), note also a suspiciously similar set of meanings [ESSJa](src-458) here.
The idea about a derivation of the Slavic lexemes from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'walk, go' with a semantic development '(get) ready to go, prepare(d) for a journey' > '(get) ready, prepare(d)' (> 'do, make') has good IE parallels (cf. German bereit and fertig with secondary derivatives as vorbereiten, zubereiten 'prepare, make', anfertigen 'make', English ready). An issue is that the meaning 'go' is hardly (if ever) attested in Slavic. Its hypothetical traces in Old Russian are very sparse and not unambiguous: negotovami dorogami 'untrodden roads'. However, this etymology seems to be reasonable and is adopted here.

Lexemes continuing Proto(-Insular)-Celtic *bā- 'to die' (cf. OIr. baïd 'die'), further derived from PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step' ([LIV²](src-141) 205, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:1, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):214-216, [Matasović 2009](src-50):52, 59).

Lit. 'not-clean', cf. Lithuanian švarùs 'clean', of uncertain etymology ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):654, cf. [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1040 for older proposals). [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353)].
Loanword from Arabic اخسأ

Romance lexemes continuing Latin horridus 'standing on end, rough, shaggy, bristly, prickly' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):350, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:486-487), further derived from Latin horreō 'to be stiffly erect, shudder' and ultimately derived from PIE *g̑ʰers- 'to bristle, stiffen' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):290, [LIV²](src-141) 178).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *un-hraini- 'un-clean', an old verbal adjective to the nasal-present stem *kri-né/n-h₁- to PIE *kreh₁(i̯)- 'to sift, to separate'; but the verbal stem *hrinan- is not attested in Germanic ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):302-303, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):241, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 366-367, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):190).
Root reference form follows [LIV²](src-141) 499-500 to PIE *reh₁dʰ- 'to successfully accomplish', but cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):432, 437.
Adjective derived from Proto-Germanic *hurhwa- 'dirt, mucus'. Further connections unclear, perhaps to Middle Irish corcach 'moor'? (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):258).

Lit. 'not-clean', etymology outside of Baltic uncertain ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):679; for older proposals cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:413, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):1109-1110). [Not in [ALEW](src-352) or [Derksen 2015](src-353)].

Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *dʰeh₁- 'to put, place, to set up; to do' ([LIV²](src-141) 136-138; [ESSJa](src-458) 4:231-232; 5:7-8, [Derksen 2008](src-81):102-103, [Seebold 1970](src-556):157-160, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):98, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):209-213, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):198-199, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):271-272 no. 3128). The Italic forms in this class are generally agreed to be cognate, although exhibiting an extension *-k- of unclear origin (listed as a separate lemma ?*dʰeh₁k- in [LIV²](src-141) 139).

Modern Greek lexemes derived from Ancient Greek κάμνω 'exert oneself, build; be tired (from work)' → 'make something (using technical means)' → 'make, do' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):629), ultimately derived from PIE *k̑emh₂- via a nasal-present stem *k̑m̥-né/n-h₂- ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):490, [Beekes 2010](src-66):632, [LIV²](src-141) 323-324).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *k̑u̯ón-, *k̑un-, *k̑u̯n̥-, the inherited Indo-European word for 'dog' ([NIL](src-274) 436-440, [EIEC](src-657) 168, cf. [Melchert 1989](src-692), [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):505-506, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):187, [Adams 2013](src-345):190, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):520-522, Beekes 2010}:811, [EWAia](src-172) II:674-675, [ALEW](src-352) 1054-1055, [Derksen 2015](src-353):455, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):256, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):87, [Matasović 2009](src-50):181).
Loan into East Slavic from Iranic *sabāka- 'dog' ([Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 3:702-703, cf. [Černyh 1999](src-599) 2:183, [Šanskij et al. 1975](src-608):419).

Brythonic Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *u̯reg-e/o- 'to make, do', ultimately from PIE *u̯erg̑- 'to act, do' ([LIV²](src-141) 686-687, cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):76, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):707-711, [Matasović 2009](src-50):429-430).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *gn-ii̯o- 'to beget; to make, do', a derivative of PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to produce, beget' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:149, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):339-347, [Matasović 2009](src-50):163-164, [LIV²](src-141) 163-165). The Goidelic lexemes in this set continue a compound with the preverb de-, di- 'from, away from'.

From α- (privative prefix) + the verbal adjective of (α)παλαίνω 'to wet', i.e. 'not wet' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.); The verb (α)παλαίνω is a variant of ἁπαλύνω 'to soften', which is in turn derived from Ancient Greek ἁπαλός 'tender, weak', with no further etymology outside of Greek ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):95, [Beekes 2010](src-66):113).

Romance forms from Latin exsūctus 'sucked out, dry' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):268 no. 3074), the past passive participle to Lat. (ex)sugere 'to suck (out)', further to PIE *seu̯k̑- 'to suck' ([LIV²](src-141) 539-540, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):664, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):598).

Comment: Klingenschmitt (2000: 216 fn. 86) sets these words together with Pashto caṣǝl in relation to Old Ind. *cakṣ.
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *čaš- 'to drip; to drink, eat'? ([Cheung 2007](src-83):35-36).
Etymology uncertain, either to be grouped with Vedic pāṁśu- 'crumbling soil, dust, sand' or púrīṣa- 'fullness(?)' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):452 no. 8019, 469 no. 8287).

Comment: {Kashmiri form after pyonu dat. pĕnas ʻto drink' (cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 3867)?, cf. Armenian kc(an)em "bite" (5942)}
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes likely to be continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *kʰād-, further connections outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):445, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):203-204 no. 3865, 3867, [EWAia](src-172) I:451-452, [LIV²](src-141) 559-560).

Modern Indic cognates to be connected with Vedic khād- 'chew, bite; eat' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):203, no. 3865). No certain cognates outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) I:451-452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 359-360).

Iranic and Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *sek- 'to run dry, dry out' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):414, [EWAia](src-172) II:687-688, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):623, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):562, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):651 no. 7897, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 523-524). For the Goidelic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:96, [Matasović 2009](src-50):337.

Germanic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ters- 'to dry out, become thirsty' ([NIL](src-274) 701-704, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):358, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):632-633, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):554, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:74-75, [Matasović 2009](src-50):379-380, [LIV²](src-141) 637-638).

Iranic lexemes derived from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰau̯š- 'to hear, listen to' (cf. Vedic √ghoṣ- 'to sound'), further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ([Cheung 2007](src-83):115-116, [EWAia](src-172) I:518-519; [LIV²](src-141) 200 mechanically reconstructs ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯s-).

Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *k̑leu̯s- 'to listen to' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):209, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:126-127). This root is very likely to have been abstracted from a desiderative verb form of *k̑leu̯- ([LIV²](src-141) 334-335) already in the protolanguage, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 336n1.

Tocharian lexemes generally derived from PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear', although some uncertainty remains over the precise nominal stem formation ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):145-146, [Adams 2013](src-345):249, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 336-337).

Italic and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *ters- 'to dry out; become thirsty' ([NIL](src-274) 701-704, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):687-688, [Untermann 2000](src-279):736, 745, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):616, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:74-75, [Matasović 2009](src-50):379-380).
Loan from Sanskrit pr̥thivī́- 'earth'.

Cf. Vedic sú-mahānt- 'very great, huge' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):778, no. 13493), for further etymology ultimately to PIE *meg̑- 'big' cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:337-338, [NIL](src-274) 468-478).

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek τρώγω 'to gnaw, nibble, munch' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1461). Generally considered to continue a thematic present stem *tréh₃⁽g̑⁾-e- to a root *treh₃⁽g̑⁾- 'to gnaw away' on the basis of comparison with Tocharian B treṣṣäṃ 'to chew (up)' < *tr̥h₃⁽g̑⁾-sk̑é- ([LIV²](src-141) 647, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1141-1142); alternatively [Beekes 2010](src-66):1514-1515 prefers a 'Pre-Greek' origin.

Brythonic Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic preverb *tu- + *ag- 'to drive', ultimately cognate with PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):189-193, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):27, [LIV²](src-141) 255-256).

Hellenic and Celtic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *h₂eg̑- 'to drive' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1097, [Beekes 2010](src-66):18-19, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):3, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):189-193, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 255-256). The Tsakonian lexemes in this class might instead go back to AGk. ἥκω 'I have come' (so [Andriotis 1974](src-460):270), but a derivation from AGk. ἄγω 'go, drive' is more plausible (Nikos Liosis, p.c.).

Ossetic lexemes connected with other Indo-Iranic words for 'sand, dust' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:187-188). The correspondence of Indic *s- with Iranic *θ-, *s- is irregular, suggesting a possible parallel loan from a third-source or lexical contamination within Indic or Iranic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):772, no. 13386); [EWAia](src-172) II:728, however, considers the Indic and Iranic forms not to be separated.

Italic lexemes continuing Latin mandūcāre 'to chew, bite' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):431 no. 5292, cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 6/1:160-161). Latin mandūcāre is a secondary derivative to a primary verbal formation attested in Latin mandere 'to chew, bite' (cf. mandūcō 'glutton'). Traditionally attributed to a root *meth₂- 'to tear off' via a semantic development to *'tear (prey)' → 'to lacerate' → 'to devour' → 'to chew' ([LIV²](src-141) 442-443), alternatively [de Vaan 2008](src-54):361-362 sees a development from *menth₂- 'to stir, whirl' ([LIV²](src-141) 438-439) via a nasal-infix stem *mt-n(é)-h₂-. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):382 consider a word of expressive origin.
From Middle English egge, a loan from Old Norse egg 'egg', replacing Old English ǽg 'egg' which continued the inherited lexeme ([Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Comment: from Sanskrit (Mbh.) phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers),Pali phulla- 'blossoming', Prakrit phulla- 'opened, blossoming', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 511, no. 9092
Justification: As though continuing Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511 no. 9092), perhaps continuing a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit phálati 'to burst' ([KEWA](src-399) II:398).

As though continuing Sanskrit phulla- 'expanded, blown (of flowers)' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):511 no. 9092), perhaps continuing a past passive participle *phal-na- to Sanskrit phálati 'to burst' ([KEWA](src-399) II:398).

Comment: cf. Vedic síkatā-, later sigatā- unlike Old Persian θikā- 'pebbles', cf. also cognate/7858/
Justification: The correspondence of Indic initial *s- with Iranic *θ-, *s- is irregular, suggesting a possible parallel loan from a third-source or lexical contamination within Indic or Iranic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):772, no. 13386); [EWAia](src-172) II:728, however, considers the Indic and Iranic forms not to be separated.

Two possible etymologies: Either identical to Lat. porrō 'forward' if from *p(o)rsōd, alternatively from *πόρσω, derived from πρός 'towards' (< PIE *próti) with a commonly found liquid metathesis. Since both derivations have similar semantic paths of derivation it is difficult to choose between the two possibilities ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):929, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1223).

Comment: Fr. Lat. laxius, comparative to laxus.
Justification: Ibero-Romance lexemes derived from Latin laxius 'more widely, more freely', the comparative adverb to Latin laxus 'spacious, wide' ([DCECH](src-423) III:626-627, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):403 no. 4956), further derived from PIE *sle⁽g̑⁾- 'to slacken, go limp' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):331, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 565).

Cf. Standard German Boden, continuing PIE *bʰudʰ-men-; the root appears to only be attested in the zero-grade. It is unclear whether the full-grade form would be *bʰeu̯dʰ- or *bʰu̯edʰ- ([EWA 2](src-386):222-225, [Kluge 2011](src-397):137, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):82, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:228-229).
Comparable to Avestan spəṇta- 'beneficent' and further to PIE *k̑u̯eh₁- 'to swell up' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):394-395, [EWAia](src-172) II:678, 623-624; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 339-340).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Iranic, Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing PIE *h₂ōu̯ió- 'egg', which may be a vr̥ddhi-derivative to the Indo-European word for 'bird' *h₂eu̯-i- ([EIEC](src-657) 176, cf. [cognate set 856](cog-856)); alternatively [Schindler 1969](src-653) reconstructs an adpositional construction *ō-h₂uiom 'towards the bird'. For individual branches, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1681, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):439, [Orel 1998](src-105):497, [Holm 2011](src-130):60, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:41, [Bailey 1979](src-320):30, [ESSJa](src-458) 1:61-64, [Derksen 2008](src-81):27, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):17, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):438, [Matasović 2009](src-50):50.

A nominal compound, lit. 'bird-produce'. Cognacy in this set is coded for Armenian Arm. haw 'bird', continuing PIE *h₂eu̯-i- 'bird' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):398-399). PIE *h₂ōu̯ió- 'egg' is considered by some to be a vr̥ddhi-derivative of this stem (cf. 'egg' in [cognate set 28](cog-28) for further discussion).
Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of' ([EWAia](src-172) I:523-524, [ESIJa](src-331) II:238-242, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 383-385).

As though from Latin *stancus ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):679, [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), further to Latin stant-, the participle of stāre 'to stand' (cf. [cognate set 309](cog-309) for further etymological discussion).
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *derk̑- 'to look at, catch sight of' ([Delamarre 2003](src-157):139-140, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:55-56, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 122).

According to [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):77, as though from an Iranic diminutive *str̥-kā, and in view of the meaning 'planet' (cf. Avestan star- 'star', Vedic stár- 'id.) probably to be further connected to the Indo-European word for 'star', *h₂stér- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:755-756). The same semantic development is also attested in Modern Indic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):330 no. 5798).
Derived from PIE *dʰegʷʰ- 'to burn' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):164, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 133-134).

As though from Sanskrit dōla- 'swinging' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442) no. 6582). Further etymology less certain, but probably a loanword from an Austroasiatic language (cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:67 for further discussion).

Germanic lexemes continuing preverb *pe-/po- + PIE *h₃elh₁- 'to decay, perish' ([Neri 2007](src-635), cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):125-126, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389); formerly reconstructed as *peh₃lH- 'to fall' in [LIV²](src-141) 463-464).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Italic lexemes continuing or derived from PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' ([NIL](src-274), cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):78-79, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1077-1078, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):826, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):22-23, [Orel 1998](src-105):405, [Holm 2011](src-130):60-61, [EWAia](src-172) I:42-43, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):2 no. 43, [ALEW](src-352) 25-27, [Derksen 2015](src-353):47, [ESSJa](src-458) 32:41-42, [Derksen 2008](src-81):365, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):425)

Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic lexemes from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-) to PIE *steh₂- ([NIL](src-274) 639, cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):199, [EWAia](src-172) II:768-769, [ALEW](src-352) 979, [Derksen 2015](src-353):430).
Usually interpreted as based on PIE *pro- 'forward, to the front' with adverbial suffixes ({cf. [LIPP 2](src-294):490, 643; [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):537-538, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):491-492).

Tocharian and Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *preK- 'to be afraid' ([LIV²](src-141) 491, cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):711-712, [Adams 2013](src-345):402, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):111, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):402). The identity of the root final velar is not certain.
Probably loans from East Caucasian, cf. Lezgian rug 'dust', Tabasaran rug 'earth' (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.). [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:443-444 suggests Iranic *ru-ka- but gives no Iranic cognates.
Loanword from East Caucasian, cf. Cech. kog, Tush. kok, Ing. kog, etc. ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:619).

Etymology uncertain. No etymology given in [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236); not in [Falileyev 2000](src-240), [Matasović 2009](src-50), [Schumacher 2004](src-304), or [Stokes 1894](src-761).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11456 s.v. vahana- n. 'carrying' (MBh.)
Justification: Light verb construction, coded for Bengali bahan < Sanskrit vahana- 'a carrying' derived from Vedic √vah- 'to drive, ride (a cart, chariot)' and further to PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to float, drive' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):668 no. 11456, [EWAia](src-172) II:535-537, [LIV²](src-141) 661-662).

Ossetic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ni-waz- 'to carry/flow downwards', further to PIE *u̯eḡ- 'to float; to drive' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):429-432, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:535-537, [LIV²](src-141) 661-662).
Lexemes from Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive', further to PIE *u̯eḡ- 'to ride, drive' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):429-432, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:535-537, [LIV²](src-141) 661-662).

The original meaning was 'cart with a tent, living cart, tent' > 'house', a derivative of Proto-Slavic *vezti 'drive, carry', ultimately from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'move, go (by a vehicle)'. (cf. [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1608, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 661-662),

Italic lexemes from Latin ruere 'to rush, hurry on; tumble down, collapse' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):613 no. 7423), further to PIE *h₃reu̯- 'to run, hurry', perhaps further derived from PIE *h₃er- 'to set (oneself) in motion'? (cf. [Meiser 2003](src-762):613, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):530). [Verbal root not in [LIV²](src-141) or {ref [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)].

The precise root and stem reconstruction for this form in Indo-European is debated, but the cognacy of the lexemes in this class to each other is generally agreed. For the Slavic, Germanic, and Italic lexemes in this class, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 4:184-187, [Derksen 2008](src-81):133, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):360-361, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):327, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):348, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):415 no. 5116, 5119. The reconstructed root form for this class follows [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389).
Armenian and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *per- 'through, beyond, over; very' ([LIPP 2](src-294):607-614, cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):404, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):137).

Modern Greek forms to be derived from Ancient Greek εὐθύς 'straight' (via εὐθειάζω with various analogical re-characterisations of the present stem, cf. [Babinotis 2010](src-382):1565-1566 for further discussion); no further satisfactory etymology outside of Greek; for some possible explanations within Greek cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):384-385, [Beekes 2010](src-66):479.

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):678-679 and [Kluge 2011](src-397):980 for several possibilities of formal correspondences with Vedic forms vītá-  (from different etymological sources); the etymology to a compound *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- 'set apart' favoured by [Lubotsky 1994](src-706):203-204, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):584-585 requires the assumption of a glottalic model of interpretation for the PIE voiceless stops within the framework of the Leiden School, where traditional *d is assumed to have been pre-glottalized *[ˀd], and susceptible to dissimilation to *h₁, which is interpreted as glottal stop *[ʔ].

Etymology outside of Germanic uncertain; cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):678-679 and [Kluge 2011](src-397):980 for several possibilities of formal correspondences with Vedic forms vītá-  (from different etymological sources); the etymology to a compound *h₁uei-dʰh₁-o- 'set apart' favoured by [Lubotsky 1994](src-706):203-204, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):584-585 requires the assumption of a glottalic model of interpretation for the PIE voiceless stops within the framework of the Leiden School, where traditional *d is assumed to have been pre-glottalized *[ˀd], and susceptible to dissimilation to *h₁, which is interpreted as glottal stop *[ʔ].

Germanic and Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *h₂egʰ- 'to get scared, become distressed' ([LIV²](src-141) 257, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):270, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):3, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:23, [Matasović 2009](src-50):26).
From PIE *u̯ei̯k- 'to overcome, conquer' ([LIV²](src-141) 670-671, cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):683-688, [Matasović 2009](src-50):421).

Albanian and Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *trem- 'to tremble (in fear)'. The Romance lexemes apparently continue Latin tremere 'to tremble' contaminated with the Celtic root *krit-, cf. Old Irish crith 'trembling, shaking' ([LIV²](src-141) 648-649, cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):388-389, [Orel 1998](src-105):463, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):738 no. 8877, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 13/2:238-240, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):628).

Etymology outside of Germanic disputed, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):112-113, [Orel 2003](src-388):102, [EWA 3](src-441):67-68. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84) for various proposals. No lemma in [Kroonen 2013](src-165).

Root etymology in this class follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):970-971 to *dʰreh₂s-, a parallel root to dʰreh₂gʰ- 'aufgewühlt werden, in Aufruhr geraten' (LIV² 154f.). For older proposals, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):76.

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish ecla 'fear, dread', cf. ecal 'timorous, fearful' < *eks-gal, to which Old Irish gal 'valour' < Proto-Celtic *galā 'valor, ability', ultimately a derivative of PIE *gelH- 'to have power over' ([Electronic Dictionary of the Irish Language (eDIL)](src-300), [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):149, [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):5, [Matasović 2009](src-50):149, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 185-186).

West Germanic lexemes in light verb constructions with derivatives of PIE *h₂emg̑ʰ- 'to restrict, hinder' as the nominal semantic-bearing head. ([Kluge 2011](src-397):45, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):28-29). The Dutch and Frisian lexemes are prefixed with initial *be- ([EWNl](src-757) I:216). For the PIE root reconstruction, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 264-265.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', usually compared to Middle Irish slacc 'sword' and slahta 'struck' to a root *slak- as a Celtic-Germanic isogloss. Whether such a root may be postulated for Proto-Indo-European remains uncertain ([Seebold 1970](src-556):425-427, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):452, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 564).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing a stem *laḍ(h)- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):633 no. 10920). Further etymology uncertain.

Comment: The Avestan word varǝδa- refers to a plant "v[ie]ll[eicht] Rose" (Bartholomae 1904: 1369). The Sogdian word "ward" means "rose", which is a common meaning of 'flower' in most modern Iranic languages. Also attested in Parthian as wār.
Justification: Lexemes reflecting Proto-Iranic *u̯arda-, traditionally further connected to Vedic √vardh- 'to increase, grow' and further to an IE root *u̯erdʰ- (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:399-400, [IEW](src-49) 1167), but cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:520-521, [LIV²](src-141) 228 against connections of this proposed root outside of Indo-Iranic.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *u̯az- 'to carry, drive (chariot, vel sim.)', further from PIE *u̯eg̑ʰ- 'to ride, drive, transport, fly' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):432, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 661-662).
Parallel loans from Hindi लड़ना / laṛnā ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):633 no. 10920, [Turner 1931](src-69):548).

Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Indic *uddrāti 'flees, flies' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):93 no. 2001), further connected to Vedic √drā- 'to run, make haste' and ultimately to PIE *dreh₂- 'to run (away)' ([EWAia](src-172) I:757, [LIV²](src-141) 127).

Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om- 'earth' ([NIL](src-274) 86-99, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):195, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):287-288, [Matasović 2009](src-50):156, [ALEW](src-352) 1323).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fleugan- 'to fly', continuing a derivative from a root *pleu̯k- that is generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):146, [EWA 3](src-441):385-388).

No consensus etymology outside of Greek (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):673-674, [Beekes 2010](src-66):916-917); [Malzahn & Peters 2010](src-648) propose a connection to Tocharian B mäk- 'run', but the meanings are divergent (cf. 'run' in [cognate set 7203](cog-7203)). [LIV²](src-141) 422 assigns to *magʰ- 'to be able'.
Loan from Turkish, cf. Turkish dövüş 'fight' (n.), dövüşmek 'to fight'.

From Ancient Greek *συμπιάζω (AGk. συμπιέζω), cf. [Andriotis 1974](src-460):528. Further etymology disputed, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):899-900, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1189, for references to further literature.

From Ancient Greek ἐμπλέκω ‘to entwine’ ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):145, further from Ancient Greek (ἐμ)πλέκω 'to braid, knit, wind, twine' and ultimately derived from PIE *plek̑- 'to braid, twine' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):914-915, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1206-1207, [LIV²](src-141) 486).
Without certain etymology ([Smoczyński 2005](src-686):382).

Comment: Old Persian ham-arana- "zusammenwogend"
Justification: Light verb construction with Old Persian ham-arana- 'fight' < *'coming together' as a the semantic head. The root etymology of the semantic-bearing element of the compound ºarana- is to the Indo-Iranic verbal root *ar- < PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself (forward) in motion' ([Schmitt 2014](src-358):187-188, [EWAia](src-172) II:702, I:105-106, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 299-301).

Possibly continuing a formation (as though) from PIE *trud-no- according to [Pedersen 1909](src-307):160, comparing Latin trudō 'to thrust, push', Gothic us-ϸriutan 'to maltreat' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:148-149, [LIV²](src-141) 651-652). The etymology of [IEW](src-49) 1026 to a dental-enlarged root *streu- is less likely. [Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)].

Lexemes denominal from Proto-Celtic *kando- 'white', with the sense of 'to bleach laundry (by beating)' > 'to beat; to fight' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):336), further derived from PIE *skend- 'to shine' (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. Welsh cann 'white', [de Vaan 2008](src-54):87, [LIV²](src-141) 554; not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *part- 'to fight, struggle', perhaps further related to PIE *per- 'to beat' with a dental extension? (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):298, [EWAia](src-172) II:160, [LIV²](src-141) 447).

Cf. Middle Welsh lladd 'to kill', further derived from Proto-Celtic *slad-i̯o- 'to hit; to slay'. Further etymology uncertain ([Matasović 2009](src-50):345), cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):583-587 setting up either PIE *sleHd- or *sleHdʰ- following [Schrijver 1995](src-305):178. [Not in [LIV²](src-141)].

Derived from Proto-Slavic *mog-/*mag- 'to be able' ([Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 3:336-337), further generally derived to an IE root *magʰ- 'to be able' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 422, [Derksen 2008](src-81):321, [ESSJa](src-458) 19:107-111).

Identical to Irish cogadh ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):56), from Old Irish cocad 'war; means of waging war', a compound of com- + cath 'battle' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:137. The extent to which there are further Indo-European connections is debated; generally further connected to Hitt. kattu- 'enmity, strife' (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):466), and Proto-Germanic *haϸu- 'battle' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):214-215), and perhaps further to Sanskrit śátru- via a different stem formation (but cf. the reservations of [EWAia](src-172) II:607). Traditionally reconstructed as *k̑atu- ([IEW](src-49) 534, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):195), but because the Leiden school denies the reconstruction of an Indo-European phoneme *a, alternative reconstructions *k̑h₂et- and *⁽k̑⁾h₃-tu- are proposed respectively by [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80) and [Kroonen 2013](src-165). Here the traditional reconstruction of [IEW](src-49) has been tentatively followed.
Loan from Standard German kämpfen 'to fight'.

Comment: Czech lexeme (which is also attested in other Slavic languages in a similar (but not-Swadesh) meaning) are derived from the Slavic word for 'belt' (it primarily denoted a kind of a fight in which one tries to down the other on the ground pulling parts of his clothes, like Judo).
Bailey (1979: 56) suggests a relation to *kap- "grey" in O.Ind. kapila- and to the blue/grey word *kapauta-, weiter dazu EWAia I: 303
Justification: Lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kapā̆- 'fish', generally found in Eastern Iranic as a replacement for inherited Proto-Indo-Iranic *matsi̯a- 'fish' ([ESIJa](src-331) 4:241-242, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):56, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):458). Perhaps further to an Indo-Iranic root *kap- 'grey', maybe in Vedic kapila- 'tawny, brown, reddish', but cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:300-303.
Loanword from Dardic, cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):37.
Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' ([NIL](src-274) 698-700, [Matasović 2009](src-50):375, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 629-630).

Indic lexemes from Vedic himá- 'cold, frost' ([EWAia](src-172) II:815-816). From the ablaut patterns attested among the daughter languages a basic root *g̑ʰei̯- can be abstracted, to which was derived an original m-stem noun *g̑ʰéi̯-om, *g̑ʰ(i)i̯-ém-, *g̑ʰi-m-´- ([NIL](src-274) 162-169).
Parallel loans from Persian گل / gol 'flower'.
Loanword from Latin piscātus 'a catch of fish' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).

Tocharian forms, according to [Adams 2013](src-345):440, to be connected with PIE *pei̯H- 'to swell up' via a Schwebeablaut variant *pi̯eH- and connected with Vedic √pyā- 'to swell' but the existence of this variant remains uncertain, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:84, II:172; [KEWA](src-399) II:349, [LIV²](src-141) 464-465.

Comment: mālikā- f. derived from Late Vedic mā́la- f. 'wreath, garland', cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 628; Turner 1062-66, p. 580, no. 10092; ultimately of Dravidian origin
Justification: From Late Vedic mā́la- 'wreath, garland', probably a loanword from Dravidian, cf. Tamil mālai 'wreath, garland' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):580 no. 10092, cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:628, [EWAia](src-172) II:351).
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *sp⁽ʰ⁾erh₂g- 'to hiss, crackle'(?) (cf. [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):315, [Cheung 2007](src-83):198, [LIV²](src-141) 586).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *fleugōn 'fly', continuing a derivative from a root *pleu̯k- that is generally considered a *-k- extended form of the root *pleu̯- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488) → ?*pleu̯k- 'float, swim' ([LIV²](src-141) 488). The *-k- extended root is only securely found in Germanic and Baltic (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):146, [EWA 3](src-441):385-388).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11384 s.v. vardhita- 'increased, strengthened' (MBh.), Pali vaḍḍhita
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):664 no. 11384 Skt. vardhita 'increased, strengthened, gladdened', a derivative of Vedic √vardh- 'to increase, grow'. Further etymology uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:520-521; [LIV²](src-141) 228 mechanically reconstructs ?*Hu̯eRdʰ-).

The PIE root underlying these lexemes is generally reconstructed as *(s)per- 'to fly' ([ALEW](src-352) 955-956, [EWAia](src-172) II:97, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 579-580; without s-mobile [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):646-647). [Derksen 2008](src-81):396 and [Derksen 2015](src-353):419 favour a reconstruction *perH- in view of the Baltic acute accent in forms such as Lithuanian papártis and Latvian papãrde (cf. also [Derksen 1996](src-678):79).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian магла 'fog'.
Hellenic, Iranic, and Italic lexemes from PIE *mr̥g̑ʰ-ú- 'short' ([NIL](src-274) 497-499, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):236, [EWAia](src-172) II:364-365, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):75).
Romance lexemes from Latin coxa 'hip' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):212), further to PIE *kok̑s-h₂- 'limb, joint' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):140).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *koxsā/o-, further connected to PIE *kok̑so- ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:214, [Matasović 2009](src-50):220).
Loanword from Catalan or Occitan bǫsc 'forest' ([DCECH](src-423) I:636-637).
To be connected with Avestan gaδā-, Old Indic gadā- 'club', but no certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:281-282, [EWAia](src-172) I:460).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √yam- 'to sustain, hold, hold up, support', further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):603 no. 10428, [EWAia](src-172) II:399-400, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 312).
Loan from Old French forest (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):297, [DCECH](src-423) II:919).

An Indo-European root etymology outside of Celtic for Proto-Celtic *treget- 'foot' is controversial, cf. esp. [Irslinger 2002](src-299):60 for further discussion. Older hypotheses suppose a root *tregʰ- 'to walk' and a connection to Latin trahere 'to drag' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):387, 389 following [IEW](src-49) 1089, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):635-636)
Baltic and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eu̯g- 'to grow, become strong' ([ALEW](src-352) 67-69, [Seebold 1970](src-556):532-533, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):566).

Comment: first part would nearly fit with 7747 *leh₁g̑ʰ- which would give rāz-
Justification: Traditionally with PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' according to [IEW](src-49) 855, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:398-399, [LIV²](src-141) 304-305).

Italic and Romance lexemes continuing nominal derivatives of PIE ?*bʰreu̯H⁽g̑⁾- 'to enjoy, use' ([Untermann 2000](src-279):297-298, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):244-245, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):303). The attestation of this lexical root is restricted to Italic and Germanic (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 96).

Comment: Morgenstierne (2003: 53) quotes Henning (BSOAS 12/1: 56) for *migda-, cf. Sogdian mγδˀk. The COBL comment on Sogdian "fruit" considers it possible for this word to be a Semitic loanword. The reason that Sogdian in COBL does not show mγδˀk is that the source that was used to fill the Sogdian list uses another word instead.
Justification: As though continuing a Iranic stem *migda(ka)- 'fruit'; a probable loanword from West Semitic, cf. Biblical Hebrew מֶגֶד 'choice produce', Syriac maγδā 'fruit', etc. (cf. [Henning 1947](src-763):56).

Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic  *sadъ 'plant', cf. Proto-Slavic *saditi 'to plant' from the causative-iterative stem *sod-éi̯e- to PIE *sed- 'to sit' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):442-443, [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1263, 1279-1280, [NIL](src-274) 590-600).

Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 559; cf. also [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):200, [Beekes 2010](src-66):649, and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):452-453 (s.v. Hitt. karp(ii̯e/a)- 'to take (away), take up, lift, pluck').

The lexeme is doubtless a loanword whose the ultimate source is Latin frūctus. However, the direct source is disputable. Some scholars assume Polish [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598): 208, [Šanskij et al. 1975](src-608): 474, some German or Dutch {Černyh 1999}: 2: 325, some mention the ultimate source only [Šapošnikov 2010](src-636) 2: 485, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 6: 134.

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish mes(s) 'tree fruit, mast' ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):298, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):246). Further IE root etymology in this set follows [NIL](src-274) 463-465 to PIE *med- 'to become full, sated', but cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):268-269.

[Adams 2013](src-345):115 prefers to connect the Tocharian B forms with Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic words in meanings variously 'fruit (of a tree), berry, acorn'. The proposed etymology is certainly attractive but is not fully certain, cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):27, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):18-19, [ALEW](src-352) 1151-1152.
Loan from Persian (cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):53).
Traditionally with PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' according to [IEW](src-49) 855, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:398-399, [LIV²](src-141) 304-305).
Maybe to be connected with Hittite šiš- 'to prosper, proliferate', but no further etymology outside of Hittite ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):749, 756-757).
From Classical Armenian mirg, a loan from Iranic, cf. Sogdian mγδʾk 'fruit' ([Olsen 1999](src-180):895, [Benveniste 1964](src-745):5). [MM: Proto-Armenian mirg]
Loanword from Turkish yemiş 'fruit' ([Georgiev et al. 1971-](src-603) 1:496).

Comment: If the proposed etymology of [Neri 2007](src-635) holds, then cf. 'take' in [cognate set 5158](cog-5158).
Justification: Etymology outside of Latin traditionally considered uncertain ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):520). A recent proposal by [Neri 2007](src-635):71 plausibly considers *h₁e/om-o- 'what is to be taken', combined with a preverb *po- in Proto-Italic as *po-e/omo- 'taken off, picked' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):188-189; 479).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhar- 'to carry', further to PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):535 no. 9397, [EWAia](src-172) II:246-249, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77).
Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives of PIE *g̑ʰengʰ- 'to stride' ([LIV²](src-141) 175-176, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):213-216, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):166-167).
Germanic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives from PIE 1. *per- 'to cross, go through' ([LIV²](src-141) 472-473, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):186-188, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):128).

Comment: probably derived from verb "bar" : "to carry"
Justification: Iranic lexemes probably to be derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry', as though via Proto-Iranic *baraka- ([ESIJa](src-331) 2:100, cf. [Henning 1971](src-681):33-34, [Benzing 1983](src-764):201).

Indic lexemes derived from Vedic √gam- < PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come', present stem gaccha- < *gʷm̥-sk̑e/o- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):211 no. 3955, [EWAia](src-172) I:465-466, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 209-210).

Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'to wash' ([LIV²](src-141) 450, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1020-1021, [EWAia](src-172) II:54, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):410 no. 7167, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) N:16-17, [Matasović 2009](src-50):290-291).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12961
Justification: Continuing Vedic sáṁbharati 'brings together, prepares, rolls up' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):751 no. 12961), a derivative of Vedic √bhar- < PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ([EWAia](src-172) I:246-249, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77).

Comment: cf. Vedic mála- n. 'dirt'; cf. *mel- 'black', presumably originally *mel- 'earthy' (RP); cf. also *mel- 'soft'
Justification: Indic lexemes generally connected with Greek and Baltic lexemes designating dark colours ([EWAia](src-172) II:332-333; cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):680-681, [Beekes 2010](src-66):923-924, [Derksen 2015](src-353):544). For the Modern Indic lexemes in this class, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):569, no. 9905.

Brythonic lexemes derived from Proto-Celtic *luk-ati- 'seer', a derivative of Proto-Celtic *luk-e/o- 'to look at', ultimately a derivative of PIE *leu̯k- 'to shine' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):460, cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):248, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):103, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):447, [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Anatolian, Greek, Armenian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat' ([LIV²](src-141) 230-231, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):261-263, [Beekes 2010](src-66):375, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):644, [EWAia](src-172) I:61-62, [ALEW](src-352) 269-270, [Derksen 2015](src-353):157-158, [Smoczyński 2005](src-686):183-184, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:53-54, [Derksen 2008](src-81):154, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):119, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):185-186, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):196, [Matasović 2009](src-50):113).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4094 s.v. *gavatta- ʻcattle-fodderʼ, gáv- 'cow' + *atta- 1 'eaten'
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *gavatta- 'cattle-fodder', a compound containing Skt. gáv- 'cow' + *atta- 'eaten' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):219 no. 4094). The cognacy in this cognate set reflects the element *atta- 'eaten' continuing a derivative of PIE *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat' (cf. 'eat' in [cognate set 210](cog-210)).

As though continuing Sanskrit cāra- *'grazing, fodder' (< 'motion, course'), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):258 no. 4471. Further derived from Vedic √car-ⁱ 'to move oneself, go, walk, move, stir, roam about, wander', ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, turn oneself around' ([EWAia](src-172) I:534-535, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388).

Scottish Gaelic gorm 'green', continuing Old Irish gorm 'blue, green'; within Celtic cf. also Middle Welsh gwrm 'brown', Old Breton uu(o)rm- 'brown'. Etymology outside of Celtic uncertain: Previous proposals have included (1) [Stokes 1894](src-761):114, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):202 as a derivative of PIE *gʷʰer- in the sense 'the warm colour', (2) [IEW](src-49) 1152 considering a loanword from Anglo-Saxon wurma 'Purpurschnecke; woad; purple'. [Matasović 2009](src-50):169 does not consider any IE etymology to be viable.

Modern Greek πράσινος 'green' was originally a derived adjective 'leek-green' based on Ancient Greek πράσον 'leek'. Compared with Lat. porrum, one could assume a common pre-form *pr̥som, but the maintenance of intervocalic *-s- in Greek is unexpected. For this reason it is more likely we are dealing with independent loanwords from a third source ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):934, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1129; cf. s.v. Lat. porrum in [de Vaan 2008](src-54):481-482).

To be related to Tocharian A motarts- (a colour term) but it is not possible to reconcile these two forms to a common Proto-Tocharian stem. Outside Tocharian some Slavic and Germanic comparanda are possible but remain uncertain (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):511-512 for further discussion).
Loan from East Caucasian (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).

For Khowar, cf. Vedic akṣa- 'blue vitriol' only attested in lexicographical works, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):2, no. 24; for Pashto from Proto-Iranic axšai̯na- 'dark coloured, dark blue', cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):79. For the probable cognate relationship between the two on the basis of Proto-Indo-Iranic *akša-, cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:543, [EWAia](src-172) III:3.

Comment: Further Indo-European cognates uncertain. The root is probably dialectal (North Slavic). Variants with a/u s/x can coexist in one single language or its dialects, normally with slightly different meaning (probably the variant with -a- is a result of a contamination with another root).
Kathās., cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4564
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit caṅga- 'of good understanding; handsome' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):247 no. 4564). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a Dravidian loanword ([KEWA](src-399) I:267).

The Goidelic forms from OId Irish nél cannot reflect an inherited formation based on IE *nebʰ-l- and consequently a loanword from Latin is generally assumed, possibly via Brythonic (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) N:8, [IEW](src-49) 315).

Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ([LIV²](src-141) 76-77, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):397-398, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1562-1564, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):176, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):965, [EWAia](src-172) I:246-249, [Cheung 2007](src-83):6-10, [Seebold 1970](src-556):104-106, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):59, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):213-214, [Matasović 2009](src-50):62).

Comment: connection with Sanskrit pinaṣṭi, piṁṣati is not clear, cf. [cognate set 6111](cog-6111)
Justification: As though from Sanskrit *prabhindati 'splits' from Vedic √bhid- 'to split; to break, cut (to pieces)', perhaps influenced in its semantics from Sanskrit piṁṣáti, cf. [cognate set 6111](cog-6111) ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):491 no. 8714, cf. [Turner 1931](src-69):379). Further to PIE *bʰei̯d- 'to split' ([EWAia](src-172) II:273-274, [LIV²](src-141) 70-71).

Lexemes continuing Indo-Iranic *drau̯- ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:400-401, [Bailey 1979](src-320):170). Further etymology uncertain, conjecturally connected in older literature (cf. [IEW](src-49) 276) to Gk. θρίξ, τριχός via root IE *dʰreu̯- with the assumption of root extensions *dʰr-ei̯-gʰ-, *dʰr-ei̯-kʰ-.

From Hellenistic Greek μαλλί(ον), the diminutive of Ancient Greek μαλλός 'flock of wool' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):811-812); further etymology outside of Greek unclear ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):663, [Beekes 2010](src-66):889).

Indic lexemes from Sanskrit kapā́la- 'cup, skull'. The Proto-Indic base *kap- is often considered to be cognate with Lat. caput, OEng. hēafod, etc., but there is some uncertainty over the etymology of the Modern Indic lexemes from Ved. kapā́la-, and of Ved. kapā́la- itself, cf. discussion in Mayrhofer [EWAia](src-172) I:300, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):137 no. 2744).
Continuing Proto-Germanic *skufta- 'hair of the head', further connections uncertain ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):449, cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):313).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4883 cūḍā- 3 f. ʻtopknot on headʼ
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):266 no. 4883 cūḍā- 'topknot on head', probably a Middle Indic formation as though from a participle *kṣur(i)ta- to Vedic kṣuráti 'to cut, scrape' from Vedic kṣurá- 'razor', a nominal derivative of PIE *kseu̯- 'to scrape, to whet' (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:292, 397, [LIV²](src-141) 372).
Cf. Gurani raq 'hard', Luri riiq 'wet-hardened in the cold', 'starched clothes', 'dried out in the cold', Shugni. rāx 'numb' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363):192).

Traditionally connected to PIE *meh₁- 'to measure (out)' in the sense 'measure' > 'body part used as measure unit' > 'length of hair used as a measure unit' > 'hair' ([Karulis 1992](src-534) I:572-573; cf. for the root reconstruction cf. [LIV²](src-141) 424-425).

Cf. Standard Albanian lesh 'wool; hair; fleece'; further etymology uncertain. A popular hypothesis considers a derivative to the same root as the Indo-European word for 'wool', *Hu̯l̥h₁neh₂-, if to be morphologically segmented *Hu̯l̥h₁-neh₂- via an alternative preform *Hu̯l̥h₁-so- (so [Demiraj 1997](src-369):238-239, similarly [Huld 1984](src-571):85-86). [Orel 1998](src-105):219-220 considers a connection to the Balto-Slavic word for 'foliage'; against which cf. [Holm 2011](src-130):65.

Brythonic lexemes as though from Proto-Celtic *blou̯i- 'hair, wool'. Further etymology uncertain: [Lane 1931](src-765):279 attempted to derive from a preform *ml̥-eu̯-s comparable to Ancient Greek μαλλός 'flock of wool' (< *ml̥-nó-), but this conjecture has not been widely accepted (cf.
