[Deshayes 2003](src-309):115, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Falileyev 2000](src-240):16, [Fleuriot 1964a](src-301):85, [IEW](src-49) 721 [without Brythonic forms given as cognates]). The proposed comparandum in Ancient Greek μαλλός, moreover, is generally considered without satisfactory etymology ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):663, [Beekes 2010](src-66):899; cf. [cognate set 1492](cog-1492)). [Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)].

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hēra- 'hair'. Further etymology disputed, either (1)  with Lithuanian šerỹs 'bristle' < *k̑er(H)- ([Kluge 2011](src-397):382, cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):443), or (2) from PIE *k̑es- 'to arrange in order; comb' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):220; if so, cf. lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *kosa 'hair, braided hair' in [cognate set 8240](cog-8240)). A third option considered by [EWNl](src-757) II:360 is the possibility of a European substratum loanword.

Indo-Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *stembʰH- 'to support, to lift' ([EWAia](src-172) II:754, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):788 no. 13676, [Cheung 2007](src-83):362, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 595-596).

Iranic and Italic lexemes continuing PIE *duh₂-ró- ([Bailey 1979](src-320):161, [EWAia](src-172) I:739, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):184; for the root *du̯eh₂- 'to remove, separate from' cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389))
Identical with 'hair' in East Germanic. Possible comparisons outside of Germanic, but ultimately uncertain. Cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):338, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):504 for further discussion.

Etymology disputed. There are two main possibilities: either to (1) pre-form *kuHso- '(place of) protection', a derivation from the IE verbal root *(s)keu̯H- 'to cover', or to (2) pre-Proto-Germanic *kudʰso- to the IE verbal root *keu̯dʰ- 'to hide' cf. [EWA 4](src-415):1288-1290 for further details of either etymology, with references; cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):260.

Anatolian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *k̑erd- 'heart' ([NIL](src-274) 417-423, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):469-471, [Beekes 2010](src-66):644, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):576-578, [EWAia](src-172) II:818, [ALEW](src-352) 1032-1034, [Derksen 2015](src-353):448-449, [Derksen 2008](src-81):485, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):134-135, [Matasović 2009](src-50):223-224). The irregular correspondence of Proto-Indo-Iranic word-initial *j́ʰ- (> Ved. h-, Av. z-) is presumably due to contamination with Proto-Indo-Iranic outcome of PIE *g̑ʰórh₁-/g̑ʰr̥h₁- 'guts', cf. cognate set 2672.

Comment: cf. Sanskrit mastaka- m. n. (Up+) 'skull, head', related to Vedic mastr̥han- m. 'brain' < Proto-Indo-Iranian *mastr̥gʱan- (cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 326).
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit masta-, more commonly Sanskrit mastaka- 'skull, head' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):571 no. 9926. The stem appears to continue an r/n-stem with the Sanskrit stem masta- continuing earlier *mastn̥-, while the r-stem is preserved in Vedic mastr̥han- 'brain', YAv. mastərəγan- 'brain'. Further connections uncertain, perhaps a derivative of PIE *mosgʰ- 'marrow'(?), cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:336 for further discussion.

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *u̯i-u̯ai̯d-, further to PIE *u̯oi̯d- 'to know', to perfect stem of PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to see' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:174, [Cheung 2007](src-83):408-409, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 665-667).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bodh- 'to wake up; to perceive, become aware; to know' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):525 no. 9279), further to PIE *bʰeu̯dʰ- 'to awaken, become alert' ([EWAia](src-172) II:233-235, [LIV²](src-141) 82-83).
Loan from Latin pēnsum (cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) s.v. Welsh pwys).

Celtic lexemes generally derived from PIE *treu̯d- 'to thrust, push', although the specific stem-formation is disputed ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:149-151, [Matasović 2009](src-50):391, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 651-652).

Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ou̯s-os-, *h₂au̯s-os-, *h₂us-es- 'ear' ([NIL](src-274) 339-343, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1130-1131, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):637-638, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):415, [Orel 1998](src-105):501, [ALEW](src-352) 74, [Derksen 2015](src-353):71, [Derksen 2008](src-81):507, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):63, [Matasović 2009](src-50):48-49).

Comment: original meaning "ear" + verbaliser: k-oš-kēnīt
Justification: Probably a light verb construction involving PIE *h₂us-i- 'ear' (cf. Young Avestan uši- 'ear') as the semantic head ([Korn 2005](src-344):350). For the Indo-European comparanda cf. [NIL](src-274) 339-343.

Italic lexemes generally compared to Ancient Greek ἀΐω 'to perceive, hear', possibly from a root ?*h₂u̯ei̯s- 'to hear', but the details of the Latin stem-formation remain obscure, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):55, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):61, [LIV²](src-141) 288 for further discussion. For Romance cognates, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):61 no. 779.

Denominal formations to Proto-Celtic *kowdo- 'hiding place' < PIE *k̑ou̯dʰo- ([Matasović 2009](src-50):219, cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):442); for the root *keu̯dʰ- 'to hide' cf. [LIV²](src-141) 358-359.

West Germanic lexemes from Proto-Germanic *habiga- 'weighty, heavy', a derivative from the root as the Germanic strong verb *hafjan- 'to raise, lift', and further derived from PIE *keh₂p- 'to seize, snatch' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):244-246, [Orel 2003](src-388):147-148, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):198, [LIV²](src-141) 344-345).
Loanword from Italian pesante 'heavy'.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √bhar- 'to carry' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):539 no. 9459 and 9465), cf. further PIE *bʰer- 'to carry' ([EWAia](src-172) II:246-249, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77).

Comment: cf. Lith. smagùs 'strong, heavy'
Justification: The Baltic adjective is to be connected with the root of Lithuanian smõgti 'to hit, strike' whose root is generally further connected to Polish smagać 'to whip', etc. < Proto-Balto-Slavic *smāg-, further etymology uncertain ([Smoczyński 2007](src-531):579, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):837-838, 848; cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) II:235-236).

Etymology uncertain. If [Kroonen 2013](src-165):167 is correct, then the traditional etymology (cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):165-166, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):151) within Germanic to Proto-Germanic *gawēn- (and perhaps further to OCS gověti 'to revere and Latin faveō 'to be favorable' < *gʷʰou-eh₁-) is to be abandoned. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):167 alternatively proposes cognacy to the Indo-Iranic root ?*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰeu̯g̑ʰ- (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 199), but this proposal has not yet met with widespread acceptance (not in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Since [Jokl 1912](src-750):192-195 generally connected with Ancient Greek σκέπω 'to cover, protect' from PIE ?2. *(s)kep- 'to cover', cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):104, [LIV²](src-141) 555 (without Albanian cognates listed).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, and Baltic derivatives from PIE *nebʰ- 'become damp, cloudy, misty' ([NIL](src-274) 499-504). Cf. also [ALEW](src-352) 186-187, [Derksen 2015](src-353):118, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1012, [EWAia](src-172) I:94, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):49-51).
Italic lexemes derived from PIE *(s)neu̯dʰ- ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):448-449, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):417, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):491).

Connections outside Tocharian unclear. [Adams 2013](src-345):297-298 proposes connections to PIE *dʰerg- comparing Lithuanian dérgia 'there is bad weather', Middle Irish derg 'red', Old English deorc 'dark', but these connections are not fully certain ([ALEW](src-352) 195-196 rejects extra-Baltic connections for the proposed Lithuanian cognates; the appurtenance of the Germanic and Celtic forms to a root *dʰerg- may well be possible, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):153, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:57-58, but the connection of Tocharian forms to this root are questionable. [Matasović 2009](src-50):96 regards the connection of the Tocharian forms to this etymon doubtful; cf. further discussion in [cognate set 1734](cog-1734)).

Comment: Further connection unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain. Three main possibilities: Either (1) connected with Gk. ὀμίχλη 'fog, mist', Lith. miglà 'id.', Slav. *mьgla 'darkness, mist' (so [Orel 1998](src-105):269) ultimately derived from *h₃mei̯gʰ- [cognate set 42](cog-42)), or from PIE *mergʷ- (so [Demiraj 1997](src-369):271-273), alternatively a borrowing from Lat. nebula 'mist, fog' (suggested by [Meyer 1891](src-585):283-284, cf. [cognate set 2150](cog-2150)). Either of these sources could also have been contaminated with one another (cf. the discussion of [Huld 1984](src-571):93). Ultimately unclear.

Continuing Latin colligere 'to gather, collect; read' (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):194 no. 2048), in origin a compound con-legere, further to PIE *leg̑- 'to gather, pick up' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):332-333, [LIV²](src-141) 397).

Comment: For the IE reconstruction, see ALEW.
Justification: The root assignment for this set follows [ALEW](src-352) 674-675 in connection to Vedic muṣṭi- 'fist', Young Avestan mušti.masah- 'fist-sized', and Tocharian B maśce 'fist', cf. [Derksen 2015](src-353):326-327 dismissing earlier proposals to Ancient Greek ἀμύσσω 'scratch, tear, lacerate', ἀμυχή 'rent, wound', and Latin mūcrō f. 'point (of a sword etc.)' from a putative root *h₂meu̯k̑-, also [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):413.

From Proto-Iranic *abi- or *apa- + *snaH- 'to wash, swim', via an intermediate meaning 'to clean up', further to PIE *(s)neh₂- 'to bathe, swim' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:111-112, [Cheung 2007](src-83):348-349, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 572-573).

Cf. Latv. glabât 'keep, guard, protect; bury, hide', from PIE *gleh₁bʰ- 'to encompass, cover' according to [ALEW](src-352) 343, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):187 assumes *glebʰ-. Cf. also discussion of [Derksen 2015](src-353):180-181. (Not in [LIV²](src-141)).
Derived from PIE *bʰei̯H- 'to beat' ([LIV²](src-141) 7, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:32-34, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):226-232, [Matasović 2009](src-50):65-66, [LIV²](src-141) 72).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *slahan- 'to beat, strike, slay', possibly from a root ?*slak- 'to hit, beat' only otherwise attested Celtic, cf. Middle Irish slacc 'sword' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):425-427, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):314, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):452, [LIV²](src-141) 564).

Modern Greek lexemes from Hellenistic Greek δίδω 'give' (Ancient Greek δίδωμι) with the present stem re-characterised as a nasal present stem δίνω ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):374), further to PIE *deh₃- 'give' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):331-332), cf. [LIV²](src-141) 105-106).

Italic and Romance lexemes continuing PIE *bʰerH- 'to work with a sharp tool' ([LIV²](src-141) 80, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):213; for Germanic lexemes in this set not in the target meaning, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):53).
From Proto-Iranic *paiš 'to crush, grind', further connected to PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, beat' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):292-293, [EWAia](src-172) II:169, [LIV²](src-141) 466-467).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 6216
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit dálati 'cracks, splits', probably an l-form of the same root as Vedic √dar- 'to scatter, split' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):355 no. 6216, [KEWA](src-399) II:24), further to PIE *der- 'to tear (intr.), split' ([EWAia](src-172) I:701-703, [LIV²](src-141) 119-121).

Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *bando- 'top, peak', as though from Proto-Indo-European *bn̥d-no- which may be further connected to a PIE root *bend-, a root exclusive to Celtic and Germanic (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):54, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):66, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:35).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *haita- 'hot', no certain etymology outside of Germanic ({Heidermanns 1993}:271-272, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):202, cf. [EWA 4](src-415):887-888, 915-916).
Slavic lexemes as though from PIE *steh₂-ro-, derived from PIE *steh₂- 'to stand' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):476, cf. [NIL](src-274) 637-659).

Italic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *k̑el- 'warm' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):83), cf. [Nussbaum 1999](src-639) for a detailed discussion of the Latin stem formation; for Romance lexemes cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):139 no. 1506 (Lat. caldus 'warm'). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning attached to this set, cf. [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):294, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):231.

Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing Sanskrit vi-stara- 'spread-out', a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew' and ultimately to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):693 no. 11987, [EWAia](src-172) II:756-757, [LIV²](src-141) 599-600).

Modern Hellenic lexemes from Hellenistic or Roman period Greek *ὀσπίτιον, via Medieval Greek σπίτι(ν), either a Hellenistic or Late Antique loan from Latin hospitium 'lodging, guest-house' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1314).

Continuing Latin hospitalis, -e 'hospitable' in a nominalised sense of 'accommodation; house' ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 4:493-498). Latin hospitalis is further a derived adjective from Latin hospes, itis 'guest, visitor; host, entertainer', probably an old compound containing the roots of hostis 'foreigner; enemy' < PIE *gʰosti- and potis, -e 'having power' < PIE *poti- 'master, in control of' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):291, [Untermann 2000](src-279):336, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):300-301).

Tocharian lexemes, generally compared with  Vedic vā́stu- 'residence, abode' and Ancient Greek ἄστυ 'town', which may continue a proto-form *u̯ā̆stu- (< *u̯éh₂stu- ~ *uh₂stéu̯-?). Further root etymology unclear. A connection with PIE *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' (cf. [IEW](src-49) 1170-1171, [LIV²](src-141) 293-294) is semantically attractive but uncertain (cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):134, [EWAia](src-172) II:549, [Beekes 2010](src-66):158-159 for discussion and references to further literature).

Cf. Old Lithuanian butà 'building, house, dwelling'; these Baltic lexemes are not to be separated from Proto-Celtic *butā- 'house' (cf. Old Irish buth, Middle Welsh bod); perhaps a derivative of PIE *bʰu̯eh₂- 'to grow, originate, become', although the short vowel found in the Baltic forms is problematic and has led some to consider an old loanword from Continental Celtic into Proto-Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 153, [Derksen 2015](src-353):107, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):83, [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360):68).

Cf. Old Lithuanian klùpti 'to fall on the knees, stumble', traditionally connected to an IE root *kleu̯b- 'to stumble, hop' ([LIV²](src-141) 364, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):293, 301-302), but cf. [ALEW](src-352) 510-511 objecting to the comparative semantics. [Not in [Derksen 2015](src-353)]. Cf. also 'run' in [cognate set 6948](cog-6948) and 'walk' in cognate set 332 for the proposed Germanic comparanda in Gothic us-hlaupan, etc.

From Vedic sthūlá- 'large, thick', a variant of Vedic sthūrá- 'id.' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):795 no. 13776), ultimately from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-), a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ([EWAia](src-172) II:768-769, [NIL](src-274) 639). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'big' in [cognate set 7106](cog-7106).

Continuing Vedic goṣṭhá- m. 'cow-house', a compound of Vedic gav- 'cow, steer' < PIE *gʷou̯- 'id.', and *steh₂- 'to stand', lit. 'standing place for cows' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):232 no 4336, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:502, I:478-480, II:764-766). This cognate set is coded for *steh₂- 'to stand' (> ºṣṭá- ºṣṭā́(na)- 'standing place').
As though from *ἐξ-ίστημι > Tsakon. τσ̔ιτ̔αίνου, i.e. τσ̔ι- 'un' < ἐξ- + τ̔αίνου 'to get up' < ἵστημι 'stand' (Nikos Liosis, p.c.). For further etymology, cf. 'stand' in [cognate set 309](cog-309).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'to dig, bury', probably via a periphrastic formation *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o- 'to make a stroke/stab' to PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):410-413, [Matasović 2009](src-50):206, Britta Irslinger, p.c., cf. [LIV²](src-141) 350, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:111-112)

Celtic lexemes, denominal verbal formations based on Proto-Celtic *selgā 'hunt', a derivative of PIE *selg̑- 'to let go, release, send away' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):329, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) S:80-81, [Falileyev 2000](src-240):82, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):325, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 528-529).

Light verb construction with Ossetic cwan | cawæn 'hunt, chase' as the semantic head, from Iranic *či̯āu̯ana- from *√či̯au̯- 'to move, go', further to PIE *kʷi̯eu̯- 'to set oneself in motion' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:318, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):40-42, [EWAia](src-172) I:552-553, [LIV²](src-141) 394-395).
Light verb construction with Arbëresh kaça 'hunt' (n.) as the semantic head, a loanword from Italian caccia 'hunt'.

Light verb constructions with nominal 'wild animals, quarry, hunting' as the semantic-bearing head. The etymology of Middle Persian naxčīr was originally interpreted by [Bailey 1946](src-770):774n1 as though from Iranic *naxti-čiθra- 'originating in the night' (cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:36-37). [Bailey 1958](src-771):44 later revised his view in light of new Middle discoveries and alternatively considered as though from Middle Persian *naxa-čarya- 'moving about in the expanse, open spaces, the wilds'. If so, we could consider to either *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, arrive' → Iranic *naxa- 'expanse, wilderness', or to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to move, turn' > Proto-Iranic *carH- ([Cheung 2007](src-83):33-34) depending on which morpheme is best considered the original semantic head of the nominal compound.
Probably of onomatopoeic origin (Oleg Belyaev, p.c., cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:330-335).

Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *ǰan- 'to kill, slay, strike' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):224-225); Slavic lexemes derived from Proto-Slavic *goniti ‘chase, persecute’ and further to PIE *gʷʰen- 'to beat' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):177, [ESSJa](src-458) 7:23, 196-197, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 218-219).

Comment: cognate with 'stick' cognate/1680/
Justification: Cf. s.v. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):350 no. 6130 *daṇḍakakarman- 'forest-work'; the semantic head coded for cognacy in this set is Vedic daṇḍá- 'stick', without further etymology outside of Indic ([EWAia](src-172) I:692, [KEWA](src-399) II:11-12).

By internal reconstruction, possibly from a nasal-infix stem *h₂ur-n-H to a root *h₂u̯erH- although there are no certain cognates outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):372; not in [LIV²](src-141)).

According to [Kroonen 2013](src-165):257, Old English huntian continues a Proto-Germanic weak verb *hūnton- as though from PIE *⁽k̑⁾n̥t-néh₂-, an iterative formation to Proto-Germanic *hinϸan- 'to reach for' and connects further to Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand' as though from PIE *⁽k̑⁾ont-ú-, although there are no certain cognates outside of Germanic; cf. also [Lehmann 1986](src-179):122 and discussion to Proto-Germanic *handu- 'hand' in [cognate set 234](cog-234).

Cf. Standard German hauen, from Proto-Germanic *hawwan- 'to hew, chop' and further derived from PIE 2. *keh₂u̯- 'to beat, to split' ([LIV²](src-141) 345-346, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):251-252, [Kluge 2011](src-397):399, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):218).

The IE root etymology of Proto-Germanicc *daujan- given here follows [LIV²](src-141) to *dʰeu̯- 'laufen, eilen'. For an alternative etymology attempting to connect the Germanic words to Hitt. tuḫḫuš- 'to end', cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):90-91 (but cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):893-894, who does not give an IE etymology for Hitt. tuḫḫuš-). For older etymologies attempting to connect the words to PIE *dʰu̯eh₂- 'rauch machen' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 158) and hypothesised variants, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):147-149 (followed in Seebold's revised version of [Kluge 2011](src-397):919 s.v. Tod).

Comment: Morgenstierne (1974: 82) derives this word from the verb ϑāw- 'to burn', which derives from *tep-, while Cheung (2007: 68) from *deh₂u-.
Justification: Root etymology disputed. [Morgenstierne 1974](src-325):82-83 derives from Proto-Iranic *tap/f- < PIE *tep- 'to be warm, hot' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 629-630); [Cheung 2007](src-83):67-68 derives from Proto-Iranic *dauH- 'to burn' < PIE *deh₂u̯- 'to kindle, catch on fire' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 104-105).

[Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:88-89 interprets the Ossetic lexemes as from a *warāka- to a root *war- 'bent', although good correspondences within Iranic are lacking; there are similar East Caucasian terms which Abaev interprets as loanwords from Alanic (cf. Bats varang 'shoulder', Ingush voruv, Chechen vare 'thigh'), but it is possible the loans occurred in the opposite direction (Oleg Belyaev, p.c.).

Comment: Although Common Iranic would continue *g̑ʰ as /z/ (as with Avestan), Klingenschmitt (2000: 200, fn. 30) emphasises that /d/-forms are not a sign of loans from Persian, but the result of an early dissimilation of *d͜zasta- > *dasta-: "Die Bedeutung des Wortes und die weite Verbreitung der Lautform *dasta- schließen aus, daß es sich um eine Entlehnung aus dem Persischen (ap. dasta-, mp. dast) handelt. Die Lautform *dasta- muß vielmehr durch Dissimilation entstanden sein (vgl. Morgenstierne, EVP, S. 39)."
Justification: Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes from PIE *g̑ʰes- *'grasp'(?), 'hand', 'grip' ([NIL](src-274) 170-173). Indo-Iranic cognates reflect *g̑ʰes-to- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:812), other languages reflect an r-stem g̑ʰes-r- or thematised r-stem *g̑ʰes-r-o- ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):471-472, [Adams 2013](src-345):711-712, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1620-1621, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):431-432, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):140, [Orel 1998](src-105):70).
Celtic lexemes derived from a stem *pl̥h₂-mo/eh₂- to PIE *pleh₂- 'flat, broad' (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):132, [NIL](src-274) 562-564).

Baltic lexemes continuing denominal verbs based on nominal formations in the meaning 'tree, wood; forest' continuing PIE *medʰi̯o- 'middle' ([ALEW](src-352) 625-627, [Smoczyński 2007](src-531):382, cf. [NIL](src-274) 465-466).

Generally considered a derivative of Ancient Greek κρύος 'cold' in the older literature (cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:28-29, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):588-589), although the stem-formation is obscure. [Beekes 2010](src-66):787 therefore has rejected the older proposed etymology in favour of assuming a substratum borrowing from a 'Pre-Greek' language. A third possibility is that there has been some degree of contamination or blending of the lexical root underlying Ancient Greek κρύος with some other (substratum?) lexical material (cf. note by Scarborough in this class), although this too is a speculative solution.

Traditionally reconstructed as *i̯eg- ([IEW](src-49) 503) but the connection of Indo-Iranic *yaja- 'cold' points to *i̯eg̑- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):601 no. 10396; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):234-235, [HED A+E/I](src-406):257-259, [Matasović 2009](src-50):435).

Comment: Nu. forms from OIA. vi-str̥-ta- ‘spread; wide’  T. 12011 (-Strand).
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes from *vi-str̥ta- 'spread, expanded, wide', Sanskrit vistr̥ta- 'id.' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):694-695 no. 12011), a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew', and ultimately further to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:756-757, [LIV²](src-141) 599-600).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 497, no. 8857 s.v. prastará- m. 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' (RV), later 'flat surface' Mn., 'plain', 'rock, stone' Hit.; Pali Prakrit patthara- m. 'stone', from PIE 'strew' cf. LIV, p. 599
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic prastará- 'anything strewn, grass to sit on' (RV.), later 'flat surface', 'stone', a derivative of Vedic √star-ⁱ 'to spread out, strew' and ultimately to PIE *sterh₃- 'to spread out' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):497 no. 8857, [EWAia](src-172) II:187, II:756-757, [LIV²](src-141) 599-600).
Parallel loans from Persian (شكار (كردن / šekār (kardan) 'to do a hunt; hunt'

Comment: cf. Parthian iškar- and Zoroastrian Middle Persian wiškar "hunting ground, wilderness"; Cheung (2007: 345) puts this verb to an Iranic root *skar- "pursue, drive, look for (the cattle)".
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing primary verbal derivatives and light-verb constructions continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *skar- 'to pursue, drive'; no known etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):346).

Modern Goidelic lexemes continuing Old Irish greimm 'seizure, hold, grasp, profit, advantage, sway', ultimately nominal derivatives continuing Proto-Celtic *gremmen-, a derivative to PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):167-168, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 201).

Compound verb with preverb ad- + claidid 'dig'. The verb continues Proto-Celtic *klad-o- 'to dig, bury', probably via a periphrastic formation *kl̥h₂-dʰh₁-o- 'to make a stroke/stab' to PIE *kelh₂- 'to hit, break' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):410-413, [Matasović 2009](src-50):206, Britta Irslinger, p.c., cf. [LIV²](src-141) 350, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:111-112)

Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):318 no. 5605 s.v. Indic *ḍhōṅga- 'projecting part of body', probably to be further connected with various words beginning with *ḍh- in the meaning 'lump' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):316 no. 5580) but further etymology obscure.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *mari- 'lake, sea', further from PIE *mor-i- 'id.'. Generally considered a western Indo-European isogloss, but cf. a possible further attestation in Iranic via Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):354-355, cf. [EIEC](src-657) 503-504, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:68-69).
Loanword from Persian (if inherited, expected Anlaut z-, cf. zangun 'knee' < *zānukāna- derived from PIE *g̑enu-).

Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *dʰalh₁- 'to spring up, sprout' ([NIL](src-274) 83-85, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:216-217, [Matasović 2009](src-50):102-103, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 132). It is possible, but uncertain that Latin folium and the Romance lexemes continuing it belong here, cf. further discussion in [cognate set 8247](cog-8247).

Possibly to IE *teuto- if cognate with Lat. tūtus 'safe', Goth. ϸiuϸ 'good' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) T:164-165; cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):387 with some doubts). The proposed connections with the Italic and Germanic lexemes are judged difficult by [Lehmann 1986](src-179):362-363 and not considered by [de Vaan 2008](src-54):632-633. For possible semantic parallel for a euphemism, cf. Greek ἀριστερός in [cognate set 1504](cog-1504).
Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *grabH- 'to grab, seize, take', further from PIE *gʰrebh₂- 'to seize' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):119-121, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:505-507, [LIV²](src-141) 201).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5539; non-Indo-Aryan
Justification: A loanword from Dravidian, cf. Telugu eḍama 'left, left-hand, left-hand side', Tamil iṭai, iṭam 'left side' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):311 no. 5539, cf. [Burrow & Emeneau 1984](src-756):44 no. 449).

Iranic lexemes probably to be related to Vedic valká- 'bark' ([EWAia](src-172) II:525-526, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):275, [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:123). Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, perhaps to be further connected to Serbo-Croatian vlákno, Russian волокно 'fibre', but cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):526.
Generally considered to be an *-mn̥-stem noun derived to *steh₂- 'stand' ([Adams 2013](src-345):776-777, [NIL](src-274) 639).
Latin dīcere, from PIE 1. *dei̯k̑- 'to indicate, show' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):169-170, [LIV²](src-141) 108-109). For the Romance lexemes attached to this class, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):240.
Continuing a derivative of PIE *Hei̯k̑- 'to take possession of' ([LIV²](src-141) 223, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):543-544, [Adams 2013](src-345):107-108).
Loanword from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian блато 'marsh, swamp, bog' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), see also Albanian baltë 'swamp, marsh'.

From Ancient Greek στρεβλός (Nikos Liosis, p.c.), perhaps further to be derived from Ancient Greek στρέφω 'to twist, turn' (cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1062-1064, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1412), but otherwise of obscure origin.

Comment: For the discussion on the Slavic cognates cf. [cognate set 5209](cog-5209) and [cognate set 5149](cog-5149).
Justification: Tocharian, Hellenic, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, and Slavic lexemes continuing derivatives of a PIE root *s⁽k̑⁾eH- where the indeterminate laryngeal is probably *-h₂- on the basis of Ancient Greek σκηνή (West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́) 'tent' < *'cloth to provide shade' < *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂-néh₂ ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1350-1351). Also attested in Greek is σκότος 'darkness, gloom' which must formally continue *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-to- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1359-1360). It is probably best to separate these as distinct roots, although formally they may well be (sandhi?) variants of one another at the PIE level. For further discussion cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):773, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1350-1351, [Andriotis 1974](src-460):498, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):201, [Orel 1998](src-105):147-148, [EWAia](src-172) I:559-560, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):275-276 no. 5027, [Derksen 2008](src-81):447).

The cognacy of the Hellenic, Germanic, Italic, Celtic, and Albanian lexemes in this set is generally agreed, but the precise root reconstruction is disputed, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1271, 1285, [Vine 1999](src-606):5-30, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):350-351, [Orel 1998](src-105):384, [Holm 2011](src-130):76, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):601, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):512, [Matasović 2009](src-50):430).

As though from Latin *dē-ramāre 'to dismember' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):236), a derivative of Latin rāmus 'branch, twig' which is traditionally further connected to the root of Latin rādix 'root' if *rādmo- < *wrād-mo-, cf. Ancient Greek ῥάδιξ, -ικος 'branch, twig' (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):564, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):513).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯ar-i̯e/o- 'to laugh', a derivative of PIE 1. *su̯er- 'to sound' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):608-609, [Matasović 2009](src-50):361, cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):64, [Deshayes 2003](src-309):162, [LIV²](src-141) 613).
As though from Indic *goḍḍa- 'foot, leg, knee'; further connections unclear, perhaps related to *khuṭṭa- 'leg' in [cognate set 9629](cog-9629) ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):229 no. 4272).

Lexemes as though from Proto-Germanic *baina- 'bone, leg' (North and West Germanic, but no attestation from Gothic), further etymology uncertain (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):48, [Kluge 2011](src-397):105-106).

Celtic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *g̑ar- (?*g̑eh₂r-) 'to sound, call' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):331-334, [Matasović 2009](src-50):153, [LIV²](src-141) 161, cf. [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):186, [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):187).

Germanic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *(s)ken⁽g̑⁾- 'to limp' via a secondary nominalisation of Proto-Germanic *skanka- 'crooked' ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):446, [Orel 2003](src-388):334, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):485, [Kluge 2011](src-397):800). For the root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555). The semantics of Luxembourgish Schank appear to have shifted from the sense 'leg, thigh, shinbone' found elsewhere in Germanic.

Indo-Iranic and Germanic lexemes from a PIE derived stem *stuh₂ró- (< *sth₂-ur-ó-), a derivative of PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ([NIL](src-274) 639, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):795 no. 13776, [EWAia](src-172) II:768-769, [Sims-Williams 2007](src-567):266, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) III:158-159, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):557-558, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):482).

Germanic and Celtic lexemes continuing a root *s⁽k̑⁾eh₃-, probably lexically distinct from PIE *s⁽k̑⁾eH- on the basis of both forms having reflexes in Greek (cf. Ancient Greek σκηνή (West Greek σκᾱνᾱ́) 'tent' < *'cloth to provide shade' < *s⁽k̑⁾eh₂-néh₂ ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1350-1351 versus Ancient Greek is σκότος 'darkness, gloom' which must formally continue *s⁽k̑⁾h₃-to- ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1359-1360). It is probably best to separate these as distinct roots, although they may well have been (sandhi?) variants of one another in PIE. For further discussion cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1350-1351, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):438, [Matasović 2009](src-50):340).

According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):437 to be connected with Ancient Greek σκαιός 'left, western', Latin scaeuus 'left, inauspicious' < as though from *skeh₂-i-uo- 'shaded; left' (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1339, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):541-542). For further discussion regarding the root reconstruction cf. 'shadow' in [cognate set 5058](cog-5058).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10666 s.v. *rahati ʻremainsʼ, *rahyati, cf. raha- m. (RV, BhP.), rahas- n. (MBh.) ʻisolation, secrecyʼ - from 'be isolated, left over' via 'remain' and 'stay' to 'live' - compare the meaning of the root of [cognate set 255](cog-255)
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing a Vedic verbal stem *rahati, cf. Sanskrit ráhas- 'loneliness, solitude, secrecy' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):617 no. 10666). There are comparanda in Iranic, cf. Middle Persian rāz, Parthian rʾz 'secret, mystery' etc., but connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:442).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *gamala- 'old', of uncertain etymology. Cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):154, [Orel 2003](src-388):125, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):166 for various proposals.

Armenian and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑erh₂- 'to wear down, make old' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):338, [EWAia](src-172) I:576, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:304-305, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 165-166). For non-target Modern Hellenic lexemes attached to this set, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):268-269, [Babinotis 2010](src-382):296.

Comment: Bailey (1979: 50f.) connects the house word kata- and the city word kanthā- in Saka with a verbal root 'kan' "to cover, hide". Cheung (2007: 232) notes the Sogdian city word knδh (and variants) with the root 'kanH' "to dig". This would not work with the hourse word because kn̩Hta- would give kāta-. It may rather be the root 'kan'  "to throw, place, put; destroy' (Cheung 2007: 229, although the 'destroy' meaning may rather derive from 'kanH' "to dig"). Note Old Ind. khánāmi, which if deriving from *kh₂ would account for the other Iranic house word xān-.
Justification: Etymology disputed. [ESIJa](src-331) 4:340-348 groups Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' together with Proto-Iranic *xāna- 'house', both as derivatives from Proto-Iranic *kanH- (1) 'to dig' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):232-233), although this etymology is rejected by [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):432. Alternatively [Bailey 1979](src-320):50 considers to a verb *kat- 'to cover, hide' (rejected by [ESIJa](src-331) 4:340-341). If from a PIE root *kenH- 'to dig', the aspiration found in xāna- is difficult to account for in Iranic except by comparison with Vedic khan- 'to dig', although this is usually explained by contamination with kha- 'canal, opening, hole', khā́- 'source, spring' within Indic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):233). In view of the formal difficulties, Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' and *xāna- 'house' have been split into separate cognate sets. For further discussion regarding the difficulties of the reconstruction of the Indo-Iranic root 'to dig', cf. [cognate set 7327](cog-7327).

Comment: Note Old Ind. khánāmi, which if deriving from *kh₂ would account for the Iranic ‘house’ word xān- (besides the kadag-forms). If it is related to “dig”, the question remains, why this verb usually appears with #k and not #x (cf. Mayrhofer 1992: 445), cf. also Cheung (2007: 231) “In many Iranian languages the roots *kan1 ‘to throw’, *kanH1 ’to dig’ and *kan2 ‘to fill’ forms are homonymous and therefore often show mutual interference.”
Justification: Etymology disputed. [ESIJa](src-331) 4:340-348 groups Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' together with Proto-Iranic *xāna- 'house', both as derivatives from Proto-Iranic *kanH- (1) 'to dig' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):232-233), although this etymology is rejected by [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):432. Alternatively [Bailey 1979](src-320):50 considers to a verb *kat- 'to cover, hide' (rejected by [ESIJa](src-331) 4:340-341). If from *kenH-, the aspiration found in xāna- is difficult to account for in Iranic except by comparison with Vedic khan- 'to dig', although this is usually explained by contamination with kha- 'canal, opening, hole', khā́- 'source, spring' within Indic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):233). In view of the formal difficulties, Proto-Iranic *kata- 'house' and *xāna- 'house' have been split into separate cognate sets. For further discussion regarding the difficulties of the reconstruction of the Indo-Iranic root 'to dig', cf. [cognate set 7327](cog-7327).

Etymologically connected with the family of words surrounding Vedic pipīlá-, etc. 'ant' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):463 no. 8201). Further etymological connections remain unclear, probably of substratum origin (cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:284-285, [EWAia](src-172) II:132-133).

Root ref. form for this class follows the reconstruction of [LIV²](src-141) 344 ?*k⁽ʷ⁾eh₂- 'to dig', but cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:455-456 and [Cheung 2007](src-83):232-233. We may be dealing with a specifically IIr. root *kanH- (< ?*kenh₁-, if the comparison to Phrygian keneman (a monument or part of it) is correct). [LIV²](src-141) 344n1 assumes the creation of a neo-root within Indo-Iranic on the basis of the nasal-present stem *k⁽ʷ⁾-né/n̥-h₂-.

The Bulgarian form goes back to the *korkŭ variant. The etymology of the Slavic lexeme and its further IE cognates are not entirely clear. Lithuanian kárka is rather a cognate but the other words linked to PS *korkŭ not.

These Tocharian lexemes are probably better explained via PIE *dʰei̯Hgʷ- 'to sting' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 142, [Ringe 1988-1990](src-592):71), although are sometimes considered derivatives of *denk̑- 'to bite'. Cf. also [Malzahn 2010](src-341):975-976, [Adams 2013](src-345):800.

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *dāsá-, cf. Vedic dāsá- 'non-Aryan; fiend, demon, evil-being; slave, servant', further connections uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:723-724, [Steblin-Kamenskij 1999](src-321):162-163, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):155).
Loan from South Slavic, cf. Macedonian црн дроб, Bulgarian черен дроб 'liver'.
Tocharian lexemes as though from *n̥k̑-u̯-o- 'mortal', derived from PIE *nek̑- 'to disappear, go missing' ([Adams 2013](src-345):82-83, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 451-452).

From Latin barbatus 'bearded' ([Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), a derivative of Latin barba 'beard'. For the IE reconstruction see [ALEW](src-352) 97, but cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):69 considering a European loanword on the basis of having to reconstruct PIE *a.

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 10951 lamba- ʻpendentʼ MBh. (ʻlongʼ in lamba-karṇa-); PIE *lemb(H)- 'hang loosely, droop, sag, cf. LIV, p. 411
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √ramb- ~ √lamb- 'hang down, dangle', cf. Sanskrit lamba- 'pendent', 'long' in lamba-karṇa- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):636 no. 10951), further to PIE *lembH- 'to hang slack' ([EWAia](src-172) II:436-437, [LIV²](src-141) 411).

Generally connected to PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to ignite, burn' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):118-119, [Adams 2013](src-345):225-226). For the root reconstruction, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) (formerly [LIV²](src-141) 345 1. *keh₂u̯-).

Generally derived from Indo-European *gʰer- 'to desire, be delighted' ({ref LIV² 176-177 s.v. *g̑ʰer-, cf. now *gʰer- in [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389), [Adams 2013](src-345):208-209, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):135-136, [van Windekens 1976](src-76):188), but cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):604-605 with some doubts and possible alternative proposals.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Albanian, Iranic, and Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰég̑ʰ-om-, etc. 'earth' ([NIL](src-274) 86-99, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):858-863, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):128, [Adams 2013](src-345):205, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):155-156, [Orel 1998](src-105):80-81, [EWAia](src-172) I:424-425, [ALEW](src-352) 1296-1298, [Derksen 2015](src-353):516, [Derksen 2008](src-81):542).

Tocharian, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- 'tongue'. The forms as attested appear to have undergone multiple contaminations in several daughter languages: (1) The Tocharian forms reflect *ĝn̥dʰu̯éh₂- ← PIE *dn̥g̑ʰu̯éh₂- by metathesis of place of articulation (cf. [Ringe 1996](src-695):45-6, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):79, [Adams 2013](src-345):147). (2) Balto-Slavic lexemes appear to have lost initial *d- already at a common Balto-Slavic stage ([Derksen 2008](src-81):159, [Derksen 2015](src-353):285, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 6:74-75). (3) Armenian, Italic, and Lithuanian lexemes appear to have independently contaminated with initial l-, probably under influence of their respective regular reflexes of PIE *lei̯g̑ʰ- 'to lick' ([Martirosyan 2010](src-79):307-308, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):343, {ref Derksen 2015:285). (4) Celtic forms appear to have undergone a distance assimilation *dengʷāt- > *tengʷāt-  ([Matasović 2009](src-50):368). (5) Indo-Iranic forms have a similar preform *ºg̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*ºg̑ʰuh₂- to the form *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂- found in other branches, but instead appears to i-reduplicate the initial syllable (cf. notes to Ved. jihvā́- in [EWAia](src-172) I:591-593). Additionally, the Iranian forms appear to show a different Anlaut from the Indic ones (Indic *j-, Iranian *s-). This small deviation aside, the Indo-Iranic forms appear to go back to basic form *ji-ju̯aH-/*ji-juH- (vel sim.) in Proto-Indo-Iranic. This apparent reduplication could be secondary reanalysis of an original *dn̥g̑ʰu̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰuh₂- > *daju̯aH-/dajuH- as a reduplicated form *ji-ju̯aH-, (cf. forms such as *kʷe-kʷl-o- > cakra- 'wheel'), cf. [Mallory & Adams 2006](src-75):175. For the purposes of root-cognacy, The Indo-Iranic forms are treated in this class as cognate with the other forms which are more clearly from PIE *dn̥g̑ʰ-u̯eh₂-/*dn̥g̑ʰ-uh₂-. The least disturbed forms appear to be found in Germanic, for which see [Lehmann 1986](src-179):349, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):526-527.

Generally connected to PIE *k̑eh₂u̯- 'to ignite, burn' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):118-119, [Adams 2013](src-345):225-226). For the root reconstruction, cf. [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389) (formerly [LIV²](src-141) 345 1. *keh₂u̯-).
Precise semantics uncertain, therefore etymological comparisons remain speculative (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):87, [Adams 2013](src-345):151).

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from PIE *gʷen- 'woman' ([NIL](src-274) 177-185, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):501-505, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):157-159, [Adams 2013](src-345):242, [Beekes 2010](src-66):291-292, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)363-364, [EWAia](src-172) I:568-569, [Derksen 2015](src-353):558, [Derksen 2008](src-81):558, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):317, [Matasović 2009](src-50):61).
Similar to nursery words for 'meat' in Caucasian languages, cf. Gruz. čičia, Svan. ʒiʒil, Chech., Ing. žižig ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:397).
Parallel loans from the Sanskrit compound candrá- 'bright' [cognate set 2338](cog-2338) + mā́ḥ 'moon' [cognate set 2232](cog-2232).

East Romance lexemes continuing Latin geusiae 'throat' (cf. [Ciorănescu et al. 2002](src-85)), a probable loanword from Continental Celtic (cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):320 no. 3750, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):274).

Italic lexemes continuing an n-stem to PIE *(s)kerH- 'to split, separate' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):94, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):101, [LIV²](src-141) 558). For Romance lexemes, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):162 no. 1706.

[Matasović 2009](src-50):118-119 connects to Balto-Slavic lexemes (OCS iskra 'spark', Lith. áiškus 'bright') via PIE *h₁ei̯sk-, however the etymology of these proposed Balto-Slavic cognates are disputed (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):214, [Derksen 2015](src-353):45 connecting instead to *h₂ei̯dʰ- 'kindle' assuming a connection with OIc. eiskra 'rage with heated excitement; [ALEW](src-352) 24 assuming no clear cognates outside of Balto-Slavic). Consequently only a Proto-Celtic root ref. form has been given for this cognate set.

Traditionally connected to the root *g̑ʰeh₁i̯- 'to gape, open up (the mouth)', although aspects of the stem-formation remain disputed (cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):171-172, [Adams 2013](src-345):216-217, [LIV²](src-141) 173-174).

Generally derived from PIE *k̑lei̯- 'to lean' ([LIV²](src-141) 332-333, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):592-593, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):69-70, also Ron Kim p.c.), less likely [Adams 2013](src-345):184-186 derives to *kel(h₁)- 'raise up', cf. [Malzahn 2010](src-341):593 for further discussion.
Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE *kers- 'to cut (off)' ([LIV²](src-141) 355-356, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):579-581, [Adams 2013](src-345):176-177, cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):92).

Etymology outside of Celtic obscure ([Matasović 2009](src-50):60, cf. Deshayes 2003}:98-99). [Delamarre 2003](src-157) suggests an etymology to an onomatopoeic IE root *buk- 'bark, scream', although the vocalism of Gaulish bocca rather than *bucca is unexpected.

Anatolian, Armenian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *dei̯-, di- 'be bright; shine' ([NIL](src-274) 69-81, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):766-767, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):616, [EWAia](src-172) I:750-752, II:304, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):362 no. 6328, [ALEW](src-352) 205, [Derksen 2015](src-353):127, [ESSJa](src-458) 5:213-214 [Derksen 2008](src-81):134-135, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):170, 315-316, [Untermann 2000](src-279):352, 868, [Matasović 2009](src-50):101).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic jyótsnā- 'moonlight night' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):292 no. 5301), derived from Vedic √jyot- 'to shine' a phonetic variant of Vedic √dyot- 'to shine', a neo-root further to the same root as Vedic dyáv- 'sky', itself a derivative of PIE *dei̯- 'shine' via *di̯-éu̯- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:604-606, II:750-754, [NIL](src-274) 69-81).

Pontic ρασ̌ί(ν) 'mountain' < Ancient Greek ῥάχις 'spine, backbone' ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):477). Further traditionally compared with Lithuanian ražis 'stubble' to a putative PIE *u̯rā̆gʰ- ([IEW](src-49) 1180, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):968-969), but the necessity to reconstruct *a ~ *ā ablaut to account for the Greek forms is suspicious from an IE point of view ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1277-1278). Perhaps the assumption of a prehistoric loanword is a better hypothesis.

Comment: cf. Ossetic kom and NP kām „gums, palate“
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *kāhman- 'mouth, opening', further connected in Indo-Iranic to the Vedic root √kas- 'to burst, split, break' according to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:598-599, [ESIJa](src-331) 4:169-170, although cf. the scepticism of further connections to Vedic √kas- in [EWAia](src-172) I:332-333.

Romance lexemes from Latin bucca ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):122). Possibly a loanword from Celtic (cf. Proto-Celtic *bek(k)o- in [cognate set 6204](cog-6204)), but ultimately unclear ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):77, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):76).

Korn (2005: 88) assumes a (dialectal?) substitution of f > h; cf. Avestan zafar/n-. She follows Bailey (1979: 351b) in connecting this word with "tooth", cf. Old Ind. jámbʰa-. This evidence suggests an input *g̑m̩bʰ- > *zaβ- > *zaf- and > *δaβ- > (*daf- >) dah- respectively. Avestan shows cases of β > f, e.g. “navel” nāfa- vs. Vedic nā́bʰi- (Hoffmann/Forssman 1996: 98). I [TJ] don't see the need to assume a root without nasal for the Iranic forms (cf. Bailey, l.c.; but see Pokorny 1959: 382).

Albanian and Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *gʷerh₃- 'to devour' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 211-212). Albanian Arbëresh gríka 'mouth' is equivalent to Standard Albanian grýkë 'throat' ([Rohr 2000](src-687):31; for the root etymology see [Demiraj 1997](src-369):297-298; cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):126). The Modern Indic lexemes are as though from Sanskrit gilana- 'swallowing', continuing a derivative of Vedic √gar-ⁱ (2) 'to devour' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):223 no. 4164, [EWAia](src-172) I:469-470).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic kaṇṭhá- 'throat' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):134 no. 2680). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps a loanword from Dravidian (cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:292, [Burrow & Emeneau 1984](src-756):127).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5853 s.v. tuṇḍa- n. ʻbeak, trunk, snoutʼ (TĀr. MBh.); cf. ibid. no. 10163 s.v. mukhatuṇḍaka m.n. (?) ʻmouthʼ Divyāv. (múkha- + tuṇḍa-) cf. [cognate set 6016](cog-6016)
Justification: Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):509-510 s.v. tuṇḍa- 'beak, trunk, snout'. Etymology uncertain, probably a loanword of non-Indic origin (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:509-510).

A Brythonic word without certain external correspondences (cf. [Schrijver 1995](src-305):52n1 against an earlier proposal of [Pedersen 1909](src-307):63 to connect to Gothic gatwo 'street'). The reconstruction of a common proto-form is difficult, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) and [Deshayes 2003](src-309):288 for attempts at a Proto-Celtic reconstruction.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *hnekkan- ~ *hnakka(n)- 'neck', perhaps further comparable with Tocharian A kñuk 'neck' although there is some uncertainty the formal aspects of this proposed etymology. For further discussion cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):646, [Kroonen 2011](src-656):167-169, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):234, [van Windekens 1976](src-76):225-226, [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):162-163.

Anatolian, Tocharian, Hellenic, Armenian, Albanian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes reflecting the Indo-European inherited word for 'name' (cf. [EIEC](src-657) 390-391). Certain details of the reconstruction of the PIE word are disputed (cf. [Stüber 1998](src-315):53-59), but a general shape *Hneh₃-mn̥ with different ablaut variants of the root and suffix tend to be agreed upon. Debate on the identity of the initial laryngeal as *h₁ or *h₃ hinge on interpretation of the Doric Greek forms in ἐνυμα- versus the ὄνομα forms more commonly found elsewhere (cf. esp. discussions of [EWAia](src-172) II:35-37, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1084-1085). Cf. also [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):517-519, [Adams 2013](src-345):288, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):96-97, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):165, [Orel 1998](src-105):87, [Derksen 2015](src-353):556-557, [Derksen 2008](src-81):212, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):382-383, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):412-413, [Matasović 2009](src-50):38).

East Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *u̯ordʰo- 'word'. In East Baltic the o-grade of the root was generalised, although Old Prussian wīrds, wirds 'word' reflects a zero-grade < *u̯r̥dʰ-o-, also found in Germanic (Gothic waurd 'word' etc.). The stem is also attested with e-grade vocalism in Latin verbum 'word' ([ALEW](src-352) 1188-1189, [Derksen 2015](src-353):489).

Variants among the Ancient Greek dialects point to an original u-stem *stenu- that was later thematised as *stenu̯o- (with subsequent loss of medial *-u̯-), but further connections outside of Greek remain unclear ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1051-1052, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1399).

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *maiwa- 'slim, narrow', as though from PIE *moi̯H-u̯o-, a derivative of PIE *mei̯H- 'to diminish' ([de Vries 1977](src-468):399, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):397-398, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):349, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 427).

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Indo-Iranic *(H)nār-, probably to be further to a root *(h₁)ner- on the basis of the comparison to Ancient Greek νέρθεν, ἔνερθεν 'from below', cf. also Sabellic 'left' in [cognate set 3315](cog-3315). Cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:156-157, [EWAia](src-172) II:37 for further discussion.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic pátra- 'wing, feather' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):436, no. 7733). Further to PIE *pet- 'to fall, fly' ([EWAia](src-172) II:71-72, 75-76; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 476, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing adjectival derivatives of Vedic pátra- 'wing, feather; leaf' in the sense 'leaflike, thin' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):437 no. 7736). Further to PIE *pet- 'to fall, fly' ([EWAia](src-172) II:71-72, 75-76, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 476, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389)).

Comment: cf. cakkavāḷaŋ atisambādhaŋ Brahmaloko atinīcako 'the World is too narrow and Heaven too low' DhA i.310; iii.310 = VvA 68
Justification: Cf. Sanskrit sambādha- 'contracted, narrow' ([Pali Text Society 1921–1925](src-246):693), further to Vedic √bādh- 'to press, force', probably further to PIE *bʰeh₁dʰ- 'to press, oppress' ([LIV²](src-141) 68, however more sceptically [EWAia](src-172) II:222).

The lexemes in this set continue a basic root *Hoi̯- 'single, alone' with different adjectival suffixes ([LIPP 2](src-294):587-591): (1) *Hoi̯-ko- (Indic, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:262-263, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):119 no. 2462); (2) *Hoi̯-u̯o- (Iranic, cf. [ESIJa](src-331) I:134-136, [EWAia](src-172) I:262-263); (3) *Hoi̯-no- (Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, Celtic, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1233-1236, [Derksen 2015](src-353):501, [ESSJa](src-458) 6:11-13, [Derksen 2008](src-81):138-139 212-213, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):11, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):642, [Matasović 2009](src-50):304-305),

Germanic and Italic lexemes as though from PIE *kólso- 'neck' (cf. [Ringe 2006](src-395):95, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):205, [EWA 4](src-415) 777-780, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):125). Root etymology disputed. Root reference form for this set follows the reconstruction of [Ringe 2006](src-395):95. If ultimately from PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to turn' ([LIV²](src-141) 386-388), then these lexemes may be root-cognate with the Baltic lexemes in [cognate set 1868](cog-1868), but the etymology of the Baltic lexemes is less than certain; cf. further discussion in that cognate class. Alternatively a root etymology has been proposed to PIE *kelH- 'to tower, soar' (cf. [EWA 4](src-415) 477-480).
Indo-Iranic lexemes probably reflecting PIE *gʷriH-u̯eh₂- ([EWAia](src-172) I:509). It is difficult to isolate a further root etymology.

Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn', without any clear correspondences outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):104-105, 110-111, cf. [Bailey 1979](src-320):78, [ESIJa](src-331) III:196-203).

Nuristani lexemes as though from *mârâṇik and probably to be connected with Sanskrit maṇi- 'hump; Adam's apple' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):557 no. 9732), further considered as though from PIE *monh₂-i- (~ *moneh₂-) 'neck' by [EWAia](src-172) II:293-294 and connected with Vedic mányā- (cf. [cognate set 1728](cog-1728)), although this etymology is doubted by [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):557 no. 9732 on semantic grounds, cf. also discussion in [KEWA](src-399) II:556-557.

Generally agreed to continue a derived n-stem to PIE *k̑er-h₂- 'head' ([Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):175, [Adams 2013](src-345):230). For further etymological discussion regarding the basic root *k̂er- cf. 'head' in [cognate set 53](cog-53) and 'horn' in [cognate set 2457](cog-2457).

According to [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):15 to be connected with Latin umerus 'shoulder', Ancient Greek ὦμος 'id.', Goth. amsa 'id.', Skt. áṃsa- 'id.', although without clear antecedents in earlier Celtic. If so, then to PIE *h₃ems-o- (cf. 'back' in [cognate set 7111](cog-7111)). [Not in [Matasović 2009](src-50)].

While the cognacy between Lat. vesper, Gk. ἕσπερος, Arm. gišer, Lith. vãkaras, OCS večerъ, etc. is generally agreed, a morphological analysis of the proto-form from which these lexemes arose is not generally agreed upon. For the purposes of providing a root reference form for this cognate set, we have followed the analysis of [Beekes 2004](src-702), cf. also [Beekes 2010](src-66):470-471) s.v. Ancient Greek ἕσπερος. Exceptionally against the these lexemes forming a class, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294) s.v. †*u̯é-kʷsp-ero-. Cf. also [Derksen 2008](src-81):513, [ALEW](src-352) 1174-1175, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):215-216. If *k⁽ʷ⁾sep- is the lexical root underlying this formation, then these lexemes may ultimately be cognate with Hittite išpant-, Vedic kṣáp- 'night', etc. in [cognate set 87](cog-87).
Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *steh₂- 'to stand', cf. Vedic stā́na- 'place for standing' ([EWAia](src-172) II:764-766, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 590-592).

Continuing Proto-Iranic *stūnā-, cf. Young Avestan stūnā-, Old Persian stūnā- 'pillar', and probably further connected with Vedic sthūrá- 'big, strong, thick' < *stuh₂-ró-, a derivative to PIE *steh₂- 'to stand' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:282, [EWAia](src-172) II:768). For further etymological discussion, cf. 'big' in [cognate set 7106](cog-7106).

Modern Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Iranic *mr̥j́u- 'vertebra' (cf. YAv. mərəzu- 'vertebra', Old Persian *mr̥du- implied by Middle Persian mrdʾ 'throat' and other reflexes among modern West Iranic languages), further etymology unclear ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:656-657, [Bartholomae 1904](src-184):1173-1174).

Baltic lexemes, generally analysed as containing a PIE noun for 'life, lifetime, life expectancy' *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- combined with the derivational suffix *-h₃en-, i.e. transponat *h₂i̯-eu̯-h₃n-ó- > Old Lithuanian jáunas 'young, new' ([NIL](src-274) 277-287, [ALEW](src-352) 408-409, [Derksen 2015](src-353):209). The nominal stem *h₂ei̯-u-, *h₂oi̯-u-, *h₂i̯-eu̯- which serves the basis of this formation appears to have inflected as an ablauting u-stem but a corresponding verbal root *h₂ei̯- has not yet been identified (cf. [NIL](src-274) 279n1 for further discussion).

This cognate class is based on the assumption that ModIr. scáil f. 'shadow' continues OIr. scál m. 'phantom', involving a semantic shift and a change of gender or MIr. scáile masc. and fem. 'shadow, reflexion, image, illusion'. 
If one rejects this connection, it would be possible to postulate *skeh₃-lā- vel sim. for Ir. scáil, Sc. sgàil and connect them with [cognate set 8269](cog-8269). However, this has not been suggested so far, probably because there does not seem to be any evidence for a feminine word denoting 'shadow' before Late Middle / Early Modern Irish.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √vas- 'to live, reside, spend the night' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):667 no. 11435), further to PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ([EWAia](src-172) II:531-532, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 293-294).
Tocharian lexemes derived from PIE 2. *h₂u̯es- 'to dwell, spend the night' ([Adams 2013](src-345):566, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 293-294).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2450
Justification: Continuing Vedic r̥ñjáti 'makes straight, pulls, stretches' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):117 no. 2450), a derivative of Vedic √raj- 'to direct, stretch, attain' and further to PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to make straight, stretch out' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:425, [LIV²](src-141) 304-305).

Comment: Middle and New Iranic languages exhibit an additional nominal suffix (e.g. Middle Persian -īg).
Justification: The Iranian forms in this set are based on a secondary root *u̯ai(H)n- 'to see' of denominal origin, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):412-413). For the primary verbal root, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 668-669 s.v. *u̯ei̯h₁-.
Etymology not yet satisfactorily ascertained, cf. [Karulis 1992](src-534) I:206-207 for various hypotheses.
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *laikan- 'to jump', further derived from PIE *lei̯⁽g̑⁾- 'to jump' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):321-322, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):323, [LIV²](src-141) 405).

Comment: Cf. Vedic (RV) píṇḍa- m. 'lump, clod, piece' *piṇḍara-, Turner 1962-66, no. 8171, 8168; Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 128; presumably of non-Indo-Aryan origin
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing *piṇḍara- 'round like a lump' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):462 no. 8171), derived to Vedic pinḍa- 'lump, clod'. Further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:128).

According to [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:14-15, from Proto-Iranic *nas- 'to take' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):183-184 s.v. *Hnas- 'to reach, attain, take'), if so further to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, obtain' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 282-284).

Continuing Vedic dhamáni- 'vein, nerve; throat, neck', ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):385 no. 6733), further derived from Vedic √dham-ⁱ 'to blow' probably via an intermediate meaning 'pipe' and further to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ([KEWA](src-399) II:92-93, [EWAia](src-172) I:775, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 153).

Romanian împinge continues Latin im-pingere ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):358 no. 4309), the remaining Romance lexemes continue Latin ex-pingere ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):266 no. 3048). The non-prefixed verb, Latin pāngere 'to beat, strike' continues a nasal-present stem formation to PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):442-443, [LIV²](src-141) 461).

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though continuing a derivatives of Vedic mr̥ṣā 'in vain, wrongly' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594 no. 10298, [Strand 1998](src-431), further derived from Vedic √marṣ- 'to forget' and further to PIE *mers- 'to forget' ([KEWA](src-399) II:678-679, [EWAia](src-172) II:332, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 440-441).

Albanian lexemes generally connected to PIE *(s)teu̯d- 'to strike, beat' ([Demiraj 1997](src-369):379-380, [Orel 1998](src-105):444, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):999, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 601 [without Albanian]). For Germanic lexemes not in the target meaning in this set, cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):476.
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *kap/f- 'to (be)fall, strike down', further connected to PIE *(s)kep- 'to hack, hew' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):234-235, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 555).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *pьxati 'push, shove', a derivative of PIE *pei̯s- 'to pound, crush' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):420, [Boryś 2005](src-259):420, [LIV²](src-141) 466-467).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of a root √dhakk- (cf. Sanskrit dhakkayati 'destroys, annihilates', further etymology uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):383 no. 6701, [KEWA](src-399) II:88).

According to [Bailey 1979](src-320):466, probably from the same root as Khotanese ajs- 'to cling to, pursue' (with the semantic development in the sense of 'cling to the scent of' vel sim.). Further probably to PIE 1. *seg- 'to adhere, cling to' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):128-129, [EWAia](src-172) II:688-689, [LIV²](src-141) 516).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *kotto- 'old', possibly an old substratum borrowing from a non-IE language (cf. [Deshayes 2003](src-309):425, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):127, [Sims-Williams 2006](src-643):67-69, [Matasović 2009](src-50):218-219).

Comment: cf. Vedic varṣám n. 1. ʻrain ʼ (RV+), m. pl. varṣā́ḥ ʻthe Rainsʼ (AV), 2. ʻyear' (ŚB) (root vr̥ṣ-), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 446, no. 1139: Pali vassa- m. n. ʻrainʼ, pl. ʻthe Rainsʼ, Prakrit vāsa- m. (or < vārṣa-), varisa- m. n. - ultimately cognate with 'year' in [cognate set 1634](cog-1634); for Marathi pāūs < pra-vŕ̥ṣ- f. 'rainy season' cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8964
Justification: Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂u̯ers- 'to rain' ([EWAia](src-172) II:522-523, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):664 no. 11392, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 291-292)
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *regna- 'rain', further etymology unclear (cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):284, [Kluge 2011](src-397):753, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):408).

Iranic lexemes continuing a PIE r-stem *u̯eh₁-r-, *uh₁-r- 'water', cf. Vedic vā́r- 'water'. The root *u̯eh₁- is possibly a variant of PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:544-545, [NIL](src-274) 715-717).

Italic lexemes continuing Latin pluvia 'rain', a derived noun to Latin pluō, -ere 'to rain' and further to PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):474-475, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):550).

Brythonic lexemes generally agreed to be cognate, cf. [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236). [Deshayes 2003](src-309):274 reconstructs Proto-Celtic *u̯olau̯o- which has been tentatively followed here as a root reference form for this cognate set.
East Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE 2. *lei̯H- 'to pour' ([ALEW](src-352) 581-582, [Derksen 2015](src-353):284, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 405-406).
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic meghá- 'cloud' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):595 no.10302), further generally derived from PIE *h₃moi̯gʰ-o- ([EWAia](src-172) II:374-375).

Middle Indic lexemes from Vedic vr̥ddhá- 'grown, large', a derivative to Vedic √vardh- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):699, no.12073), further connections outside of Indo-Iranic are difficult (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:520-521; [LIV²](src-141) 228 mechanically reconstructs ?*Hu̯eRdʰ-).

According to [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:306, as though from Proto-Iranic *dam-na- > *dav-n > *dafn, derived from Proto-Iranic *damH- 'to blow, breathe; to swell' and consequently ultimately to PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):55-56, [EWAia](src-172) I:775, [LIV²](src-141) 153).

Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):385 no. 6732, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:381-383, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:775-776, [Cheung 2007](src-83):55-56, [LIV²](src-141) 153).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit pānīya- 'water' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):456 no. 8082), a derivative of Vedic √pā- 'to drink' and further to PIE *peh₃(i̯)- 'to drink' ([EWAia](src-172) II:113-114, [LIV²](src-141) 262).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *bitra- 'biting, bitter', an adjectival derivative to PIE *bʰei̯d- 'to split' ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):126-127, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):65-66, cf. [NIL](src-274) 11-12, [LIV²](src-141) 70-71).
Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *dʰmeH- 'to blow' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):55-56, [EWAia](src-172) I:775, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 153).
Continuing Latin aqua 'water' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):46 no. 570), cf. 'water' in [cognate set 953](cog-953) and 'river' in [cognate set 2649](cog-2649) for further etymological discussion.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though continuing derivatives of Sanskrit gola- 'ball, round object' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):232 no. 4321), cf. also variant guḍá- (1) m. 'globe, ball' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):223 no. 4181), presumably a Dravidian loanword (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:349).

Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell', cf. Vedic gandhá- 'smell', Young Avestan gaiṇti 'bad smell', further connections remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:461-462, [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) I:368-369).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *staina- 'stone', reflecting PIE *stoiH-no- ([Kroonen 2013](src-165):472, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):546, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):321-322). Further derived from PIE *sti̯eH- 'to become stiff' (following the reconstruction of [LIV²](src-141) 603).

Pace [Kroonen 2013](src-165), the different morphology of the Germanic-Italic lexemes on one hand and the Indo-Iranian, and Baltic lexemes on the other does not favour the view that PIE *h₂ekʷ- and *h₂ep- were variants of one another (Martin Kümmel, p.c.). Likewise it is not clear whether the Germanic and Italic lexemes are independent borrowings from a third source (as advocated by [Beekes 1998](src-709)), but in view of the regular correspondences between Italic and Germanic, gratuitous. Further proposed connections are less certain (cf. [EWA 1](src-383) 99-103 for a thorough discussion). Less certain is the connection of the Celtic and Anatolian lexemes (cf. discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)). Regarding the Oscan form in this class, an alternative root etymology to PIE *h₂ep- is sometimes considered on the basis of the apparent lengthened root vowel as in the Indo-Iranian forms (e.g. Skt. āp-) cf. [Untermann 2000](src-279):42-43, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):19), however it is possible that the lengthening of the vowel could be secondary. While it is possible that the Oscan form could preserve an isolated reflex of the root *h₂ep- as found in Indo-Iranian, Baltic, and Tocharian, given that there are no other potential reflexes of the root *h₂ep- in Italic connections with Latin aqua cannot be ruled out, and it seems preferable, on the balance of probability, to connect Oscan aapam with Latin aqua < *h₂ekʷ-(e)h₂ (acknowledged by both Untermann & de Vaan). (NB: In Oscan PIE *kʷ > p).

Baltic and Italic lexemes in the meaning 'red' derived from IE *u̯r̥mi- 'snake, worm' adopted from the use of insects to produce red dye ([von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 14:288-291, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):665, [Derksen 2015](src-353):567), cf. also [cognate set 1163](cog-1163). See 'worm' in [cognate set 348](cog-348) for further etymological discussion.

Modern Hellenic lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ἀληθινός 'true, genuine' ([Rohlfs 1964](src-587):25), further perhaps to be derived from PIE *leh₂d-, although the postulated root is based entirely upon internal reconstruction of the Greek evidence (cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):65-66, [LIV²](src-141) 401-402).

Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *kraviya- 'bloody, raw' [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):186 no. 3585), cf. Vedic kraviṣ- 'red, bloody flesh', ultimately from PIE *kreu̯h₂-s-, a derivative of *kreu̯h₂- '(clotted) blood, blood outside of the body' ([NIL](src-274) 444-448, [EWAia](src-172) I:411).

Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. [ALEW](src-352) s.v. Lith. lãbas, [LIV²](src-141) 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 speculatively considered a connection with Armenian law (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8081](cog-8081)), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352). A lemma for Lithuanian lãbas is lacking in [Derksen 2015](src-353). Apart from the as yet uncertain proposal to Vedic rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

As though from Sanskrit sajya- 'strung (of bow); prepared, ready', a derivative of Vedic √sa(ñ)j- 'to adhere to' and further to PIE 1. *seg- 'to adhere, to cling to' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):758 no. 13095, [KEWA](src-399) III:419-420, [EWAia](src-172) II:688-689, [LIV²](src-141) 516).

Comment: Parallel loans from Arabic 'carnelian, cornelian, garnet' لَعْل via Persian 'ruby'; also Indo-Iranian surname and given name ('darling'), cf. Persian لعل‎‎, Hindi लाल, Urdu لال‎, Pashto lāl‎, but cf. also ep. Sanskrit lálati , Sanskrit root lal- 'cajole, play, dally, caress' ~ laḍ- cf. Mayrhofer KEWA III, p. 91, Turner 1962-66, p. 633, no. 10922, p. 640, no. 11030; epithet of Agni 'fire' is lālela-, lālilá- (Up+) - Krishna is also called "lalla" लल्ला - some conflation?

Justification: Goidelic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *gelo-, most likely to continue a derivative of PIE *g̑ʰelh₃- 'yellow, green' ([Lucht 2007](src-151):431-432, [Matasović 2009](src-50):156).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √pac- 'to cook' and further derived from PIE 1. *pekʷ- 'to become ripe, make cooked' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):431 no. 7654, [EWAia](src-172) II:64, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 468).
Loan from early Scandinavian, cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84).

Cf. s.v. Proto-Iranic *gart- 'to turn', a root first attested in Middle Iranic without clear correspondences outside of Iranic. Possibly the same root as Proto-Iranic *gar- 'to turn, wind' in [cognate set 8719](cog-8719) with a dental enlargement possibly under the influence of Proto-Iranic *u̯art- 'to turn', cf. YAv. varət- 'to turn' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):110-111).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 280, no. 5086 s.v. jáṭā f. ʻhair twisted togetherʼ, PārGr̥. ʻfibrous root, rootʼ Bhpr., Mayrhofer EWAia I, p. 564 - further source unclear
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic jaṭā- 'hair twisted together', further etymology unclear ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):280 no. 5086, [EWAia](src-172) I:564).

Nuristani lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *gandʰá- 'smell' in light verb constructions (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):214-215 no. 4014), further connections outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:461-462).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes continuing Indic *rukṣa- 'tree', a metathesised variant of Vedic vr̥kṣá- 'tree', from Proto-Indo-Iranic *u̯r̥ćšá-. Further connections uncertain, perhaps to be connected with Vedic valśa- 'shoot, branch, twig' ([EWAia](src-172) II:572, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):622 no. 10757).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *rinnan- 'to run', a nasal-infix present stem formed to PIE *h₃rei̯H- 'to flow, swirl' ([Seebold 1970](src-556):375-377, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):413-414, [LIV²](src-141) 305-306).

Based on an Indic root *kuth- 'to stink' attested only quite late in Sanskrit, further etymology unclear (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):169 no. 3282, [KEWA](src-399) I:228; see [EWAia](src-172) II:41 for an uncertain Vedic attestation of the root).

Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *hu̯ad- 'to become, make savoury, pleasant', further to PIE *su̯eh₂d- 'to make/become tasty' ([Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:494-495, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):141, [EWAia](src-172) II:788-789, [NIL](src-274) 670-675, [LIV²](src-141) 606-607).

Comment: < Vedic mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, polished, pure', later R. 'prepared, savoury' via Mbh. miṣṭa- 'dainty, sweet, pure, good', cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 594f., no. 10299
Justification: Indic lexemes continuing Vedic mr̥ṣṭá- 'rubbed, washed, pure' > Classical Sanskrit 'prepared, savoury', further root etymology outside of Indo-Iranic difficult (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):594-595 no. 10299, [EWAia](src-172) II:324-325).

Nuristani lexemes as though from Indic rucaka- 'pleasing, sharp, acid', a derivative of Proto-Indo-Iranic *rau̯k/č- 'to shine' and further to PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):622 no. 10761, [EWAia](src-172) II:463-464, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).
Hellenic lexemes derived from PIE *leu̯k- 'to become bright' ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):632-633, [Beekes 2010](src-66):851, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).

Anatolian, Indic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *melh₂- 'to crush, grind' ([LIV²](src-141) 432-433; cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80) 547-548, [ALEW](src-352) 610-611, [Derksen 2015](src-353):302-303, [ESSJa](src-458) 18:90-91, [Derksen 2008](src-81):307}, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):351, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):386-387, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:58, M:32, [Matasović 2009](src-50):255).
A derivative of Latin mola(m) 'millstone' (Giovanni Abete, p.c.), further to PIE *melh₂- 'grind' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):386-387, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 432-433).

Probably from Proto-Celtic *grau̯ā (cf. Old Irish griän 'gravel', Welsh gro 'gravel, shingle'), postulated for Gaulish on the basis of loanwords attested in Romance ([Delamarre 2003](src-157):183-184, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):328 no. 3851). Further etymology uncertain: [IEW](src-49) 460 suggests a root etymology *gʰreu- 'to crush, grind', [Campanile 1974](src-730):131-138 argues for a pre-IE loanword.

Modern Indic lexemes reflecting Sanskrit ākhyāti 'tells' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):47 no. 1041) and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Slavic *kāzati, both probably to be derived from PIE *kʷek̑- ([LIV²](src-141) 383-385, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:456-457, [Derksen 2008](src-81):222, [ESSJa](src-458) 4:100-101, 9:168-170).
Initial b- in all languages seems to preclude direct derivation from vr̥ddhá- 'grown, increased, large', cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):524 no. 9271.

Originally a compound of Proto-Indo-Iranic *u̯r̥ćšá- 'tree' + √*ǰai- 'to win, conquer' (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:572). This cognate set is coded for *u̯r̥ćšá- 'tree' as the semantic bearing head, cf. 'tree' in [cognate set 2368](cog-2368) for further discussion. For Proto-Iranic *ǰai- 'to win, conquer' < PIE *gʷei̯- 'to win, conquer' cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):222, [LIV²](src-141) 206.

Probably a substratum loan in view of the Ancient Greek dialectal variants (Dor. γλέπω) and alternation in final aspiration in related vocabulary (cf. βλέφαρον, γλέφαρον 'eyelid'), cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):219-220 for further discussion. In view of these alternations, possibly borrowed as a root ?*gʷlep⁽ʰ⁾- (cf. note by Scarborough in this set).

Comment: cf. Sanskrit kathayati ʻconverses with, describesʼ (MBh.) (√kath-), derived from kathā- f. 'narration, telling how and why' (MBh.), ultimately derived from kathā 'how, why', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 2703f., Mayrhofer KEWA I, p. 148f.
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Sanskrit katháyati 'converses with, describes' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):135 no. 2703), derived from the Vedic interrogative adverb kathā́ 'how?' and further to the interrogative pronoun ká- 'who, which?' < PIE *kʷó-, *kʷí- ([EWAia](src-172) I:294-295, 284-285, cf. [LIPP 2](src-294):452-479).

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *kweϸan- 'to say'. Further etymology outside of Germanic uncertain, possibly from PIE *gʷet- if comparable to Arm. kočʻem 'to call, invite', but the comparison is not entirely clear; cf. [LIV²](src-141) 212, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):319, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):277-278, [Seebold 1970](src-556):318-320, [Olsen 1999](src-180):811.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *u̯et-e/o- 'to say, speak', further derived from PIE *u̯eth₂- 'to say' ([LIV²](src-141) 694-695, [Schumacher 2004](src-304):679-680, [Matasović 2009](src-50):418, cf. [Falileyev 2000](src-240):67).

Comment: < Vedic mantráyate (denominal) 'speaks (*recites mantras)' (RV), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 565, no. 9837
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic mantráyate 'speaks', a denominal formation to Vedic mántra- 'speech, sacred text or speech, a prayer', a nominal derivative from PIE 1. *men- 'to think' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):565 no. 9837, [EWAia](src-172) II:311, 305-306, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 435-436).
Ossetic lexemes probably continuing derivatives of a Proto-Iranic root *zag-, without certain etymology outside of Iranic ([Cheung 2007](src-83):460, cf. [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:292-293).
Slavic lexemes ultimately derived from PIE *pro- 'forwards, to the front' (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):418, [LIPP 2](src-294):639, cf. [Schuster-Šewc 1978–1989](src-260):1149).
Denominal verb, cf. Cuneiform Luvian āaš- 'mouth' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):166-167, cf. [NIL](src-274) 387-390). For further etymological discussion cf. 'mouth' in [cognate set 796](cog-796).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 11480 s.v. vāṭa- m. 'enclosure, fence' (MhB.): "Early east MIA. < *vārtra-", from 1. var-
Justification: Cf. Sanskrit vāṭa- m. 'enclosure, fence', a formation originating in Middle Indic as though from Sanskrit *vārtra- or Sanskrit *vārta- < PIE *u̯orto- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):670 no. 11480 + addenda; cf. [Burrow 1975](src-769):68). For the root, cf. Vedic 2. √var- 'to cover, conceal, hide, surround'.
