Further root etymology difficult; the Vedic root appears to continue a conflation of several different IE sources that have become homophonous (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:512-513, [LIV²](src-141) 227-228 s.v. *Hu̯er-, 674 s.v. *u̯el- and 684 s.v. 1. u̯er-).

Comment: retra- n. 'perfumed powder', presumably of non-Indic origin (according to Kuiper apud Turner 1962-66, p. 626, no. 10816 "Sanskritization" of a Munda loan)
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit retra- 'perfumed or aromatic powder' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):626 no. 10816). Further etymology uncertain, cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:73 for further discussion.

There is no generally accepted etymology for Proto-Germanic *klawō- outside of Germanic ([Kluge 2011](src-397):496-497, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):292). [Adams 2013](src-345):219 suggests a possible connection to with Proto-Tocharian **kolʸ- 'animal's foot'(?) but this remains uncertain.

Comment: < varṇáyati (denominal) 'relates, describes' (MBh.), cf. Turner 1962-66, p. 661, no. 11342; from varṇá- m. 'sound, syllable' (AitBr.)
Justification: As though from Sanskrit varṇayati 'relates, describes', a denominal formation to Sanskrit varṇa- 'sound, syllable' and probably a specialised semantic development of Sanskrit várṇa- 'type, kind, colour', a derivative of Vedic √var-² 'to cover, conceal, hide, surround'. Further root etymology difficult; the Vedic root appears to continue a conflation of several different IE sources that have become homophonous (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:512-513, [LIV²](src-141) 227-228 s.v. *Hu̯er-, 674 s.v. *u̯el- and 684 s.v. 1. u̯er-).
Slavic lexemes from PIE *drep- 'to cut off, tear off' ([Derksen 2008](src-81):115, [LIV²](src-141) 128-129, cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 5:101-102 assuming a basic root *der- with a root extension).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *u̯el-e/o- 'to see', a derivative of PIE 3. *u̯el- 'to see, perceive' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):669-675, [Matasović 2009](src-50):412, [LIV²](src-141) 675).
Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *spek̑- 'to look (at), see' ([LIV²](src-141) 575-576, [EWAia](src-172) II:107-108, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):452 no. 8012).

An Indo-Iranic and Albanian lexical isogloss from PIE *dʰei̯H- 'to envisage, contemplate' ([LIV²](src-141) 141-142, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):969; however doubted by [Cheung 2007](src-83):48-50, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:777-778 without Albanian).

Nuristani and Modern Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of PIE *kʷek̑- 'to see, catch sight of', cf. Vedic kāś- 'to be visible, appear', Proto-Iranic *kas- 'to look, appear' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):159 no. 3114, [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):40, [Cheung 2007](src-83):245-246, [EWAia](src-172) I:344-345, [LIV²](src-141) 383-385).
Phonology excludes inheritance

Brythonic lexemes without satisfactory etymology. Proposed to be connected with PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to bear, beget; create' by [Pedersen 1913](src-308):544 via the sense 'make, do', although there are formal difficulties with this etymological identification (cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):346). [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236) suggests a root *u̯er- 'to turn, spin (wool)' via an nasal-infix stem with an enlargement in *-b⁽ʰ⁾ (after [IEW](src-49) 1153), but this remains highly speculative. [Not in [LIV²](src-141).]

Etymology disputed. Lexemes continuing Proto-Slavic *obačiti, traditionally explained as a compound verb *ob-ačiti where *-ačiti is interpreted as a derivative of PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' (cf. Slavic lexemes for 'eye' in [cognate set 211](cog-211)), although there are some formal issues with this identification (cf. [ESSJa](src-458) 26:91-92, 32:41-42). Less plausibly it has been suggested that the lexemes were borrowed through East Slavic from Polish (cf. [Martynaǔ, Cyhun et al. 1978-](src-607) 1:337, [Mel'ničuk et al. 1982-2012](src-602) 1:154-155, [Vasmer 1986-1987](src-598) 1:138), however, the presence of cognates in many Russian dialects (Smolensk, Kostroma, Pskov, Tver' Novgorod, cf. [ESSJa](src-458): 26: 91} makes the hypothesis about an ordinary borrowing from Polish somehow questionable.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic vī́kṣate 'looks at, sees' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):696 no. 12041), further to Vedic √īkṣ- 'to perceive, view, see' continuing a reduplicated desiderative stem *h₃i-h₃kʷ-s- to PIE *h₃ekʷ- 'to catch sight of, behold' ([EWAia](src-172) I:203, [LIV²](src-141) 297-298).

Comment: Cognate with e.g. Russian смотреть 'look at'
Justification: Baltic lexemes generally agreed to be cognate with Proto-Slavic *motriti 'look at, watch' from a Proto-Balto-Slavic stem *mot(r)-, but a further IE root etymology remains disputed (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 620-621, [Derksen 2015](src-353):307, [Derksen 2008](src-81):327 for further discussion).

Connections outside of Germanic disputed: the principal hypotheses are (1) an adjectival formation based on a local particle *nē- (cf. [Kluge 2011](src-397):647) or (2) a lengthened-grade formation to PIE *h₂nek̑- 'to reach, obtain; accomplish' (cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):387). See [Faltings 2010](src-698):409-412 for further discussion (not in [Heidermanns 1993](src-697)). The Scandinavian and Modern English forms in this class are originally the comparative degree of the adjective which had taken over the meaning of the positive degree, i.e. *'nearer' > 'near' (cf. [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84)).

Romance forms from Latin pressē, the adverbial form of Latin pressus, -a, -um 'pressed, straitened' (cf. [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 9:365-367, [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):559), a past passive participle to Latin premō, -ere 'to press'. Further root etymology difficult (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):487-488 for further discussion).

Generally connected to Germanic words for 'approach, meet', cf. Goth. ga-motjan 'to meet', but a more precise root reconstruction is remains uncertain (cf. [Olsen 1999](src-180):49-50, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):451-452, [Lehmann 1986](src-179):145, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):372).
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):309, [Beekes 2010](src-66):369-370 for various hypotheses.
The precise semantics of the Hittite lexeme are not entirely clear, and therefore the etymology is also uncertain (cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):170-171).

Comment: Sanskritism, cf. tīkṣṇa-, Vedic tīkṣṇá-
Justification: Loanword from Sanskrit tīkṣṇa- 'sharp'.

Lexemes as though from Proto-Iranic *ričaka-, cf. Vedic √rekh- 'to scratch', further to PIE *(h₁)rei̯k⁽ʷ⁾h₂- 'to scratch, score' ([Bailey 1979](src-320):363, [EWAia](src-172) II:457, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 504).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √vāś- 'to roar, resound' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):675 no. 11586), further to Proto-Indo-Iranic √*u̯āć-, cf. Proto-Iranic *u̯ās- 'to make a noise, roar, shout', but without clear correspondences outside of Indo-Iranic ([EWAia](src-172) II:547-548, [Cheung 2007](src-83):432).
Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *srau̯- 'to hear, listen', further to PIE *k̑leu̯- 'to hear' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):356-357, [EWAia](src-172) II:666-667, [LIV²](src-141) 334-335).
Baltic lexemes continuing PIE *gʰrem- 'to roar, rage' ([Smoczyński 2005](src-686):164-165, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 204). For non-target Khwarazmian maγmeda in this set, cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):122.

Nuristani lexemes in this set represent a light-verb construction 'to make a song', where cognacy in this set is assigned to the semantic bearing head 'song', as though from Old Indic *lalla- ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):636 no. 10972), probably further of onomatopoeic origin.

Comment: original meaning "to praise"
Justification: Lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *fraiH- 'to rejoice? to atone, [med.] please', further from PIE *prei̯H- 'to please, be pleased, enjoy' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):87-88, [LIV²](src-141) 490, cf. [Samadi 1986](src-724):69).

Manx lexemes representing a light-verb construction 'to make a song' where for the purposes of cognacy Manx arrane 'song' is encoded as the semantic bearing head (cf. [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):12). From Old Irish amrán 'song; a kind of poem', a diminutive of amar 'sorrow, suffering'. Further to Welsh afar 'sadness, lamentation' but of uncertain etymology outside of Celtic ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:65).

Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic √drā- 'to sleep, slumber' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):411 no. 7200, 7201). Further root etymology uncertain, perhaps to ?*dreh₁- 'to sleep' ([LIV²](src-141) 126-127) if OCS -drěmljǫ is a contamination of this root with PIE 2. *drem- ([LIV²](src-141) 128), but this remains uncertain (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 126-128, [EWAia](src-172) I:757-758 for further discussion).

Comment: cf. Vedic bálbalī́ti (ŚB 2.3.2.11), malmalāyati  (ŚBK), balbalā kar- (Br), Sanskrit barbara- 'stammering' (cf. Greek bárbaros) - thus among the ideophonic roots *bal- ~ *bar- ~ *blV- ~ *mal- ~ *mlV-  vel sim. for 'babble, stammer, say blabla', cf. Vedic brav(i)- 'speak'; remodelled independently due to ideophonic needs, but in one or some forms inherited from PIE, cf. Mayrhofer  EWAia II, p. 217
cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5005: "H. chāl f. ʻbark, skin, peelʼ, chālī f. ʻsmall blisterʼ, chālā m. ʻskin, hideʼ (→ P. N. chālā m.)"
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes from Sanskrit or Prakrit challī- 'bark' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):274, no. 5005). Of non-IE origin, possibly Dravidian or Munda (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:405-406).

Parallel loans from Latin aēr 'air, atmosphere, sky' (cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:20-21, [Broaderick 1984b](src-728):4, [Macbain & Macfarlane 1911](src-231):24, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)).
Loanword from Arabic جلد 'skin, leather'.

Baltic lexemes continuing derivatives to the same root as Lithuanian deñgti 'to cover', further from PIE *dʰengʰ- 'to cover' ([ALEW](src-352) 174, 192-193; [Derksen 2015](src-353):115, 121-122, cf. [IEW](src-49) 250 [not in [LIV²](src-141)]).
Connected to PIE *nebʰ- by [van Windekens 1976](src-76) and [Adams 2013](src-345):70, but this etymology remains uncertain; cf. [NIL](src-274) 503n21 for further discussion.

Italic lexemes, derived as an instrument noun from a root *bak- whose distribution appears to be an isogloss restricted to Western Indo-European languages. Perhaps a European loanword from an unidentified source ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):67, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):64, cf. [IEW](src-49) 93).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin rīpa 'shore, riverbank' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):605 no. 7328), further from PIE *h₁reip-h₂ 'steep slope' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):524, cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):574).

Comment: With prefix ni-, original meaning "to lie down", i.e. "to sleep".
Justification: Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *ni- 'down' + √*pad- 'to fall' via an intermediate sense 'to lie down', further to PIE *ped- 'to step; to fall, sink' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):287-288, cf. [Cabolov 2001–2010](src-363) II:46, [EWAia](src-172) II:77-78, [LIV²](src-141) 458).

Modern Hellenic lexemes backformed from Ancient Greek (ἀπο-)μύσσομαι 'to blow one's nose, snort' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):906), further to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, take off' ([LIV²](src-141) 443-444, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):726, [Beekes 2010](src-66):985-986).

Continuing a derivative of Proto-Iranic *mau̯č- (1) 'to release, let loose/free', further to PIE *meu̯k- 'to untie, take off' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):269-270, cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:382, [LIV²](src-141) 443-444).
North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *smēha- 'small', further etymology uncertain ([Heidermanns 1993](src-697):519, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):456, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):519).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 8152 s.v. 'slimy, slippery'
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit picchala- 'slimy, slippery' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):460 no. 8152). Further etymology uncertain, probably a loan from a non-Indic source ([KEWA](src-399) II:271).

Romance lexemes continuing Late Latin flagrāre, Classical Latin fragrāre 'to smell strongly' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):298). Further etymology uncertain, possibly to be connected with OHG braccho 'hound', Middle Irish brén 'putrid, foul' from a root *bʰreh₁g-, in which case the Latin verb would have been deadjectival from an unattested *frag-ro- 'smelling', although this proposal remains quite uncertain (cf. [Schrijver 1991](src-679):185-186, [Schrijver 1995](src-305):170-171, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):238; further to the proposed Celtic comparanda cf. [Schumacher 2004](src-304):232-233, [Zair 2012](src-776):70-71). Alternatively a connection with Sanskrit ghrā́ti, jíghrati 'smells' has been considered but this proposal is formally problematic (cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):251, [Schrijver 1991](src-679):185-186).
Baltic lexemes continuing a PIE u-stem *lig-u-, further to a PIE root *lei̯g- 'equal, similar, alike' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 584-586, [Derksen 2015](src-353):286).

Traditionally connected with Goth. hiwi 'appearance', Skt. śyāvá- 'dark brown', OCS sivъ 'grey', Lith. šývas 'dark grey' ([Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:68-69, [IEW](src-49) 951), but the etymology is now considered doubtful ([Matasović 2009](src-50):205, cf. [ALEW](src-352) 1039 s.v. OLith. šývas, [EWAia](src-172) II:661 s.v. Ved. śyāvá- without connected the Celtic forms in this set).

Most of the Slavic etymology dictionaries assume a PIE root *peu̯- 'blow' with extentions or additional morphemes in Slavic lexemes with the meanings 'blow' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Serbo-Croat puhati), 'dust' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Kashubian pich; **peu̯-l-, e.g. Polish pył) and 'swell' (*peu̯-s-, e.g. Polish puchnąć). As cognates lexemes like Sanskrit púṣyati 'thrive, flourish', Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' or Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' are listed. In the modern reference sources roots like ?*peu̯s- or ?*peu̯t- are assumed. Note that Lithuanian pũsti, pučiù 'blow' has been judged as isolated [Smoczyński 2007](src-531) and Greek φυ̃σα 'blowing' as obscure with a hardly identifiable root or even Pre-Greek [Beekes 2010](src-66).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin vivenda 'foodstuffs' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):786 no. 9410, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 14:575), originally a neuter plural gerundive form derived from Latin vivere 'to live' and ultimately to PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' (cf. [de Vaan 2008](src-54):685-686 and further discussion in [cognate set 72](cog-72)).
A derivative of Lithuanian gyvatà 'life', ultimately a derivative of PIE *gʷi̯eh₃- 'to live' (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 340, [Derksen 2015](src-353):180 for discussion of the nominal derivation).

Comment: from 'creature' via 'any animal of the lowest order, insect, worm', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5110
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing derivatives of Vedic jantú- m. 'offspring, creature, man', via a secondary semantic shift 'any animal of lowest order, insect, worm' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):282 no. 5110). Further from PIE *g̑enh₁-tú-, a derivative of PIE *g̑enh₁- 'to produce, beget' ([EWAia](src-172) I:570, cf. [NIL](src-274) 139-153, [LIV²](src-141) 163-165).

Cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):87 walˈāṛ 'standing' from *awa-darta/i- or *wi-darta/i-, further to Proto-Iranic *dar- 'to hold, keep; dwell', and ultimately PIE *dʰer- 'to stick, fix' (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):57-59, [LIV²](src-141) 145-146).

Comment: < Vedic nāgá- m. 'snake' (ŚB); perhaps cognate with [cognate set 1358](cog-1358) - but later also used for 'elephant', perhaps rather < PIE *nogʷó- 'naked', cf. Mayrhofer KEWA II, p. 151 for further suggestions
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic nāgá- 'elephant; snake' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):404 no. 7039). Further etymology not certainly explained, possibly a derivative of PIE 2. *negʷ- 'naked' if the original meaning was 'the hairless, naked animal' (cf. [KEWA](src-399) II:150-151, [EWAia](src-172) II:33 [NIL](src-274) 513-515 for further discussion).

Generally assumed to reflect a derivative of PIE *gʷeh₂- 'to take a step', originally a suppletive aorist stem to PIE *gʷem- 'to go, come' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):249-250, 344-345, [LIV²](src-141) 205).

Etymology uncertain. [Bailey 1979](src-320):395 proposed *k̑i-es-d- derived to PIE *k̑ei̯h₂- 'to move' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 346, [IEW](src-49) 538-539), but the function of the nominal morphemes ('increments') proposed in order to satisfy the etymology formally remains unclear.
Etymology uncertain, cf. [Emmerick & Skjærvø 1997](src-777):146-150 with extensive discussion and rejecting the etymology of [Bailey 1979](src-320):404 to Proto-Iranic *aiu̯a- 'one').

Comment: *pa-bim-sta < IE *bʰuh₂-men-
Justification: According to [Strand 1998](src-431) from *pa-büm-ta- where Kâmviri büm 'earth' < Vedic bhūman- 'earth, world' (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):545 no. 9556).

A participle to the Ossetic verb xīlyn | xelun 'to crawl'. Further connected to Sanskrit khelati by [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) IV:201, but the etymology of the compared Sanskrit verb is difficult to ascertain (cf. [KEWA](src-399) I:312 and cross-references). Ossetic xīlyn | xelun is not listed in [Cheung 2007](src-83).

No certain etymology outside of Balto-Slavic ([Derksen 2008](src-81):548, [ALEW](src-352) 1290-1291, 1301-1302; [LIV²](src-141) 177 mechanically reconstructs a root ?3. *g̑⁽ʰ⁾er- 'to shine, radiate').

Light verb constructions using verbal nouns of Latin regere 'to guide, direct, govern' as the semantic-bearing head. For Neapolitan all'erta cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):257 no. 2899 Lat. erigere, erēctus 'erheben, aufrichten', 2. *ergere, *erctus; for Old Occitan drech, dreit cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):241 no. 2648 Lat. dīrēctus 'gerade'. Further to PIE *h₃reg̑- 'to straighten, stretch out' ([LIV²](src-141) 304-305, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):517-518)
Loan from Persian ستاره / setāreh 'star'

Anatolian, Hellenic, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic derivatives from PIE *steh₂- 'to position (oneself), stand' ([LIV²](src-141) 590-592, cf. [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):879-880, [Beekes 2010](src-66):601, [EWAia](src-172) II:764-766, [ALEW](src-352) 981-982, [Derksen 2015](src-353):430, [Derksen 2008](src-81):465-466, 468, [Seebold 1970](src-556):464-465, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):473, 477, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):589-590, [Matasović 2009](src-50):338).

Comment: lit. "to stand up"
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *Hrab/f- 'to go'. An etymology to a PIE root *rebʰ- 'to move oneself (boldly)' is tentatively considered by [LIV²](src-141) 496, but it is by no means assured (cf. [Cheung 2007](src-83):184).

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes as though from Sanskrit *laṣṭi- 'stick', perhaps a contamination of Vedic yaṣṭí- 'stick, pole' with lakuṭa- 'club' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):637 no. 10991). Further connections are uncertain (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:406).

Romance lexemes continuing Latin pālus 'stake, wooden post' ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):536-537), continuing an Italic instrument noun *pā̆g-slo- derived from PIE *peh₂g̑- 'to become firm', cf. Latin pangō, -ere 'to insert firmly, fix' ([Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):478-479, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):442-443, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 461).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff', further from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):334).

Welsh lexemes consisting of a compound  cyn- 'before' + ffon 'stick' ([Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236)); the 'stick' compound member, for which cognacy is being encoded in this set, continues Proto-Celtic *sfondo- 'stick, staff', further from PIE *sph₂en- 'piece of wood' ([Matasović 2009](src-50):334).

Continuing a nominal derivative from Proto-Germanic *bangōn- 'to beat, hit', if not onomatopoeic possibly further connected to verbs continuing PIE *bʰ-né/n-g- from *bʰeg- 'to break' ([Kluge 2011](src-397):109, [EWNl](src-757) I:265, cf. [Orel 2003](src-388):35, not listed in [LIV²](src-141)).

Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Indo-Iranic *stʰala- 'dry land, ground place; flat surface, roof'. Traditionally connected to the Sanskrit (Dhātupāṭha) root √sthal- 'to stand (firm)', further etymology uncertain (cf. [Strand 1998](src-431), [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):793 no. 13744, [KEWA](src-399) III:525).

Comment: Unknown origin; cf. lexeme 1878.
Justification: Of unknown origin ([Olsen 1999](src-180):965, cf. [HAB](src-740) III:596; not in [Martirosyan 2010](src-79)). [MM: Proto-Armenian *oi̯/u̯łił-o-].

Modern Greek lexemes continuing Ancient Greek ὀρθός 'upright, straight; right, true'. Further etymology disputed, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):818-819 and [Beekes 2010](src-66):1101 for various competing proposals.

Similar to Indic *kutta- 'dog', which first appears in Middle Indic. The Indic forms have been hypothesised to be onomatopoeic (cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):168, however given similar forms in Uralic (cf. Hungarian kutya 'dog'), it seems more likely to be a Wanderwört. The fact that the Indic and Iranic lexemes only appear in the later languages and are not reconcilable to a common proto-form are suggestive of independent borrowings from a third source. Cf. also [ESIJa](src-331) IV:413-415 s.v. Proto-Iranian *kuta- 'собака, пёс', *kūtī̆-.

Modern Greek lexemes from Medieval Greek σκύλος 'dog', morphologically transferred into the o-stem declension from Ancient Greek σκύλαξ 'whelp, puppy' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1290). No agreed etymology outside of Greek; cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1023, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1361 for various proposals.

Comment: Loan from Persian

Justification: Late loanword from Balkan Romance, showing no trace of rhotacism in Tosk ([Huld 1984](src-571):107, [Orel 1998](src-105):356). Due to the apparent lateness of the borrowing, this loan is treated as separate loan events in Gheg and Tosk (cf. [Tosk-based] Standard Albanian in [cognate set 5925](cog-5925)).

Comment: Loan from Latin.
Justification: Late loanword from Balkan Romance, showing no trace of rhotacism in Tosk ([Huld 1984](src-571):107, [Orel 1998](src-105):356). Due to the apparent lateness of the borrowing, this loan is treated as separate loan events in Gheg and Tosk (cf. Gheg in [cognate set 5505](cog-5505)).
Generally derived from PIE *pleh₂- 'wide, flat' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):415-416, [NIL](src-274) 562-564 for further discussion).

Originally a feminine adjectival form of Vedic pr̥thú- 'wide, broad' <*pl̥th₂-ú- as an epithet of the earth, further to PIE *pleth₂- 'to become wide, broad; to spread out' ([EWAia](src-172) II:161-163, [NIL](src-274) 564, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 486-487).

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, Germanic, and Celtic lexemes from the perfect stem *u̯oi̯d- 'to know' (< *'to have seen') from PIE *u̯ei̯d- 'to catch sight of' ([LIV²](src-141) 665-667, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1053, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):211, [EWAia](src-172) II:579-581, [Cheung 2007](src-83):408-409, [Derksen 2015](src-353):566, [Derksen 2008](src-81):518), Matasović 2009}:422-423).
Parallel loans from Sanskrit sū́rya- 'sun'.

Tocharian, Indo-Iranic, Balto-Slavic, and Germanic lexemes derived from PIE *g̑neh₃- 'to perceive, recognise' ([LIV²](src-141) 168-170, cf. [Hilmarsson 1996](src-149):160-161, [Malzahn 2010](src-341):609-611, [EWAia](src-172) I:599-601, [Cheung 2007](src-83):466-467, [ALEW](src-352) 1311-1313, [Derksen 2015](src-353):519-520, [Derksen 2008](src-81):546, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):311-312)

The Modern Greek present stem ξέρω was backformed based on the Ancient Greek aorist stem ἐξεῦρον ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):949, cf. ἐξευρίσκω 'find out, discover'). Root ref. form follows [LIV²](src-141) 698, but cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):482-483 for further discussion.
From Proto-Iranic *u̯ar(H)- 'to choose, convince; (med.) believe' + preverb *u̯i-; root etymology further to PIE *u̯elh₁- 'to choose, select' ([Cheung 2007](src-83):420, [LIV²](src-141) 677-678).

Slavic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *mor-i- 'lake, sea' (ESSJa} 19:227-229, [Derksen 2008](src-81):325, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):354-355, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):365, [Matasović 2009](src-50):277; cf. also [Derksen 2015](src-353):305-306 for Lithuanian mãrios 'isthmus; (dial.) sea'). Generally considered a western Indo-European isogloss, but cf. a possible further attestation in Iranic via Ossetic mal 'deep standing water' (cf. [EIEC](src-657) 503-504, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) II:68-69).

Iranic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rái̯as-, an s-stem noun formed to Proto-Indo-Iranic *j́rai̯-'to stretch, extend', cf. Vedic √jray- 'id.', further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:606-607).
Loanword from Turkic, cf. Turkish dengiz 'sea' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:362).
Loanword from Turkic, cf. [cognate set 3329](cog-3329).

No accepted etymology outside of Germanic; cf. [Lehmann 1986](src-179):292, for the suggestion that Proto-Germanic *saiwi- is a probable non-IE, pre-Gmc. loanword. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):423, 435-436 accepts an etymology from IE *sei̯kʷ- without referring to other hypotheses.

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *watar- ~ *watan- 'water', further from the PIE heteroclite r/n-stem *u̯ód-r̥- ~ *u̯ed-en- 'water', derived from PIE *u̯ed- 'to well up, stream' ([NIL](src-274) 706-715, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):575-576).

Comment: The Balochi word could be related to *čāt- via *čād- > *čūl (East Iranic) with -ak suffix or borrowed from a Persian form čāh > *čōh > ? *čūh + Turkish -lIK suffix (cf. Rastorgueva/Edelman 2003: 253), cf. Tadjik čalǝk.

Justification: The English word for 'lake' might be inherited from Germanic (cf. OHG lacha 'bog, mire'), but if so in the meaning 'lake' it would appear to be a semantic borrowing from Latin lacus (cf. similarly Greek: Italiot λάκκ̔ο in [cognate set 8394](cog-8394) which might be a semantic calque based on Italian); the cognate Germanic lexemes are unrelated to Lat. lacus, and probably further connected to PIE ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'drip' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 397), otherwise only attested in Celtic ([EWA 5](src-398):976-978). If from PIE ?*le⁽g̑⁾- 'drip' then possibly to be connected with Armenian lič in [cognate set 607](cog-607).
Modern Greek lexemes continuing a diminutive formation of Hellenistic Greek *πούλλο(υ)ς, a loanword from Latin pullus 'young fowl, chicken' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1146).
Hellenic lexemes, ultimately derivatives from PIE *h₃er- 'to set oneself in motion' ([Beekes 2010](src-66):1106, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):822-823, [LIV²](src-141) 299-300).

Anatolian and Celtic lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ebʰ-. Since [Watkins 1973](src-711) the Celtic words have been connected to Hittite and Palaic words for 'river' from a PIE n-stem *h₂ebʰ-n-, more recently followed by [Willi 2004](src-710) and [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):294-295 s.v. Hitt. ḫapa-. A popular alternative analysis reconciles the Celtic words with Indo-Iranic words for 'water' (cf. [cognate set 157](cog-157)) and Baltic and Nuristani lexemes for 'river' (cf. [cognate set 7856](cog-7856)) via a derivation using the 'Hoffmann Suffix' *h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):23-24 s.v. Proto-Celtic *abon-; [NIL](src-274) 311-317 tentatively reconstructs for Celtic ?*h₂ep-h₃on-, cf. [NIL](src-274) with references to further literature), but this analysis must assume an inner-PIE development *-ph₃- > *-b- (e.g. *pi-ph₃-e-ti > Ved. píbati '(s)he drinks'; cf. Lat. bibō with voicing assimilation to the reduplicated syllable). Since the number of examples of *-ph₃- > *-b- are few in number, this must remain a conjectural proposal.  The cognacy in this class therefore follows the etymology of [Watkins 1973](src-711) to a root *h₂ebʰ-. Cf. also [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) A:4-5.
Tocharian and Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *tekʷ- 'to run, flow' ([Adams 2013](src-345):267, [EWAia](src-172) I:610-611, [Bailey 1979](src-320):121-122, 182-183, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 620-621).

Italic lexemes derived from Latin rīpa 'riverbank' from PIE *h₁rei̯p- ([Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):605, [von Wartburg 1922–2002](src-443) 10:415-417, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):524; cf. [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):574).

Iranic lexemes from Proto-Iranic *dānu-, probably to be further connected with Vedic dā́nu- 'dropping flow, dripping; drops, dew'(?); the possibility of a contamination with Proto-Iranic *dan- < Proto-Indo-Iranic *dʰan- 'to run, flow' (< PIE *dʰenh₂- 'to set in motion; to move off', cf. [LIV²](src-141) 144-145) is not to be excluded ([ESIJa](src-331) II:450-451, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:719-720, [Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:366-367).

Although the "Celtic" etymology of OBr. staer figures in the etymological dictionaries, there was never a real discussion of this isolated word, which shares with the Latin and Greek words only the root, not the suffix(es). Bernier, on the other hand, convincingly points out the extensive parallelism in the semantics of staer, ster and estoir, estier and of their use in onomastics.
It seems possible, that Old Breton, being exposes to intense linguistic contace, had several words for river. These were regional varieties or linked to different speaker groups respectively.
Loanword from Old/Middle French riviere 'river' ([Deshayes 2003](src-309):629, [Favereau 1997a](src-235):641).

Comment: originally name of the river Ganges, cf. Vedic gaṅgā f.
Justification: Continuing Vedic gáṅgā- '(river name), Ganges' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):211 no. 3952), further etymology uncertain. Perhaps a reduplicated nominal formation to Vedic √gam- 'to go' (< PIE *gʷem-) or a pre-IE river name.
Loanword from Indic ([Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):74, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):774 no. 13415).
Cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):210 no. 3943 *khōla- (2) 'cavity, hollow', further etymology uncertain.
Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic dhā́ra- 'flow, ray', etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):388 no. 6788, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:788-789).

Iranic lexemes, often assumed to be connected with Vedic śákhā- 'limb, branch', although the correspondence of the word-initial sibilants is inexact. Only a reconstructed Proto-Iranic root reference form has therefore been given here, but cf. [KEWA](src-399) III:321-322, [EWAia](src-172) II:628 with further discussion.

Celtic lexemes from Proto-Celtic *bando- 'top, peak', as though from Proto-Indo-European *bn̥d-no- which may be further connected to a PIE root *bend-, a root exclusive to Celtic and Germanic (cf. [Matasović 2009](src-50):54, [Delamarre 2003](src-157):66, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) B:35).

Balto-Slavic lexemes, perhaps to be further connected with PIE *putlo- 'son', but this proposed connection is generally considered to be uncertain ([ALEW](src-352) 745-746, [Derksen 2008](src-81):424-425, [Derksen 2015](src-353):375).
Etymology outside of Indo-Iranic unclear ([EWAia](src-172) II:370-371, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):593 no. 10265).

Baltic and Nuristani lexemes derived from PIE *h₂ep- 'water, river' ([NIL](src-274) 311-317, [EWAia](src-172) I:81-82, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):19, [Strand 2011a](src-432), no. 407, [ALEW](src-352) 1155-1156, [Derksen 2015](src-353):483). Perhaps root-cognate with of Anatolian and Celtic lexemes meaning 'river', if the Celtic lexemes are to be analysed as from ?*h₂ep-h₃on- (cf. [NIL](src-274) 311-317 and further discussion in [cognate set 1735](cog-1735)).

This cognate class is coded for Proto-Tocharian *luwā- 'animal'; further connections uncertain. Pace [Adams 2013](src-345):606-607, the comparison to Greek λέων is unsatisfactory as this word is likely to be a Near Eastern loanword, cf. Akkadian lābu, Ugaritic lbʾ, Hebrew lābī ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):635, [Beekes 2010](src-66):854). Adams's further comparison to OCS lovъ 'the chase' and other Slavic lexemes in the meaning 'hunt' may be possible, but the etymology of these forms are not certainly established (cf. further discussion in [cognate set 1145](cog-1145)).

Indic lexemes from Vedic bhadrá- 'fortunate, delightful' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):533, no. 9377). Further etymology uncertain, perhaps from PIE *bʰend- if connected with Germanic *batiza- 'better', but the comparison is uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:244, [Heidermanns 1993](src-697):118-119, [LIV²](src-141) 75). For Assamese and Bengali, cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):535 no. 9408.
Etymology outside of Albanian uncertain (cf. [Demiraj 1997](src-369):268, [Orel 1998](src-105):267, [Holm 2011](src-130):64) for various proposals).

Extra-Baltic connections uncertain, possibly to PIE *labʰ- if the root is to be reconstructed as such (cf. [ALEW](src-352) s.v. Lith. lãbas, [LIV²](src-141) 411-412 s.v. *lembʰ- n1), but such a reconstruction is uncertain, unusually requiring *-a- in the ablaut series. Likewise, the proposed cognates in Greek ἀμφι-λαφής, etc. can be more easily accounted by a zero-grade formation *lm̥bʰ-. [Hübschmann 1897](src-564):451 speculatively considered a connection with Armenian law (cf. discussion in [cognate set 8081](cog-8081)), but this etymology is not certain and is not even mentioned by [Fraenkel 1962–1965](src-360) or [ALEW](src-352). A lemma for Lithuanian lãbas is lacking in [Derksen 2015](src-353). Apart from the as yet uncertain proposal to Vedic rabh- 'seize, grasp', the Baltic lexemes appear to be etymologically isolated.

As through from Sanskrit *rukta- 'bright, liked' to Vedic √roc- 'to shine', further to PIE *leu̯k- 'to be bright' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):621 no. 10755, [EWAia](src-172) II:463-464, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 418-419).
Perhaps to be connected to Latin cupiō, -ere 'to desire', but etymology ultimately unclear ([Untermann 2000](src-279):405-406, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):155).

Comment: < Sanskrit nir-mala- 'spotless, clean' (Up.) ('*having no dirt'), cf. mála-; cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7366; cog. with [cognate set 692](cog-692)
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit nirmala- 'spotless, clean', cf. Vedic mála- 'dirt' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):417 no. 7366). For the further etymology, cf. 'black' in [cognate set 1575](cog-1575), 'dirty' in [cognate set 692](cog-692).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 7150
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic niktá- 'washed, purified' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):409 no. 7150), further derived from PIE *nei̯gʷ- 'to wash' ([EWAia](src-172) II:54, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 450).
Etymology outside of Italic unclear ([Untermann 2000](src-279):821-822, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):651-652).
Cf. Persian javān 'young' from PIE *h₂i̯éu̯-Hon- (cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:413-414).

Comment: Cf. Ossetic Digoron äxsidzgä "pleasant", Khotanese kṣiṃj- "to desire, long for".

Justification: Iranic words for 'narrow' are better derived from *temk-, cf. already Horn 1893: 89 and Cheung 2007: 377f. Derivation from *tanu-ka- (thus e.g. Korn 2005: 168) might be formally possible but does not really explain the semantic difference found in Persian tang 'narrow' vs. tanuk 'thin'. None of the Iranic forms meaning 'narrow' require *tanu- or *tana-, while there is good evidence for a root *tank-/tanč- 'tp strain, press'.

Hellenic lexemes derived from the adverb πάλαι, probably a fossilised case form of a root noun *pl̥h₂-ei̯ and to be connected with πέλας 'near', πελάζω 'approach, draw near', πίλναμαι 'draw near, approach', πλησίον 'near' (adv.) from *pelh₂-, in the sense *'in the (near, recent) past' > 'old' ([Chadwick 1976](src-718), [Beekes 2010](src-66):1144-1145). Older etymologies attempting to connect to the same root as Att. τῆλε 'far away' (cf. Aeol. πήλυι) cannot be correct since Mycenaean pa-ra-jo does not contain a labiovelar as one would expect ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):851, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1144-1145).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12632 s.v. śodhya- 'be clean(sed)'; cf. LIV, p. 330
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Sanskrit śodhya- 'to be cleaned' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):733 no. 12632), further derived from a Proto-Indo-Iranic root *ćau̯dʰ- 'to clean, make clean', but further cognates outside of Indo-Iranic remain uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) II:657). [LIV²](src-141) 330 mechanically reconstructs ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'to become clean'.

Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic śuddhá- 'clean, bright, white', a derivative of Vedic √śodh- 'to clean, to make clean' and further to Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯dʰ-/*ćudʰ- ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):725-726 no. 12520, [EWAia](src-172) II:657). Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain, [LIV²](src-141) 330 mechanically reconstructs ?*k̑eu̯dʰ- 'to become clean'.
Cf. Latvian maût 'to submerge, swim', Lithuanian máuti, further to PIE *mi̯eu̯h₁- 'to move (oneself)' ([ALEW](src-352) 621-622, [Derksen 2015](src-353):308, 543-544, [LIV²](src-141) 445-446).

Comment: From the divine name Ahura Mazdā, the principal deity in Zoroastrianism.
Justification: From the divine name Ahura Mazdā, the principal deity in Zoroastrianism ([Bailey 1979](src-320):40). The name is often hypothesised to have originally meant 'wise lord' (vel sim.), although the grammatical relations in the noun phrase remain disputed (cf. [Encyclopædia Iranica](src-780) s.v.). Because of the substantivisation of the noun from a compound theonym, it is difficult to isolate a semantic head for etymological analysis. For etymological discussion of the individual elements of the original compound / noun phrase, cf. [EWAia](src-172) I:147-148 (~ OAv. ahura-), [EWAia](src-172) II:378 (~ OAv. mazdā-).

Comment: cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 12525 s.v. *śudhya-; from Vedic śúdhyate 'becomes pure, clear; is purified, clear', cf. Mayrhofer EWAia II, p. 657; thus ultimately from PIE *k̑eu-dʰ- (from *k̑eu-), cf. LIV, p. 330
Justification: Modern Indic lexemes continuing Proto-Indo-Iranic *ćau̯dʰ- 'to clean, make pure', cf. Vedic √śodh- 'to become clean, pure'. Further etymology outside of Indo-Iranic uncertain ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):726 no. 12525, [EWAia](src-172) II:657; [LIV²](src-141) 330 mechanically reconstructs PIE ?*k̑eu̯dʰ-).
Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *swellan- 'to swell', without certain connections outside of Germanic ([Seebold 1970](src-556):489-490, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):499).

Traditionally compared to Proto-Germanic *weϸra- ~ *wedra- 'weather' and further connected with PIE *h₂u̯eh₁- via *h₂uh₁-edʰr-o- or *u̯edʰrom, although there are formal difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic comparanda (cf. discussion in [cognate set 9440](cog-9440)). The difficulties in the reconstruction of the Germanic form, however, do not preclude the possibility of the derivation of the Slavic form being ultimately derived from PIE **h₂u̯eh₁- 'blow', however the uncertainty over the etymological identity of the proposed Germanic cognates weakens the case somewhat (cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):513, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):583-584, [Snoj 1997-2016](src-594) 4:287-288).

Comment: lit. "to make wind"
Justification: Iranic lexemes in light verb constructions, literally 'to make wind'. Cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:542 and 'wind' in [cognate set 342](cog-342) for further etymological discussion.

As though from *ā-prus-a- 'bubble up' ([Strand 1998](src-431), cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):84 no. 1832), further to PIE *preu̯s- 'to spray, spatter' ([EWAia](src-172) II:192-193, [LIV²](src-141) 493).

Nuristani lexemes in light verb constructions. Cognacy in this set is coded for 'water', cf. [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):19 no. 407 s.v. Vedic áp-, pl. ā́paḥ 'waters'. For further etymological discussion, cf. 'water' in [cognate set 157](cog-157).

Hellenic, Indic, and Slavic lexemes from PIE *pleu̯- 'to swim, float' ([LIV²](src-141) 487-488, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):1208-1209, [EWAia](src-172) II:194-196). Assignment of the Slavic lexemes to this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 487-488 and other sources, but cf. reservations of [Derksen 1996](src-678):116-117, [Derksen 2008](src-81):403.

Middle Indic lexemes continuing a derivative of Vedic √sphā- 'to come fat, plump', further to PIE *sp⁽ʰ⁾eh₁- ([EWAia](src-172) II:776-777, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):799 no. 13828, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 584).

Brythonic lexemes continuing Proto-Celtic *su̯ei̯d-e/o- 'to swell up', generally connected with PIE 1. *su̯ei̯d- 'to break out in sweat' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):610-611, [Matasović 2009](src-50):362, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 607).

Modern Indic and Nuristani lexemes as though continuing Old Indic madhurá- 'sweet', a secondary derivative of Old Indic mádhu- 'honey, mead' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):562 no. 9793), further from PIE *medʰu- 'mead, honey; sweet drink; alcoholic drink' ([EWAia](src-172) II:302-303, cf. [EIEC](src-657) 271).

Comment: Only non-active forms in Alb. denote 'to swim'
Justification: Albanian lexemes probably continuing PIE *leu̯h₃-e/o- with a present-stem n-suffix ([Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):980, [LIV² Addenda \& Corrigenda](src-389); for the root reconstruction, cf. [Melchert 2011](src-690)). For older literature, cf. [Meyer 1891](src-585):237, [Huld 1984](src-571):85, [Demiraj 1997](src-369):230-231, [Orel 1998](src-105):210.

Lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *sterta- 'tail', possibly a dental-enlarged root *sterd- to PIE *ster- 'stiff' but uncertain, cf. [EWNl](src-757), {ref Kluge 2011:877, 883, [de Vries 1977](src-468):547, [Orel 2003](src-388):376).

North Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *halan- 'tail, tip', traditionally further compared variously with Sanskrit śalá- 'staff', Middle Irish cail 'spear', Ancient Greek κῆλον 'shaft, arrow' from a proposed IE root *k̑el- 'to prick, sting' ([IEW](src-49) 552, cf. [de Vries 1977](src-468):204, [Orel 2003](src-388):156, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):203; not in [LIV²](src-141)), but more sceptically regarding the proposed comparanda cf. [EWAia](src-172) II:615-616, [KEWA](src-399) III:306, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:10-11, [Beekes 2010](src-66):685.

Comment: Is there any reason to suspect that the Elfdalian is a more recent loanword from Swedish rumpa 'tail' instead of being inherited?

Justification:
See discussion under https://cobl.info[cognate set 5697](cog-5697).  And see also https://cobl.info[cognate set 9688](cog-9688).
Inclusion of Luxembourgish here is questionable, as not directly derived from Middle *High* German, but it is not clear that this loanword appears so early that there was likely little real separation of the Luxembourgish lineage from those that led to the other languages included in this cognate set.
See discussion under https://cobl.info[cognate set 5512](cog-5512)

Difficult case to analyse.  The term is known across various North Germanic languages:  Faroese, Swedish, Danish and Riksmal.  Because Riksmal lexicon derives from Danish essentially only in the last few centuries, those can be considered not parallel, whereas the case seems to support more a parallel loan view for the other languages.  The Riksmal and Danish are therefore now to be split off into a separate non-parallel loan cognate set, https://cobl.info[cognate set 9687](cog-9687).  (An alternative analysis is that the loan event was into very early Norse, with a meaning shift in parallel since, but since no Old Norse form is registered here, we do not follow that analysis.)

Germanic lexemes continuing an early loan into West Germanic from Latin cūpa, cuppa 'cup, bowl'. For the semantic development, cf. similarly within Romance: Fr. tête 'head' < Lat. testa 'earthenware vessel, tile, sherd, vessel' in [cognate set 3171](cog-3171).
The loan event is taken here as so early that it would have introduced e lexeme into a very early form of Continental West Germanic, before these three lineages (standard German , Luxembourgish and Bernese) diverged from each other, so this is not a parallel loan.  Only these three would then have made the semantic shift to the 'head' meaning, whether in parallel or still at the stage of a later, narrower common ancestor of theirs.  That this shift is not yet recorded in our Middle High German list, however, supports the idea of parallel semantic shift, but after an original non-parallel loan to enter the Germanic lexicon (with an originally different meaning).

The West Germanic lexemes in this set are parallel loans from Old French. 
The same original Old French source was also loaned into other West Germanic languages. 
 Given the timing of the loans after the basic Dutch/German fragmentation is taken to have already begun, these define separate loan event cognate sets:   
https://cobl.info[cognate set 9688](cog-9688) in Dutch;  https://cobl.info[cognate set 9689](cog-9689) in Upper German. 

A later, follow-on loan-event from Middle Low German into North Germanic languages, is https://cobl.info[cognate set 5697](cog-5697).  

Cf. [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97). [Kluge 2011](src-397):777-778, [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84), [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).

See discussion under https://cobl.info[cognate set 5697](cog-5697).  And see also https://cobl.info[cognate set 9689](cog-9689).
The loan is so early that it is inconsistent to call it a parallel loan into both Middle and modern Dutch, rather than a loanword event type that at least Modern Dutch did inherit by transmission from Middle Dutch (or a closely related variety).

The North Germanic lexemes in this set are likely to be loans from Middle Low German, of a word originally borrowed from Old French.

See the other loan event cognate sets that also go back to this same Old French source:
https://cobl.info[cognate set 9688](cog-9688) in Dutch;  
https://cobl.info[cognate set 9689](cog-9689) in Upper German, 
https://cobl.info[cognate set 9690](cog-9690) as a parallel loan into English and Frisian

Cf. [Den Danske Ordbog](src-97). [Kluge 2011](src-397):777-778, [Oxford English Dictionary (OED)](src-84), [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392)).

Loan from Early Low German ([de Vries 1977](src-468):368). The inherited lexeme is found in Elfdalian 'smell' [cognate set 8301](cog-8301) and 'sky' in [cognate set 2903](cog-2903).  Since this is present in Old Norse, the case can be made that this is not necessarily a parallel loan, although the inclusion of Faroese in this set suggests the loan must have been particularly early.

The connection of the forms in this class to those from PIE *pstḗn in [cognate set 2217](cog-2217) is disputed, and rest on assuming that it is root-cognate with a gloss στήνιον from Hesychius's Lexicon. The word-formation within Greek is, however, unclear ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:795, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1054-1055, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1403-1404, cf. [IEW](src-49) 990).
Parallel loans from Old French.  See also https://cobl.info[cognate set 6198](cog-6198), a further cognate set with the same Old French loan source, but parallel loans into English and Frisian..

Parallel loans from Old French.  See also https://cobl.info[cognate set 9691](cog-9691), a further cognate set with the same Old French loan source, but including inheritance after the initial loan event..

Comment: etymology unknown.
Justification: Etymology uncertain, cf. [Orel 1998](src-105):135, [Holm 2011](src-130):54-55, [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):265 for further discussion.

Germanic lexemes continuing Proto-Germanic *takan- 'to touch; take', probably further to be derived from PIE *teh₂⁽g̑⁾- 'to touch, grasp' ([LIV²](src-141) 616-617, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):507, cf. [Seebold 1970](src-556):507).

Modern Greek lexemes continuing Medieval Greek ἐπαίρνω, a remodelled nasal-present stem continuing Ancient Greek ἐπαίρω 'lift up' ([Babinotis 2010](src-382):1021), except Tsakonian: Peloponnese αζ̌ίκ̔ου < *αρ-ίσκω ([Andriotis 1974](src-460):76), both continuing the basic verbal root of Ancient Greek αἴρω ~  ἀείρω 'to raise'. Probably further to a PIE root *h₂u̯er- 'to hang' ([LIV²](src-141) 290, cf. [Beekes 2010](src-66):23-24).
Original sense 'female breast' derived from PIE *dʰeh₁(i̯)- 'to suckle' ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):875-877).
Loanword from Low German borst 'chest' (cf. Middle Dutch borst 'id.').

Root etymology for the Hellenic lexemes in this class follows [LIV²](src-141) 535 as though from PIE *sr̥-i̯é- to PIE 3. *ser- 'to take, seize, grasp', but cf. [Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) I:43-44, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):38, [Beekes 2010](src-66):42 (without reference to new literature in [LIV²](src-141)).

Lexemes as though continuing Proto-Celtic *kom-ber-e/o- 'bring together', whose basic verbal root *ber- continues PIE *bʰer- 'to carry, bring' ([Schumacher 2004](src-304):218-223, [Matasović 2009](src-50):214, 62, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 76-77, [Geiriadur Prifysgol Cymru (GPC)](src-236), [Deshayes 2003](src-309):382-383).
Cf. Old Lithuanian krẽklas 'female breast'; no certain etymology outside of Baltic (cf. [ALEW](src-352) 523).
Old Frisian has berna while the Modern West Frisian variant is baarne, which is not a loanword

Tocharian, Armenian, and Indo-Iranic lexemes derived from PIE *pstḗn ([IEW](src-49) 990, cf. [Adams 2013](src-345):386, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):584-585, [EWAia](src-172) II:752). The potential connection of the Greek forms from Ancient Greek στῆθος ([cognate set 8545](cog-8545)) to this class is disputed, and rest on assuming that it is root-cognate with a gloss στήνιον from Hesychius's Lexicon. The word-formation within Greek is, however, unclear ([Frisk 1960-1972](src-174) II:795, [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):1054-1055, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1403-1404).

Identical to Irish cliabh ([Broaderick 1984b](src-728):83-84) from Old Irish clíab 'basket, woven container, hive'. Further etymology uncertain, cf. [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) C:118 for a suggestion to Old Norse hlíf 'shield'.

Italic and Romance lexemes derived from PIE *h₂eh₁s- 'to dry (through heat)' ([LIV²](src-141) 257-258, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):53, [Untermann 2000](src-279):130-131, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):50 no. 620).

Two possible Indo-European etymologies, either (1) derived to PIE *h₂eh₁- as a denominal verb from *ayr- 'fire' compared to Av. ātar-/āθr- 'fire', Lat. āter 'black, dark', OIr. āith 'furnace', Palaic ḫā- 'be hot' ([Hübschmann 1897](src-564):418), or (2) from PIE *h₂ei̯dʰ-, cf. Gk. αἴθω 'to kindle, burn', Skt. edh- 'to set alight, kindle; shine' ([Jasanoff 1979](src-581):145, [Viredaz 2003](src-582):85). Alternatively [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):98n16 has assumed an Iranian loanword. (Cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):63).

From PIE *u̯erh₁- 'to be hot'; the root reference form for this set follows the reconstruction of [Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):923-925, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 689 reconstructing *u̯erH- with indeterminate final laryngeal.

Middle and Modern Indic lexemes from Vedic vā́ma- 'left', presumably a euphemistic replacement from Vedic vāmá- 'dear', no further etymology ([EWAia](src-172) II:543-544, [KEWA](src-399) III:189, [Turner 1962–1966](src-442):672-673, no. 11533).

Root etymology uncertain. Perhaps to *h₂er- 'to fit (together)' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 269-270) in the original sense 'more fitting' > 'better' > 'the better side, left' via popular euphemism ([Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):106-107, [Beekes 2010](src-66):128, 131-132).

Ossetic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *čarH- 'to come and go, wander', further to PIE *kʷelh₁- 'to make a turn, to turn' ([Abaev 1959–1995](src-156) I:303, [Cheung 2007](src-83):33-35, [EWAia](src-172) I:534-535, cf. [LIV²](src-141) 386-388).

No convincing etymology outside of Anatolian ([Kloekhorst 2008](src-80):525). [HED L](src-409):97-98 suggests a connection to Armenian leard, but the Armenian forms are more generally considered to be connected to the inherited IE word for 'liver' (cf. [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):306-307 and notes to [cognate set 718](cog-718)).

A relationship of this lexeme to PS *trěskati, a lexeme referring to sounds made by splitting or cracking things, seems reasonable. For the semantic development cf. PS *drobŭ *drobŭ (>)'guts' and PS *drobiti 'shatter, crush' (cognate/1153/). However, taking into account ideophonic origin of the PS root(s) and the irregular sound shape of PS *troxa that has to be assumed by accepting this relationship, no reliable further etymology can be found.

Balto-Slavic lexemes derived from PIE *bʰegʷ- 'to run away, flee' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 67, [ESSJa](src-458) 2:58-60, 92, [ALEW](src-352) 103-104, [Derksen 2008](src-81):40-41, [Derksen 2015](src-353):85-86).

Probably from Armenian *əndi (< PIE *h₂ent-i) prefixed to *tʰana- (< PIE ?*pt-n(e)-h₂-) ([Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):114-115, [LIV²](src-141) 479). Alternatively [HAB](src-740) II:125-126, [IEW](src-49) 908 proposes to PIE *sent- 'gehen' but this is phonologically difficult (cf. [Klingenschmitt 1982](src-558):114).
More archaic is lofts (still part of the written language)..

Baltic and Slavic lexemes from Proto-Balto-Slavic *deb- are traditionally connected with Germanic lexemes from putative PIE *dʰeb- 'thick, firm, solid' ([IEW](src-49) 239). Due to the rarity of PIE *b and the areal proximity of the languages, however, these cognates might not be of Indo-European date, if they even are cognate at all. Note that because the Leiden school doubts the existence of PIE *b, the Leiden dictionaries reconstruct a *dʰebʰ-. This, however, causes problems for formal correspondences with the Germanic (although cf. [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89 attempting to save the etymology by invoking analogy with the Germanic iterative stem *dapp/bōn- 'to become heavy' as though from *dʰobʰ-néh₂-). Cf. [Derksen 2008](src-81):97-98, [Derksen 2015](src-353):530-531, [Kroonen 2013](src-165):89, [Kluge 2011](src-397):907 for further discussion.

Root reconstruction difficult. A contamination between two (possibly related) roots *teu̯h₂- and *teu̯k- is a possibility. Cf. discussion in citations to this cognate class. Cf. also Germanic words for 'thigh' in [cognate set 6956](cog-6956).

Comment: cf. Skrt. jaḍa- 'stupid, dumb', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 5090

Justification: Iberian Romance lexemes from Latin gurdus 'blockhead, stupid person' ([DCECH](src-423) III:173, cf. [Meyer-Lübke 1935](src-444):333). A root-etymology to a zero-grade form *gʷr̥d-  might be found with the family of lexemes found in Greek βραδύς 'slow', Lithuanian gurdùs 'id.', Latv. gur̃ds 'tired', OCS grьdъ 'haughty, proud' ([de Vaan 2008](src-54):275, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):275); in antiquity the grammarian Quintilian considered Latin gurdus a word of Spanish origin.
Frisian doesn't have open syllable lengthening - cannot be Frisian; OFri. liwere

Etymology in this class follows [Schumacher & Matzinger 2013](src-364):1008-1009 to PIE 2. *u̯elH- 'to roll' (cf. [LIV²](src-141) 677), but cf. [Huld 1984](src-571):130, [Orel 1998](src-105):511 to 2. *u̯el- 'spin, roll' (cf. Lat. uoluō 'turn', etc.).

Comment: Probably an experiencer construction: "one's heart comes up/beats" with "heart" for the inner part of the body or the inner condition.

Justification: To be connected with lexemes meaning 'to crack' in other Germanic languages (cf. OHG krahhōn, OE cracian), but ultimately of onomatopoeic origin (cf. [Svenska Akademiens ordbok](src-392) s.v. kräkas, [Kluge 2011](src-397):535).
more archaic is libje (still used by a minority of speakers)
the archaic form is tsjok - rarely used nowadays
[frɔu] - likely from Middle Dutch; Also 'person'. AF: mins.
comp. EFri. dialects säie, sii etc.

Considered to be a loanword from Medieval Latin boscus in earlier literature, but given that the Medieval Latin form (and its descendants in modern Romance languages) have no clear etymology from earlier Italic, the Germanic forms are now generally considered to be inherited, although their further etymology is obscure. It remains possible that the Medieval Latin and the Germanic forms are independent borrowings from a third source (cf. [EWA 2](src-386):474-476, [Kluge 2011](src-397):165).

Comment: some NIA forms may be blends with grāsa m. ʻmouthful', √gras- 'devour', cf. Turner 1962-66, no. 4379
Justification: Middle and Modern Indic lexemes continuing Vedic ghāsá- 'food, pasture grass' ([Turner 1962–1966](src-442):241 no. 4471), a derivative of Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, consume', cf. Young Avestan gah- 'to eat, devour'; further etymology uncertain ([EWAia](src-172) I:514; [LIV²](src-141) 198-199 mechanically reconstructs ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume').

Cognacy in this set follows [Cheung 2007](src-83):93 to Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to devour', but cf. [Morgenstierne 2003](src-323):33 suggesting instead to *gaz- 'to bite'. Outside of Iranic further cf. Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas-, cf. Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, devour, gnaw'. No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. [LIV²](src-141) 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.

Although also the name of the internal organ 'stomach', in the variety of English targeted here, i.e. standard British English and following majority usage in England, the word 'stomach' has broadened to refer to the abdomen in general, and is has become the default, unmarked word for the target sense here.  The lexeme 'belly' is more marked in register, often with overtones of a protruding 'pot belly'..

See also the independent loan of the same ultimate Greek source lexeme into a variety of Macedonian, at https://cobl.info[cognate set 7400](cog-7400).
'sick' is a Germanic root, found also in Dutch and German, for example.

Comment: cf. Avestan gah- and Sanskrit ghas-.
Justification: Iranic lexemes continuing derivatives of Proto-Iranic *gah- 'to gorge, devour', further from Proto-Indo-Iranic *gʰas-, cf. Vedic √ghas- 'to eat, devour, gnaw'. The Khwarezmian lexeme would contain the preverb *apa- ([MacKenzie 1975](src-783):392, [Samadi 1986](src-724):17, [Cheung 2007](src-83):93), while the Sogdian form probably continues a form with preverb *uz- as though *uz-gahaya- vel sim. (Nicholas Sims-Williams, p.c.). No certain etymology outside of Indo-Iranic. [LIV²](src-141) 198-199 mechanically reconstructs  ?1.*g⁽ʷ⁾ʰes- 'to eat, devour, consume'.

Hellenic, Armenian, Indo-Iranic, Baltic, Germanic, Italic, and Celtic lexemes continuing an inherited word for 'tooth', widely considered to continue a participle *h₁d-ónt- to the verbal root *h₁ed- *'to bite' → 'to eat', lexicalised as 'tooth' already in PIE ([NIL](src-274) 208-220, [LIV²](src-141) 230-231, [EIEC](src-657) 594). Under this explanation the original Ancient Greek form would be continued by Aeolic ἔδοντ-, which underwent vowel assimilation in other dialects. The Leiden School of Indo-European reconstruction alternatively reconstructs a distinct root *h₃ed- 'to bite, sting' following [Kortlandt 2003](src-549):77, who argues that it would better account for ὀδών much more straightforwardly, and it would also much better account for the Ancient Greek privative adjective νωδός 'toothless' < *n̥-h₃d-ó-, (expected †νηδός < *n̥-h₃d-ó-); as for Aeolic ἔδοντ-, it only occurs in late grammatical texts and could have itself been created on the basis of an analogy to Greek ἔδ- 'eat'. For individual branches, cf. [Chantraine 1968–1980](src-270):776, [Beekes 2010](src-66):1049, [Martirosyan 2010](src-79):1049, [EWAia](src-172) I:693-694, [ALEW](src-352) 174-175, [Derksen 2015](src-353):115, [Ernout & Meillet 1985](src-316):169, [de Vaan 2008](src-54):166-167, [Vendryes et al. 1959–1996](src-296) D:62-63 [Matasović 2009](src-50):90).
